HEADLINE: Thaw in Budget Talks Freezes Over a Bit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton submitted revisions to his budget and a slight thaw seemed to have developed in the budget negotiations, the President and Republican leaders in Congress reverted today to casting aspersions and drawing lines in the sand.
With further formal negotiations put off until next week, Mr. Clinton called reporters to the Cabinet Room at the White House before a meeting with Democratic governors to say he would stand firm against the Federal Government's relinquishing control of Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor. 
 Republicans want to end the 30-year-old Medicaid system under which everyone who meets Federal eligibility standards is entitled to whatever medical treatment or nursing home care they need. The budget legislation approved by Congress last month and vetoed by the President this week would cut deeply into projected spending for the program, give what Federal money was left to the states in the form of block grants with few strings attached and allow the states to set eligibility.
The White House has clearly decided that this is an issue on which to take the firmest possible stand.
"The Republican budget," the President declared, "would be a disaster for the states and for the people who depend on Medicaid."
"So I just want to be clear about this," he said. "I very much want to work with the Republican Congress to get a balanced budget, but I will not -- I will not -- permit the repeal of guaranteed medical coverage for senior citizens or disabled people, for poor children and pregnant women. That would violate our values."
Later, the White House publicity machine was switched on, and assistants spread word of how serious the Medicaid issue was to the President.
But Republicans said they too intended to insist on their Medicaid position.
"This isn't about values, and it isn't about money," said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, chairman of the House Commerce Committee, which has jurisdiction over Medicaid. "No, this is about power," Mr. Bliley added, speaking in the Capitol at a news conference he had called to respond to the President. "This is about whether the states will be given the flexibility they need to meet the needs of their own citizens or whether they'll continue to have their hands tied by a huge, distant, inflexible Federal bureaucracy."
The revised budget Mr. Clinton submitted on Thursday would save $54 billion in the Medicaid program over the next seven years, only a third as much as the Republican plan would save.
The Republican legislation would set rigid ceilings on the Federal money that the program would make available to the states each year. Mr. Clinton, in contrast, would impose a limit only on the average amount that would be spent each year for each beneficiary. That approach would allow increases in total spending as Medicaid enrollment grew, a particular likelihood in times of recession.
The President's demand that Medicaid remain an entitlement is in contrast with his position on welfare. There, he has accepted the Republican argument that the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, should be turned over to the states and that poor families with children should no longer be guaranteed Federal assistance.
On Tuesday, the Congressional Budget Office is scheduled to issue its latest economic projections and spending forecasts. But it is unclear whether that will be the moment for serious negotiations on the budget to begin or whether the two sides will continue, as they have for the last two weeks, merely to jockey for political position.
The agreement between the President and Congress that ended the partial shutdown of the Government last month expires next Friday. With no progress made in the negotiations this week, there seems little chance of a budget agreement before the deadline.
Mr. Clinton asked Congress on Thursday to approve another temporary measure that would extend the Government's spending authority through much of January, but Republicans in the House of Representatives have been resistant.
This afternoon the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, and Speaker Newt Gingrich sent a letter to the White House asking the President to submit a new budget next week with $400 billion in lower spending, the amount needed to match the Republican savings.
In a letter of response, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, did not directly address the request but urged the Congressional leaders to agree to temporary legislation that would prevent another partial Government shutdown.

HEADLINE: Melvin Kranzberg, 78, Historian of Technology

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Melvin Kranzberg, a scholar who helped establish the study of the history of technology and explained its impact on society, died on Wednesday at his home in Atlanta. Dr. Kranzberg, a professor at the Georgia Institute of Technology, was 78.
The cause was cancer, said August Giebelhaus, a professor of history at Georgia Tech and a longtime colleague. 
 Dr. Kranzberg co-founded the Society for the History of Technology in 1958. From then until 1984, he was the editor of its quarterly journal, Technology and Culture.
"His life's work was to assert the autonomy of this discipline," Professor Giebelhaus said. "It was not just applied science, and it was not just a minor part of economic history, but it was a discipline in itself.
Dr. Kranzberg argued that technological development could not be understood without seeing how it was linked to society.
He wrote or edited 11 books and wrote more than 150 scholarly articles; he also popularized his field in newspaper articles.
In a 1968 article, he wrote: "Engineers, in general, live in the suburbs, vote Republican and mouth the cliches of conservatism. Actually, if unwittingly, they are greater social revolutionaries than many wild-eyed political radicals.
"Without necessarily meaning to, they invent new products, processes, systems and devices that produce profound socio-cultural transformations."
The automobile self-starter, he wrote, freed women and children to see the world and electric washers, driers, vacuum cleaners, supermarkets and telephones freed women for "drinking, loafing, heavy thinking about issues like Vietnam and even jobs, the same as men."
"Radicals" like the inventors Watt, Fulton, McCormick, Edison and Marconi, he said, changed the face of the world.
Early in the computer era, he foresaw immense social upheaval, but he remained optimistic, as he generally was about technological change.
Writing more than 25 years ago, he said, "There is no doubt that many individuals will be thrown out of their jobs by automation, and the process will accelerate with every passing year. At the same time computers are speeding and extending the advance of science and technology at a pace never before witnessed in history. This, we know, will create new lines of productivity, new and better jobs, new professions and untold wealth."
Dr. Kranzberg was born on Nov. 22, 1917, in St Louis. He studied history and economics at Amherst College in Massachusetts, where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1938. At Harvard University he earned a master's degree in 1938 and a doctorate in 1942.
During World War II, he served in the Army in Europe as a sergeant in military intelligence, fought in the Battle of the Bulge and interrogated German prisoners on the front lines. He won the Bronze Star for finding crucial enemy gun emplacements.
Originally a specialist in modern French history, Dr. Kranzberg taught at Harvard, the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., and Amherst. In 1952 he joined the faculty of at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. There, while developing a history course for engineering students, he shifted to the history of technology.
He was appointed a professor at Case in 1959, and left in 1972 to become the Callaway Professor of the History of Technology at Georgia Tech. When he retired in 1988, he became a professor emeritus, and the institute named a professorship in the history of technology in his honor.
His awards included the NASA Apollo Achievement Award, the Roe Medal of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the State of Israel's Jabotinsky Centennial Medal for eminence in science and letters, the Olmstead Award of the American Society for Engineering Education and the Bernal Award of the Society for Social Studies of Science.
Dr. Kranzberg is survived by his wife, the former Louise Lester of Atlanta; two sons by a previous marriage, John and Steven, both of St. Louis; a brother, Maurice, also of St. Louis, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A New Safety Net Is Created For Homeowners in Quakes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
California took a big step yesterday toward overhauling its homeowners' earthquake insurance market to create a new financial safety net for homeowners, replacing insurance companies.
After a heated competition among 40 securities firms, the state said firms led byMorgan Stanley & Company would handle an innovative $1.5 billion bond sale that would be part of a $10.5 billion package to pay homeowners' claims. 
 The plan also calls for homeowners to absorb much more of the risk from earthquakes because new policies will provide less coverage than existing policies.
After the Northridge earthquake in January 1994, which resulted in $12.5 billion of insurance losses -- $8.2 billion from homeowners, most insurance companies stopped accepting new customers, putting California officials under pressure to change the market.
"This plan makes insurance more widely available," said Chuck Quackenbush, California's Insurance Commissioner, adding that it also answered concerns about the solvency of many companies after a big quake.
Under the new mini-policies that will go on sale Jan. 1, homeowner premiums will be about the same as those for existing earthquake policies, but the new policies will provide less coverage. The two largest cutbacks are a $5,000 limit on coverage for a home's contents and a $1,500 limit on living expenses paid if a home is uninhabitable.
If the new mini-policies had been in place for the earthquake at Northridge, near Los Angeles, claims on homeowner policies would have been cut in half, insurers say. California Insurance Department officials expect the mini-policies to cost about the same as old policies, where premiums currently range from about $1.50 per $1,000 of coverage in a low-risk areas, to $4 per $1,000 in high- risk areas.
Although insurance companies will sell the new mini-policies and handle their claims, the $1.1 billion in annual premiums will go to the California Earthquake Authority, not the companies. The authority will use the premiums to pay for its expenses and for the $10.5 billion insurance plan.
The $10.5 billion plan taps many sources to pay homeowner claims, starting with $1 billion in cash contributed by insurance companies. The next $3 billion in claims would be covered by funds that insurance companies promise to provide if needed. The next $2 billion of coverage comes from reinsurers, followed by $1 billion from tax-exempt bonds that would be sold after an earthquake. The next $1.5 billion of claims would be covered by investors in the Morgan Stanley bond issue to be sold early next year, with another $2 billion available from an assessment on insurance companies.
Insurers and securities dealers close to the financing are optimistic that reinsurance can be bought for not much more than $300 million a year, or more than 15 percent of the coverage offered. Interest rates on the bonds would average slightly less than the reinsurance cost, but would vary widely depending on how much risk investors took.
Some investors, who agree that they would lose only part of their interest after an earthquake, might earn interest rates comparable with those of medium-quality corporate bonds, while others who could lose all of their interest or principal could earn rates more than 10 percentage points higher than Treasury notes.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Leaps in Early Trading But Falls Back on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar soared in early trading yesterday to an 11-week high against the German mark, but then European traders took their profits and the currency ended little changed.
Currency traders said the dollar's ascent was set off by a rally in United States Treasury bond prices, which caused traders to push the currency through important technical levels. 
 Treasury bonds jumped after the release of a weaker-than-expected employment report for November improved the odds of lower interest rates ahead.
"The market bought the dollar because the bonds were rallying," said Joe Viola, a manager at Credit Suisse. "But after that there was no follow-through and the market sold it back down."
The dollar hit a high of 1.4550 marks, and soared to a 17-month high of $1.5205 to a British pound.
But once the bond rally stalled, European corporate traders, particularly from Germany, cashed in their dollar holdings.
"The dollar made some nice new ground on the top side, and we had some Friday afternoon profit taking," said Richard Vullo, dealer at Bayerische Hypobank. "That brought us down off the highs, but I don't think it changes the overall bullish tone."
The dollar continued to be supported by comments on Thursday by the president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, who said he hoped for a stronger dollar against the mark. Traders said the comments suggested that the central bank, the Bundesbank, could soon lower interest rates.
And the dollar was helped as French markets continued to perform strongly in the face of a crippling national strike by public-sector workers, but some economists said investors might be too optimistic. The French franc's resilience against the mark makes the dollar more attactive relative to the mark.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4475 German marks, up from 1.4467 marks on Thursday. The British pound ended unchanged at $1.5325. The dollar slipped to 101.30 Japanese yen from 101.47 yen.
"It was really just magnified by thin conditions," said David Solin, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics. "There has really been no net change on the day."

HEADLINE: Data Show Fewer Jobs in New York Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Employment in the New York City metropolitan region dipped in November as a national slowdown continued to spill over into sluggish hiring across New York City, New York State and New Jersey.
According to the Federal Government's monthly employment report, there were 35,000 fewer jobs in New York State in November than in October, a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent. The loss was concentrated in New York City, where there were 46,000 fewer jobs in November than in the previous month, a 2 percent decline. 
 In New Jersey, the report said, 36,000 fewer people were employed in November than in October, a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The unemployment rate, a measure of the number of people who are actively seeking jobs but unable to find them, improved slightly in New York State, to 6 percent, from 6.3 percent in October, and in New York City, to 7.8 percent, from 8 percent in October. But the rate rose in New Jersey, to 6.1 percent, from 5.8 percent in October.
John L. Wieting, the New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which issued the report, said the slowdown reflected a decline in hiring across the nation. The report covered employment in the 11 largest industrial states; Connecticut is not among the 11 surveyed.
"The forces of the national slowdown filtered into the region in November," he said. Among those forces, he said, was a downturn in manufacturing that was particularly sharp in the Middle West, but also undermined employment in the region, particularly in New Jersey.
The dip in November came after a slight improvement in October, when both New York and New Jersey had employment gains, and reflected a series of small monthly gains and losses that have left the regional economy sluggish, but on a largely even economic keel, since the beginning of the year.
Among the strongest sectors of the regional economy in recent months have been tourism, restaurant sales and the entertainment industries.
"The numbers are still somewhat encouraging," Mr. Wieting said. Although the New York region lagged behind most of the nation in the economic recovery of 1993-94, he said, it did not experience the downturn suffered by other regions in the last 11 months.
"We are holding our own," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
With No McDowell, The Focus Is on Cone

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
The Yankees made a last-ditch attempt to maintain dialogue with Jack McDowell by asking him to reject salary arbitration if they offered it to him by Thursday's deadline. Not surprisingly, McDowell refused this proposal because it would have heavily favored the Yankees. Thus, they relinquished their negotiating rights to the pitcher and essentially terminated any possibility of re-signing him.
If McDowell had accepted the proposal, he would have rejected their arbitration offer by Dec. 19, meaning that the Yankees would not have had to pay him as much as $6 million in 1996. Then the Yankees could have still discussed a more economically feasible contract with him and held his rights until Jan. 8. 
 Since McDowell never even received a preliminary offer from the Yankees, did not want to be played against David Cone, a fellow free agent, and did not want another team to be forced to surrender draft choices to the Yankees if he signed elsewhere, he rejected the idea.
"That wouldn't have done us any good," Jim McDowell, McDowell's brother and agent, said about a practice that is not unusual in baseball.
Without McDowell, the Yankees seriously desire Cone. They already have Mariano Duncan, they want Mickey Tettleton and they should not neglect Roberto Alomar. Welcome to the Yankees' hectic off season, in which they are competing with Baltimore for Cone and Alomar and where they won a smaller skirmish over the Orioles by signing Duncan, a utility infielder, to a two-year, $1.5 million contract yesterday.
By severing ties with McDowell, the Yankees have made it even more imperative that they sign Cone to anchor the pitching staff. Since Cone had a positive meeting with General Manager Pat Gillick and Manager Davey Johnson on Thursday and told an Oriole official that he wants his wife to visit the Baltimore area next week, the Yankees could wave goodbye to two former Cy Young Award winners in a brief time span. Still, the owner George Steinbrenner is not panicking.
"If we don't sign Cone or one of the other free agents, we could be short," Steinbrenner said. "But Cone's not the only one out there."
General Manager Bob Watson said Cone is expected to respond to a three-year, $15 million offer early next week, but Cone's price tag probably escalated when the Yankees parted with McDowell. The Orioles, who have not yet made an offer, figure that Cone wants a three-year, $18 million contract, and they are concerned about the Yankees outspending them because New York does not have a safety net in McDowell.
"As I look at it, it puts them in a tenuous position with Cone," said Jim McDowell. "I assume they feel pretty good about their chances of signing him. But if they don't sign him and they've given up on Jack, then who knows?"
McDowell was 15-10 with a 3.93 earned run average for the Yankees and was first in the American League in complete games and third in innings pitched. He is durable, but the Yankees privately expressed concern about back spasms that sidelined him last season and about a congenital condition in his right hip. Despite the hip condition, McDowell is routinely among the league leaders in starts, innings and complete games.
"Maybe more pitchers should have a hip like Jack, and then they would be able to pitch as well as him," Jim McDowell said.
Watson, who did not return telephone calls, signed Duncan yesterday to try to replace Randy Velarde. Duncan, who hit .287 with 6 homers and 36 runs batted in for the Phillies and Reds last year, accepted New York's offer to be a utility player over Baltimore's one-year offer to be a second baseman.
Since the Orioles told Duncan he would play second, what about their interest in Alomar? Not to be outmaneuvered, Gillick quickly contacted Jaime Torres, Alomar's agent, yesterday. Gillick said the Orioles can afford Cone and Alomar, who had told the Orioles he wanted a three-year, $23 million contract. But Gillick said it would be difficult to sign the duo and also snare a high-priced closer like Rick Aguilera or Jeff Montgomery.
Alomar's proposal to the Yankees was three years for $25 million, and Torres has not heard from Watson since last week. Watson's chief priority is signing Cone, but Torres will not wait for the Yankees because several teams are interested in Alomar.
"If Roberto Alomar is down on their list of priorities, that would indicate to me they are not that interested in him," Torres said. "We will not hold back in analyzing and deciding on other clubs to give the Yankees time to come around and discuss more seriously with Roberto."
The Yankees have made an undisclosed offer to Tettleton, who they want to use as a designated hitter and as a shaky backup at catcher, first base and in the outfield. But Tettleton has three other offers and would rather return to Texas.
After sporting one of the best one-two pitching punches in baseball with the durable Cone and the more durable McDowell, who combined to go 24-12 for the Yankees last year, they might not have either in 1996. Steinbrenner said the decision on McDowell was a blend of baseball and financial considerations. His former manager might have acted differently.
"It's not my money, but I'd bring both of them back," Buck Showalter said in September. "Where else are you going to find guys like that?"

HEADLINE: The Culture of Poverty

BYLINE: By Robert Pear; Robert Pear is a Washington correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE WAR AGAINST THE POOR
The Underclass and Antipoverty Policy.
By Herbert J. Gans.
195 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $22.
 
IF YOU CAME THIS WAY
A Journey Through the Lives of the Underclass.
By Peter Davis.
202 pp. New York:
John Wiley & Sons. $22.95.
HERBERT J. GANS, a professor of sociology at Columbia University, has written a prescient, clear-eyed analysis of American social policy. He suggests that affluent people stereotype the poor as undeserving for complex reasons, just as the citizens of Salem, Mass., projected certain problems of colonial America on people accused of witchcraft. 
 But Mr. Gans pushes his thesis a bit beyond his evidence. He uses a political argument to challenge one of the most basic functions of sociology, the classifying and labeling of individuals and groups, because he does not like the way the labels have been used. The title of Mr. Gans's book is "The War Against the Poor," but he spends much of his time analyzing "the war of words -- or of pejorative labels -- that stereotype, stigmatize and harass the poor by questioning their morality and their values." His thesis is that the "terms and labels" that designate poor people as undeserving may be obstacles preventing their escape from poverty. He asserts that scholars, social scientists and journalists who use such terms contribute, knowingly or unknowingly, to the perpetuation of poverty.
Mr. Gans's argument helps explain why it is so difficult to count the underclass. That word, denoting extreme, persistent poverty, has a certain intuitive appeal, but there is no official or standard definition of the underclass. Knowing the poverty level for families of a particular size ($11,821 for a family of three last year), the Census Bureau can estimate the number of poor people in the United States. The concept of the underclass is more elusive: it refers not only to income but also to kinds of behavior that supposedly trap people in poverty.
Mr. Gans suggests, in a fresh and thought-provoking way, that intellectuals use the "underclass" label because it helps keep the poor at a distance. "By labeling some people as undeserving," he writes, "label users protect themselves from the risk of getting close to them and being hurt by the encounter." In addition, he says, loose use of the word validates the idea that "poverty is largely the fault of the poor," who bear children out of wedlock or engage in other behavior that flouts middle-class norms. Once labeled, Mr. Gans says, "the undeserving poor can be used to justify attacks on the welfare state," so they become scapegoats in a conflict of politics and ideology.
The ideas in this book germinated before Newt Gingrich and the Contract With America set the agenda for Congress. But it can be safely assumed that Mr. Gans would cite recent events as evidence that Republicans have declared war on the poor.
In "If You Came This Way," Peter Davis, who undertook his book after having been mugged at gunpoint outside his New York City apartment, provides a journalistic chronicle of underclass life that complements Mr. Gans's more theoretical discussion. The authors' politics are similar. "The war on poverty of the 60's has become the war against the poor of the 90's," Mr. Davis writes. At another point, he says that "the poor have replaced the Communists as our principal enemies." He introduces the "poverty caste," including elderly people, tough teen-agers and families at soup kitchens. This is a workmanlike account, but Mr. Davis, the author of "Hometown" and "Where Is Nicaragua?" and a film maker, does not set his literary sights very high. Neither his description of the poor nor his own journey of discovery, as he travels across the country talking with the urban and rural poor, is compelling. What conclusions are readers supposed to draw from these impressions?
Mr. Davis's political insights are tantalizing, but he does not develop them. Ending welfare as we know it, he says, alluding to Bill Clinton's campaign promise, is the wrong goal and is doomed to fail. "Instead," he says, "the debate should be over ending poverty as we know it."
For his part, Mr. Gans is at his best when he traces the evolution of the word "underclass" from its original meaning of people living in extreme, persistent poverty into a term denoting deviant or abnormal behavior. But he seems to gloss over the conservatives' argument that there is a genuine problem with young teen-agers' having babies before they finish junior high school. Mr. Gans does not try to document or measure the extent of grinding urban poverty, but says that the labels used in such empirical research too often assume the validity of middle-class norms.
In the early 60's, Mr. Gans says, Michael Harrington described "the culture of poverty," but the concept did not acquire racial connotations until a few years later. Daniel Patrick Moynihan analyzed "the female-headed black family," and Mr. Gans implies that the Moynihan Report of 1965 accelerated a process of labeling that "blamed poor blacks for their actual or imagined behavior."
MR. GANS derides "label makers," but aren't labeling, classifying and categorizing essential elements of research in science and social science? A social taxonomy, rich in demographic data, may be the first step to understanding the problems of the underclass. Such information can be used for odious or immoral purposes, but it can also be used to arouse the concern and compassion needed to cure misery. Indeed, this was one purpose of French positivists like Auguste Comte and of novelists like Charles Dickens, who documented the underclass of Victorian England without romanticizing or stigmatizing it.
Mr. Gans says the use of labels to scapegoat the poor can "shield politicians and citizens from having to deal with difficult social problems." But the use of labels can also help people identify and recognize such problems.
Many economists see technology as a source of jobs, or at least as a source of increased productivity and economic growth, needed to raise the nation's standard of living. Mr. Gans says that government may have a role in industrial policy, but unlike many politicians, who want to foster technology, he seeks ways to "prevent the further proliferation of job-destroying technology."
Prescribing antipoverty policy for the 21st century, Mr. Gans writes, "Luddite nostalgia is out of place, and giving up the computer is senseless, but a case could be made for returning to the labor-intensive and thus costlier manufacture of, say, cars." Alternatively, to spread income and wealth, he recommends a system of work sharing to shrink the normal workweek by 40 percent, to 24 hours. Mr. Gans sees this futuristic plan for "the virtual abolition of full-time work" as a way to create a more egalitarian society by distributing available work and doing away with unemployment. This hardly seems the most feasible means to that desirable end.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1308 words

HEADLINE: Piano Men

BYLINE: By Eva Hoffman; Eva Hoffman, the author of "Lost in Translation: A Life in a New Language," is an amateur musician.

 BODY:

STEINWAY & SONS
By Richard K. Lieberman.
Illustrated. 374 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $35.
TO the countless aficionados who have relished its supple action and its rich, round tone, a Steinway piano may be a thing of beauty and a joy forever. But an expensive instrument is an object existing at an intersection of culture and commerce, and to those who produce it, it means mostly business. In "Steinway & Sons," Richard K. Lieberman brings a revealing, if not always uplifting, perspective to the story by looking at the company that for a century and a half made, marketed and sold Steinways. 
 Actually, this is the second history of the Steinway to appear this year. An earlier one, "The Steinway Saga," by D. W. Fostle, drew heavily on Steinway family archives. Mr. Lieberman's book, based largely on company archives, is not an investigative report but an institutional chronicle, perhaps too conscientiously concerned with promotion techniques and sales and profit figures through the ages. But a history of the Steinway is also, implicitly, a history of the pianistic tradition; and while concentrating on his specific brief, Mr. Lieberman also gives us an often fascinating overview of a musical epoch that may, regrettably, be coming to an end.
Mr. Lieberman -- a historian and the director of LaGuardia Community College's LaGuardia and Wagner Archives, which house the Steinway collection of documents -- approaches his subject largely through profiles of the men who ran Steinway & Sons in successive generations, in a system of inheritance that passed the leadership from father to nephew, as often as to the son. The family saga begins with Heinrich Engelhard Steinweg, a cabinet and instrument maker who in 1835 started a modest piano manufacturing concern in the small German town of Seesen. In 1850, to escape restrictive trade regulations and political agitation, the Steinwegs followed their son Charles to New York, where they apprenticed themselves to such piano makers as Henry Pirsson, famed for producing "the American double-grand pianoforte," with keyboards facing one another.
By 1853, the new immigrants were ready to strike out on their own in the New World, with the Anglicized name Steinway & Sons. The piano, like the novel, rose with the middle classes, and the Steinways' success was largely due to their product's increasing popularity. However, in a trade then dominated by German manufacturers, they also distinguished themselves by their careful workmanship. Each instrument that came out of their factory was produced by a precise, patient process, which involved drying wood for a year, applying several coats of varnish to the piano case with long intervals between each coat, and shaping and fitting hundreds of small parts by hand. The early Steinway craftsmen included studious innovators like Henry Steinway Jr., who in the 1850's perfected the technique of over-stringing, which gave the piano a larger, warmer tone.
But aside from the high level of their skills, the Steinways were also canny about injecting into their instruments the impalpable extra ingredient of cultural cachet. The latter part of the 19th century was the era of superstar performers, and the Steinways capitalized on this to good effect by sponsoring the more famous among them in return for endorsements. Mr. Lieberman tells wonderful anecdotes of heroic performances -- like Anton Rubinstein's 1872 New York debut, during which he was kept playing till 4 o'clock in the morning by the wildly excited audience. In 1891, Ignace Paderewski, the musical idol of his day (and for a while the President of Poland), played six different concertos in his first week in New York, and the next year he gave 107 concerts in 117 days, much of the time playing in agony from an injured finger. He and other musicians, like Josef Hofmann, Rachmaninoff, Horowitz and Arthur Rubinstein, were kept loyal to Steinway in part by fat fees and careful coddling.
On the strength of such events and associations, the very name Steinway gradually became a byword for pianistic grandeur, as well as for bourgeois ambition and cultivation. Although the company's fortunes went through various ups and downs, Steinway & Sons mostly prospered and expanded, opening branches in Germany and England and shipping pianos to households across America and Europe. The Steinways themselves became a major cultural force in New York, opening the elegant Steinway Hall in 1866 and supporting musical causes and institutions. For a while they were also a major economic force in Queens, where they built factories and private mansions, established rail links to Manhattan and opened the immensely lucrative North Beach Amusement Park (on the site of today's LaGuardia Airport). Steinway & Sons initially transferred its operations to Queens to escape what one member of the family called the "anarchists and socialists" causing violent labor unrest in volatile Manhattan; perhaps their most inventive piece of business strategy was the creation of a "company village," in which they rented houses to their employees, supplied most of the public services and provided English and German lessons to the workers' children.
But the Steinways' paternalism wasn't always so benevolent. Within their own enclave, they never allowed women near the seat of power; within their factories, they kept strikers out and wages low. The chairmen in successive generations ranged from sensitive souls, who cracked from the pressures of their job, to ruthless businessmen and corporate thinkers. Mr. Lieberman's tale is surprisingly full of fraternal dissension, sexual scandal, dubious tactics and cutthroat competitiveness. In the early days, the company's management repeatedly bribed juries at international exhibits and competitions, thus assuring Steinway victories over such pianos as Chickering and Weber. During World War II, the Hamburg branch of Steinway & Sons complied with the Nazi regime without a murmur.
But finally, whatever their temperaments or managerial style, none of the Steinway leaders were immune to the effects of larger social and economic trends. In recent years the piano has come to occupy a less central place in our musical imaginations. The capricious element of charisma has moved from the classical virtuoso to the rock singer; and since the advent of the record player, fewer people have felt the need to make music in their homes themselves.
At the same time, with the rise of unions and increasing labor costs, the production of handmade instruments became less financially tenable. The Steinways were never good at shifting to less prestigious, or less expensive, models. In the 1930's, they lost the market for space-efficient uprights to brands like Baldwin and Kimball. But perhaps the real coup de grace came from Yamaha, which, once its offer to represent Steinway in Japan was refused in the 50's, started competing in America with cheaper mass-produced pianos. The rest, for Steinway, is sad history. In 1972, Steinway & Sons was sold to CBS, and since then the company has changed hands twice more; the pianos are still produced in Queens and Hamburg, but by more mechanized methods.
To some cognoscenti, the new-issue Steinways lack the clarity and warmth of the old versions. But perhaps such subtleties become harder to discern amid the noise of new technologies. Steinway may have gained its pre-eminence by questionable strategies, as well as by excellence; but it was one of the best vehicles for the kind of pianism that depends on fine tonal nuances, and on bravura sound. The decline of "the instrument of the immortals," as one advertising slogan called it, undoubtedly marks the waning of a living musical environment in which such things could be heard, and in which they mattered.

Steinway; Ernest Urchs, head of Steinway's sales force; Roman de Majewski, who succeeded Urchs; Teed Steinway; Ernest Hutcheson, the pianist, and Mrs. Hutcheson. Below, Steinway's "bread and butter" piano, the model M of 1912. (FROM "STEINWAY & SONS")

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: The President's Analysts

BYLINE: By Adam Clymer; Adam Clymer, the chief Congressional correspondent of The New York Times, is writing a political biography of Edward M. Kennedy.

 BODY:

VALUES MATTER MOST
How Republicans or Democrats
or a Third Party Can Win and Renew
the American Way of Life.
By Ben J. Wattenberg.
426 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $25.
 
NIXON'S PIANO
Presidents and Racial Politics
From Washington to Clinton.
By Kenneth O'Reilly.
525 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $27.50.
PRESIDENT CLINTON may have helped sell Ben J. Wattenberg's latest book, "Values Matter Most," when he called the author and told him he agreed with its criticisms of his Presidency. But that endorsement, of a book that condemns Mr. Clinton for abandoning his centrist campaign promises, is hard to consider as more than yet another poll-propelled campaign stunt, and this book deserves better. It is both a trenchant argument for the sort of values Mr. Clinton offered as a candidate and a smart discussion of which sorts of non-economic issues can be put to effective political use and which are trouble. 
 If Mr. Wattenberg sometimes seems too focused on the politics of appealing to the electorate where it is, Kenneth O'Reilly appears to think that Presidents can operate without any relation to public attitudes at all. "Nixon's Piano" is a carefully researched effort to demonstrate that America's Presidents have been racist -- although Mr. O'Reilly doesn't seem to notice that the country has been, too. He concedes that Lincoln, Truman and Johnson made things better for African-Americans. Each, however, is faulted for only acting ahead of his time and background and not also being color-blind.
"Values Matter Most" is, first of all, an argument for the Democratic Leadership Council-vintage Bill Clinton. His early supporters -- and Mr. Wattenberg, who worked for Lyndon Johnson in the White House and Senators Hubert Humphrey and Henry Jackson in political campaigns -- counted on him to be a New Democrat on issues like crime and welfare. They expected him to support capital punishment and prisons and kicking people off welfare, and they are unhappy that most of the time he has not. In fact, if they did not know that Mr. Clinton had some very traditional liberal views too, they collaborated with him in fooling themselves.
This book's greatest strength is the distinction Mr. Wattenberg draws between those kinds of social issues and "cultural issues" like abortion, pornography and homosexuality, a distinction that makes clear that the social issues have political heft and the cultural issues are risky. "Americans, by huge majorities," he writes, "are scared about crime, furious about welfare, irate about lack of discipline among school-aged children and angry about preferences. Americans typically believe in a fairly tough response to these corrosive concerns." And, he notes, government plainly should be involved in all of them -- so they all clearly deserve to be debated in politics, and a politician can line up with the majority with little danger. The cultural issues are more politically sensitive: "There is often no consensus because there is no agreement about the very nature of what they represent. Liberals often see the cultural issues as related to liberty and leeway. Conservatives often see them as related to license and libertinism." For examples, he cites homosexuals in the military, sex education and flag burning.
Mr. Wattenberg makes the case that values matter, and that politicians should face them without worrying whether reporters will accuse them of racist demagogy. But he strains to prove that they matter most with a numbing collection of graphs and charts designed to prove that economics doesn't matter at all. Anyone who talks to voters gets a sense of unease about downsizing, health insurance and whether their children will be able to afford to buy a house, an unease that keeps poll respondents saying there's a recession when economists can prove there isn't. A good economy may not help a candidate, as Mr. Clinton may discover next year, but a troubled one only magnifies the worries Mr. Wattenberg is most concerned with.
His analysis works best on the issue of crime and on the sloppiness with which Democrats have handled voters' plausible concern about the the importance of keeping convicts locked up. And he effectively skewers the House Democrats for being unwilling to follow Mr. Clinton's lead on educational standards.
Like the President himself, Mr. Wattenberg may be at his weakest on welfare reform, the particular subject of Mr. Clinton's apologetic phone call. Mr. Wattenberg blames Mr. Clinton for going slow and for being too liberal. But the better criticism has come from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who has argued that Mr. Clinton's promise of two-years-and-off-the-rolls was naive, made with no understanding of how expensive it would be to accomplish at a relatively humane level. Mr. Wattenberg treats the issue almost entirely as an exercise in politics, not policy.
He is least convincing on quotas and affirmative action. The sort of consensus he sees, for example, on crime and the need for more certain punishment is absent from the discussion of what he calls "preference." Lots of white men agree with him that the time has come to abandon affirmative action, but many don't, and the support falls off sharply among women and blacks. More might agree if reality equaled his description. For example, the 1971 Griggs decision did not, as Mr. Wattenberg says, establish that "high school diplomas or test scores could not be used as a prerequisite for employment because in such competition blacks as a group did not do as well as whites as a group." It held that they could not be used because they had no relation to qualifications for power-plant jobs, and imposing them had the effect of denying jobs to blacks who had less education than whites. Mr. Wattenberg also brushes off Mr. Clinton's record on preference issues as having made things worse, when it could be argued that the President's statement last spring that affirmative action was good for America but needed a little fine-tuning was a brave and moral effort to calm an explosive issue.
Where Mr. Wattenberg notes approvingly Mr. Clinton's campaign denunciation of the rap performer Sister Souljah for suggesting that blacks start killing whites, in "Nixon's Piano" Mr. O'Reilly deplores it as evidence that Mr. Clinton took African-American voters for granted and was making a racist appeal to Reagan Democrats.
The best thing about Mr. O'Reilly's book is the title. He begins by describing one of those dreadful Washington evenings, the Gridiron dinner of 1970, through the appalled eyes of Roger Wilkins, one of the two black guests at this annual event where bureau chiefs and columnists buddy up with politicians. Richard Nixon, to show he was a good sport, joined the entertainment. But whatever he played on the piano was drowned out by Spiro T. Agnew, the as-yet-unindicted or even investigated Vice President, playing "Dixie."
An evening of good fun over Nixon's "Southern strategy" is Mr. O'Reilly's starting point for the argument that just about every President has pandered to the South. A few knew that slavery or segregation was wrong, but did nothing about it. Those few others who did something about it fall short, too, in Mr. O'Reilly's judgment, for insufficient purity of thought.
More than half the book is devoted to the last 35 years. John F. Kennedy is dismissed for advocating no more than "modest" civil rights legislation. Yet it was that bill that brought a quarter of a million Americans to the Lincoln Memorial, where they heard Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I have a dream" speech, and at the time it did not seem modest. Mr. O'Reilly, a professor of history at the University of Alaska and the author of "Racial Matters," contends that the disintegration of Jimmy Carter's Presidency began with equivocation over affirmative action. For both these Presidents, he acknowledges but seems unmoved by the way they impressed African-Americans from King to Andrew Young.
Fundamentally, Mr. O'Reilly argues that "the politics that came out of the Constitution and its articles on slavery are still stuck in a racial rut. With few exceptions, the deeds and dreams of our Presidents, and the choices they made and did not make in matters of race, deepened that rut." Where President Clinton is concerned, he writes, "it is a sad commentary" that Mr. Clinton, "arguably the least prejudiced of the 41 men who preceded him, sees fit to include a racial calculus in politics and policy."
What country does Mr. O'Reilly think Mr. Clinton is President of? This President, like his predecessors, must govern in a country still deeply divided over race, a nation where uncompromising politics is usually failed politics.
