HEADLINE: Why the Librarian Stays Right in Style

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IN the age of the Internet and the World Wide Web, when terms like the information superhighway are almost as passe as information explosion, one venerable source of information just keeps going and going: the public library.
And reference librarians at some of the state's biggest institutions report that despite the new marvels of the electronic age, they have not detected any decrease in calls from people seeking out information on a variety of topics ranging from the mundane to . . . well, the the weird. 
 In the latter category, the folks in the reference room at Hartford Public Library still talk about the woman who called about the snake in her oven. She said she had a stove on the back porch and when she looked inside the oven she saw the snake. She closed the oven, quickly. She didn't know what kind of snake it was, and she didn't want to hurt it. All she wanted was to get it out of the oven.
The reference people scurried for a clue on enticing a snake out of an oven. Aha! In a children's book, it was mentioned that snakes are partial to raw eggs. The librarians suggested that the woman dribble raw egg from the oven to the end of the porch, then open the oven door with a broom handle and see if the snake would take the bait, eating its way to the yard.
They assume the method worked. In any case, they did not hear back from the woman.
In contrast to this one, most questions are relatively prosaic, can be answered quickly, and then are forgotten. But no matter what the question, all calls are treated with respect, said Carol Fitting, head of T.I.S. (that's Telephone Information Service) at the Hartford library.
"Most people have a serious reason for calling," she said. "They need information and don't know where else to get it. We regard every question as serious."
And some are more serious than others. "One call we get, but rarely, is when a pet or child has ingested something that may be poisonous," said Ms. Fitting. "We give the number of the Poison Control Center and say to dial it immediately. And we feel sorry about people who call up for information on diseases."
In fact, quick information services at bigger libraries, have always been part social agencies, affording people a real link to often impersonal cities. And there seems to be no immediate prospect that that role will diminish. As cities get poorer and poorer, the number of people who can afford computers to go surfing through the Internet gets proportionally smaller and smaller. "We're the last resort for people who do not have access to computers," said Ms. Fitting. "We're always here."
Some things in the questioning line never change. Thirty years ago, and this year, too, one of the leading questions is what were the seven wonders of the ancient world. "I'm probably the only person in creation who can rattle them off without thinking," Ms. Fitting said. (The seven wonders, one more time, are the Colossus of Rhodes, the Pharos lighthouse at Alexandria, the hanging gardens of Babylon, the Temple of Diana at Ephesus, the pyramids of Egypt, the tomb of Mausolus at Halicarnassus and the statue of Zeus at Olympia.)
The other hardy perennial among questions is when does the time change from daylight saving to standard, or vice versa. Twice a year, the phones ring off the hook.
The Hartford Public Library was one of the pioneers in the nation in establishing a separate telephone information line. The date was June 14, 1965, and Ms. Fitting, who had just gone to work for the library, was given the job of running it. Thirty years later, she is still running it, using other librarians to help her staff the phones. On Aug. 10 of this year, T.I.S. observed a real milestone: the 50 millionth question answered over the phone.
As the makeup of the city has changed, so too has the makeup of the library and its telephone service. Hartford's main ethnic group is now Hispanic, so at the library there are now several people on the staff who speak Spanish.
When the telephone service started, and for most of the three decades since, nearly all of the answers came out of books: general reference books, city directories, books on laws, books on folk practices, books on dates in history -- and, of course, telephone books. More recently, the research librarian may be more apt to hit a few symbols on a keyboard than go rummaging through the stacks.
"We're hooking into the Internet right now," said Vera Skop, head of the reference department at Greenwich Library. "We're learning to be techies."
As Hartford reflects its population by many of the questions directed at its library, such as where to find social services and medical help, so too does Greenwich reflect its population with questions about mutual funds or the relative rank of big corporations.
But affluent Greenwich, the nation's richest community in per capita income, has also been hard hit by the economic distress of this decade. Executives with six-figure salaries have been some of the casualties.
So on any given day, a call to the library might be from a woman planning her daughter's wedding; what does the Old Farmer's Almanac predict for weather on a particular day several months hence? But the next call might be for information on some major corporations by a former executive who is now out of a job.
The calls of economic distress have decreased a little recently, Ms. Skop said, as the economy seems to be recovering somewhat. "But it has been a tough time for a lot of people here," she said.
About a quarter of her library's incoming calls are referred to the children's room. Some are from teachers, getting background on, say, a dinosaur project. Some are from youngsters, planning the dinosaur project. And some, said Ms. Skop, are from "home schoolers," youngsters whose parents elect to educate them at home. There are a lot of them in Greenwich, she said.
Telephone information services at the public libraries in New Haven and Bridgeport were hard hit by Connecticut's recession, but are now recovering, research librarians in both cities say.
In New Haven, hours at the Free Library were cut back to 24 a week in 1990, but with more financial support from the city in the past two years, it is now open 53 hours a week.
It might be supposed that Yale would be the source of calls for information at the New Haven library. But that is not the case, according to Valeria Haines, head of public services at the library.
The reason is that the university has so many of its own excellent reference resources, she said. Consequently, the people who use the city library are mostly from the community outside Yale and their questions reflect that community. "They want more basic information, a large part of it consumer information," Ms. Haines said. "We get a lot of questions about tenants' rights, and medical kinds of questions, about laser liposuction and melantonin, about the side effects of drugs."
And if Yale students don't call the library much, public school students certainly do. "We always know when term papers are due," Ms. Haines said, "about the American Revolution, about Martin Luther King. The kids ask the same questions." She said the librarians will give the budding term-paper writers basic information like dates but won't do their homework for them. "We tell them to come in so we can teach them how to use the library."
Eighteen miles from the New Haven Free Public Library, the Bridgeport Public Library has also endured major cutbacks. In 1990, when it appeared that the city actually might go into bankruptcy, the hours of the library were reduced to 20 a week.
Like its counterpart in New Haven, however, it has received more money to operate in the last few years and is now open 48 hours a week, spread over five days.
In the past several months the telephone calls for information have reflected the main interest, if not the fixation, of many of city residents: gambling.
Bridgeport had been earmarked by Gov. John G. Rowland for a big gambling casino to be run by the Mashantucket Pequots, as the way to pump new economic life into the impoverished city. Where were the casinos, callers asked. How successful were they? What did the national press say about them? Judging from the calls, "Just about everyone in Bridgeport was a supporter of a casino," said Anne Maio, the head of reference services at the library.
On Nov. 17, however, despite the zealousness of Bridgeport Mayor Joseph Ganim and other city officials, despite busloads of Bridgeport residents who went to the state capital in Hartford to lend support, despite Governor Rowland's pushing, the State Senate, in a 24-10 vote said no, Bridgeport was not going to get a casino. One of the minor ripples from the vote: calls about gambling ceased at the the city library.
But life goes on, and there are other questions. All sorts of questions about other countries, about animals, museums, state capitals, ethnic breakdowns, anything that anyone wants to call about. And sometimes the little questions, the ones that should be easy to answer, drive research librarians crazy, said Ms. Maio.
Like the one the other day. Someone wanted to get a telephone number for Ellis Island. What could be more simple than that?
Most questions, it developed, could be more simple. The research librarian started with the New York phone books. No address or telephone number listed for Ellis Island. "There was no address on the Internet, or museum directories," Ms. Maio added. It was bizarre. The Federal Government spent a fortune to create a museum of immigration on Ellis Island. There had to be a phone number somewhere.
'We finally found one, in a guide book," said Ms. Maio. "Would you believe that!"

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: College President Discusses Arts Cuts

 BODY:
I read "Arts Cut at Old Westbury Revives a Battle" [Dec. 3] with interest. The reporter had called me at least twice to respond to the allegations contained in the article. As both our public relations staff and the academic vice president for academic affairs had discussed the allegations with her at length, there did not seem to be a reason for me to repeat the same concepts.
None of what the public relations officer said was printed, and very little of what the vice president for academic affairs said is printed. Why? 
 Your reporter apparently spent a great deal of time on the campus interviewing faculty and students. Unfortunately while on campus she did not make the effort to interview administration, nor did she inform the administration that she was on campus. She could have received additional information if she had chosen to visit relevant administrators.
There are many errors and unsupported allegations in the article.
The retrenchment of the American music theater and dance program is not related to the 1995-96 operational budget for the campus of $18.2 million. Our original budget for the 1995-96 year was $19.4 million.
After the SUNY budget was passed by the Legislature and signed by the Governor, it became clear that all SUNY campuses would have budget cuts. Our cut was $1.2 million, leaving us with $18.2 million. Since that cut we have experienced a midyear cut of $190,000 and will also pay $150,000 back to the system because of an enrollment shortfall in 1993.
The funds that will be saved by the retrenchment of the program will amount to about $350,000 for salaries for the 1996-97 budget year, not the 1995-96 year. However that latter figure does not include the costs of new instruments nor the repair of old ones. Nor does it include maintenance costs for the facilities.
In the past 10 years I have authorized the purchase of two sets of instruments for the program. Most of those instruments are no longer at the college, and to support the program it would be necessary to make another purchase.
Thus the total costs would amount to at least $500,000 for 20 students. In addition, the program had already been identified by analyses from SUNY central as a high-cost low-enrollment program, and the college was asked to consider whether it could defend its continuance.
We have also proposed cutting two other programs, a French certificate program and an economics program. In fact, most SUNY campuses have proposed program cuts.
Why is Old Westbury being singled out for news? Why not the other SUNY campuses on Long Island?
There is no "racial" line in the retrenchment process. The article compares actions taken by a past president, who happened to have been a white male, to me as an African-American female. Is there some real purpose in this type of comparison? Does the reporter suggest that race should be a factor in making program cuts to achieve fiscal viability? Such reporting is at best misleading and at worst an attempt to create news based on race than on administrative decisions.
My doctorate degree, achieved in 1966, is in psychology, not in music education. I hold a bachelor of music degree, with a major in piano and a minor in organ. As an undergraduate student, I often played jazz on the organ at dances to add to my income to achieve my educational goals.
The SUNY officials did not order me in 1993 to rescind the retrenchment action taken at that time. Such was done on my initiative, once the program agreed to develop a proposal that would allow them to offer a registered-degree program. The program was not a registered-degree program at that time.
The proposal had to be approved by SUNY and the State Board of Education before I rescinded the retrenchment. The program was approved in the fall of 1994. However enrollment has continued to decline, and graduates have also declined.
According to Article 35 of the 1991-1995 U.U.P. contract with SUNY, U.U.P. members who are to be retrenched must be given a year's notice. Thus the retrenchment will begin in the fall of 1996.
Prof. Richard Harper's reported assertion that I am "no jazz fan" is not relevant to the administrative decision that has been made. It was I who brought the Long Island Jazz to the campus as visiting artists. References to whether or not I like jazz merely divert attention from the administrative aspects of the decision.
The recommendation to retrench the program has been made to me twice in the last three years by two different vice presidents for academic affairs, using relevant data about program cost, enrollment, graduation rates, entry into graduate school and the development of performance groups on the campus. These two senior officers reached the same decision independent of each other.
The issues raised by Prof. Maureen Dolan about the college's Budget Planning Committee suggests that I have stopped the process. In fact I only canceled one meeting because of time needed to review the Faculty Strategic Planning Report. No SUNY budget for 1967-97 had been developed, and because the report of the SUNY board of trustees to the Governor and the Legislature due on Dec. 1 had not been completed, there was no fiscal-policy context nor recommendations from the board within which we might review such a report.
Since the trustees' report has now been sent to the Governor, I have instructed the chair of the Budget Planning Committee to schedule meetings for the committee and to review the Strategic Planning Report within the context of the trustees' report.
The SUNY board of trustees did not and have not requested a multiyear report from all campuses by the end of October 1995.
The general administrative costs of the college amount to 8.1 percent of the total operating budget, not 11 percent. Several administrators who are not part of general administration were included in the original dollar amount. SUNY Old Westbury has the smallest number of general administrators of all of the university colleges.
The trip to China was to conduct a workshop at the Fourth U.N. Conference on Women in Beijing. Three Old Westbury faculty were part of the workshop, along with three other participants. The entire trip was supported by donated external funds.
SUNY would not have paid for such an activity, nor would I ever have considered asking the university to pay for the trip.
The trip to South Africa was part of my responsibilities as chair of SUNY's Commission on Africa and was conducted to assess the possibility of academic interaction between SUNY campuses and institutions of higher education in South Africa. I have responded to students on those issues several times.
The college did support theater students to attend a theater festival at Buffalo last year. They received accolades for their performances. No request for this years has been received by me.
 
L. EUDORA PETTIGREW
President, SUNY at Old Westbury

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Downsize, They Ordered. No Way, He Said.

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
THE FACT that those people lost their jobs, that was my responsibility," said Raymond E. McCreary, businessman.
Say what? The Dow's been blazing a blue streak. Corporate profits are up, and downsizing is why. Last month, while the Moet corks popped on Wall Street, another batch of premier companies on this side of the Hudson got into fighting trim, laying off thousands of those cumbersome employees: Prudential in Newark, AT&T in Basking Ridge, Midlantic in Edison and West Paterson. 
 But here we have some guy in a leased factory the size of a high school gym, beside the railroad tracks in Clifton, talking about corporate responsibility -- and putting his money where his mouth is.
The other day, Mr. McCreary was puttering around his used steel-punch presses and heat sealers, preparing to restart production in a business that was downsized last summer, when its corporate owners, Willert Home Products, consolidated operations in St. Louis and dumped 50 workers in New Jersey.
Mr. McCreary, who is 46 years old and lives in Hackensack, had been vice president for production at Excell Products in Clifton, which Willert purchased in 1993.
In the six years he ran the factory, costs dropped and sales rose. Last June, when Willert decided to shut down manufacturing in Clifton, the company offered Mr. McCreary a vice presidency at its headquarters.
He looked at his co-workers and said no thanks.
"These employees are good people," Mr. McCreary explained. "They worked hard. We were able to cut production costs by a third before the owners closed down the company. They shouldn't be just left out in the cold."
So he spent the summer running the numbers for a business plan, and put together $500,000 from personal savings and bank loans to go back into business in Clifton.
He figured the chances for succeeding were a little better than 50-50. His wife of 21 years urged him to do go for it. "I know it's going to work," Susan McCreary, a retail executive, said firmly.
Five months later, Mr. McCreary's new company, Paragon Household Products, plans to start production this week. Some of the former employees are already back at work for Mr. McCreary, who has an engineering degree, two M.B.A.'s, years of corporate background in joint ventures and mergers -- and few illusions about business.
"I've worked for large corporations and I know what the hard realities are," he said in his austere office, which has some Japanese prints on the wall and overlooks a row of old warehouses. "Sentimentality is nice, but not when you have close to a half-million dollars at stake.
"We're not producing anything anymore in this country," he went on. "I just want to make something, as dumb as these products might sound."
Mr. McCreary's products are second-wave enough to give Newt Gingrich and the Tofflers a case of the vapors. Under the brand name Common Scents, Paragon will make mothballs and hook-on toilet-bowl, urinal and room deodorizers, all pressed out of powdered paradichlorobenzene, a far less dangerous substance than the naphthalene traditionally used.
Willert, his former company, controls about 95 percent of the national market for mothballs and toilet deodorizers.
Paragon now has six employees, including two foremen, Ramon and Fausto Rodriguez, who worked at the old company for 14 years. "It's very good to have the job," said Ramon Rodriguez, who supervises shipping. The Rodriguez brothers each earn $12 to $13 an hour -- which incidentally is the figure that some economists say edges a worker into the middle class.
Next month, Mr. McCreary said, there will be 12 employees, many of them rehired from the former company. By April, Mr. McCreary expects to employ as many as 25.
Unglamorous as it sounds, mothballs and toilet deodorizers is a cut-throat business played by Wal-Mart rules, where an intruder who appears on the big boys' radar screens can get blown out of the sky with a blast of predatory price-cutting.
Mr. McCreary intends to fly in low, using short distribution routes and quick deliveries to small stores and bodegas, and a few regional supermarket chains, in New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and the fringes of New England.
Later, after Paragon finds its niche, he figures some product innovation might be in order.
"Household products is a funny category," he said. "You know, that one little aisle in the supermarket that nobody likes to go down?"
The aisle where they sell not just mothballs and deodorizers, but "brooms, mops, dust-pans, scrub brushes, drain cleaners, rust removers . . . ."
He thought for a minute. "Mousetraps," he said, wondering about the prospects of building a better one.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
AT&T Offer: One Said No, One Said Yes

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

DATELINE: NEW VERNON, N.J.

 BODY:
JIM BOWERS wraps the ham, roast beef and cheese left over from lunch and talks about why he is refusing the voluntary severance package AT&T offered him last month.
Even though he may be "involuntarily separated" from his middle-management job as early as next month, it doesn't make sense for him to take the risk, said Mr. Bowers, who at 48 has spent 13 years at AT&T. For him, the buyout offer is not much higher than severance would be. Besides, he and his wife, Judith, do not want to uproot their teen-age daughter, Alaire, a talented flutist and a member of the New Jersey Youth Orchestra. Given the poor New Jersey job market, a move would be likely. 
 "I think AT&T is going to need me," said Mr. Bowers, in the house he helped design and build near AT&T's headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J.. "But there's not a single person AT&T couldn't do without. I'd have to be a fool to say I wasn't worried."
An hour and a half's drive and a life's experience away in Manhattan, Clare Powell sits perched on a cardboard moving-company box and talks about why she accepted AT&T's buyout offer. She is about to move to Connecticut to a new job as a sports marketing consultant. Her last day at AT&T is Jan. 10.
"You don't just walk away from a company that you have a very deep emotional attachment to," said Ms. Powell, who is 35 and single. "But I think I'm a better employee if I have one foot out the door. It keeps you from being complacent."
She added: "You always read about another company laying people off and you have to be cognizant that you could be next. It's a useful paranoia."
Mr. Bowers and Ms. Powell are two of the more than 72,000 employees --half of AT&T's managers -- offered the voluntary severance package. Like other big companies, AT&T uses such packages -- a combination of cash, pension sweeteners and other incentives -- to avoid the cheaper but more demoralizing method of summary dismissal. Only about 300 employees have volunteered, and if not enough employees step forward, dismissals will be necessary as early as Jan. 15. And there is no guarantee that the shrinkage will stop there.
What is unusual about the AT&T plan is not only the number of employees involved, but also the fact that even those who stay will face almost permanent uncertainty. It used to be that cutbacks were painful surgery that employees could soon put behind them. Now the blade is never far away.
The buyout offer follows the September announcement that AT&T plans to break up into three less-gargantuan pieces: a long-distance telephone company, an equipment company and a computer maker.
And everyone at the new companies could be "at risk," the company euphemism for subject to layoff, if not now, then a year or 10 years from now. It is a stark reversal of the monopoly days, when AT&T was the biggest company on earth and a job there could mean a lifetime assignment and a fat pension.
"It's almost as tough to be a survivor as someone who has been asked to leave," said John Derse Jr., a partner at Ernst & Young who is an employee benefits consultant. "People are having the hell scared out of them."
ALAN JOHNSON, head of Johnson Associates, another benefits consultant, said: "For people who don't take the buyout and retain their jobs, it should be a wake-up call. You need to keep your skill sets in line with the needs of your industry, or else."
He added that many people, especially professionals, neglect to consider the bleakest possibility in industries in the turmoil of retrenchment. "No matter what you do," Mr. Johnson said, "you may have no future whatsoever."
And Jim L. Meadows, AT&T's human resources vice president in charge of "career placement alternatives," said: "There is no magic number" of employees at which AT&T would stop reassessing its staffing needs. "I don't think there is an answer to the question, 'When does this process stop?' Business changes. The world changes."
Like many other companies, AT&T has been steadily paring the number of employees to cut costs. But unlike other companies, AT&T is doing so not because it is losing money -- it is expected to post a profit of $5.6 billion this year -- but because it is trying to escape its bloated past.
AT&T, with more than $75 billion in annual revenue, has cut an average of nearly 900 employees, about the size of a medium-sized business, every month for the 12 years since the 1984 breakup accord that created AT&T and the seven regional Bells, like Nynex and Bell Atlantic. That comes to 126,000 jobs.
AT&T is the largest profitable company to choose a more or less permanent state of revolution, in which it may rapidly add jobs, either piecemeal or through acquisitions, and years later just as rapidly shed jobs in a gigantic, nerve-jangling (for employees, at least) work in progress.
For Jim Bowers and Clare Powell, the big picture was the furthest thing from their minds on Sept. 20, a Wednesday, when AT&T announced what employees call the "trivestiture." Both Mr. Bowers and Ms. Powell had similar reactions and took a similar length of time to realize the personal consequences.
Mr. Bowers is a product manager in charge of software for giant telephone networks, like one that helps maintenance workers pinpoint faults in transmission. He remembers hearing the announcement by AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, on his car radio while on his way to visit a corporate customer.
As a senior marketer, Mr. Bowers had had trouble selling products to local phone companies like Nynex because AT&T's long-distance branch is a likely competitor when the local phone market is opened to competition, much as long distance was in the 1980's. The competition can only become more intense as cable companies like Time Warner also offer telephone service.
The trivestiture "really is in the best interests of the company," Mr. Bowers said. "It's better to be the arms merchant for all the warring parties than trying to sell ammo to someone who says, 'Hey, you're my enemy.' "
Ms. Powell is corporate event marketing director in the Manhattan office of AT&T. She helps organize events like the AT&T Pro-Am Pebble Beach golf tournament, as well as sponsorship of shows and institutions like Cirque du Soleil and the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame.
Ms. Powell's boss warned her to cancel all appointments that Wednesday morning in anticipation of an important announcement from Mr. Allen. Ms. Powell watched the announcement on her office television set and thought to herself, "What a brilliant, smart, smart decision." Trivestiture, she said, made AT&T much more competitive.
Both Mr. Bowers and Ms. Powell were in a bit of a daze after the announcement, and both had so much work that they plunged into it, hoping to avoid thinking about the effect on their jobs.
When Ms. Powell told her parents the news, her father, David Powell, a recently retired public relations executive at Allied Signal, recalled asking, "Where are you going to get assigned, Clare?"
What he really meant, Mr. Powell said, is, "Are you going to have a job?" Ms. Powell said she didn't know where she would be assigned.
Whatever affection Ms. Powell felt for AT&T ("It's like my family"), she thought it only prudent to update her resume and return the phone calls of executive recruiters.
An economics graduate of Hamilton College, Ms. Powell abandoned what she thought was a possible career as a stockbroker or money manager for a much more tenuous career in marketing.
She had worked her way up from a temporary position in 1985 to a job organizing corporate sponsorship for concerts and street festivals for the Hispanic market. After the band leader Tito Puente kissed her, "I almost didn't wash my cheek for days," she said.
A week passed before it really sank in that she could be laid off. "In the back of my mind, I always live assuming I might get a pink slip," she said. "I'd be lying if I said it was something I enjoyed thinking about. But this is not the world it was when my father was working. You don't have lifetime employment."
"Clare's typical of a new breed," said her father, who worked for 23 years at Exxon and 16 years at Allied Signal. "The old paternalistic relationship is dead. The employee is simply the sum of his or her skills."
Just two weeks after the announcement, Ms. Powell got a call from the ISL Company, a Stamford, Conn., subsidiary of a Swiss sports-licensing concern: Would she like to do at ISL what she does at AT&T? Ms. Powell liked the principals of the firm, whom she got to know in working on AT&T projects, and thought seriously about leaving.
Then, last month, AT&T made its buyout offer. "At some point I knew I had to leave because I eventually want to own my business," Ms. Powell said. "But when is the right time? If I didn't jump, I'd probably regret it for the rest of my life."
Recently separated and about to complete a divorce, Ms. Powell also had no children to complicate a decision. Under the buyout, she will receive about a half year's salary. She would not disclose her salary, but Ms. Powell's type of job typically pays between $80,000 and $120,000.
"If you're going to go, it would be great to go when they give you money to go," she said. "Pretty simple."
For Jim Bowers, the decision was also straightforward -- after he took more than a week to sense that his job could be in danger. He quickly realized, however, that he was too young to quit and, he feared, too old to get another job.
A physiology major at Ohio State, Mr. Bowers got a master's degree in library science at Rutgers University. After serving on the library-science faculty at the University of Florida in Gainesville, he became the corporate librarian and marketing manager at Allied Chemical, which eventually became Allied Signal. He also received an M.B.A. from Fairleigh-Dickinson University.
THEN, thinking videotext would be the next big thing, he joined AT&T in 1982 in the abortive project to develop and market a precursor of business and residential computer services. He eventually moved up to become a project manager for computer software.
But the job market today in New Jersey is weaker than it was a decade ago, Mr. Bowers said. The traditional route of early retirees -- returning to AT&T as a consultant at a large fraction of your old salary -- is vanishing.
Mr. Bowers and his wife decided they would simply have to tough it out. "The whole thing was a nondecision for me," he said on a recent afternoon dressed in a plaid shirt and a "Camp Friendship" T-shirt.
"I could leave this house, which I love, in a day. But everything my wife and I do now is focused on daughter," referring to Alaire, the flutist. "Daughter goes to private school. Daughter would lose her music tutor. Daughter would lose her place in the New Jersey Youth Orchestra, which is very competitive." Even a standard flute for Alaire costs more than $4,000.
He added, 'If I don't have to go, I'm willing to stick it out for daughter."
The family lives in comfort in a home filled with family keepsakes and furniture picked up at flea markets and antique stores. But Mr. Bowers sees few places where they can cut costs if he loses his job, whose salary Mr. Bowers does not want to specify but is probably between $60,000 and $80,000.
The family doesn't eat at expensive restaurants or take costly vacations, and Mrs. Bowers only rarely goes to Manhattan to the opera. Mr. Bowers heats much of the house with more than four cords of wood gathered from nearby roads.
Except for Alaire's schooling and martial-arts lessons, the family's main outlay is for extensive payments into AT&T retirement and savings accounts. They also have $20,000 in savings that a financial planner recommended as a supplement to Social Security. But a car recently hit the family Ford Taurus, which had an insurance value of just $7,000. They want to buy a new car to replace it, but that will eat up $13,000 of the couple's special fund.
Moreover, the financial planner gave Mr. Bowers the sobering advice that he must work until age 62, or 14 more years, mainly to cover Alaire's college expenses, as well as qualify for a higher pension.
Under the buyout program, Mr. Bowers would get a little more than half a year's salary "to take a walk." If he waits to get dismissed, he only loses eight weeks' salary, or about $9,000 to $12,000.
Mr. Bowers, 48, doesn't qualify for a full pension. Typically, an AT&T manager would have to be 55, with 20 years of service, to qualify. There is always the pension he will receive after working for 10 years at Allied Chemical, about $300 a month.
"Enough to buy a loaf of bread in the year 2009," Mr. Bowers said ruefully.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1318 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Global Thinkers Urged to Bring Some Money Home

SERIES: FRESH START: A periodic look at the crossroads of personal finance

BYLINE: By ROBERT BRYCE

 BODY:
STEVE LORENZEN took his first trip abroad in 1957, when his parents drove the family to Mexico City for a vacation. Since then, Mr. Lorenzen, now 49, has returned to Mexico dozens of times, and has visited Africa, Europe and Central America.
In fact, foreign lands have become a field of study for him. "I have a longstanding interest in the former Soviet Union and in Central and Eastern Europe," Mr. Lorenzen said. An economist at the Texas Department of Human Services, he has also done research on how people eke out a living in the slums outside Mexico City, and he continues to stay in touch with Mexican friends. 
 With these interests, it is no surprise that Mr. Lorenzen and his wife, Cathy, who is 43 and a data manager at the same agency, have many foreign investments. The couple, who live in Austin, have accounts in 17 mutual funds, and nine of them focus on international equities. Of the $115,500 they have in retirement and nonretirement assets, $54,400 is in foreign stocks and just $32,100 in American ones. They also own four Mexican stocks in the form of American depository receipts, and to gauge their prospects Mr. Lorenzen uses the Internet to track Mexican unemployment rates, interest rates and factory production.
But David Diesslin, a fee-only certified financial planner at Diesslin & Associates in Fort Worth, warns them that while scholarly interests are fine, putting lots of assets abroad makes for a lopsided portfolio.
"You may be taking more risk than you realize," he said, noting that with international stocks "not only do you have market risk but you have currency risk" as well.
Also, the Lorenzens have too much money in stocks for Mr. Diesslin's taste -- nearly 80 percent of their assets, counting some small shares in limited partnerships. "I don't think this is the time to bet the ranch in the stock market," he said.
Oddly enough, it was a wager of sorts, in addition to their intellectual interests, that helped draw the couple's money abroad.
"A year or so ago, I made a bet that the international markets would do better than they have," Mr. Lorenzen said. "So I shifted a substantial share of my assets into international funds." But reality did not cooperate in this attempt at market timing. According to the Morgan Stanley Europe, Austral-Asia and Far East index, a widely used performance measure, foreign stocks have risen 16.83 percent this year through Nov. 30, while the Standard & Poor's 500 has gained 34.98 percent in the same period.
Of course, the wisdom of taking risks depends on investors' income, expenses, time frame and other factors. But a look at the Lorenzens suggests that by these measures their investing may be too chancy.
For example, their combined annual income of $95,000 is offset by substantial expenses. Their monthly mortgage payment is $1,250 -- they have 21 years to go on it -- and they spend another $500 a month to keep their 22-year-old son, Kurt, in cheeseburgers, books and protractors as he studies physics at the University of Texas. Other monthly expenses include about $300 in car and life insurance payments.
And while longer horizons can lessen investment risks, some of the couple's cash needs may come well before retirement. There will be college costs for their 7-year-old daughter, Kristina, for example, and both of them harbor professional dreams that may shrink their income.
Mr. Lorenzen hopes to start a business someday in which he can use his knowledge of Mexico. And Mrs. Lorenzen -- who has two novels, as yet unpublished, to her credit -- would rather be known for her writing than for managing data.
They may not change their jobs, but if they do, they may have to tap the $9,000 in their Acorn International mutual fund account, or the $4,000 in Harbor International, at an inopportune time.
Moreover, the bulk of their $115,500 -- $82,100 -- is in tax-advantaged retirement accounts like 401(k)'s and I.R.A.'s. But raiding this money might lead to tax penalties, so that leaves the remaining $33,400 as the likeliest candidate in times of need. And this nonretirement money, unfortunately, is where the Lorenzens have some of their riskiest investments.
The couple may also be less tolerant of risk than their current investments suggest. "In any one year, how much of a loss would drive you out of stocks?" Mr. Diesslin asked Mr. Lorenzen. "If in two years, your portfolio was worth $50,000, you'd still be comfortable?" Though Mr. Lorenzen spoke of the virtues of long-term investing, he still seemed fairly discomfited at the possibility.
Based on all this, Mr. Diesslin presented the couple with several recommendations.
First, he favored lowering stocks from nearly 80 percent of the couple's assets to about 65 percent, and raising bonds from 5.2 percent to 25 percent. "Even though bonds outperform stocks only 27 percent of the time," Mr. Diesslin said, the couple would have more protection if stocks fall.
Also for safety, he recommended that they hold more stocks in domestic issues. "If we really do balance the budget in the United States, and the dollar has substantial strengthening, gains made overseas could be wiped out," he said.
Mr. Diesslin felt that the Lorenzens should reduce the number of mutual funds they hold as well. "I'm into simplification," he said. "If you want to hold this many funds, you have to do more homework." He suggested that the Lorenzens sell at least 5 of their 17 funds, and that they compare the top 10 holdings of each of the remainder to see if there is any substantial duplication.
The planner also believes that the couple need to make other investment changes if they are to retire on an annual income of $60,000, as they wish.
Both are in line for pensions from the state, though the amounts depend on their lengths of stay. They also put pretax money into 401(k) plans -- he devotes 15 percent of income while she puts in 7 percent -- for a total of $1,325 a month.
In judging whether these savings were adequate, Mr. Diesslin made some very conservative projections. Because of intervening inflation, he figured, the spending power of $60,000 today would require $116,000 a year when Mr. Lorenzen retires. Mr. Diesslin also assumed that Mr. Lorenzen might leave his agency before he reached age 65 and, as a result, might get only about $20,000 in annual pension.
Under these assumptions, the Lorenzens need to pick up the pace of their 401(k) savings, Mr. Diesslin said. Ms. Lorenzen must invest $500 more a month. "That's where you can get the farthest distance toward building that nest egg," he said. "A dollar in the 401(k) saves 30 cents in taxes."
Mr. Diesslin also urged the couple to save for Kristina's college bills, putting money into the Twentieth Century Giftrust, a growth fund specializing in small-company stocks and used for trusts for minors.
A few days after talking with Mr. Diesslin, the Lorenzens discussed finances while sipping iced tea on the deck of their home. Ms. Lorenzen agreed that they needed to save more in their 401(k)'s, but an extra $500 "seems like a lot to me at this point," she said. "Every week, with school activities and Brownies, there are always small expenses and it just all adds up." But she believes an added $200 a month is doable.
Similarly, Mr. Lorenzen plans to begin buying some bond funds; Mr. Diesslin recommended Loomis Sayles Bond fund and the Lindner Dividend fund. But Mr. Lorenzen wondered where Kristina's college money would come from. In a few years, " Kurt, hopefully, will be through with college," he said. "Maybe after he gets out, we can free up some money."
But one thing will not change for the Lorenzens: their belief in international investing, particularly the emerging markets. "If you ignore those economies," Mr. Lorenzen said, "you are ignoring a growing part of the capitalization of the world."

PUB-DATE: December 10, 1995

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1071 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
FUNDS WATCH

BYLINE: By CAROL GOULD 

 BODY:

Gauging the Cost Of 401(k) Plans
The amount paid for 401(k) plans can vary widely, according to the Butler Index, begun recently by the Pension Dynamics Corporation of Lafayette, Calif. 
 The index shows what 12 mutual fund and other companies would charge for a plan with $1 million in assets and 50 employees -- in other words, a small plan. The annualized costs are divided into the amount paid by the employer and that paid cumulatively by the 50 employees. Though they may not realize it, employees who check on their plans will generally find that a portion is deducted from the accounts of individual participants.
For a plan of this size, the lowest-cost providers were Principal Financial, T. Rowe Price Century Plan and Vanguard, according to the index.
Along with costs, a critical factor is investment performance. "A vendor may say that, although its costs and fees are above average, you are being awarded with superior investment performance," said Stephen J. Butler, president of Pension Dynamics. "Don't take this claim on faith. Check the performance of your prospective vendors' investments in a respected source, such as Morningstar."
 
Best of the Bonds? Corporates and Munis
Buying shares in a Government bond fund is easier than buying small quantities of Government bonds. But most Government funds lag behind their benchmarks. They're expensive, and there are better alternatives, John Rekenthaler, editor of the Morningstar Investor, wrote in the most recent issue.
About 85 percent of Government Treasury and mortgage bond funds trail the Lehman Brothers Government index, and they don't compensate by showing lower risk. The reason is that the market is very efficient, and fund managers are handicapped by expenses, which average 1.05 percent of assets a year.
Best bets for investors are the low-cost Vanguard funds, Mr. Rekenthaler concludes. Other options are Strong Government Securities, which stretches the definition of Government to include unusual mortgages and some corporate bonds, and Sit U.S. Government Securities, which owns mobile-home mortgages.
Otherwise, investors in low tax brackets should now go with corporates, Mr. Rekenthaler argues. They are less costly and their market is less efficient. FPA New Income has beaten the Government indexes for a decade with less risk, he said. Other funds he recommends: Loomis Sayles Bond, Dodge & Cox Income and Harbor Bond.
For people taxed at 28 percent or more, municipal bond funds, especially single-state funds, are the way to go. Exempt from Federal and state tax for in-state residents, the single-state funds yield more without sacrificing long-term performance. Best bets are run by Vanguard, Fidelity Investments, T. Rowe Price and Scudder, Stevens & Clark, Mr. Rekenthaler says.
Because long-term munis carry a lot of interest-rate risk, cautious investors might consider intermediate-term muni funds even though yields are lower.
 
A Rift Over Money Funds
A proposal by the Securities and Exchange Commission to force money market funds to report their holdings quarterly is running into opposition from the industry.
The Investment Company Institute, the mutual-fund trade group, says the proposal is neither "necessary nor appropriate" and would result in unnecessary costs.
Not so, says Glen King Parker, publisher of the Income Fund Outlook, an investment newsletter in Deerfield Beach, Fla. Many institutional money funds already publish portfolios monthly and make them available to shareholders, he said, and those that sell to the general public should provide more disclosure.
In fact, he would prefer reporting monthly instead of quarterly. "Money funds have become quasi-banks," he said, "and I don't think that there's anything wrong with an increased level of scrutiny."
 
A Portfolio Thinks Small
James Oberweis, manager of the $135 million Oberweis Emerging Growth fund, is starting the Micro-Cap Portfolio, which will invest in very, very small stocks. The average market capitalization of the stocks in the Emerging Growth portfolio is $400 million to $500 million; in the new fund it will be less than $100 million.
The new fund is being structured to let investors get in at the starting gate. Money will be collected from mid-December, but it won't be invested until the fund begins operating on Jan. 2.
To stay true to his small-cap mission, Mr. Oberweis plans to close the fund when it reaches $50 million in assets. Even existing shareholders won't be allowed to add new money, though they can reinvest their earnings.
 
More New Funds
Robertson, Stephens & Company, San Francisco, is adding three funds. Its Information Age fund, managed by Ron Elijah, who already runs the company's Value and Growth fund, will concentrate on small-capitalization technology companies with unusual offerings in multimedia, wireless communications, networking, software and the like. Global Natural Resources will be managed by Andy J. Pilara Jr., who also manages the Partners and Contrarian funds. Global Low Priced Stock will buy overlooked companies with share prices of $10 or less.
Bank of America has started three Time Horizon funds with stated maturity dates in the life-style category. The funds aim to maximize total return and then emphasize capital preservation as the fund approaches its maturity date. Time Horizon Portfolio 1 is for investors with a financial goal near the year 2005, Portfolio 2 for 2015 and Portfolio 3 for 2025.
Fidelity Investments has added to its international lineup with six aggressive growth funds that invest in single countries and regions abroad. All the funds carry a 3 percent sales charge and a 1.5 percent redemption fee on shares held less than 90 days. They are Fidelity France, Germany, Hong Kong and China, Japan Small Companies, Nordic and United Kingdom.
 
New Management
Ernst H. Von Metzsch, who picked up the Vanguard Wellington fund after the death of Vincent Bajakian in September, has been named the permanent manager.
Catherine Dudley left Phoenix Growth to join Chancellor Investments. She is replaced at the fund by William J. Newman, the company's chief investment strategist.
In Brief
Fidelity Investments plans to make all its prospectuses available soon on the Internet. The company has 83 prospectuses there now (http://www.fid-inv.com) and expects to put the remainder there by early next year.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
Once Again, Armory Shelters Homeless and Stirs Dispute

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
For the 14 years that the Flushing Armory was used by the city's Department of Homeless Services as a women's shelter, it was a source of controversy. Neighborhood residents said the homeless women at the shelter loitered on the streets, used drugs and alcohol and solicited male students at nearby Flushing High School.
Now, with the armory reopened as an emergency shelter for homeless men, residents are again up in arms, and local elected officials said the city was circumventing regulations by operating the shelter without a permit from the state. 
 In a joint statement, State Assemblyman Brian McLaughlin and State Senator Leonard Stavisky said the city had "either deliberately violated or deliberately circumvented" its own procurement rules by awarding a $540,000 contract to the Salvation Army to run the shelter without an open-bidding process. In addition, an aide to Mr. McLaughlin said the city does not have an operating license from the State Department of Social Services to run an emergency shelter at the armory.
City officials said open bidding was not necessary because the city was merely extending an existing Salvation Army contract to run a shelter on Borden Avenue in Long Island City. "It was completely appropriate and completely consistent with the city's procurement rule," said Muzzy Rosenblatt, chief of staff at the Department of Homeless Services. "The Salvation Army is the only contract who met all of our needs."
Terrence McGrath, a spokesman for the State Department of Social Services, said the city does not need state certification to run the shelter because it is used only on an as-needed basis.
Community leaders, who had hoped that the armory would be converted into a multipurpose community center with offices for the Police Department's Queens North Task Force and Community Board 7, said they feared that the shelter would be detrimental to the area's recent economic improvement.
"We certainly understand and are sympathetic to the administration and to the needs of the homeless," said Jo-Ann Jones, executive director of the Flushing Arts Council, which has headquarters at Flushing Town Hall, across the street from the armory. "But for those of us who are working toward the quality of life and enhancing the safety of the area, this is certainly a setback."
Ms. Jones said the shelter was "extremely detrimental to the area" when it was used to house homeless women, who she and other residents said often engaged in drug use and prostitution. "Businesses near the shelter closed because owners couldn't put up with the harassment," she said.
Mr. Rosenblatt said the armory, at 137-58 Northern Boulevard, would be used from December through April when other shelters exceeded than 95 percent capacity. To further insure the community's safety, the homeless will be bused in from Manhattan from a central processing unit in the evening and will be bused back to Manhattan by 8 the next morning.
Maj. Betty Israel, social services secretary for the Salvation Army for Greater New York operations, said the center, which has its own security guard and about 30 employees, would not accept any walk-ins.
Mr. Rosenblatt said the Flushing Armory, with a capacity of 180 in the homeless shelter, took in 120 people on Dec. 1, its opening night, and 24 people each on two nights last week. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Fur Center Sale: The Synagogue

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
In its glory days, the Fur Center Synagogue on West 29th Street was so crowded that some services had three seatings. Today, the congregation, founded in 1935, has fallen to 27 members from a peak of 700. Struggling to pay its bills, it is negotiating to sell the one-story synagogue it built in 1965 to a meditation group. Last month it stopped holding services.
"We're all heartsick," said Abby Thomas, the synagogue's administrator. "But the fur district isn't what it used to be." 
 The synagogue's troubles mirror the economic and demographic changes that have wrenched the fur industry. Cheap imports, a string of warm winters and the animal-rights movement have conspired against a once-thriving industry centered at 30th Street and Eighth Avenue. In 1955, there were 25,000 fur district workers, 80 percent of whom were Jewish. Today the workers, most of Greek descent, number 2,000.
Seven years ago, the congregation hired a 26-year-old rabbi, Joel Kenny, who members say helped bring about a renaissance in the synagogue's spiritual life. Dozens of Jews who live in the surrounding area joined the synagogue and attended services on weekends, when most of the furriers are home in the suburbs. Although the synagogue is Orthodox, all Jews were welcomed. "Before he came, this place was really moribund," said Joan Rosenfelt, a film maker who lives in Greenwich Village. "He brought in the fire of youth and attracted a diverse bunch of people."
But enthusiasm was not enough to pay the $18,000 a year it costs to heat and light the building or the $40,000 it took to fix a leaking roof. Ms. Thomas, who did not disclose the building's sale price, said she hoped the new owner would let the congregation meet in the basement.
Sol Goldstein, chairman of the synagogue, remembers when hundreds of skin merchants, coat manufacturers and fur wholesalers would gather in the main sanctuary for yahrzeit, the service marking the anniversary of the death of a relative. "You'd look around and every face would be a familiar one," said Mr. Goldstein, 81, a retired furrier. "They're all gone now, and I can't tell you how sad that is for me." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: The Center Holds Out

BYLINE: By Paul Tsongas; Paul Tsongas, a lawyer and a Democrat, was a Senator from Massachusetts from 1979 to 1984.

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass.

 BODY:
If you are ever in front of an audience and searching for an engaging topic, try this: suggest there is a "passionate center" to the American body politic -- or "sensible center," as Colin Powell would say, or "radical center" as others would argue. Suggest that this center is held together by four basic points of agreement.
First, it is fiscally conservative. It strongly supports a balanced budget -- not so much because of the economic consequences of large-scale debt but because of the irresponsibility such debt symbolizes. While it is true that a balanced budget will reduce interest rates and free up capital to enhance America's global competitiveness, the passion for fiscal responsibility really flows from people's adamant opposition to saddling their children with a $5 trillion debt. 
 Second, the passionate center is socially inclusive and protective of individual liberties. Most Americans are not racist or sexist. Increasing numbers accept homosexuality. Polls show, unsurprisingly, that most Democratic and independent women are pro-choice, but they also show that most Republican women are pro-choice as well.
 Third, it is pro-environment. Where did anyone get the idea that Americans were so fed up with Federal regulations that they would want Congress to gut the Clean Water Act and Clean Air Act? Or to open up wildlife refuges to oil companies? Or to support any of the myriad bonehead ideas of the last year? Most Americans, especially the young, see the environment as fundamental to their quality of life, as a legacy to be protected, not a place to be plundered for the profit of the few.
Fourth, the passionate center wants campaign finance reform. Americans are sickened by political action committees owning Congress and by "soft money" funds that evade campaign laws to benefit the very people who passed those laws. When President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich shook hands in New Hampshire in June and agreed to strengthen campaign laws, most Americans doubted that they were serious. As the weak "reform" package passed by Congress shows, the skeptics were right.
Run these four principles past most audiences and you will meet very little resistance. You will likely get vigorous assent. But if you ask which of the two major parties shares them, you will get silence.Perhaps some Democrats will get up and talk proudly about their party's noble record on civil rights. And Republicans will get up and talk proudly about their party's courage this year in seeking to end the budget deficit. But can anyone vouch for his or her party on all four principles? Or even on three? No.
Why is it that the only attempt by the White House to produce a balanced budget missed by some $200 billion a year? Why is it that Republicans want a tax cut for the wealthy that will necessitate severe cuts in programs for the most vulnerable? Why is it that no remaining Republican Presidential candidate is pro-choice? Why does it take a public outcry to force the White House to reconsider and reject the Democratic National Committee's plan to charge big contributors $100,000 each for a dinner with the President?
Both parties fail to give Americans what they really want because they are beholden to the ideologically pure in their ranks: old-time big spenders on the Democratic left and the Reaganomic stalwarts on the Republican right. That is why the voters of the "passionate center" feel alienated.
In 1992 they embraced Ross Perot until his temperament diverted their interest from his sincere efforts to educate the country on the perils of the huge deficit. This year they longed, in vain, for Colin Powell. America needs someone or some group to force, cajole and embarrass the two major parties into moving toward this passionate center. That is why I have taken part in several recent meetings with prominent centrists including the former Governors Richard D. Lamm of Colorado and Lowell Weicker of Connecticut, and the former Representatives John Anderson of Illinois and Tim Penny of Minnesota.
We prefer a two-party system and don't want to be spoilers. But if the 1996 election shows that Republican and Democratic leaders cannot or will not respect the passionate center, there will be a third-party movement in 1997, whether we are part of it or not. Americans will not stand by mutely and watch their future jeopardized by the mood swings of two unresponsive parties.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Some Winnings for Farmers From Atlantic City Gambling

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

 BODY:
Money gambled in Atlantic City's casinos is helping buy a new tractor for Virgil Eachus's farm in Mullica Hill.
Mr. Eachus recently received a check for $65,600, the first chunk of $3 million in loans that the Casino Revinvestment Development Authority is making to farmers in southern New Jersey. Twenty-two farmers have already qualified for $2 million. 
 Since the casino reinvestment agency was set up in 1984, it has funneled millions of dollars into economic development projects around the state. Until now, its focus has been urban areas in general and Atlantic City in particular.
In announcing the loan program, state officials talked about the economic importance of preserving the stability of farming in southern New Jersey. That message, particularly when backed by money, is good news to farmers like the Eachus family, who have owned Wellacrest Farms in Gloucester County since 1942. "We're kind of in a hardship now," Mr. Eachus said. "Farm prices are really down."
No matter what price milk is bringing in, the farm's 300 cows must be milked every day. "We start about 8 in the morning and go until about 4," Mr. Eachus said. "Then we start up about 8 P.M. and go all night." And when the milking is done, there's the rest of the day-to-day business of running the 1,500-acre farm.
That doesn't leave much free time. But, yes, Mr. Eachus says, he has been to Atlantic City once or twice himself. SUSAN JO KELLER

HEADLINE: Doors Open to China's Remote West

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Karl E. Meyer's "Asia's Lost World" (Editorial Notebook, Dec. 4) raises some interesting points about the Xinjiang-Uighur Autonomous Region in western China.
The area was designated such by the Chinese in 1958. Autonomy is limited only to some aspects of culture, not economy or politics. 
 Uighur is a created name for the titular ethnic group in the region. A Turkic people, the Uighur, came to the area in the 800's and formed the Uighur Empire in the eastern portion of the area. They intermarried with local Turkic and Persian groups.
After the Mongol conquest in the 1200's, people referred to themselves only as being from Kashgar or Turpan without a specific ethnic identity. Uighur as an ethnic term fell into disuse until the 1920's.
The Soviets resurrected this term to refer to these descendants of the Uighur Empire. Another "minority" group in the area, the Kazakh, have a similarly complicated history, but with the newly independent state of Kazakhstan, the Kazakhs in China will be finding a new voice.
China's open-door policy has meant greater circulation of foreign goods, travelers and traders in the region as well as foreign ideas -- not just from neighboring places like Pakistan and Kazakhstan but also from Europe, the United States and Japan. Linkages in Central Asia will become as strong as those in the Pacific Rim. The open borders have linked Uighurs and Kazakhs with the global community.
In the past 10 years that I have been going to the region, many changes have occurred. Besides the rail link to Kazakhstan and through that to Russia and Europe, roads tie Xinjiang to Kirghizia, Mongolia and Pakistan, and jets connect to Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates and soon to Pakistan and Russia.
 
STANLEY TOOPS
Oxford, Ohio, Dec. 5, 1995
 
Prof., Geography and Intl. Studies
Miami University

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: WHO'S SORRY NOW?;
Stalwart in Defense Of His Shrinking Turf

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON blocked the Republicans' sweeping plans for reshaping three decades of American social and fiscal policy last week sitting squarely behind a symbol of the spirit he sought to project in the Oval Office: the burly, dark oak desk that Queen Victoria gave to Rutherford B. Hayes. It is made of timber from a British ship whose name is this President's latest watchword: Resolute.
"I am using this pen to preserve our commitment to our parents, to protect opportunity for our children, to defend the public health and our natural resources and natural beauty, and to stop a tax increase that actually undercuts the value of work," Mr. Clinton intoned, wielding the pen that Lyndon B. Johnson used 30 years ago to sign legislation creating Medicare and Medicaid. 
 His aides were jubilant that their President, so often accused of standing for so little, had at last clearly defined a patch of ground and stood it -- defending Medicare and Medicaid to apparent public acclaim. He has been equally firm on an issue with much less public support: sending troops to police a peace accord in Bosnia.
But even as he vetoed the Republicans' plan to cut taxes, shrink Federal programs and reduce tax credits for the working poor, Mr. Clinton offered his own proposal for meeting their goal of balancing the Federal budget by 2002, with slower and shallower cuts in many of the same programs. In that teeter-tottering tension between determination and accommodation lies a tale.
For Mr. Clinton's current resolve was born of months of small, sidewinding steps of contrition and compromise that have moved him steadily closer to Republican aims while preserving just enough of his carefully culled priorities to make it plausible to claim that he is protecting them. Indeed, it may be that Mr. Clinton can only presume to conquer by compromising.
This may be partly congenital. Mr. Clinton, the accommodating elder son of a classically dysfunctional family, can seldom resist trying to win converts, as he did when he seemed to repudiate his own 1993 budget by telling an audience of rich Texans this fall that he raised their taxes too much.
But it is also tactical. When Republicans won control of Congress last year promising tax cuts and leaner Government, Mr. Clinton revived his own call for middle-class tax relief and renewed his efforts to "re-invent" Government. When Republicans said that Mr. Clinton was resisting balancing the budget, he said he wanted to, too -- but insisted it would take 10 years.
Finally, last month, to restart the Government after it was halted by a stalemate over a temporary spending bill, Mr. Clinton agreed to the Republicans' call for balancing the budget in seven years but only in exchange for language to protect popular programs for health, education and the environment that the White House thinks could be key to the President's re-election.
 
A Spate of Mea Culpas
 Ceding ground to gain ground is one of the oldest patterns in politics. Mr. Clinton reclaimed the Arkansas Governorship in 1982 with a campaign that apologized for the mistakes of his first term. Dick Morris, the ambidextrous pollster who was his strategist then, has become his strategist again, urging the President to join the Republicans when he can't beat them -- so he can beat them when he couldn't join them without alienating Democrats. Even Republicans acknowledge the strategy has borne fruit.
Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster, said Mr. Morris is trying "to take the underpinnings away from the issues that hold together a Republican majority coalition. He's trying to say, 'Don't fight them on the balanced budget idea; get into the mechanics, get into the sausage, agree with the goal and pick them to death on how.' "
"I think they have pursued a relatively coherent policy in terms of political positioning, in a relatively stable fashion for a year in a row," he said. "That is something Mr. Clinton was not able to do in the first two years in office, and as a result his political standing is better. The trouble is, it is very difficult to maintain that balancing act."
Michael Beschloss, a historian, sums up Mr. Clinton's year a bit differently.
 
Going for the Center
 "What he's done on the one hand is to dive for the center, and at the same time, in order not to give the impression of being a capitulator, he has picked his battles and used language and little moments like the veto speech to give the impression that this is someone who is standing up," Mr. Beschloss said. "I think it's a roll of the dice, a gamble that people's attention spans are short enough that they will remember those bold moments, and not the other moments."
The other moments have included a confessional to the conservative columnist Ben Wattenberg, in which Mr. Clinton denounced his own welfare reform plan as too weak and said he had behaved like a prime minister, shepherding legislation, and not enough like a President, leading public opinion.
Having pledged in the 1992 campaign to "end welfare as we know it," Mr. Clinton helped unleash public demand for overhaul that this year produced Republican bills far more extreme than he would have wished. The President was so eager to be seen as supporting change that he backed a Senate bill that his own aides warned would put more than a million children into poverty. But because House negotiators are insisting on even harsher terms, Mr. Clinton may end up vetoing whatever welfare measure ultimately emerges.
 
An Eye on History
 Doris Kearns Goodwin, author of biographies of Franklin D. Roosevelt and President Johnson, noted that politicians who are accommodationists by instinct, training and necessity often come to relish the benefits of having a clearly defined opposition, as Roosevelt did in the fight over the New Deal and Johnson did in the battle over civil rights.
For his first two years, Mr. Clinton fought with, or bowed to, the Democratic barons of Capitol Hill as much as he did with Republicans. Once the shell shock of last fall's Republican sweep wore off, a White House that thrives on campaigning was liberated. Mr. Clinton's aides now talk self-consciously of playing for the history books in the budget battle, and they say that Mr. Clinton knows the outcome could end up defining not only his Presidency but the future of the Democratic party and the programs it helped create.
"It may well be that the combination of the budget fight and the Bosnia decision coming together, both of which challenge him to take a risky stance, has inspired him," Ms. Goodwin said. "I think he's got to feel more freedom now. If you stand firm, and it pays off, there are more muscles for the next time. He just seems to be enjoying himself more in a positive way, in terms of exercising his leadership, and knowing that capacity is there."
 
Dancing in the Dark
 Still, the outcome is uncertain. Even if Mr. Clinton wins on the terms he has defined -- smaller cuts in Medicare, smaller tax cuts, protection for programs he likes -- there are inherent risks.
"This is much more of a gamble than the White House tacticians may think," Mr. Beschloss said. "If a President seems to be something during the first two years of his term, and something else the last two, what that suggests is that virtually nothing he has said is a reliable indicator of what we might expect during a second term, when he has no constraints of re-election. It is a very important weapon of leadership to have at least enough consistency that people know what they're voting for."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Japan, Blacks as Outsiders

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

 BODY:
FOR many black Americans, Japan is less the great economic power or serene synthesizer of the arts and more a country of offensive remarks about blacks and other minorities by prominent government officials, including former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.
When a black film maker, Reggie Life, headed to Japan on a National Endowment for the Arts fellowship three years ago, friends warned him that racism was rampant in Japan. On the eve of his trip a Japanese Government official publicly compared prostitutes in Tokyo's notorious red-light district to blacks who move into white neighborhoods and "ruin the atmosphere." 
 "I thought maybe my friends' concerns about racism in Japan had some validity," recalled Mr. Life, who lives in East Chatham, N.Y., near Albany.
But the insensitivity, prejudice and snubs that many foreigners -- black, white or other -- experience in Japan has less to do with race and everything to do with being "gaijin." A foreigner. The other. The outsider. Japan prides itself on homogeneity, on a group consciousness that subsumes that of ethnic minorities like the Koreans and Chinese. There is a large gap to bridge as an outsider, one far more complicated than the black-white dynamic at the core of America's racial ferment.
Some Japanese are likely to get out of a communal bath when a non-Japanese enters it. They may move away on the subway when foreigners sit down. Or, more characteristically, they may not answer, indeed, ignore the presence of a questioner, when approached and asked a question in English.
The experience leaves many Americans, blacks in particular, assuming that they have been slighted or insulted racially.
The recent arrest of three American servicemen, all black, accused of the kidnapping and rape of a 12-year-old Japanese girl in Okinawa, prompted charges of racial discrimination by their families in the United States. The Japanese, however, saw the suspects as American servicemen, not black servicemen.
 
Not Black but Gaijin
 "Some blacks come here prepared to face, and repel, racism," said Karen Hill Anton, a black American and columnist for The Japan Times. "But if they can let down their armor, they will recognize that they are first and foremost part of that larger group called gaijin.
"Anyone who is not Japanese in this country is part of a minority -- and, of course, that means whites, too," said Mrs. Anton, a resident of Japan for more than 20 years.
Donald Richie, a white American writer and film scholar who speaks Japanese and has lived in Japan for more than 40 years, said that outside his neighborhood and circle of friends, he is still considered an outsider. "Giggly school girls on the subway will sit and talk about me, thinking I don't speak Japanese, about how pink I am, how hairy," he said.
Even though Mr. Richie recently received the Japan Foundation award, one of the highest awards given by the Japanese Government, he said "I'm still gaijin." He captures the feeling in his 1971 classic about Japan called "The Inland Sea" (Kodansha). "I live in this country as the water insect lives in the pond," he writes, "skating across the surface, not so much mindful as incapable of seeing the depths."
The Japanese, however, do have stereotypical images of black Americans, gleaned from American television and press accounts. Some of them assume that blacks are either entertainers or sports figures or slow, lazy, strong and destructive. Americans, overall, are seen as violent. Yet the manifestations of Japanese racial superiority are not comparable to those expressed by some American racists.
"The Japanese may be phobic and insular, but they're not going to bother you," said Mr. Life, who has done two films on Japan, one on black Americans living there, the other on Japanese children of mixed race. "There's no physical threat there. As a black male in America, you always have to consider, if I go here, how will I be received. Is it safe?"
