HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Accord On Budget Won't End The Debate

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE is a deep and impatient hunger among much of the Washington establishment for a budget deal. Why, they ask, can't the sensible centrists in each party hunker down in some back room of the Capitol, split the difference on Medicaid, Medicare and the size of the tax cut, find a suitable fudge on the differing economic assumptions and let the Government get back to business?
It is, after all, the way things are usually done, and it is still considered a reasonably likely outcome of the budget war of 1995. But there is another school of thought: that at least some of the differences between the two parties are too profound for the closed-door politesse of budget summitry; that these differences ought to be taken to the voters in 1996, and that the unresolved philosophical debate of the 1980's, which was always finessed, ought to be rejoined.
 
Resolve (Gulp) These Issues?
 What, exactly, does it mean to get the Federal Government off the backs of the people? Does it mean rolling back environmental regulations? What programs are voters willing to trim to balance the budget and create billions in new tax cuts? How much do they realize, as the current class of Republicans candidly acknowledges, that it cannot be done by simply eliminating waste, fraud and abuse? 
 Should the Federal Government leave poverty programs to the states, or should there be a Federal guarantee of health coverage and cash assistance to poor women and children? Is the 30-year record of welfare policy so poisonous that, in fact, anything would be better?
Even if some kind of budget deal is reached, and there were a few tentative signs of progress last week, many believe it will only paper over some of these ideological divisions. It is hard to split the difference on questions like these.
Republicans argue that the voters already gave their answers when they ousted, with surgical precision, the Democratic majority in 1994 and replaced it with an ideologically charged Republican class brandishing a detailed Contract With America. If ever there was a mandate, the Republicans say, it came in 1994. But Democrats considered 1992 to be a mandate to embark on a sweeping expansion of benefits for "the forgotten middle class" -- remember the Health Security Act of 1994? -- and found, to their horror, that the voters had something else in mind.
The meaning of these last two elections is a subject of great debate among political scientists and pollsters. Some do see 1994 as a classic realignment toward the Republican Party, an analysis that prompted a wave of obituaries for the Democrats last summer. But others assert that each party has dramatically over-interpreted its mandate in the last four years, and that it is once again time for the voters to sort things out.
Few would dispute the notion that voters sent an anti-Democratic, anti-Clinton message in 1994. But post-election polls showed most Americans were unfamiliar with the Republicans' Contract, which has shaped the Republicans' budget and assumed the status of holy writ in the House.
Moreover, those who turned out in 1994 were disproportionately Republican and conservative; dispirited Democrats tended to stay home. If history is any guide, the turnout in 1996 will be substantially larger.
"There's much to be said for thrashing it out in another election," said Walter Dean Burnham, a political scientist at the University of Texas, and an expert on realignment.
Two things could happen in 1996, he said: The Republican revolution could be reaffirmed, giving the Republicans a clear field for governing. Or it could be derailed, with a Clinton victory and Democratic gains in the House, in which case the 1990's will look less like the decade of realignment than the decade of repudiation, a series of slaps to whichever party is in power at the time. (Of course, the voters could also produce a mixed result with a Clinton re-election and a strengthened Republican Congress.)
A less scholarly and more partisan conclusion comes from James Carville, the Clinton campaign adviser.
"The best thing would be to have a budget deal that protects the things President Clinton cares about," Mr. Carville said. "But if these issues are too big to be resolved, the people are going to have to resolve them. Why is that necessarily a bad thing?
"The real friction is with the elite, anti-small-d-democrats, who basically say, 'Let's act like adults, get behind closed doors, hammer something out, cut a deal and go forward; that these are unseemly questions that the voters ought not to be bothered about.' It's only about their education, their health care, their environment."
But can the politics of the 1990's produce a big, issue-oriented election that says more than "throw the bums out?"
Once upon a time there were such elections: Martin P. Wattenberg, a political scientist at the University of California at Irvine, notes that 80 percent of the voters in 1964 were familiar with the Civil Rights Act, and knew which candidate was for it and which was against it. President Lyndon Johnson's victory that year was a mandate on civil rights and other major issues, like the creation of Medicare.
There are many, however, who doubt that a big, budget-driven election would be an uplifting exercise in democracy. And there are many here in Washington who defend the notion of "split the difference" policy-making. According to that thinking, when the voters produce a mixed result -- a conservative Republican Congress and a Democratic White House -- closed-door compromising between the two can produce something approximating what the people really want.
 
The Ultimate Fear: a Third Party
 Moreover, both the Republican leadership and the Administration may ultimately feel it's in their best interest to reach a deal and mute their differences. Otherwise, the conventional wisdom holds, a grumpy electorate might grow even more disgusted with Washington gridlock and even more open to an independent candidate, an abiding fear in both parties.
By that scenario, the voters would be spared, once again, the messy chore of sorting out their own priorities. They would not have to choose between their competing needs and wants: a balanced budget, a big tax cut, a Medicare program that hums along largely unchanged, a Medicaid program that will cover their parents' nursing home costs, a Federal Government that is dramatically pared back, yet still cleans up toxic waste dumps and monitors water. Their politicians will finesse those differences for them.
Maybe an independent candidate will come along who will try to force a debate. Perhaps just as likely, maybe one will emerge who tells Americans they can have it all.
Summitry, in other words, is unlikely to bring a lasting peace in the budget wars until the voters are brought into the room.

HEADLINE: China to Start Trial of Top Dissident This Week

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 9

 BODY:
China's Communist Party leadership has notified the family of the country's most prominent dissident, Wei Jingsheng, that his trial on charges of attempting to overthrow the Government will begin on Wednesday.
International human rights groups called on President Clinton today to condemn the criminal proceedings against the outspoken democracy campaigner, who has already spent 16 years in prison or detention for his essays and public statements. 
 Two former United States Attorneys General, Richard Thornburgh and Nicholas Katzenbach, publicly offered to assist Mr. Wei's family in preparing his defense, although the gesture is sure to be rejected by the Chinese authorities.
The outcry over Mr. Wei's case in part reflects the frustration among his supporters that the Clinton Administration, which at one time strongly identified itself with Mr. Wei's appeal for democracy, has gradually put distance between itself and China's pro-democracy dissidents. Mr. Clinton has instead pursued a course of dialogue and "engagement" with China, in hopes that stable relations and continuing economic reform here will eventually lead to an end to political repression.
What is also clear, Chinese and American officials say, is that Mr. Wei's fate is being decided as Beijing and Washington are engaged in secret negotiations over the annual effort by the United States and European and other countries to condemn China's human rights record at the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva.
The question that will only be answered by Mr. Wei's trial and sentencing is whether the Chinese authorities are seeking to exert pressure on Washington to drop the condemnatory initiative in Geneva. But it could also be that they simply want to dispose of Mr. Wei's case well in advance of the Geneva proceedings in March to signal that they are not willing to grant Mr. Wei his freedom at any price.
Tonight, Mr. Wei's younger brother, Wei Xiaotao, said the family had retained a prominent Chinese lawyer, Zhang Sizhi, who in the past has defended prominent dissidents like Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming.
The charge carries a minimum penalty of 10 years in prison and a maximum penalty of death, although the death penalty is almost never invoked against prominent political dissidents.

HEADLINE: Giuliani and Bratton See Racism in Harlem Fire

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday that the black gunman-arsonist who killed seven people and himself in a fiery attack on a Jewish-owned clothing store in Harlem on Friday had apparently been motivated by racism.
At a joint news conference at One Police Plaza a day after Freddy's clothing store on 125th Street was turned into a blazing death trap by a man with a revolver and a container of flammable liquid, the police said they still knew little about the gunman and the Mayor urged caution about the interpretation of an incident with potentially explosive racial overtones. 
 But he said the attack was apparently related to weeks of emotional demonstrations and a boycott called to protest expansion plans by the store involving the eviction of a neighboring black-owned record shop that has been a Harlem fixture for decades.
At a news conference in Harlem yesterday, a sharply different view was expressed by the Rev. Al Sharpton, by Morris Powell, the leader of the 125th Street Vendors Association who helped organize the demonstrations, and by Sikhulu Shange, the owner of the record shop. They insisted that there were no racial overtones to the protests.
"We didn't want to see a man put out on the sidewalk who had paid his rent for 20 years," Mr. Powell said. "Whatever race was doing something like that would have us step to it." And, referring to the attack, Mr. Shange said: "We never knew something like this would ever come from this matter. We are not hatemongers."
The conclusion that the gunman was motivated by racism, Commissioner Bratton said, was based on "comments he made during the course of the incident." The officials did not disclose the assailant's remarks that had persuaded them that the case was a bias crime. But one investigator said that the gunman, after running into the store, had shouted: "It's on now! All blacks out!"
Some black people did escape unharmed, but four people in the store -- the white Jewish manager, a Guyanese employee and two white construction workers -- were shot by the assailant. The conditions of three of them, initially listed as critical, were upgraded to serious but stable after each underwent surgery at St. Luke's Hospital.
The Mayor and the Commissioner sounded notes of caution yesterday that reflected the many questions still swirling unanswered about the deadly blaze. While the authorities had concluded that it was an apparent bias case, they still could not say whether the attacker acted alone, had close ties to the protesters or what his precise motive might have been.
Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Bratton said the assailant, who carried an apparently phony photo identification card bearing the name Abubunde Mulocko, still had not been identified. They suggested he was not well known in Harlem, but had been seen -- and videotaped -- at several demonstrations outside Freddy's in recent weeks. Efforts to trace his identity through computer records of fingerprints turned up nothing, one police investigator said.
Mr. Giuliani said it was not yet clear whether the attacker had acted alone or had been part of a conspiracy involving others.
"This is an incident that will change several times in terms of the gathering of the facts," the Mayor said. "It will take a while to determine precisely what the motive is. And it is going to take a while to determine whether or not the perpetrator acted alone, whether there was some complicity by others."
But whether the gunman acted alone or with the help of others, the Mayor indicated that what had begun as a real estate dispute -- between the building owner, a predominantly black Pentecostal congregation called the United House of Prayer for All People, the white owner of the clothing store, Fred Harari, and Mr. Shange, the owner of the Record Shack next door -- was apparently subverted by people with a racial agenda.
"We do know this was an economic dispute between a landlord, a tenant and a subtenant that somehow turned into something far worse than that," the Mayor declared. "That shouldn't have happened. And we should not allow others to push that agenda any further. It's a shame that some degree of racial arson was inserted into this."
Commissioner Bratton said that investigators had determined that the flammable liquid the gunman splashed over piles of clothing around the store to start the fire was paint thinner. They said they also found a fuse for an M-80 firecracker, suggesting that he may have intended to escape after setting the place ablaze.
The Mayor and Commissioner Bratton said the protests outside the store in recent weeks, and efforts to mediate the complex dispute, had been handled by the Police Department. "It was dealt with as a police matter," Mr. Giuliani said when asked if City Hall had known about the protests and the dispute. He later acknowledged: "We had not been informed of it."
Mr. Giuliani bristled when asked about comments earlier yesterday by Mr. Sharpton at his news conference at a Harlem elementary school, where he and others disavowed any racial bias in the demonstrations.
"I think the least said about what he said the better for the safety of the city and the decency of the city," Mr. Giuliani said of Mr. Sharpton.
In painting the protests as an economic boycott of Freddy's, Mr. Sharpton had earlier said: "I want to stress that I saw no anti-Semitic, anti-white or any other expressions of racism. The fact of the matter is that the pickets was just as adamantly opposed to the action of the black church that was the landlord as they were the actions of Freddy's."
Mr. Shange, looking weary, said he was shaken by Friday's events. He said he had contacted Harlem's Representative Charles B. Rangel, as well as Assemblyman Keith L. Wright and and City Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, seeking help in his real estate dispute with the owner of the clothing store.
Negotiations had appeared to resolve the dispute several weeks ago. Mr. Shange was to acquire another site a few doors away at a corner of 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, though the rent would be nearly double his present $2,500-a-month payments. But the deal fell through, apparently when Mr. Shange objected to other lease terms that would have weakened his position.
Mr. Rangel and other Harlem political and civic leaders met at the 28th Precinct yesterday in a mood of deepening concern. They called for calm and expressed hope that the violence would not harm the economic rebirth of 125th Street.
They also heard the Precinct commander, Deputy Inspector Joyce Stephen, detail a police bias investigation that began Nov. 29 after a demonstrator -- who was not the gunman -- threatened to "burn and loot the Jews." Extra patrols had been assigned to the block and demonstrations were videotaped, she said. Community affairs officers also were assigned to help ease tensions
As confusion over the case continued, grieving families mourned the victims of the attack and Harlem leaders and residents called for calm. On 125th Street, residents laid bouquets for the dead on a rainwashed sidewalk and peered into the burned-out wreckage of Freddy's.
It was a gray and gloomy day, fit for mourning, but the streets of Harlem were crowded with Saturday shoppers, and a scalloped sea of umbrellas moved like tides on the busy boulevards.
The clothing store at 272 West 125th Street was a charred gruesome reminder of the tragedy that had unfolded there. As a cold drizzle fell, a steady stream of people stopped to peer into the hellish interior: a darkened eerie stage of dangling cables and light fixtures, fallen beams, piles of ashes and the half-burned remnants of shirts, jeans and jackets.
On the sidewalk in front, behind blue police barricades, lay a jumble of rubble piled like an impression by Miro: a ladder, a broken chair, a shattered cabinet, coated with snow and ash and tatters of charred clothing. Nearby, someone had left a bittersweet bouquet of pink carnations, freesias, daisies and lilies. It, too, was surrounded by slush from the day's snow and sleet.
There were no remnants of the name of Freddy's. The cream stucco facade over the storefront was still black from flames that had licked up and out; the second-floor windows were all shattered. A boutique to one side was boarded up, and a banner tacked to the plywood advertised videos of the Million Man March.
On the other side, steel gates were down over the Record Shack. They had been painted with a city skyline, a gold record disk and musical notes floating in the air. There was no name on the shop.
Bundled against the cold, Tamara Martin, 22, a Harlem resident, stopped and said she wished she could have brought flowers or candles. She said she had read of the tragedy and recognized the picture of one of the dead women -- it was someone she remembered fondly, though she did not know her well.
"She was so nice," Ms. Martin said. "You knew who she was just by her smile." Looking into the dark recess of Freddy's, at the place where the people had been killed, she shook her head sadly and said: "It's sick. They had their whole lives ahead of them, and suddenly it's all up in flames in a death trap."
One of the wounded, Alan Grossberg, the store's manager, told his family that he had escaped from the burning building by crawling through a hole in a basement wall.
Mr. Grossberg's nephew, Matthew Tallis, 21, said at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday that his uncle told him that he had pulled the store's bookkeeper, Jack Douek, through the hole after him.
"He knew there was a hole where the store was burglarized last month," Mr. Tallis said.
Mr. Tallis said that his uncle, who is known as Tennessee because he was reared in Memphis, had not yet been told how many people perished. "He knows people died, but he didn't know they were employees," Mr. Tallis said. "He treated them like they were his family."
The attacker was found, with three female victims, lying at the back of the store's main floor. He apparently shot himself once in the chest, the police said. Four other victims -- two men and two women -- were found in the store's basement.
An autopsy by the Medical Examiner's office yesterday concluded that the gunman had died of the gunshot wound and of carbon monoxide poisoning, the result of inhaling smoke in the fire. The other seven victims, all employees of the store, were found to have died of smoke inhalation. They had not been shot.
Stymied in their immediate efforts to identify the assailant, the police asked for the public's help yesterday. They released a picture of him and asked anyone with information about him to call (800) 577-TIPS, or the 28th Precinct at (212) 678-1608.

HEADLINE: DEATH ON 125th STREET: The Dispute;
From a Quiet Beginning, a Volatile Brew Explodes in Harlem

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
It was three years ago that Freddy's clothing store settled into a former meat market on 125th Street in Harlem, and began selling discounted men's and boys' wear. Its immediate neighbor was the Record Shack, which had been in place for 17 years offering used 45's and old gospel albums, and whose lease was encased within Freddy's lease.
Almost the very first conversation between Fred Harari, the clothing store owner, and Sikhulu Shange, the proprietor of the record shop, placed the men in opposing camps. According to Mr. Shange, Mr. Harari told him that he would have to leave when his lease expired at the end of 1995, unless he paid more rent. 
 From that tame and unremarkable beginning, months of tangled events would culminate in gruesome drama Friday morning. A tall black man who the authorities believe was somehow caught up in an escalating dispute burst into Freddy's with a gun and a container of flammable liquid. By the time he was done, he and seven victims lay dead in the incinerated remains of the clothing store. Four others had been wounded.
Given that Mr. Harari is white and Jewish and Mr. Shange and the attacker are black, it would be easy to reduce these events to a simple morality tale reeking of one of the uglier and most enduring stereotypes of prejudice.
But the volatile ingredients that flowed together inside Freddy's appear to be nowhere that straightforward. Another party central to the dispute was a predominantly black Pentecostal church that owned the building and had been aggressively striving to maximize the return on its land holdings. And there were protesters who undoubtedly held mixed goals.
Yesterday, the police said the attacker carried an apparently phony identification bearing the name Abubunde Mulocko. But everything else about him -- his real name, his motivation, whether he acted alone -- remained a mystery. For his part, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani characterized the dispute as an economic disagreement that was subverted by people with a racial agenda.
No one knows now if race was ever at the root of this long-running dispute or if it was the allure of money or even just two people who didn't much like each other. But as is often the case in issues of life and death in New York, a mix of factors may have transformed it into something other than it was. Before it was over, the predicament of one record shop had come to represent for some people the entire anguished history and enduring scars of the street that has been Harlem's soul.
The "25," as it is known in the community, has always been a street of expectations and disillusionment, a street where capitalism has dangled its sweet and elusive promise.
When blacks first moved to Harlem at the end of the 19th century, they were forced to use fair-skinned members of their race as fronts to acquire houses and apartments. Even during the Harlem Renaissance, the days of the 1920's when Harlem was alive with jazz and basement clubs, blacks could not go to many of the clubs and they could not eat in the luncheonettes and restaurants.
At Howard's Hat shop, blacks could buy hats, but they could not try them on without first covering their head with a shower cap. They could buy shoes, but only after they slipped on another store-supplied sock. At Frank's Restaurant, blacks could go to the bar but not into the restaurant proper.
The merchants craved blacks' business but not their services. The only blacks who could get jobs in the stores were those who took menial positions.
The biggest store on the block was Blumstein's department store, and it became an early target of black protest. Only in 1929 did it hire its first blacks -- as elevator operators and porters. In 1934, blacks started a "Buy-Where-You-Can-Work" campaign, picketing Blumstein's until it agreed to hire 35 blacks for clerical and sales positions. Other stores capitulated, and a turning point was reached in Harlem history.
Along 125th Street today, an economic rejuvenation in Harlem has sparked greater diversification in the ownership of businesses on 125th Street. Stores are owned not only by whites, but by blacks, Koreans and Hispanic people. Although some community leaders complain that blacks still own few businesses there, the 125th Street Business Improvement District says that of 322 businesses on West 125th Street, 158 are black-owned.
When Harlem was included last year as part of a new Federal Empowerment Zone that meant more than $300 million in Federal, state and city funds would be applied to the community, Harlem business owners began preparing for growth and expansion.
But the revival of the street has also brought fresh friction. Last year, the city moved scores of illegal street vendors off to a separate market, saying they clogged the sidewalks. Rents have soared, and some of the small businesses that struggled through the lean years have been squeezed out. Others are unsure if the influx of money will benefit or harm them. This new tension "is more economic than racial," said Lloyd Williams, president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, "but it is very difficult in a community like Harlem to separate one from the other."
 
The Beginning 3 Sets of Players, Different Views
Originally, there were three primary players in the story of 272 W. 125th Street, and their geographic proximity to one another formed a triangle.
Fred Harari, the 31-year-old owner of Freddy's, belonged to a tightly knit Orthodox Jewish community in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. He grew up in Brooklyn's Ocean Park area and followed a family tradition into the clothing business. At first, he worked as a shipping supervisor for Conway Stores, a large chain of discount stores co-founded 60 years ago by his grandfather, Abe Cohen.
Mr. Harari opened his own store on Third Avenue in the Bronx seven years ago, adding the one on 125th Street in 1992. A third store is on Fordham Road in the Bronx. All three specialize in low-priced closeout clothing. Business was good enough that he was pursuing more space. At his Third Avenue site, he recently bought the building that housed the store and was displacing a coffee shop.
He is married with two children. Yesterday, a statement that came through his attorney said that he was in seclusion, mourning for the victims and their families.
Sikhulu Shange was born in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, 54 years ago, and came to this country in 1964 with a Zulu dance troupe. He set up his record store in 1975, and in time it became one of the best-known black-owned businesses on 125th Street. Across from the famed Apollo Theater, it specializes in blues, Motown, African and Caribbean music.
Though those who knew him said he was not a politically active presence, he was impassioned in condemning apartheid. Four years ago, he helped found the South African-American Organization, a nonprofit group dedicated to raising awareness about South Africa. His pet project was rebuilding a primary school, the Lungelani School in his hometown, which was finished last year.
He has also explored the possibility of opening a music outlet in South Africa while using his Harlem store to school Americans and Africans in retailing.
A tall man with a deep voice and a strong accent, Mr. Shange typically dressed in African attire, including his signature brimless hats. He lives in the Bronx and has three grown daughters.
Above the two merchants, both physically and in terms of power, was the owner of the building, the United House of Prayer for All People, a predominantly black Pentecostal church based in Washington, which conducted its services on the second floor.
The church was founded in 1926 in Charlotte, N.C., by Bishop C.M. (Daddy) Grace. During the 1920's and 1930's, he was a man accorded mythical stature in Harlem, where he was known as Sweet Daddy. Besides healing people, he sold them a line of products including eggs, coffee, toothpaste and cold cream. All this enabled him to live more than comfortably in a 20-room mansion in Montclair, N.J., and an 85-room estate in Los Angeles.
The church says it has members in 132 cities in 23 states, in numbers variously estimated on a range from 27,000 to three million. Its real-estate holdings include churches, low-rent apartment buildings, day-care centers, cafeterias and senior-citizen homes. The national leader is Bishop Samuel C. Madison.
The church settled on 125th Street in 1936, and today is one of the biggest landlords on the street. Besides the building at 272 West 125th Street that housed Freddy's and the Record Shack, it owns the building directly across the street. One of the tenants is the 125th Street Business Improvement District. The church has plans to develop almost three blocks of housing between Frederick Douglass Avenue and Manhattan Avenue, from 118th to 121st Street
The church recently embarked on a $4.5 million renovation of the building that was to be ravaged by the fire. Because of the work, the local congregation of 300 people is temporarily worshipping on 116th Street. Every August, the church conducts street baptisms on 111th Street using hoses.
"The church had been aggressively trying to do something over there," said Frank Hernandez, a real estate broker in the neighborhood. "If certain things don't fit into a landlord's plans, then they try to make a change."
Its actions suggested that it wished to extract the most out of its land holdings. The Dilrich meat market that had occupied the space taken by Freddy's was told in late 1992 that its lease would not be renewed and it left. Windsor Drugs had a 10-year lease with the church in a space near the meat market. Irving Katz, the owner of the drugstore, said that in July 1993, Malcolm Barksdale, a real estate broker who represented the church, came in and told him that his lease would not be renewed and he had to leave in 60 days. "He said to me, 'You're out,"' Mr. Katz said yesterday. "We're beautifying the church, we need the space, you're out."
At first, Mr. Katz thought the decision was racially motivated, since he was white. But he said the church refused to renew leases for a black-owned shoe-repair shop and an instructional tennis program. "He was the same to blacks as well as to whites," Mr. Katz said. "It was just a question of money."
 
Differing Views A Notice Of No Renewal
From the start, Mr. Harari, Mr. Shange and officials of the church did not see things the same way. Soon after Mr. Harari secured the lease on the space, including the sublease on the Record Shack, he let Mr. Shange know that he would not renew his lease when it expired on Dec. 31, 1995.
Mr. Shange told him he could not leave: "This was my livelihood."
He said he wanted to renew, and he said Mr. Harari told him that to stay he would have to pay more money. A business associate of Mr. Harari said Mr. Shange was paying about $2,500 a month, well below the market rate on a street where rents had been climbing rapidly.
The merchants returned their attentions to their businesses and the months and years passed. Last spring, with the expiration of his lease more clearly in sight, Mr. Shange got edgy. He tried to feel Mr. Harari out about renewing and said he could get no answer. He tried to contact Jeff Sutton, Mr. Harari's real estate partner, but said he did not return his calls. "He started ducking me about discussing the lease," Mr. Shange said.
Finally, the two connected, and Mr. Sutton asked Mr. Shange to make an offer. He came up with a proposal, which he would not divulge, and had a friend present it to Mr. Sutton. "He never responded to us," Mr. Shange said.
Things began to follow the familiar pattern of landlord-tenant confrontations. Mr. Shange turned to the weapon of money. He refused to give the rent check to the man Mr. Harari regularly sent to collect it. "I told him, I want your boss to come pick up the check," Mr. Shange said. "I want your boss to come see me."
Shortly afterward, Mr. Sutton did come to see Mr. Shange. According to Mr. Shange, he told him, "I want to be candid with you. I want you to move out of here. My family is going to take this spot."
Mr. Shange replied, "Really? I'm not going to let you just push me out of here. I'm going to fight back."
The stage was now set for the fourth character to enter this still unremarkable drama, and this was a collective character that could be called the protesters. Its ultimate ambition may not necessarily have been entirely in line with that of its sponsor, Mr. Shange, but it was this character, coupled with actions by the other three, that pushed events toward a disastrous, and utterly unanticipated, denouement.
Feeling he had been drawn into a battle he could not win alone, Mr. Shange appealed to the Harlem community. He had begun laying the groundwork back in April, when he was on a show on a radio station during which he spoke of his problem. He wrote to Representative Charles P. Rangel, the longtime Democrat who represents Harlem, as well as Assemblyman Keith L. T. Wright. Increasingly he showed up at street rallies, where he told everyone that his business was in dire jeopardy.
In time, he enlisted the support of the Rev. Al Sharpton, who heads the National Action Network, and Morris Powell, the leader of the 125th Street Vendors Association, which came into being to fight city efforts to remove the illegal vendors from 125th Street.
In September, protesters commenced picketing Freddy's, beseeching shoppers to boycott the store unless it allowed the Record Shack to stay. A petition was circulated advocating that Mr. Shange's store be kept open on 125th Street.
Although Mr. Shange acknowledged in an interview that the church had "double-crossed" him, he apparently rarely made mention of the church in his efforts to muster support. The issue was portrayed more starkly in him-versus-me terms, the him being Fred Harari. Some of those who embraced the cause simplified it further -- a white Jew versus a black.
An article on the matter in The New York Amsterdam News asked, "Could this be the beginning of a systematic attempt to drive viable black-owned businesses out of Harlem? Prior to the 1950's, blacks could not shop on 125th Street, let alone run their own business operations in the area."
Some members of the black community quickly embraced this as a cause with more resonance than a record shop in jeopardy. To them, the black-white friction in Harlem through the decades was somehow embodied in the tapes and CD's that lined its shelves. "This man symbolized the plight of black people in Harlem and their inability to find safety nets and support," said Conrad Muhammad, who heads the Nation of Islam in New York and who supported the boycott. "And so he was a cause celebre."
The protesters themselves became a factor of some consequence. Many were street vendors, some of whom were said to be keen to renew attention to their own situation. Mr. Shange apparently had a mixed view of the vendors. "He hated the peddlers," said Mr. Katz. "They were ruining his business. He once went out there with a machete." Others, however, said Mr. Shange wanted the vendors who sold illegal tapes gone but felt comfortable with others.
To some extent, Mr. Harari, according to associates of his, felt he was caught in a larger game rightfully being played between the church and the Record Shack. One associate, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Harari needed more money from the Record Shack to meet his own rent to the church. He felt it was unfair that his store was being picketed.
Dismayed by what it saw on the street, the United House of Prayer made itself heard. It asked Mr. Shange to call off the pickets. It said it would offer him a new space on the corner of 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard.
Mr. Shange agreed. He told the pickets to put down their placards, that he was in negotiations for a new lease. Mr. Shange said his supporters were reluctant to disband until there was something more tangible, but he insisted.
In short order, Mr. Shange said he began discussions with Malcolm Barksdale, the broker representing the United House of Prayer. "He said within three to four days he would come to me with a drafted lease," Mr. Shange said. He thought the dispute had finally come to a satisfactory end.
 
Weeks Pass A Lease Offered And Rejected
Those weeks came and went. After eight weeks, Mr. Shange got suspicious. He appealed to The Amsterdam News to publish an article on his situation. He said that soon after a reporter from that paper called Mr. Barksdale for comment, a lease was delivered to his store.
When he studied its terms, he said, his mood turned bleak again. While he described the rent as "exorbitant," -- others said it was $5,000, double the present rent -- he said that money was not his principal objection. There were clauses and sub-clauses, he said, that compromised his position. He said one clause established a year-long probationary period during which the landlord reserved the right to cancel the lease "for any reason or no reason at all."
In his mind, he said, this was no lease. It was an eviction order.
Mr. Shange said he showed the lease to his lawyer, Douglas Haywood, who he said told him, "You don't have a lease if that clause is in there."
When Mr. Barksdale next came by the Record Shack, Mr. Shange hoped to discuss the lease. First, he said, he complained to Mr. Barksdale about scaffolding that had been erected outside his store without notification. "He walked out," Mr. Shange said. "And he never came back."
Thereupon Mr. Shange notified his supporters that he and his landlord had reached an impasse. The picket line took form again. Fliers were circulated imploring people not to buy from Freddy's. "Freddy didn't have any interest in me being part of anything," Mr. Shange said. "He just wanted me out of there."
Other leaflets also raised questions about the role of the House of Prayer in the dispute. Still others included anti-Semitic language. The police opened a racial bias investigation after they said a security guard told the police that a demonstrator on Nov. 29 said, "Twenty niggers are going to come back and burn and loot the Jews."
Last Saturday, Mr. Sharpton showed up at the picket line and yelled for the owner of Freddy's to come out; he also threatened to go in and sit on the counter. The store manager spoke to Mr. Sharpton, and he appeared to be appeased.
Mr. Shange, though, grew increasingly embittered at both Mr. Harari and the church. Though he said he did not view the dispute entirely in racial terms, he found it shaped by that backdrop. "I saw it this way," he said. "Somebody was being ruthless with me, regardless of his color or creed. Something could have been worked out. Yes, it is a serious problem. There are almost no black businesses in Harlem, and I'm one of the few. If I go out of business, it's going to be very difficult for me to come back."
Some of the people embroiled in the dispute thought Thursday was a pivotal day. On that day, Mr. Harari filed a civil suit in Supreme Court seeking to stop the pickets. The suit named Mr. Shange and the National Action Network. There was to have been a hearing tomorrow.
Mr. Harari's associates said the protest was crimping his business. He began considering closing the store, and though he readied a liquidation sale, associates said nothing was imminent. On Wednesday, Freddy's was shuttered to prepare for the sale. A sign pasted on the window read: "That's it. We've had it. Freddy's 125th Street location only, wall to wall liquidation."
The sale was advertised to start at 11 A.M. on Thursday. However, the doors opened at 9:30 in order to circumvent the picketing. When a dozen or so protesters turned up at 11, they were angered to see the store doing a lot of business.
Some of the protesters, according to an associate of Mr. Harari, chanted, "Bring a casket to work tomorrow."
The next day, the weather turned bitter cold. Collars were turned up against the clawing wind. A little after 10 in the morning, from out of the jostling masses on the sidewalk, the tall gunman appeared. Freddy's was open for business, and when the man went in, the police said, he yelled, "It's on now! All blacks out!"

This article is based on reporting by Lizette Alvarez, Dan Barry, Pam Belluck, Emily M. Bernstein, Michael Cooper, Douglas Frantz, Garry Pierre-Pierre, Jonathan P. Hicks, Lynette Holloway, John Kifner, David Kocieniewski, Clifford Krauss, Felicia R. HEADLINE: HEALTH LOBBYISTS WIN ADJUSTMENTS TO MEDICARE PLAN

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB 

 BODY:
Out of the spotlight of the Medicare debate, the nation's private health plans have obtained a series of technical changes in the overhaul approved by Congress that stand to reap them billions of dollars.
One adjustment would raise the rate by which Government reimbursements would increase next year by several percentage points more than would have been done in previous versions of the legislation, resulting in billions of dollars more for the health-care companies. 
 This was one of several dizzyingly technical changes -- built on what many would consider minutiae -- that the industry vigorously pushed for to improve its fortunes.
The health care industry says these changes would allow health maintenance organizations and other private plans to offer greater benefits and lure enrollees out of the conventional Medicare program, in which the Government pays providers for individual services.
Critics say the adjustments will lead to greater profits for the health care industry but a bleak financial outlook for Medicare, the Federal health care program for the elderly. They say the private plans will attract mostly healthier people, leaving the sickest people, and the greatest costs, to the traditional Medicare program.
Although President Clinton last week vetoed the budget bill containing the Medicare legislation, the adjustments stand a good chance of surfacing in a compromise plan. This is because the Administration proposal for Medicare calls for far more modest cutbacks in money for the plans.
The story of how the industry got largely what it wanted is one of a politically powerful lobby haggling over subtle, lucrative details that few outside Washington even realized existed.
Industry representatives defend the changes. "Congress understands very clearly that to attract people into H.M.O.'s and managed care there has to be sufficient reimbursement so that these managed care plans can continue to provide the kind of comprehensive benefits which attract managed care beneficiaries right now," said Donald B. White, a spokesman for the Group Health Association of America, which represents 1,000 managed care plans and spearheaded the lobbying campaign. "We're not aiming for windfall profits."
Republicans say the adjustments make economic and policy sense. Representative Bill Archer, a Republican from Texas who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said the bill "offers beneficiaries the opportunity to choose better coverage while helping stem the rapid growth in the cost of the program."
Clinton Administration officials are cynical about the changes.
Bruce Vladeck, who runs the Medicare and Medicaid programs for the Administration, said he saw the increases in Congress's bill as an effort to "buy off" segments of the health care industry.
"Our take is they're trying to keep the providers happy in the short term and turn on the screws in the long term," he said. "And, as Keynes said, in the long term, we're all dead."
Large profits for private industry, at least early on, are one possible result of the changes, some experts say. "That's why everyone's thinking of getting into this business," said Lynn Etheredge, who headed the health care unit of the Office of Management and Budget in the Carter and Reagan Administrations.
He added that the ability of plans to market themselves to healthy Medicare enrollees was the key to financial success. "I think it's going to be profitable in many areas," he said, "and Congress has set it up that way largely to get enrollment."
Under the current Medicare structure, the financing for healthy enrollees, who need relatively little care, in effect subsidizes services for people with serious ailments. If healthy people and ill people end up in separate plans, many fear that services for sicker recipients would suffer.
Among the health-care lobby's other victories in the conference committee that reconciled the House and Senate versions of the bill were these:
*The final bill allows private plans to receive Medicare money for medical education and care of the uninsured, even when they do not send members to teaching hospitals or to institutions that serve uninsured patients. The Senate version of the bill had eliminated these payments.
*The final bill lets stand more of the wide disparity between payments to plans in rural and high-cost urban areas than the Senate bill would have allowed. High fees in many urban areas have led to a profitable expansion of private Medicare plans. Meanwhile, in the final bill, Congress set a minimum payment for low-cost areas, which a Clinton Administration official says could lead to windfall profits.
*The final bill continues to use a basic financing formula for private plans as a jumping off point to compute future payments. This formula has long been criticized as overly generous and a cost to the Medicare program. Alternative formulas, although discussed, were never even seriously considered in Congress.
Even with the changes in Congress's bill, the legislation calls on private plans to absorb tens of billions in reductions in anticipated annual Government payments. The plan would cut $270 billion in projected growth in Medicare spending over seven years, largely by raising recipients' premiums, encouraging recipients to use less costly services provided by private plans, and cutting increases in payments to the plans that had been projected to be far higher.
Mr. Clinton's proposal would cut Medicare's expected growth by $124 billion over seven years. Although his plan would reach its goal through many of the same devices as Congress's bill, he has proposed that they be used far more moderately. In this way, it preserves more of the flavor of the current system for the 37 million older Americans on Medicare, and seeks less in savings from the private plans.
Private insurance companies, and, more recently, managed-care plans have been potent forces on the Washington scene, contributing more than $25 million over 10 years to the two political parties and to Congressional candidates, according to the public interest group Common Cause. Some played a major role in defeating Mr. Clinton's efforts to revamp health care last year.
Another advocacy group, Citizen Action, said that eight leading insurance companies had contributed roughly $375,000 to representatives and senators this year, with roughly 80 percent going to Republicans, including Speaker Newt Gingrich and several committee heads.
In pressing for increases in the money private plans could collect for treating Medicare patients, representatives of four trade organizations decided that the Group Health Association would take the lead, industry sources say.
Association officials, often with allies on hand, argued their case before Mr. Gingrich, who was said to have an unusual understanding of minute financing details, and House and Senate committee heads and staff.
The upshot was that under the final bill, the Government would pay private plans more than in the House and Senate versions. This meant that the savings to the Government would go down and would have to made up elsewhere.
Congressional Budget Office estimates starkly reveal the loss to the Government. Under the House plan, the savings were estimated at $33.6 billion over seven years; under the Senate version, they were estimated to be $10 billion greater.
But under the final legislation, the budget office estimated savings of only $26.9 billion. This was largely if not exclusively because of benefits won by private plans.
Nothing about these estimates is simple; under an alternate computation, the budget office estimated savings of $41 billion in the final bill. But these were still an equal amount below alternate estimates for the House and Senate legislation. Revised estimates are scheduled for release on Tuesday.
The most striking way in which private plans would get more money under the final bill was through the larger increase, of 8 percent, in next year's payments. The House version of the legislation called for an increase of 5.3 percent, and the Senate's, using a more complicated formula, would probably have been lower than that.
Diane Dennett, the health association's vice president in charge of governmental affairs, described the increase as "a very key issue." She said many plans had already begun marketing products based on a fee schedule approved in October by Medicare officials that called for a 10.1 percent increase, the rate the Administration still favors. Indeed, the association pressed for the full 10.1 percent.
Republican Congressional staff members defended the increase for the same reason. They and the association also said in interviews that under Federal regulations, excess payments that plans receive have to be returned to Medicare -- which never happens -- or passed to beneficiaries through benefits or lower premiums.
But skeptics say greater benefits will only draw more enrollees to the plans, which will increase profits, and that it is nearly impossible for Medicare officials to tell whether private plans are tucking excess payments in administrative costs or other areas that are hard to pin down.
The Republican plan also builds future payments on a base that many critics say favors private plans and would cost the Government money. Alternatives were never seriously considered.
Under the financing formula retained for next year in the final bill, the plans receive for each enrollee 95 percent of the average cost for a comparable beneficiary in the traditional Medicare program in the same county. The presumption is that plans save 5 percent because most practice managed care, which tends to hold down costs.
Yet a study two years ago by a private company, Mathematica Policy Research, found that private plans saved twice as much on each beneficiary. This, the report found, was because of economies in managed care and because plans enrolled healthier Medicare patients.
The managed care industry strongly disputes these findings, citing other studies that contend that their clients are similar to Medicare's. But the Mathematica report has been cited as recently as last month by agencies like the Congressional Budget Office, the General Accounting Office, and the Physicians Payment Review Commission, an advisory council to Congress. This year the commission recommended that in many cases, rates should be set by competitive bidding.
In a report last month, the accounting office said favorable rates had led to an explosion in the number of health maintenance organizations serving the Medicare population, to 164 from 109 in less than 18 months.
Still, Congress stuck with the 95 percent rate. One Congressional staff member said Republicans felt it was important to provide continuity and insure that plans had money for more benefits.
The staff member, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, also pointed out that although the 95 percent rate applies next year, future increases are based on other figures.
In its plan, the Administration also starts with the 95 percent figure, but provides more generous increases. Mr. Vladeck said his agency, the Health Care Financing Administration, would undertake competitive bidding projects next year.
In further complications, the haggling over the bill continued over how hospitals are paid for the care of the uninsured and how teaching hospitals are paid for education.
Both sums are now included in the average figure computed for the cost of a beneficiary's care in the standard Medicare program. Because of this, these fees are passed to private plans in the 95 percent rate.
But even though plans receive this money, they often do not send patients to hospitals caring for the uninsured or training doctors.
"It does not make much sense to include a payment that was originally intended to be a reimbursement to hospitals for particular costs if those costs are not going to be incurred by the managed care organizations," said John M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Department of Medicine at Georgetown University Medical Center.
Senate Republicans agreed and eliminated the payments in their legislation. But in the conference committee, the payments were restored. Ms. Dennett argued that increasingly, managed care plans were using teaching hospitals and hiring residents.
Representative Archer said that given the sharp reductions in rates to the plans over the years, "we felt that it was important not to further depress rates by taking out funding for teaching hospitals."
Mr. Vladeck said the Administration plan called for the payments to be phased out by 1998.
Members of Congress from low-cost medical areas were also concerned about using costs of care in individual counties as the basis of payments to private plans. Countywide averages vary from less than $200 a month in Fall River County, S.D., to more than $600 in the Bronx.
As a result, private plans compete vigorously for enrollees in high-cost areas like Dade County, Fla. With so much money at their disposal, some plans there have eliminated premiums and offered extra services like free eyeglasses and drugs.
Virtually no private plans are active in 32 lower cost states.
The Senate legislation addressed the disparity by basing payments on a figure made up of a 50-50 mix of countywide costs and national costs, a solution opposed by the industry. The effect would have been to sharply decrease payments in urban areas and upgrade them in rural ones.
The House and the Administration proposed far more moderate approaches to reduce the disparity, each arguing that anything more extreme would cripple plans in high-cost areas.
In the conference committee, the Senate approach was trimmed back. But to address the concerns of rural counties, the final bill includes a floor of $300, which will eventually rise to $350, on monthly payments, regardless of local costs.
The Administration opposes this approach. Mr. Vladeck said, "In a number of those counties anybody who can get an Medicare contract has a good chance at a very significant windfall."
In another potential boon to private plans, the final bill includes a provision not in the House version that would allow plans to increase premiums to a limited degree in certain situations when it appeared Medicare payments would not cover their costs.

HEADLINE: For Yet Another City, U.S. Budget Cuts to the Quick

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MODESTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Two or three times a day, Union Pacific freight trains, some a mile long, snake through the center of this table-flat city in the Central Valley. Rolling along at barely 10 miles an hour, the trains regularly tie up traffic across a 15-block stretch of downtown.
"The joke around here is, 'I was late to a meeting because I was stopped by the Ninth Street train,' " said the city manager, J. Edward Tewes. 
 It's a stale joke, and getting staler. A $24 million, eight-year-old project that counted on a large contribution of Federal money to pay to move the railroad tracks has been trapped in the cross hairs of Washington's battle of the budget. "Without Federal funds," Mr. Tewes said, "that project will not be built in our lifetime."
Similar doubts hang over numerous Federally financed projects and programs in Modesto and Stanislaus County, of which Modesto is the hub. In these as in all American communities, the budget debate's jargon and unfathomable billions are being distilled to something with real meaning for peoples' lives and pocketbooks.
With President Clinton fighting some of the sharpest of the Republican Congress's cuts, details of the budget remain unsettled. But both sides have submitted plans to balance the budget in seven years, which requires massive reductions in spending, and the probable effects are becoming clear. The cuts will hit hardest those who depend most on Federal largesse -- poor people and poor communities.
Some communities sink and swim with the money that supports a military base, for example, or pays for highways and job training in downtrodden pockets of Appalachia. Rich cities like Santa Barbara, Calif., or Aspen, Colo., get relatively little aid and are less constrained in finding ways to pay for services they want to keep.
Modesto, population 179,000, is fairly average. Federal spending helps the poor get housing, the young get jobs, the homebound elderly get meals, addicts get treatment, the city get police and the roads get repaired -- all the little things that help make Modesto a nicer place to live. And that money is shrinking or disappearing.
Overall, cities face some pain and tough political choices in being weaned from the Federal dole. In a survey by the United States Conference of Mayors, 85 percent of 145 mayors said that the cuts would force them to shrink city services.
Sixty-one percent said they would have to lay off Government workers, and 41 percent said they would have to raise taxes. More than 80 percent said the cuts would impede their ability to reduce crime and homelessness, create jobs and meet basic transportation needs.
 
Cuts Will Be Felt Across the Board
 Here, Federal money helped pay for the county's bold, glass-and-concrete administrative headquarters, the public library, the two-year-old salmon-colored bus depot and a cavernous new welfare services building that on Fridays is quiet as a tomb because the state, fighting its own budget crisis, has shrunk the staff.
But visions of big, new, largely Government-paid projects are fast evaporating. As for the Ninth Street train, officials are betting that Congress will go along with moving the tracks but will deny or postpone money for an overpass they say is essential.
All told, said Reagan M. Wilson, chief executive of Stanislaus County, population 423,000, "I think there will be a fairly significant change."
"Some programs will be cut or eliminated," he said. "The safety net will in the short term get stretched. There may even be some tears in it." He said his work force would shrink, either by attrition or layoffs.
Still, Mr. Wilson sees a silver lining in Washington's retreat. With the spending cuts, Congress is also cutting many of the strings of Federal control and turning more program authority over to state and local governments. And even with less aid, Mr. Wilson said the county would devise better programs.
"The Federal Government doesn't listen to us," he said. "The focus of their debate is not the focus of our debate."
However the county adjusts to the cuts, payoffs will be down the road, said Representative Gary A. Condit, the county's man in Congress. "Decisions have to be made that we prefer not to make to have a balanced budget in a time certain," said Mr. Condit, a Democrat. "That would be a major victory for this county and this country."
Like many California cities, Modesto grows sideways. Mr. Tewes, the city manager, calls it "a city without suburbs." Mr. Wilson, the county executive, calls it "a suburb without a city." Modesto sits in the heart of a fertile agricultural region, a source of fruits and vegetables, milk, wine and nuts. Major employers are tomato canneries and a Gallo winery. Unemployment often exceeds 10 percent because many jobs are tied to harvests.
Federal programs are found throughout this economy. Mr. Wilson says state and Federal spending accounts for two-thirds of his $525 million operating budget. Welfare, at $170 million a year, is the biggest chunk, and of that, more than 60 percent represents cash payments through Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the largest Federal welfare program.
That whole system is changing. As things stand now, the Government will reduce its total payment for welfare and distribute the money in lump sums, known as block grants, to the states, which they can hand out to the poor based on their own criteria. Along with the reduction, Congress will set limits on the grants, so the Federal entitlement of aid for whoever qualifies as poor will end.
"It's an unfunded safety net," said Ciel Chatham, a program manager at the county office of the state's Department of Social Services. To keep costs down, the state will reduce welfare payments to families in communities with a relatively low cost of living like Modesto by 9.8 percent. For a family of two here, that means a reduction to $442 each month from $490. Recipients will also be limited to five years of welfare.
The ensuing impact of a decline in welfare spending that flows into the county, to its landlords and supermarkets, utilities and laundromats, is impossible to calculate yet. "I don't think those people know what's coming," Ms. Chatham said.
 
Unknown Effects On the Job Market
 It is also hard to gauge how another feature of the overhaul of the welfare system -- a requirement that most adult recipients look for jobs -- will affect the economy and the job market. The work requirement collides with provisions in the budget that could make jobs, already scarce in Stanislaus County, even harder to get.
Like most local governments, Stanislaus receives money from the Labor Department to train and retrain workers, including many on welfare, and help them find jobs. But in the budget, spending for job assistance is to be reduced by 20 percent, with the money distributed to the states to spend as they choose.
This comes on top of earlier cuts. Two years ago, William L. May, county director for employment and training, had $1.9 million to steer 700 at-risk youth back into school and train them for work. The program was pared to $418,000 last year, so it reached only 300 youths.
Under another Federal program, Mr. May spent $3 million this year to pay 1,400 teen-agers the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour for public service summer jobs, like cleaning parks and playgrounds. But nothing remains of the program in the likely budget. "You're talking about kids," Mr. May said. "They were doing something. What are they going to do instead of that?"
Crime and drug abuse, lures of idle youth, are already urgent issues. Judy Tognolini, administrative analyst for the Modesto Police Department, said that incidents of violent crime here rose 9 percent during the first six months this year, while statewide it fell 7 percent.
Yet Federally financed efforts to deal with these issues, too, are under the knife.
The Community Oriented Policing Services program, established by the 1994 Federal crime bill, has been helping the city fight the trend. Washington paid $1.5 million and the city $750,000 to add 14 officers to the 200-member police force for three years. But Ms. Tognolini said the Federal grant is unlikely to be renewed.
 
Addicts and Elderly Will Be Hit Hard
 Less is coming, too, for drug and alcohol treatment. Through a Federally subsidized substance abuse program, about 600 clients a year spend a month living in dormitory rooms in a former tuberculosis ward where they receive treatment and help in getting jobs. But the Republican budget would cut the Federal $1.9 million contribution to the program by 13 percent.
In addition, fewer addicts would qualify for admission. At present, substance abuse addiction is considered a disability under the Federal Supplemental Security Income program for the elderly and disabled. That makes indigent addicts eligible for both a welfare check and Government-paid treatment through Medicaid, the health program for the poor.
But in the budget, Congress disallows the addictions as disabilities to qualify for S.S.I. "That system is gone," said Robert H. Allaire, alcohol and drug programs administrator for the Stanislaus Department of Mental Health.
Low-income older people, too, stand to lose something because of cuts in spending under the Older Americans Act, which Congress adopted 30 years ago to help the elderly lead independent lives. It supports a variety of programs here, including one that assures anyone 62 or older a meal a day.
About 600 retirees gather for lunch, games and singing every weekday at 14 sites operated by the Senior Opportunity Service Program throughout the county. About 600 more, who are confined to their homes, are brought one meal a day that is prepared at the largest site, just off Ninth Street downtown.
This is a cheerful, bustling, bare-bones operation with long, covered tables. Guests are invited to put a $2 donation in a locked metal box for their meal, but many do not. Volunteers go table to table passing out portion-controlled meals.
"People come to us because they're in need," said Shirley Mooney, who supervises the countywide service for a nonprofit contractor. Demand for the meals grows 100 or so a year, but Congress has stabilized financing for several years and is now likely to reduce it. "We serve and we serve and we serve," Ms. Mooney said, "and we're going to have to cut it."
She has already closed two meal sites, leaving the 14, laid off three of 17 remaining site workers, and, last month, dismissed one of her eight cooks. But harsher cuts await the people who get meals at home.
"We'll have to re-evaluate them," Ms. Mooney said. "We're going to be getting strict and tough. We want to see if they can get up and get their meal or have a family member do it."
For the old who can get out but do not drive, getting around on Modesto's fleet of 29 buses is becoming more of a hassle because of cuts in Federal operating subsidies. Five years ago, Washington contributed $1 million, which covered 28 percent of the cost of running the buses. This year, it is contributing $455,000, which covers 8 percent.
City officials expect the Federal subsidy to be cut in half again in the new budget. "I'm sure that in the next seven years, they're going to zero out operating assistance," said Fred Cavanah, city transit manager.
To cope with the reductions, the city raised fares a nickel in July, to 75 cents. Another raise of at least a nickel is likely next July. "What we'll probably do," said Mr. Tewes, the city manager, "is a combination of service reduction and a fare increase."
To keep fares from rising more, he said, the city will divert money from maintenance of Modesto's wide, unblemished asphalt roads. The new Federal budget, said Mr. Tewes, "means more potholes."

HEADLINE: Talks on Rebuilding Bosnia Become Squabble Over Bill

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The United States and more than 40 other countries completed a two-day meeting here today on planning the reconstruction of Bosnia, but progress was slowed by the sheer scale of the problems, from repatriating refugees and rebuilding houses to restarting the shattered economy.
The countries did not even try to address the critical question of who would pay for a program that in the long run could cost $5 billion or more. And while they settled on Carl Bildt, the former Swedish Prime Minister and European envoy to the Bosnia peace talks, to lead the civilian reconstruction effort, they only touched on the complexities of specific issues, such as how to create a central bank, or a police force that will be accepted by Muslims, Croats and Serbs. 
 The United States and its major European allies used the conference to repeat that their commitment to bringing peace and stability to the former Yugoslavia did not end with the dispatch of troops to Bosnia. For peace to take root, they said, governments and international agencies would have to work together to create out of the rubble of war the physical, political, legal and economic foundations of a stable society.
The presence of 60,000 NATO troops in Bosnia "can help insure that the wounds of war do not reopen during the next year," Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative to the United Nations, told the conference today. "But the only concentrated therapy that can heal those wounds is the hard work of restoring Bosnia's economy, democracy and respect for the rule of law."
For all the talk of help, though, delegates to the conference acknowledged that efforts to turn their commitment into action would be complex, time-consuming, expensive and potentially fraught with conflicts among the many countries and international organizations taking part in them.
No one was able to say in any detail, for example, how and when the two million to three million people who were forced from their homes, including around 1.7 million who are refugees outside of Bosnia, would get the chance to return home.
Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said there had not yet been any comprehensive survey of what housing was available in what towns, and that it remained unclear how much it might cost to provide housing for those who wanted to return. Many other issues remained unresolved, as well, including whether refugees who have not returned to Bosnia by the time elections are held, probably next summer, could vote by absentee ballot.
"I realize very much the complexity and immensity of the task," Mrs. Ogata said.
The United Nations was given the task of providing a temporary police force, and said it would try to recruit 1,500 officers from member nations to provide a skeletal law-enforcement agency and begin recruiting and training Bosnians for the job.
J. Brian Atwood, the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, said one of the biggest challenges would be creating a functioning economy in a country that had not only been decimated by war, but that had not really even begun the shift from Communism to capitalism before fighting broke out.
To begin economic redevelopment would require steps like setting up a central bank and a currency, and rebuilding factories and roads, delegates said.
Mohamed Sacirbey, Bosnia's Foreign Minister, said the country's goal was to restore the per capita income of its citizens, which is now almost nothing, to two-thirds of its prewar level in five years. He said Bosnia would need at least $1 billion a year in international aid for the next three to five years to rebuild the economy.
"Promises of money are like checks in the mail, but when it comes to the international community we hope the story is different this time," Mr. Sacirbey said. "In this case real peace can be bought in part with money."
But even before there were any comprehensive independent estimates of the cost of reconstruction, the United States and Europe were haggling over who would pay how much.
Before the conference, the Clinton Administration rejected a proposal by France that the United States and Europe each pay a third of the reconstruction bill, with the rest picked up by wealthy Islamic countries that have supported the Muslim-led Bosnian Government during the war and by other wealthy nations like Japan.
Citing its budget difficulties and the need to focus on winning Congressional support for sending 20,000 American troops to Bosnia, the Administration has proposed paying around $600 million, about a third of what Europe wants the United States to contribute.
Administration officials contend that the bulk of the costs should be borne by the countries of the European Union because Bosnia is basically their problem.
"We think that the E.U. should do more and that a third is exorbitant for us," said Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser.

HEADLINE: Black Leader in Congress Chosen to Run N.A.A.C.P.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Hoping for a leader to bring it back to fiscal health and political relevance, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored people today chose Representative Kweisi Mfume of Maryland as its chief executive officer.
The civil rights organization's board of directors chose the 47-year-old Congressman to fill the N.A.A.C.P.'s top staff job, which had been vacant for more than two years since the group's former executive director, Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., was dismissed after being accused of financial mismanagement and sexual harassment. Several board members said today's vote had been unanimous. 
 Mr. Mfume, who has represented Baltimore, the site of N.A.A.C.P. headquarters, as well as several suburbs west of the city since 1987, said he would step down from his Congressional seat in mid-February. In giving up his seat, Mr. Mfume is signaling his belief that, for the moment, he can be more effective outside the Republican-controlled House than within it.
"I am absolutely honored to have been chosen for this opportunity," Mr. Mfume (pronounced Kwah-EEE-see Oom-FOO-may) said at a news conference after the vote. He promised to restore the organization's "financial, political and spiritual health."
In recent months, as events like the O. J. Simpson trial, the Million Man March and the debate over affirmative action have pushed race relations to the forefront of the national agenda, the N.A.A.C.P. has been paralyzed by internal squabbles and financial difficulties. Officials say the last time the board of directors had a meaningful debate over policy was when it was considering whether to endorse the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court in 1991. The board finally opposed him.
While the N.A.A.C.P. has turned inward, other groups and individuals, including Louis Farrakhan and the Nation of Islam, have moved forward, angering traditional allies of the civil rights movement like Jews and worrying white liberals.
Speaking of the N.A.A.C.P., Mr. Mfume said, "We must, without equivocation or timidity, reclaim our rightful place as the voice of African-Americans and others who believe in the power and the premise that all people are in fact created equal."
The selection of Mr. Mfume marks the completion of efforts by reformers within the N.A.A.C.P. to revamp its leadership, an effort that often laid bare regional and class divisions within the group, the country's oldest and largest civil rights organization. In the past two years, these reformers succeeded in ousting Mr. Chavis and William F. Gibson, who was replaced as chairman of the board last February by Myrlie Evers-Williams.
In accepting the job, Mr. Mfume vowed to revitalize the N.A.A.C.P., which is still staggering under a $3.2 million debt and recovering from internal bickering in recent years and from charges of corruption on the part of its top leaders.
His acceptance of the position marks a personal odyssey for Mr. Mfume, who rose from being a street tough in Baltimore who fathered five children out of wedlock to becoming the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus at a time when the Democrats controlled Congress.
His selection is a clear sign that the organization, which has been casting about for direction, will be emphasizing political themes like voter registration, education and lobbying. It also marks a change in direction for the organization's leadership: Mr. Mfume will become the first head of the N.A.A.C.P. since Roy Wilkins stepped down in 1977 whose background was not that of a clergyman.
In giving its top job to Mr. Mfume, the group has opted to rely on a person whose skills are more in the area of political organizing and strategy than in oratory and appeals to morality.
Mr. Mfume's decision to give up a safe Congressional seat, to which he has been re-elected by large margins four times, is a signal of how the Republican takeover of Congress has transformed the dreams and strategies of black politicians. Once considered one of the most powerful black figures in the country and a person who aspired to be the first black Speaker of the House, Mr. Mfume is taking over a debt-ridden organization whose staff has fewer than 50 people.
With the Republicans in charge, several black members of Congress, including Mr. Mfume and Representative Cleo Fields, who recently ran unsuccessfully for the Louisiana governorship, now say their political goals and ambitions can be better served outside Congress.
"I am convinced without reservation that I can best affect the social, economic and political change in the broader capacity that the N.A.A.C.P. represents," Mr. Mfume said.
By choosing Mr. Mfume, a veteran and telegenic Congressman, the 64-member board is conceding power in the running of the day-to-day activities of the group back to the chief executive officer. Since the 1980's, when the former executive Benjamin L. Hooks barely survived an attempt to oust him, power within the organization has flowed from the top staff position to the often-fractious and unwieldy board.
Indicative of this shift in power is the new title the board gave to Mr. Mfume's job, changing it from executive director to president and chief executive officer. Mr. Mfume said the change in title "represented a new power position" within the N.A.A.C.P.
Mr. Mfume was chosen after a five-month search by a special nine-member committee made up of board members and representatives of corporations, universities and the bar. The committee, headed by A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., a retired Federal judge from Philadelphia, employed the executive search firm Russell Reynolds & Associates. The committee interviewed more than 200 applicants for the position. In keeping with its mandate, the committee presented only one name -- Mr. Mfume's -- to the board for ratification.
The choice elated many members of the board, particularly the reformers. "This is someone we admire, that we trust and that we have high hopes for to turn the organization around," Ms. Evers-Williams said.
But other longtime critics of the organization were less sanguine over Mr. Mfume's prospects of revitalizing the N.A.A.C.P.
"It's an organization which is now moribund, discredited and financially insolvent," said Michael Meyers, president of the New York Civil Rights Coalition. "The N.A.A.C.P. is, I think, now a relic, a dinosaur that is about to be put out to pasture. All the naming of an executive director will do is give it some blip on the screen of a faint heartbeat."
Mr. Mfume takes on a formidable task. In addition to the debt, he has been bequeathed a board that in recent years has provided little help in gaining access to money or political power and has spent most of its time meddling in the organization's day-to-day operations.
Today, Mr. Mfume endorsed the idea of reducing the board's size, saying that "you will soon see real and meaningful efforts toward addressing the problem of size in such a way that we have a more manageable operation."
