SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2416 words

HEADLINE: Mall Aglow With New Stores and 'Real' Santa

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
BOGGED down with shopping bags from stores throughout the Roosevelt Field mall, Roy Cotignola and Mary-Jo Thompson were doing their holiday shopping at J. Crew.
"We've already been to Kay-Bee, Disney, Warner Brothers, Learningsmith and the Nature Company," said Ms. Thompson, who traveled to the mall from Queens to find the items on her holiday list. 
 "In Queens, there's no place like this mall," she said, "where we can find such variety and feel safe."
She took out her holiday list to emphasize her success over the last few hours. "I know exactly what I'm looking for, for each person," she said.
"Not me," Mr. Cotignola said as he looked at the merchandise in the men's area. "My shopping is spontaneous. I hope I can find something here for my uncle."
The Friday after Thanksgiving, the traditional start of the holiday shopping season, was extremely busy, according to the manager of J. Crew, Nicole Sliby. Business slowed down over the weekend, but became busy again on Monday and has continued to build.
The activity at J. Crew is representative of the entire mall, said Marie-Claire Cunningham, an assistant vice president of Corporate Property Investors, which owns and manages the center. Traffic over the weekend after Thanksgiving was disappointing, reflecting a national trend, she said, adding, "People are waiting longer and longer to do their holiday shopping."
Despite the optimism among managers and owners, it is too early to tell whether this will be a lucrative season. As many shoppers wait for holiday sales, last-minute shopping has become more of the norm than the exception, retailers say. Final figures for the holiday season may not be available for months.
J. Crew, which opened in Roosevelt Field three years ago, has traditionally been known as a catalogue-clothing company. Its Roosevelt Field location is its lone store on the Island.
When the store opened, it catered to a younger crowd, but now it attracts more upscale customers, Ms. Sliby said, adding: "The moms and dads who were shopping here with their kids are seeing things they like for themselves," she said. A changing customer base prompted the introduction of a more expensive line, J. Crew Exclusive, a designer collection, the manager said. The changing image is part of a trend, Ms. Cunningham said. On 106 acres, the mall, which opened in 1956, was renovated in 1993 as a three-level center, with a food court and four anchors, J. C. Penney, Macy's, Stern's and A. & S. Bloomingdale's moved from Garden City last month and replaced A. & S. last month.
Nordstrom, another upscale department store, is scheduled to open at the mall in 1997.
On the main floor, Jane Batterman was in Tourneau, paying with a credit card for a Concord watch that she had just bought for herself as a holiday gift. "This store is beautiful," she said of the Island's first Tourneau store, which opened on Nov. 16. "I had shopped around for this watch, and the prices at Tourneau were competitive. But I came here mostly because of the service."
The executive vice president of Tourneau, Anthony Dembrosio, said the store was significantly ahead of initial projections. "We've already changed our annual projections, based on business during the first few weeks," he said.
The store is selling higher-priced merchandise than it expected, Mr. Dembrosio said, adding, "Customers are more upscale than we had predicted."
The hottest items for holidays are purchases that will last, he said, adding, "People are investing in items that they can pass down to their great-grandchildren, who are not even yet born."
"I live in New York City," Ms. Batterman said, "but like to shop out here, where I can get all my holiday shopping done in one place."
Nearby, her mother, Marilyn Batterman of Westbury, said: "The new Bloomingdale's is beautiful. And at Stern's, we found great sales and got gorgeous velour shirts for the men in the family. I've lived out here for 36 years, and years ago, there was nothing in this mall except Macy's. The changes are wonderful."
 
Renovations And a New Image
The new Bloomingdale's and Tourneau reflect a changing image toward a more well-off customer. Besides the 285,000-square-foot Bloomingdale's, the mall will soon have a Nordstrom's, one of the largest specialty department stores. The chain from Seattle plans to open a 225,000-square-foot store at the mall in late 1997.
The expansion includes two restaurants near the movie theater on the former site of Herman's. The sporting-goods store reduced its size, making room for the California Cafe that opened last week and Houston's, which is to open in February.
In keeping with the new image, the California restaurant serves sophisticated cuisine with a Mediterranean influence, along with an extensive wine list and a pastry chef.
Houston's, a chain from Phoenix, is a more casual family-style restaurant.
The shift toward a more upscale image began with the 1993 expansion, Ms. Cunningham said. New shops then included Banana Republic, Warner Brothers, J. Crew and Bebe, a women's clothing chain.
"With our current expansion," she said, "we're going slightly higher. After the completion of the second level, 60 stores are to be added by next fall. They will include Crabtree & Evelyn, Kenneth Cole and F. A. O. Schwarz."
Long Island has a high level of purchasing power, said the chief economist of the Long Island Association, Dr. Pearl Kamer, adding, "Long Island residents have deep pockets."
According to the Commerce Department, the per capita income in 1993 in Nassau County was $32,966. The only other large county in the New York metropolitan area that surpassed Nassau was Westchester, at $35,945.
Dr. Kamer said that to be competitive and stay in business, malls had to stay updated and that modernization was a national trend.
"But at the same time," Ms. Cunningham said, "we do not want to alienate our more moderate tenants. Long Island is a mix of income levels, and it is important to maintain a balance so Roosevelt Field will continue to be considered the place to shop."
An 8,000-square-foot Sam Goody music store recently opened on the lower level. By next month the lower concourse, formerly just for offices, will be filled, with a Noodle Kidoodle, a store that sells children's electronics and computer games, as well as other toys.
The marketing director of the mall, Deborah Ann Flattery, said quality was also important, because people looked for value. "Customers are no longer shopping willy-nilly," Ms. Flattery said. "They are more sophisticated and more selective. They want to know that they're getting value, and they expect to be educated about their purchases. Today added customer service has become a mallwide policy."
 
Injecting 'Excitement' Into the Mall
Shelley Tessler, a longtime resident of Syosset who recently moved to California, was on her way to the airport but had to take a detour to see the new Bloomingdale's.
"It's fabulous," said Mrs. Tessler, while resting at a cosmetics counter to buy a few last-minute items. "The only consolation about moving away from Long Island is that I heard that they're opening a new Bloomingdale's in Newport Beach!"
Words of exclamation from other shoppers echoed that. "Beautiful," "exciting" and "wonderful" were frequently heard about the store that opened on Nov. 3 in the area that A. & S. formerly occupied. Aside from the Bloomingdale's on 59th Street in Manhattan, it is the largest Bloomingdale's in the country, with more than 500 employees.
Last month was a good month for business, said the general manager of the store, Richard Mast. "Now we're cautiously optimistic about December.We've brought some excitement to the mall."
Bloomingdale's customers are selective and are buying better, Mr. Mast said, with the better end of the business selling well. "As a result of Bloomingdale's coming here," Mr. Mast said, "the mall is now starting to lease to other upper-end stores."
A major change is having a salesperson accompany a customer from one purchase to another throughout the store, Mr. Mast said. "It's all about relationship building," he said. "We still have a staff at each department. But we train our salespeople to be able to shop with customers throughout the entire store, and we encourage them to stay with their customers, so they don't have to look for a different salesperson in each department. Our vision is to have 500 sales people, moving with their clients, from one department to another."
For the holiday season gifts that have been selling especially well include cosmetics -- Bloomingdale's introduced four lines, YSL, Guerlain, Fashion Fair and Origins, that it did not sell in its store in Garden City -- ties, particularly designs by Nicole Miller, Jerry Garcia, Frank Sinatra and Vicki Davis; women's cashmere and chenille sweaters; food and gift baskets, Morgan bottles with preserved specialty foods, and, for children, Woofles, a stuffed dog from Gund, and Barbie merchandise like telephones and dolls.
Bloomingdale's is the No. 1 store on Long Island for Barbie, according to Mr. Mast.
An interesting twist to being in the mall, he said, is that the store has developed a big young people's business that it did not have in Garden City. "There are so many kids in the mall," Mr. Mast said. "And we're getting a lot of spillover traffic from young people coming into Bloomingdale's to shop."
 
Valet Parking And Added Security
On a recent Friday afternoon drivers waited 10 minutes for valet parking. The two young attendants sprinted back and forth, handing tickets to newcomers and running to retrieve cars.
"You sure get a lot of exercise," said one shopper to an attendant as she handed him a $1 tip. The attendant, rosy cheeked, smiled and hurried to move the next car.
At Roosevelt Field valet parking has been a security feature for three years. It started at holiday time and is now available year-round, at a fee of $3.
Bloomingdale's has its own valet parking, which is free for customers who show a Bloomingdale's charge card. Last month the service parked 8,000 cars, Mr. Mast said.
For Debbie Fasciana of Franklin Square, valet parking is one reason that she shops at Roosevelt Field. "I always use the service," Mrs. Fasciana said. "I have three kids and usually come here with a baby and a stroller. And when I come out I usually leave with a lot of shopping bags."
Mrs. Fasciana, who said she shopped at the mall about once a week and more often before the holidays, said, "Particularly when I come here alone I feel much safer using the valet service."
Some customers complained about difficulties in finding parking spots. Even though the mall has 9,000 spaces, a south parking deck will be started after the holidays and, later, a third deck is to be added. With the three decks the mall will have 11,000 spaces.
Security is a top priority, Ms. Flattery said. Among the features are a closed-circuit television system to monitor inside and outside buildings, a new county police center, security vehicles and mounted county officers on patrol, extensive lighting, an escort service on request and two courtesy shuttle buses for the holidays.
The buses depart from the main entrance, near the Chemical Bank branch, and circulate throughout the parking area. If a bus is not crowded, Ms. Flattery said, it will go to shoppers' cars.
 
A Food Court For Many Tastes
It was standing room only at lunch time in the Food Court. Shoppers and employees hovered near tables, waiting for an empty seat. Plates were filled with deli sandwiches, hamburgers, french fries, tacos, chicken chow mein, hot dogs and yogurt with assorted toppings -- something for everyone, just like the theme of the mall.
At a table for two, Shari Hymowitz and Pam Harper, who sell Guess watches, were taking a break from visiting the stores that carry their merchandise.
"Of all the malls we visit this is the nicest on Long Island," Ms. Hymowitz, of Hewlett, said. "What they've attempted to do -- clean it up and make it more upscale -- they've really done. They've made it easy for everyone, from J. C. Penney shoppers to Bloomingdale's shoppers. There really is something for everyone."
Nearby four executives of Raymond Weil watches, dressed in suits, carried their trays as they waited for a table.
"We're here to see our accounts," one executive, Larry Lich, said. "We sell at Macy's, Tourneau and Bloomingdale's, and they're all doing well. So far it's been a very good season with our watches. People seem to be looking for a better product and are spending more."
The changes in the mall are readily apparent, starting with the look of more affluent shoppers, Mr. Lich said. As for the quality of his lunch, he said, "It's adequate."
 
Santa Claus With a Real Beard
Terri Muller of Lynbrook did not expect to be in the picture with Santa Claus and her 1-year-old daughter Danielle. "It's our first time visiting Santa," she said. "I hope she cooperates."
But Danielle was not pleased to be alone on Santa's lap. No matter how many times the photographer's assistant waved the stuffed clown at her, no matter how hard she tried to make her smile, Danielle would stop crying only when her mother stepped in to sit next to Santa and hold her daughter on her lap.
"It's too bad," Mrs. Muller said after the photograph was taken. "I really wanted a picture of just Danielle with Santa."
A half-dozen families were on the line. The Jung family, from Queens, waited. Their daughter Kristen, 3 1/2, said, "I'm going to ask Santa for a toy can opener for my kitchen and for Baby Tumbles."
"That's a doll," explained her mother, Linda.
Before visiting Santa, the Jungs had been to the Disney Store and Penney's, with great success, judging by their many shopping bags.
Two Santas alternate shifts near the grand fountain. The set has been redesigned to resemble a stroll through a country lane, with old-fashioned lampposts, foliage and simulated ponds.
The mall expects Santa -- one or the other -- to welcome 20,000 to 25,000 children, Ms. Flattery said.
For the first time, both Santas have "real beards, real bellies," she said, adding:
"They work eight-hour shifts. But can't go to the bathroom, because kids know that Santa doesn't go to the bathroom. And we allow a 15-minute break between Santas, to be sure that no kids can ever see two Santas as the same time."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Food Court at Roosevelt Field, top. Inside new Bloomingdale's, left. Patricia Buckley with daughter Briana at the Disney store, above top, and Mary-Jo Thompson and Roy Cotignola at J. Crew, all at the mall. (Photographs by Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Merchants Keep Hoping, Despite Slow Start

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
IT may be the season for glad tidings, but not so far this year for anxious retailers. In Westchester as elsewhere, shopkeepers are reporting brisk foot traffic in their stores in the weeks before Christmas -- but disappointing sales.
"The bottom line is not how crowded the stores are, but how many shoppers are leaving with bags," said Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the Westchester Chamber of Commerce. "The consumers may be out there, but whether they're buying is another question." 
 At the newly renovated 137,000-square-foot Neiman Marcus store in White Plains -- part of an upscale chain that has traditionally reported strong sales despite conditions elsewhere -- shoppers so far this season have been "just looking, taking it all in," reported Raina Penchansky, a spokeswoman.
In the store's Christmas catalogue, a $900,000 yellow diamond necklace was still languishing last week among the pages of expensive merchandise, the spokeswoman said.
Nordstrom's department store -- which like Neiman Marcus is in The Westchester Mall -- also reported that there have been more lookers than takers in the aisles. To make up for the slow start, the retailer is banking on a longer shopping season between Thanksgiving and Christmas -- five more days than a year ago -- said Christine Schrader, a spokeswoman.
Smaller retailers have also been holding their breath. Joseph Galano, the owner of Irvington Hardware, said merchants along Main Street in that village were "waiting for the big bang."
Like many analysts who are observing shopping patterns, Mr. Galano suggested that customers might be holding out until the last minute.
In Yonkers, at the Cross County Shopping Center, Leonard and Claire Morreale, owners of the Mont Royale Gift Shop, said they too were waiting for the shopping season to take off. They said the delayed start might be explained in part by the lateness this year of Hanukkah, the eight-day Jewish festival of lights, which usually begins early in the month but does not start this year until Dec. 18. Whatever the reason, retailers throughout the county -- with substantial inventories on their hands -- were fighting to draw customers. "Virtually every store I've been in has been featuring a sale, and not just a small-time sale," Mr. Vogt said. "We're talking 50 percent off at the beginning of the season. Merchants are driving very, very hard."
Meanwhile, national figures reflected the somber picture. The International Council of Shopping Centers in New York City reported that on the Friday after Thanksgiving -- the day known as Black Friday, when retailers hope to turn their ledgers the same color -- there was a 5.8 percent surge in mall sales. But over the next two days, sales declined, and the net result was a flat sales picture for the weekend.
A week later, the trade organization reported that the picture had worsened. Sales in specialty stores in regional malls declined by 1.3 percent for the first full week of the holiday shopping season, compared with the same period last year when malls reported a 0.9 percent gain.
The bright spots were in the categories of jewelry and cards, gifts and books, both of which showed an increase of 3.2 percent, the council said. The apparel category continued to be weak, falling by 6.8 percent. Music, entertainment and software, which started strongly on Black Friday, also fell by 6.8 percent.
Home furnishings were down 2.4 percent, and footwear was down 1.5 percent. The council's holiday report includes sales from specialty stores in 80 malls but does not include department stores.
Figures from TeleChek Services, a check-acceptance company in Houston, showed that over the Thanksgiving weekend retail sales in the country were down 4.7 percent from the previous year. The news was much worse in the New York City area, where sales were off 14.6 percent.
A follow-up report last Monday said that holiday sales continued to slow in the 10 days following Thanksgiving. Their figures are based on yearly comparisons of the dollar volume of authorized checks written by consumers. Checks account for 37 percent of spending, compared with 13 percent for credit and debit cards. The rest is primarily cash.
Despite the gloomy reports, some retailers were more cheery than others, and there was some good news to report. White Plains was cheered late last month when the State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco reversed part of an earlier agreement that would have required Federated Department Stores to close its White Plains Macy's to resolve anti-trust concerns.
When Federated merged with R. H. Macy & Company last year, it owned three White Plains department stores: Macy's in the downtown area, Stern's at the Galleria mall and Bloomindgdale's several miles away on Bloomingdale Road. The news that Macy's could stay cheered many smaller merchants who welcome customers that department stores bring to the area.
Though not the rule, sales -- as well as foot traffic -- were brisk at some stores, despite the sober reports elsewhere. At Sears in White Plains, Michael Leahy, the manager, said snow blowers were "flying out of the store" along with scarves, jackets and other cold-weather gear.
"Our sales are up," Mr. Leahy said. "We're meeting expectations. So somebody's buying!"
And at Borders Books & Music, a spokeswoman, Susan Burger, said: "It's not only wild in the store, but they are buying, too. Our shoppers seem very focused this year."
Ruthe Berman, executive director of marketing for the Cross County Shopping Center, said few customers were going home empty-handed. She attributed some of the success at that mall to the Sears store that opened there this year.
Even Miss Penchansky at Neiman Marcus had some good news to report. A $35,000 limited-edition BMW Z3 Roadster offered through the catalogue, a copy of the model driven in the latest James Bond movie, "Goldeneye," sold out early, she said, suggesting that perhaps customers were simply being more choosy this year.
Miss Penchansky may be right, and some shoppers who were interviewed said that they were simply buying more carefully this year.
"It has been a slow start," said Maribel Garcia, who was shopping last weekend at the Galleria mall. "We're watching the sales and waiting for the best deals. We're just not rushing things."
In Irvington, Pat Stockhamer was shopping at Arco Iris, a boutique, glad not to be caught in the crush at the malls and happy to be looking at specialized merchandise. "It's quieter here, unhurried," she said. "And the gifts aren't all mass produced. I'm looking for something a little different this year."
Paula Boyd, who was at the Galleria last week, said she was also looking for "something special, a little bit different." She bought many of her gifts this year at the yearly gem show at the County Center in White Plains
Certainly retailers were optimistic heading into Christmas, and the season could still end on an upbeat note, analysts said. In October, retail hiring was up by 800 jobs, compared with the same month a year ago. That was the highest October level -- 64,300 jobs this year -- since 1990, reported Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the state's Department of Labor.
Overall, there appeared to be a high level of confidence in the Westchester economy, said Mr. Surdey, who predicted that it would eventually translate into spending. He added that the state, in general, was in an expansion mode, with 60,000 more jobs this year than in 1994.
"We're trudging ahead, not galloping, but the indicators are postive," Mr. Surdey said. "Westchester is a big draw for shoppers from a tri-state area. It's like a family outing to go there."
Martin Deitch, a partner with Aries, Deitch & Edelson, a Hartsdale concern that develops and manages commercial properties, said merchants had every reason to be optimistic.
"Forget the doom and gloom," he said. "It's just a slow start."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shopkeepers are reporting brisk foot traffic in stores but disappointing sales. A shop on Main Street in Irvington seeks to draw customers. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Rising, Hotels Invest in Sprucing Up

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE Stouffer Renaissance Westchester Hotel in White Plains has already spent $4 million on renovation, with an additional $3 million budgeted for work to be completed in the spring.
Renovations to guest rooms and meeting rooms at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown are estimated to cost $700,000, in addition to a $3.5 million expenditure for construction of a new ballroom. 
 At the Crowne Plaza in White Plains, a $4 million refurbishing of every guest room, lobby and restaurant is under way.
And in Yonkers, the former Carvell Inn has been totally renovated by new owners, who opened it in October as the Royal Regency Hotel.
Still to come in early March is a new luxury hotel in Tarrytown that will make its debut as the Castle, which will be converted from a former landmark, Axe Castle.
"Hoteliers have solid reasons for optimism," said Georgia Kalayjian, president of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau. "This year, after several dismal years, occupancy is on the rise."
Citing the economic recovery as leading to a surge in business and leisure travel, Ms. Kalayjian said: "Hotels report that occupancy is up from 4 percent to 10 percent this year, and they predict an additional 3 to 5 percent rise for 1996. The repeal of the 5 percent state surtax on hotel rooms makes our hotels competitive with those in Connecticut and New Jersey, which will allow us to market Westchester more widely."
Figures are not yet in for 1995, but Ms. Kalayjian reported that 1,000 new jobs in the hotel industry were created in 1994. "The industry payroll is also at an all-time high, with 31,603 people employed in the hospitality industry."
The Convention Bureau's campaign to sell Westchester as a destination has shown results.
"For example, attendance at historic sites this year rose 18 percent," Ms. Kalayjian said. "And we have The Westchester, a fabulous mall, as a new attraction we can market to convention planners. With Neiman Marcus and the only Nordstrom in New York, we tell them we have something they can't find in Manhattan. Convention planners like to have activities they can refer to as being attractive for spouses. Now we've broadened our marketing efforts with a year-round national advertising campaign to sell Westchester as a wanted destination in itself, not just a stop on the road to Manhattan."
Westchester has about 4,000 hotel rooms, and room sales continue to rise, exuberant hotel managers say.
"We feel very optimistic," said John D. Williams, general manager of Stouffer. "Not only did we have a big boost in convention business, but leisure travel has increased. We have seen more international guests than ever before, and over the Thanksgiving holiday we booked relatives and friends of local residents." What is especially notable, Mr. Williams said, "is the rise in the number of Manhattan companies that are holding meetings and conventions here." He added, "We are more affordable and offer them a higher level of service than they can find in New York City."
At the Crowne Plaza in White Plains, business has also been excellent, Ann Peterson, the hotel's manager, said. "Our proximity to The Westchester mall gives us high visibility that we never had before," she said. "When our renovations are completed, we will be marketing a totally new, upscale product."
Jeffrey Weggeman, director of sales and marketing at Tarrytown House, said: "We're having a very good year. Overall business is up by 10 percent with projections for an additional 20 percent rise next year. Under new management by Dolce International, we have been successfully packaging the entire Biddle mansion to large corporate groups of 90 or more for the first time."
Tarrytown House, designated as one of the historic hotels of America by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, is also being marketed to the public successfully, Mr. Weggeman said, as a getaway destination. A great estates weekend package at Tarrytown House directed to the vacation traveler includes candlelight tours at nearby historic sites, cocktail parties and other extras.
"The getaway weekends, with room rates of $115 to $129 are going very well," Mr. Weggeman said. "They're especially popular with people from Manhattan. Our business was strong over Thanksgiving weekend, and the momentum is continuing."
And when the Castle opens this spring, visitors and business people will have an opportunity to occupy five luxury suites in the original stone landmark building, dine in a fine new restaurant and hold meetings in the Castle's ballrooms, said Kathryn Andersen, director of sales and catering for the Castle.
"The Castle is owned by a group of private investors who have positioned it to appeal to a very upscale market," Ms. Andersen said. "We're currently in the process of adding an additional 24 deluxe rooms, and when all the construction is finished we intend to apply for Relais et Chateaux status, which will make us one of a very select group of unusual luxury hotel properties."
At Doral Arrowwood Conference Center in Rye Brook, business generally follows activity on Wall Street, said Edmund J. Burns Jr., the general manager.
And lackluster, like the market, was how Mr. Burns described Arrowwood business during the first quarter of 1995.
"But the second half of this year has made up for it," he said. "Business has been spectacular. Revenues are up by 9 percent, and we expect even better things for next year."
Arrowwood has spent $2 million, Mr. Burns said, on capital improvements "to assure our position as a major conference center." He continued: "Repeat business is very important to us. We keep making capital improvements, and we also have 68 managers here because service is the key to repeat business."
Although hotel managers agree that an economic recovery and the repeal of a room tax have stimulated business, they also observe that when hotel business in Manhattan is strong, as it has been for the last year, Westchester business follows suit. Currently, hotel occupancy in Manhattan is the highest it has been in seven years.
In Yonkers, Patricia Breen, director of sales at the new 92-room Royal Regency Hotel, said that corporations have already given the hotel an enthusiastic reception. "We opened for business in October, and during the first week we were almost sold out," she said. "We have 25,000 square feet of banquet, meeting room and ballroom space, large enough to seat 800 people at a banquet. And judging from the business we have been booking, I know that lower Westchester was overdue for our type of service-oriented, moderate-priced hotel."
As for the seasonal profit maker, the holiday party, managers report an across-the-board increase this season.
"Holiday parties are very strong," Mr. Williams said. "What's more, more is being spent on them. The food is upgraded and my feeling is that it's through the party that companies are saying thank you to employees for coping during difficult economic times."

HEADLINE: Cross-Border Traffic Fuels Effort to Change Bar Closings to 2 A.M.

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

 BODY:
THE longstanding debate on what time Westchester's bars should close is simmering again, this time with a real possibility that last call will be rolled back to 2 from 4 A.M.
Proponents of the earlier closing say their reasons are simple: the move will reduce drunken driving and save lives. Supporters want to put an end to the migration of drinkers from Connecticut -- where bars close at 2 -- into such border communities as Port Chester and Lewisboro, where the police say they have problems with vandalism, rowdiness and traffic accidents. 
 Opponents say that closing bars two hours earlier will not only hurt the economy but also put more drinkers on the road. They argue that Westchester drinkers will either begin their evening of drinking outside the county or leave Westchester when the bars close and drive to the Bronx, Rockland or Putnam. Then, the argument goes, they will drive back through Westchester even later than usual, possibly more inebriated.
Last year, the County Board of Legislators voted for a resolution calling for the earlier closing. But the effort was blocked by the now defunct County Alcohol Beverage Control Board, which critics said favored the tavern industry.
But the political climate changed earlier this year, when Gov. George E. Pataki eliminated funds for the board, and decision-making authority on liquor sales was transferred to the State Liquor Authority. Anthony Casale, chairman of the three-man authority, said he would not comment on the situation in Westchester because there was no formal resolution before the State Liquor Authority. But he has said in the past that he considers closing time a local option and described himself to Gannett Suburban Newspapers as "a home-rule guy from way back."
Several municipalities are among those supporting the earlier closing time. The village hardest hit is Port Chester, where the police say that southbound Boston Post Road at 1:30 A.M. looks as if it were rush hour as people from Greenwich stream into the county. The Police Department's 1994 statistics showed that 97 of its 219 arrests for driving while intoxicated were made between 2 and 6 A.M. About one fourth of all accidents and property damage also occur during those hours. At least half of those arrested were Connecticut drivers, Capt. Joseph Ferretti of the Port Chester Police said.
"They are rushing over here to drink and then rushing home, going through our residential streets," said Mayor Christine Korff of Port Chester. "You're spending so much municipal money in order to allow people to drink between 2 and 4 A.M. You have to balance your resources."
The town of Lewisboro shares a long border with the Connecticut towns of Ridgefield, Wilton and New Canaan. Dr. Leslie N. Simon, the Supervisor of Lewisboro, said that the town and the neighboring communities of North Castle, Pound Ridge and Bedford, were experiencing the same type of problems as Port Chester.
"It's a diversion of manpower," Dr. Simon said. "Not only are police dealing with accidents, but we have a volunteer fire department, and these guys are fast asleep in the middle of the night, then they get a call and go out to another accident. Why do people have to drink in a bar from 2 A.M. to 4 A.M.? It would seem to me those couple of hours in the middle of the night don't make any sense."
The municipalities of Bedford, Harrison, Larchmont, the village of Mamaroneck, Mount Kisco, Mount Vernon, the town of Ossining, , Port Chester, Rye Town, Somers and Yonkers have all passed resolutions calling for earlier bar closing in Westchester.
The Westchester chapter of Mothers Against Drunk Driving would also like to see the earlier closing. "We are committed to seeing this through," said Barbara Spuehler, president of the chapter. "We feel it will cut down on drunken drivers being out on the road. But the basic bottom line is money. The bar owners are going to lose money. We, on the other hand, want to save lives."
Recently the Westchester chapter held a candlelight vigil for victims of drunken driving. Despite the groundswell in favor of a rollback, there is strong opposition to the change, and much of it is in the County Board of Legislators. Thomas J. Abinanti, Democrat of Greenburgh, while acknowledging the problems faced by the border communities, said that an earlier closing was not a solution.
"If we close Westchester at 2 A.M., then our people are going to get on the road," Mr. Abinanti said. "You are not going to change people and make them stop drinking earlier. You are going to move them. Let's say you have people who are accustomed to hanging out at their local bar until 2:30 A.M. Well, if they can't do that, they will go to the Bronx, leave there at 2:30 A.M., and now they are driving home at 3:15 A.M. through our communities. Where they may have had a short walk, or at worse a short drive, now they are driving on highways, in strange neighborhoods and traveling long distances, so what have we accomplished?"
Earnest D. Davis, Democrat of Mount Vernon, chairman of the Board's Legislative Committee and soon to take office as Mayor of Mount Vernon, echoed those comments. "I'm not personally convinced that closing bars at 2 A.M. would stop people drinking," he said. "I think rather that you'd see more transportation during hours you don't want. I think people will just go farther and farther."
Mr. Davis referred to the resolution as feel-good legislation. He said that younger people often didn't go out for the evening until 11 P.M. He also said he feared the move would lead to underground after-hours clubs. Such clubs would be unregulated, would provide no tax revenues and would be potentially dangerous, he said.
Mr. Abinanti and Mr. Davis suggested that education and stricter enforcement of laws would better solve the problems of drunken driving. Mr. Abinanti also suggested that closing bars at 2 A.M. discriminated against shift workers, like the police, doctors and nurses. "What about the correction officers who work until midnight?" he said. "They have a right to go out. Even if it's just a few people, who are we to say they should be deprived of that right?"
Captain Ferretti said that such an argument defied a reasonable answer. "I don't see the doctors, nurses and police officers in Connecticut complaining that they work until 2 A.M. and they have no place to drink," Captain Ferretti said. "We're not trying to bring back prohibition, but I don't see a need to be out drinking after 2 A.M., and I don't see why 2 A.M. in Connecticut should be the start-off point for drinking in Westchester." The resolution is still in the Legislative Committee. If the full Board of Legislators approves the resolution, it will then be required to hold a public hearing, and the State Liquor Authority would be asked to consider the matter.
County Legislator Paul J. Noto, a Republican-Conservative who represents Port Chester and parts of Harrison, Rye Town and Mamaroneck, said: "I think this is one of those cases of special interests versus the public interest. Certainly, people are profiting from the 4 A.M. closing, but that's not as persuasive an argument as the public safety argument. One result of this is that fewer people would be drinking and driving after 2 A.M. I don't know how people can argue that that's not a good public policy."

HEADLINE: Union Made

BYLINE: By Maurice Isserman; Maurice Isserman, a professor of history at Hamilton College, is writing a biography of Michael Harrington.

 BODY:

GASTONIA 1929
The Story of the Loray Mill Strike.
By John A. Salmond.
Illustrated. 226 pp. Chapel Hill:
University of North Carolina Press. $24.95.
THE 1920's were grim years for organized labor -- with the possible exception of the 1980's, the worst in this century. Saddled with inept leaders, helpless in the face of a sophisticated antiunion campaign by employers, divided internally along racial, ethnic and political lines, the American Federation of Labor (A.F.L.) dithered and floundered, all the while hemorrhaging members. 
 Nowhere were prospects grimmer for the labor movement than in the Southern textile industry, as John A. Salmond, a professor of history at La Trobe University in Australia, suggests in his briskly told study, "Gastonia 1929." At the start of the decade, tens of thousands of workers in the Piedmont region had joined the A.F.L.'s United Textile Workers. But labor militancy soon collapsed in the face of employer intransigence, the violent opposition of police, state militias and vigilantes, and a severe economic downturn.
Textile employers cut costs with what workers called "stretch-out" tactics, increasing the pace of work and the rigor of supervision while substituting piecework for regular wages. In the Loray Mill in Gastonia, N.C., the largest textile mill in the South, wages fell 25 to 50 percent in the late 1920's.
Across the Carolinas in the spring of 1929, thousands of desperate textile workers finally rebelled in spontaneous and short-lived strikes little noticed outside the immediate region. In terms of public attention, Gastonia proved the exception. Not that the strike at the Loray Mill was notably more successful; begun on April 1, it effectively collapsed by midmonth. What made it different was the fact that hundreds of native-born white Southerners were willing to accept leadership from the Communist Party-led National Textile Workers Union. Thus, despite the brevity of the strike, Gastonia took on mythic proportions in subsequent years -- depending on your point of view, either as the symbol of left-wing attempts to subvert the "Southern way of life" or as the welcome harbinger of the radical ferment of the 1930's.
Mr. Salmond denies that he is offering any "overarching thesis" in his book. A "well-told story," he declares in his preface, "has a justification of its own." Yet implicit throughout "Gastonia 1929" is the counterfactual proposition that had someone other than the Communists played the leading role in the strike -- some group equally dedicated and self-sacrificing, but shrewder, less burdened by dogma and more sensitive to local mores -- then Gastonia might have proved a triumph rather than a tragedy.
According to Mr. Salmond, "There is no doubt that the constant emphasis on the alien, menacing nature" of the National Textile Workers Union organizers, "the threat that they posed to basic traditions and values, did contribute to the growing climate of violence in Gaston County and gave sanction to the violent incidents that did occur."
The violence included police assaults on picket lines, vigilante attacks on the union's headquarters and, finally, the gunning down of Ella May Wiggins, a millworker and mother of nine, and the balladeer of the Gastonia strike. There was also a shoot-out between armed strikers and deputy sheriffs that resulted in the death of Gastonia's chief of police and the subsequent arrest of dozens of union supporters and organizers for conspiracy. In the ensuing trials, union leaders were sentenced to prison terms of up to 20 years; Ella May Wiggins's accused killers, on the other hand, were acquitted by a local jury after less than 30 minutes' deliberation.
THE Communists who came to Gastonia in 1929 brought with them more than their share of ideological delusions and organizational shortcomings -- their celebration of the Soviet Union, their addiction to inflammatory revolutionary rhetoric, their self-proclaimed atheism (though also, it should be remembered, their equally unpopular commitment to racial equality). But was any other outcome to the strike possible? The subsequent record of unremitting failure racked up by the A.F.L., and later by the Congress of Industrial Organizations (C.I.O.), suggests otherwise. Gastonia's strikers faced overwhelming odds; the fact that they were willing to risk livelihoods and lives -- under whatever fallible leadership presented itself to them at the time -- stands only to their credit.

HEADLINE: Bilingualism Enhances Our Competitiveness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re letters on bilingual education (Dec. 5, 7):
Spanish-speaking citizens are the fastest-growing minority group in this country, and by the year 2000 are expected to be the largest. 
 The short-term effects of English-only legislation can therefore be expected to be problematic, especially in emergency situations when warnings of dangerous conditions would go unnoticed by people who do not understand English.
Moreover, people unable to obtain bilingual services may fail to get immunizations against contagious diseases to seek essential medical attention, further endangering public health. My Republican colleagues tout integration and nationalism yet systematically chip away at the programs that would help immigrant and other foreign-language communities enjoy that reality.
Multilingualism is a tremendous resource to the United States because it permits improved communications and cross-cultural understanding.
Conversely, English-only measures undermine the economic competitiveness of the United States as well as represent an unwarranted governmental restriction on self-expression.
 
NYDIA M. VELAZQUEZ
Member of Congress
12th District, New York
Washington, Dec. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: Refugees Returning To Bosnia

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: VELIKA KLADUSA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Some were so afraid that they dared not even look at the road in front of them. Still, the 750 refugees slowly began to cross into Bosnia, their homeland.
Behind them was a refugee camp in Croatia that they said was no longer tolerable; forward lay a country where they were hated rebels. 
 These refugees took part in a rebellion here in northwest Bosnia against the Bosnian Government, killing thousands of Government troops, many their own neighbors and family members, and maintaining a semi-independent state for most of the last two years.
While in other parts of Bosnia it was Croats and Serbs who rebelled against the Muslim-led Government, here it was fellow Muslims who took up arms. And though the agreement reached in Dayton, Ohio, last month requires that any of the 1.3 million refugees who wishes to go home be allowed to do so, right now this is the only place in Bosnia where the side in control is permitting substantial numbers of former enemies to come home. The return here began last week and has already brought some 3,000 people from a camp of about 21,000.
Today, refugees moved forward past glowering Bosnian border guards. First a few buses, then the chugging tractors with families perched on them and towing homemade wagons with the families' few possessions.
Finally, the poorest of the refugees came through on horse-drawn carts. They looked worn out and fragile, bundled in blankets and shaking in the freezing fog.
Senad Sakanovic, 24, once a soldier in the rebel army, stood next to his horse, both of them sweating from the effort of a 15-mile journey through the snow-covered mountains from the camp, yet shivering from the biting cold. He said: "The only possible future for all of us is to overcome our differences. We will have to learn how to do that one step at a time."
To help both sides learn reconciliation there are more than a dozen international relief organizations here, including various branches of the United Nations. The Bosnian Government has replaced most of the local military units that fought the rebels here with police officers from other parts of the country.
In addition, the Government is allowing the work of those police officers to be monitored by a unit of 200 police officers comprising Croats, Bosnians and Turks.
Still, the local commander of the United Nations Civilian Police, which has had a post here through most of the war, is skeptical. The commander, Inspector Kurt Bannerhoff, said that as long as the international community is vigilant it will be difficult for officials to act against the returning refugees, but there is probably no way to protect them from revenge at the hand of their neighbors who supported the Government.
"This project is a good idea, maybe it will succeed, but personally I doubt it," he said. "There will be serious problems in the future."
When Yugoslavia began to tear apart in 1991, people in this region here increasingly turned for leadership to the most prominent local citizen, Fikret Abdic.
Mr. Abdic's business combine provided most of the jobs for the approximately 50,000 residents, and though he was convicted of embezzlement in 1987, he became the economic and political strong man. Then he became a warlord.
In 1993 Mr. Abdic accused the Government in Sarajevo of being dominated by Muslim fundamentalists. He declared the way to peace was through political and business deals with the Croatian and Serbian governments and with the local military forces those governments were fostering.
The Bosnian Government disagreed. But in this region most people followed Mr. Abdic, even when he effectively seceded from Bosnia and set about making hugely profitable business alliances with Croats and Serbs and, to protect his remote dominion, initially successful military alliances with them as well.
That turned him and his followers into Muslim rebels against the mostly Muslim Government.
Last August, after the Croatian Government and local Croat militias became Bosnian allies, Bosnian Government forces recaptured the area controlled by Mr. Abdic. People who had fled because they supported the Government returned as victors and Mr. Abdic's supporters fled to the camp in Croatia.
He is now reported by diplomats to be running his remaining businesses from Croatia. But here in Velika Kladusa, and the dozens of surrounding villages, people who four months ago were on opposite sides of the firing line are now faced with the challenge of how to be neighbors again.
Relief workers say so far the reintegration has gone well enough, despite scattered threats by Government supporters and reports that several hundred returning men found themselves almost immediately conscripted into the Government army.
Even so, watching today's group of refugees returning, Fatmira Keseravic, an elderly woman who supported the government, did not sound very forgiving. "Well, if someone has done something wrong, they might have reason to expect trouble," she said.
Husein Sadikovic, 62, who said his son had joined the Abdic army while he supported the Government, predicted that the hostility would be controlled here in town but not in the rural areas.
"In villages it will be much worse," he said. "No government will be able to control that, even with all these international forces here."
That is also the fear of many of the relief workers in the camp, especially, they say, as the mandate of the United Nations is to expire in mid- January and with the question of what responsibility NATO and other foreign forces will exercise over reconciliation efforts still unclear.
But the ultimate responsibility belongs to the people here, said Burhan Tansu, the commander of the Turkish police unit. "My men tell them, sooner or later you will have to live together," he said. "You are a family. We will leave someday, but this is your country."

International aid officials fear they may face retaliation from those who continued to support the Bosnian Government. (Photographs by Mannie Garcia for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Europeans Buy Home PC's At Record Pace

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 10

 BODY:
An avid keyboard player, Mario Tronco paid $2,100 six months ago for a personal computer that he hooks up to a 48-track digital recording system to produce mesmerizing music for his band, Avion Travel. When Mr. Tronco is not composing, his wife uses the computer, a simple I.B.M. clone, for her translation business.
Growing up two decades ago in Caserta, a workaday town outside Naples, the 32-year-old musician attended schools with no computers. 
 "Computers?" The idea made him laugh. "They didn't have central heating," he recalled. But his cousin's 5-year-old son, Nicola, growing up in Caserta today, "turns the family computer on and off, perfectly at ease," Mr. Tronco said.
The bets of Europe's computer industry are riding on the likes of Nicola. With improvement in European economies in the last year or two, sales of personal computers have boomed, growing at rates of 25 percent to 30 percent in each of the first three quarters of this year, after years of erratic growth.
Feeding the boom is a fierce price war, as personal computer makers from Europe, Japan and the United States flood the market with fancier and cheaper machines intended to woo computer-shy Europeans.
The European divisions of American companies are getting their share of the action. Compaq and the International Business Machines Corporation are the No. 1 and No. 2 suppliers, respectively, and Apple Computer, Hewlett-Packard and Dell rank in the top 10.
Europe's manufacturers are struggling hard against the American assault. Siemens Nixdorf and Escom A.G., in which the German industrial giant Siemens A.G. holds a 10 percent stake, have had to cut prices steeply to increase their share of the market. Olivetti of Italy lost $162 million on personal computers last year, and though it is fighting back with a new home computer system called Envision, some industry experts fear it may be the European computer war's first fatality.
What fuels the hopes of PC companies is that far fewer Europeans than Americans own home computers. Nearly 4 in 10 American households have a computer, but Europe is another story. In technology-minded Germany, slightly less than 20 percent of households have a computer, about the same percentage as in Britain. In France, postal authorities gave out small home terminals, called Minitels, virtually free of charge in the 1980's to turn Frenchmen into computer enthusiasts. Yet today, only 15 percent of French households have upgraded to a personal computer.
As the rate of increase in the sale of home computers begins to slow in the United States, the companies that make them are spending millions to convince Europeans that their future, and their children's, should have a computer in it.
They have learned that with computers, as with most other consumer products, the cost of having one is greater in Europe than in the United States. Fewer Europeans than Americans are exposed to computers in schools, and fewer use them at work. More Americans work at home or bring work home from the office than do Europeans, who more passionately defend the line between home and the workplace, according to a recent survey by Inteco, a market-research firm near London.
Europeans, the computer makers have learned, have less access than Americans to the global Internet, and when they do, government telephone monopolies make them pay more for them. And while the market for CD-ROM's is growing apace, Europe's fragmentation into relatively small language groups makes the cost of producing them greater than in the United States.
Over the last two years, I.B.M. has spent millions of dollars overhauling its personal computer division, the C.P. Company, and used television and print ads to get Europeans to try computers. The ads typically show fathers, mothers and children working or entertaining themselves at a home computer screen.
And big manufacturers like I.B.M. and Compaq are banking on brand recognition, hoping that parents who use their products at work will buy the same brand for their children to do their homework. The companies, accustomed to providing big corporations with computer systems, are tailoring new models to home use.
"We used to sell only Ferraris," said Aldo Meneghelli, chief of Compaq's Italian unit in Milan, which is pushing Compaq's Impresario multimedia system. "But you don't sell a Ferrari to someone who's satisfied with a Fiat."
The manufacturers are getting a run for their money. Recently, aggressive competitors like Escom, Hewlett-Packard and Dell have cut prices as much as 20 percent to gain market share. In the third quarter Escom catapulted into third place, from seventh, by acquiring a chain of 200 retail stores in Britain, outside its home German market, then undercutting competitors' prices by about one-third. So many producers are rushing in that some analysts fear a glut in the market.
"These are still quite high-ticket items for every household to have one," said Charles Smulders, who follows the personal computer market for Dataquest in London. "Yes, penetration of the market is higher in the United States, so the opportunity is here in Europe." But, he added, there may always be a gap between the American enthusiasm for computers and that of Europeans.
Apartments in Europe are generally smaller than American homes, with less space available for computers and peripheral equipment. And with computers somewhat more expensive here, their purchase is more heavily tilted toward the wealthy than in the United States. American consumers now spend $1,500 to $3,000 for a typical personal computer system, while prices in Europe generally begin around $2,000 -- a bigger chunk of usually lower salaries than in America.
Moreover, with fewer high-volume discount outlets, Europeans often buy their computer equipment in small retail stores, where operating costs and rent are higher per unit than at the big American discounters. The value-added tax, a kind of sales tax at each stage of production and distribution, adds as much as 20 percent to the cost of a computer.
"It's not just computers, but hi-fi's and television sets, too," said Miles Thistlethwaite, a computer analyst at Inteco. "You simply pay more in Europe."
Cost plays a role in other ways, too. Many CD-ROM's for education or entertainment -- films, encyclopedias or children's educational aids -- are American items produced in English, and the cost of having them translated and sold in relatively small European markets is high. These costs, passed along to the consumer, discourage Europeans from buying them in sufficient quantities to make their production profitable.
Beyond all that, the high cost of telephone calls and on-line services often stifles purchases of computers and modems. The European Commission has proposed directives that demand full market deregulation by Jan. 1, 1998, but with many telephone systems still run by state monopolies for now, service in Europe is costlier than in the United States.
Heiko Schmidt, a 20-year-old economics major at the University of Bonn, logs onto the Internet free of charge through the university's access system. Were he to use the German post office's BTX access ports, he would pay a $15 monthly fee, plus the cost of the call. "Their system is very slow, so you wait hours," he said.
In most countries, on-line access is only available in big cities, requiring those elsewhere to make expensive long-distance calls for access. Mr. Schmitt, for instance, is discouraged from joining Compuserve because the nearest access ports are in Frankfurt and Dusseldorf, 50 to 100 miles away.
Despite the improvement in computer sales, the tempo of market growth slowed in the second and third quarters of this year. But manufacturers hope that the Christmas season will revive home PC sales.
Elio Franci, who operates 15 Arcipelago Sparta computer stores throughout northern Italy, part of Sparta S.p.A., said that the two months of November and December generally accounted for 40 percent of sales. But echoing store owners elsewhere in Europe, he noted signs of a new European economic slowdown -- something that would not bode well for products like home computers.
Others, paradoxically, believe that even a slowdown might provide a sales stimulus, as parents seek to equip their children for an increasingly tight job market.
"Parents think kids need one," Mr. Thistlethwaite of Inteco said. "It makes them more attractive for getting a job. They need skills."

NEW YORK CITY
 
Suspect in Harlem is Identified
The gunman-arsonist who killed himself and seven other people in Harlem was identified by the police as Roland James Smith Jr., a 51-year-old laborer with an arrest record for charges relating to gun possession, war protests and draft dodging. [Page A1.]
As services at the United House of Prayer for All People took place in a makeshift sanctuary in Harlem, questions were raised about the church's role in the planned eviction of the Record Shack store. [B3.]
The motivation behind the Harlem fire may be rooted in another neighborhood quarrel: last year's heated turf war between store owners and illegal vendors. [B3.]
Victory Is Set to Reopen
The oldest theater on 42d Street, the Victory, is to reopen after an $11.4 million restoration, the first stage in the fulfillment of a promise to reclaim all of the street's historic theaters that goes back to the announcement of a major urban renewal plan for the area in 1981. [A1.]
Token Clerk Dies From Injuries
Harry Kaufman, the subway token clerk who suffered devastating burns and lung damage two weeks ago when two men turned his Brooklyn booth into an exploding inferno in a botched robbery that replayed scenes from the movie "Money Train," died at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. [B1.]
All Eyes on a Union Leader
Stanley W. Hill, executive director of New York City's largest and most powerful municipal employees union, is under pressure as never before. In the wake of the defeat of the teachers' contract, all eyes are on Mr. Hill to see whether he can rescue the agreement he negotiated for his union. [B1.]
Behind the Teachers' Vote
Members of the United Federation of Teachers voted down a contract because many said they felt they had nothing to lose. And with the Mayor up for election in two years, many figured they might have something to gain. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
Jews Honor Yitzhak Rabin
Nearly 15,000 Jews crowded into Madison Square Garden to honor the memory of Yitzhak Rabin. The response from American Jews was so great that several thousand people had to be turned away at the arena's doors. [B1.]
The Power of Words
As thousands of New York Jews went to Madison Square Garden to honor Yitzhak Rabin, and as mourners filed past the incinerated shell of Freddy's clothing store in Harlem, a question was raised: are the two communities connected by the same thread of hate? NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B3.]
A Helping Hand in Brooklyn
Two years ago, Gerardo Aponte's life had caved in, and he came to a realization: "If you don't take care of yourself, nobody will." With the help of a vocational training program, he learned the supermarket trade, and now works at a Pathmark in Brooklyn. He credits his success to his family and the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the organizations helped in part by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. [B4.]
An Affinity for 'Makropulos'
"The Makropulos Affair" is an elusive member of the standard operatic repertory, for most a familiar name but not a familiar face. So how odd it is that two of America's leading companies -- in New York and Chicago -- have taken it into their heads to offer Janacek's 1926 stage piece in new productions separated by barely a month. [C11.]
 
REGION
 
Pataki Unveils Welfare Plan
Governor Pataki unveiled a wide-ranging plan to reshape the state's welfare programs by sharply cutting benefits and creating a new system for delivering them. Monthly checks would be set by a simpler formula, localities could play a greater role and, in a potentially contentious proposal, drug testing for recipients might be mandatory. [B5.]
Frigid Weather Hits the Region
The first frigid day of the season hit the New York City area, with strong winds and temperatures dropping to 16 degrees in Central Park. The National Weather Service said the cold weather is expected to remain in the New York area until at least Thursday, when there is a chance of snow. [B5.]
On Living in Connecticut
A large majority of Connecticut residents think the state's living standards have worsened in the last five years and most expect them to continue declining, according to a new survey. [B5.]
4 Killed in Head-On Collision
Four men -- three brothers and a cousin -- were killed in Baldwin, L.I., when their car was hit head-on on the Sunrise Highway, apparently by a drunken driver. [B5.]

HEADLINE: The Wages of Winning;
Social Worker Turned Labor Leader Tries Conciliation

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
For Stanley W. Hill, executive director of New York City's largest and most powerful municipal employees union, this was supposed to be the year to shine.
With the retirement of the charismatic titans who had long dominated municipal labor, Mr. Hill would have his star turn, a long-awaited chance to wrest a generous contract from City Hall and win the adulation of his union's 125,000 members. 
 But that was not to be.
Instead Mr. Hill is under pressure as never before. Thrust into negotiations with a Mayor intent on cutting spending, Mr. Hill agreed to a labor pact that contains no new raises for the first two years of a five-year contract.
And after New York's public school teachers stunned the city by rejecting a similar deal, all eyes are on Mr. Hill to see whether he can rescue the agreement he negotiated for his union, whose members make up more than a third of the city's total municipal work force.
Known as an amiable conciliator, Mr. Hill, a former social worker, is a sharp contrast to the hard-nosed union leaders of the past whose strikes crippled the city. And now more than ever he finds himself on the defensive in trying to sell the agreement he negotiated with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Judging from the hostile welcome he received at a union delegates' meeting one recent evening, that will not be easy. As he entered, 700 municipal hospital workers who filled the back of the auditorium showered him with boos, paper cups, crumpled fliers and cries of "sellout."
They shouted that Mr. Hill had betrayed them not only because their wages would be frozen for two years but because the agreement offers no guarantees of job security for hospital employees while it promises no layoffs for three years to almost all other nonuniformed city workers. The lead heckler was James Butler, president of an 11,000-member hospital workers' local, who said: "He sold us out. He double-crossed us. I think he's holding hands with Giuliani."
Mr. Hill, normally an easygoing, self-effacing man, grabbed the microphone and shouted that he had negotiated the best contract he could -- after the two-year freeze, wages would increase 13 percent in the last three years of the pact.
"I've been fighting for you for years," he thundered at a meeting where union solidarity seemed an oxymoron. "I'm not going to take this." In the crowd, three fistfights erupted between opponents and supporters of the agreement.
The pandemonium notwithstanding, Mr. Hill emerged triumphant that night -- three-fourths of the 350 delegates at the meeting voted to recommend the contract to the rank and file. At least for the time being, he had saved the contract, and his hold on leadership, by doing his homework: he had assiduously courted the leaders of the 56 locals in his union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Despite the delegates' vote, many District Council 37 leaders predict that when the whole membership votes this month, more of them will oppose the agreement than any previous contract in the union's history. And some labor leaders who had predicted only last week that ratification would be a cinch are beginning to say a defeat is possible now that the 90,000-member United Federation of Teachers voted down its contract, 56 percent to 44 percent.
A rejection of the contract could cripple Mr. Hill's hold on power. For Mr. Giuliani, a rejection would undermine a stratagem to buy labor peace until after the 1997 election.
The key to ratification is Mr. Hill, a man known for working 16-hour days and chatting for 20 minutes with every union member he bumps into. On Thursday night, the night the teachers' rejection was announced, he met with four locals to try to sell them on the contract.
Each day, he records a message for a union telephone number that District Council 37 members can call to hear him argue for the accord. He has put out an eight-page newsletter and appeared on union-sponsored radio shows to push the contract.
"The idea of rejection is something I don't want to talk about," he said in an interview. In a candid moment, he acknowledged that what happened with the teachers' contract will make his selling job harder. The sense is that it will embolden many of his members, too, to vote no.
Making Mr. Hill's job more difficult, some people in the union, whose members are largely black and Hispanic, complain that he has become too close to Mr. Giuliani, far closer than he was to Mayor David N. Dinkins, whom District Council 37 helped to elect in 1989.
In many ways, Mr. Hill, 59, is different from his predecessor, Victor Gotbaum, the crusty unionist who helped navigate the city through its fiscal crisis in 1975 and selected Mr. Hill to replace him in 1987.
Unlike Mr. Gotbaum, Mr. Hill is considered extremely nice, a characteristic rare in the rough-and-tumble world of labor bargaining. This reputation has caused some members to suggest that he was not tough enough to negotiate a good deal, and that if Mr. Gotbaum had been the lead bargainer, the contract would be significantly better.
But from an office filled with awards and plaques from unions and civil rights groups, Mr. Hill passionately defended his record: "I've brought decent contracts back to my members," he said. "Since Mayor Giuliani is in office, we haven't experienced any layoffs. This contract gives job security to workers in mayoral agencies. We maintained our benefits despite demands for givebacks. And we got an economic package we can build on."
Mr. Hill predicts ratification because of his seven-days-a-week campaigning, because of his careful consensus building within the union, and because many city workers, whose salaries are often just a few steps above the poverty line, are delighted that the contract promises job security at a time of austerity.
Responding to Mr. Butler, Mr. Hill said that Mr. Giuliani had steadfastly refused to grant ironclad job security protections to workers in city hospitals. The Mayor insisted on maintaining flexibility to lay off hospital workers because of anticipated Medicare and Medicaid cuts and his plans to privatize municipal hospitals.
"I didn't sell out Jim Butler," Mr. Hill said. "We're going to continue to fight for job security for hospital workers."
Many days, Mr. Hill serves as a dart board for critics. From the right, business-backed groups attack him for failing to make concessions to improve productivity, making it harder to balance the city's budget over the long term. From the left, some advocates for the poor say he has won too many goodies for city workers, diverting money from the poor.
Such criticism rankles Mr. Hill, who says his years as a city social worker and his volunteer work for a dozen community groups demonstrate that he cares about the poor.
"My whole background and philosophy in life is to help the poor," he said. "Remember, I represent workers who earn on average $25,000. In this tough economy, many of them have to work two or three jobs to make ends meet."
Sandra Feldman, president of the teachers' union, said he cares not just about his members but about the good of the city. "He was a kid who grew up on the city streets, and he really identifies with the people who receive the services his members provide," she said.
What praise there is comes from two quarters. First, his nominal adversaries, City Hall officials, heap praise on him as a tough negotiator, no doubt wanting to convince District Council 37 members that he obtained the best contract he could. Praise comes as well from labor leaders who know how hard it is to negotiate a satisfactory contract during a fiscal crisis, and then sell it to the members.
Barry Feinstein, the retired teamsters leader who upstaged Mr. Hill in the 1991 contract talks, praised Mr. Hill's bargaining, noting that "this was the first time a New York mayor agreed there would be no layoffs for a set time frame."
Mr. Hill asserts he is as tough as the situation calls for, but he admits he favors conciliation over confrontation. That, he said, stems from his growing up black on the Lower East Side, where there were few blacks, making him learn how to get along with people different from him.
"Ironically, dealing with all kinds of people prepared you for leadership," said Mr. Hill, whose father was a truck driver and mechanic.
He also learned from playing basketball, first as a guard at Central Commercial High School, and later at Iona College. "My role on the court taught me communication and consensus building," he said.
Oddly enough, these communication skills are working better with the Republican Mayor than they did with Mr. Dinkins, with whom Mr. Hill repeatedly clashed. He criticized Mr. Dinkins for breaking promises and laying off hundreds of well-paid park workers and replacing them with lower-paid employees.
He is kinder to the current Mayor, and praised his budget for providing "balance, fairness and hope," adding, "Once you negotiate with him, he keeps his word."
Relations are so solid with the Mayor that District Council 37 bought two $1,000 tickets to a Giuliani fund-raising dinner and invited him to speak at a union convention.
Mr. Hill defends his ties to the Mayor, saying labor leaders need to maintain good relations with the city's most powerful man. But he says he will continue battling the Mayor in many areas, like the plans to privatize hospitals. And like Ms. Feldman, he criticized Mr. Giuliani's push to raise his own salary: "The timing was very bad because it comes when I have to sell a contract with two zeroes to my members."
The way political analysts see it, Mr. Giuliani has wooed Mr. Hill with the aim of attracting black supporters and perhaps neutralizing District Council 37's political clout in the 1997 mayoral race.
Norman Adler, a political consultant to the union, explained their closeness this way: "There's a white Republican mayor and a black Democratic union leader. It's like two sticks. One leans left and one leans right, and they both get to stand up a long time."
