HEADLINE: Speaker Seeks Ethics Inquiry Into Pataki Inaugural Group

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 11

 BODY:
The Speaker of the State Assembly ordered two legislative committees today to investigate whether any laws were broken by the private corporation that financed Gov. George E. Pataki's inauguration, setting up a confrontation between the Democratic Assembly and the Republican Governor.
Saying that the corporation operated under a "cloak of secrecy," Speaker Sheldon Silver told the committees to use their powers to subpoena records and hold public hearings to find out whether the corporation violated state election or ethics laws when it raised more than $500,000 for Mr. Pataki's inaugural events. Mr. Silver estimated that the corporation, N.Y. Inaugural '95, raised as much as $1.4 million. 
 Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said he was particularly interested in finding out why Mr. Pataki's aides decided to keep the names of inaugural contributors private after having initially promised to publicly disclose the names. Mr. Pataki's aides also broke a pledge to keep donations to the inaugural corporation within state campaign contribution limits.
"At the outset, he said it would all be disclosed," Mr. Silver said of the Governor. "Now he's saying there is no disclosure. It looks like he's hiding something. And we have a right to find out what he's hiding."
The Governor's inaugural corporation was the subject of an article in The New York Times last month that described how the corporation accepted at least five corporate contributions that were in excess of the state's $5,000 campaign contribution limit on private companies. The article also said that the corporation gave $25,000 to the New York State Republican Committee.
Mr. Silver also ordered the two committees, Governmental Operations and Elections, to investigate the activities of a separate corporation, N.Y. Transition '95, which helped finance Mr. Pataki's transition. And he asked the Assembly Committee on Oversight, Analysis and Investigations to help in the inquiries.
The Assembly's investigations come on the eve of the 1996 election season, when the Democrats will try to retain their 94-56 advantage over the Republicans in the lower house. In preparation for what are expected to be well-financed Republican challenges in dozens of districts, the Democrats have been developing a strategy to attack the ethics of the Republicans in general and the Pataki administration in particular.
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications, said the inaugural corporation did not violate any laws. Referring to Mr. Silver, she said, "He seems to have confused his role of Speaker with his role as the Democratic political operative. Past Democratic speakers have been able to put aside partisan politics. It's unfortunate that he can't."
Mr. Pataki's top campaign fund-raising officials created N.Y. Inaugural '95, a for-profit corporation, to raise money for three days of inaugural events that began on Dec. 31.
Robert E. Boyle, who had been Mr. Pataki's campaign treasurer, became treasurer of the corporation. Charles A. Gargano, who had been Mr. Pataki's chief campaign fund-raiser, became chairman of a committee that organized inaugural events, including a $1,000 per person inaugural fund-raising dinner held on Dec. 6, 1994.
Mr. Boyle is now president of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, and Mr. Gargano is the State Commissioner for Economic Development. When the corporation was created, Mr. Pataki's aides said that it would voluntarily hold all contributors to state campaign finance limits and would disclose the names of all donors.
But last month, in response to inquiries from The Times, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, announced that the corporation had decided not to disclose the names of contributors so that Mr. Pataki and his aides would not know who had helped on the inauguration. In that way, Ms. Mucha said, administration officials would not feel obligated to help inaugural contributors.
Many of the companies and individuals who contributed or raised money for the inauguration have business with the state, whether as regulated companies or as vendors holding state contracts.
While many other governors and presidents have raised money privately to finance inaugurations, they have usually disclosed the names of contributors. In several states, including Massachusetts, inaugural committees are required to follow state campaign finance rules.
That is not the case in New York, where N.Y. Inaugural '95 is under no legal obligation to release the names of its contributors. State Senator Richard A. Dollinger, a Rochester Democrat, has proposed legislation that would require inaugural committees to comply with state election laws, which would include disclosing the names of contributors.
Mr. Silver asked the investigating committees to give him their final reports by March 1.

HEADLINE: Pataki's Plan to Dismantle Lilco Is Criticized at a Public Hearing

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to break up the Long Island Lighting Company and cut electric rates on the Island by 12 percent drew criticism at a public hearing last night, particularly from workers at the utility concerned about the fate of the company.
Under the Pataki plan, Lilco would sell its gas business and power plants to private companies, and the Long Island Power Authority would buy the Lilco transmission and distribution system. The state would issue more than $4.5 billion in tax-free bonds so it could pay its debt on the defunct Shoreham nuclear plant. 
 At the hearing, the audience applauded when a Lilco gas worker talked about the need to maintain reliability if the gas system was sold. When he likened Lilco workers to a family, he drew more applause.
In an effort to assure the employees that the plan would protect them, James F. Gill, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, said, "I'm not the enemy."
Joseph W. McDonald, a vice president of Lilco, said the company would not to take a position on the plan tonight.
"We are waiting to get more information from LIPA so we can evaluate their proposal," he said. "We need to have the assumptions they used so we can see if this plan achieves the Governor's objectives."
Earlier today, the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, endorsed the plan.
"Compared with previous proposals, this is, by far, our best chance of experiencing real rate cuts in the future, and removing Lilco's choke hold on local residents and business," Mr. Gulotta said.
Mr. Gulotta said that the Pataki plan made it clear that Nassau residents would be compensated for the overassessment of the former Shoreham nuclear plant by Suffolk County. Mr. Kessel's plan called for forgiving the Suffolk debt.
Suffolk owes Lilco $83 million for the overassessment, and faces an additional payment of more than $400 million in a pending case.
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, is still reviewing the plan, a spokesman said.
Mr. Gulotta said the plan would protect Lilco employees by assuring them jobs with Lilco's successors. But at news conference today, leaders of two electrical workers union locals representing 3,600 Lilco employees attacked the plan, saying that it does not protect jobs and will damage Long Island's economy.

HEADLINE: Panel Faults Education Of Disabled

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
Hoping to set in motion the biggest effort in New York City's history to change how students in special education are treated, an independent panel yesterday recommended taking tens of thousands of children now in separate schools or classrooms and returning them to regular schools, where they would receive extra help.
While the framework of recommended changes was announced last May, the final report outlines in detail the legal and financial dimensions of making the changes. The proposal, by a panel of New York University educators appointed by the Board of Education, does not offer a cost estimate, but an official familiar with the report said it could be $100 million during the three to five years that it would take for the changes. Most of the money would be used to train teachers. 
 The recommendations will test the resolve of political leaders to bring about changes in what is widely regarded as a bloated and costly special-education bureaucracy. "In the long run, it will turn out to be more economical, but there's going to have to be an expenditure up front," said Carol Gresser, the Board of Education president. "It's a far-reaching report."
Both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, have called for reform in special education. Yesterday, Peter J. Powers, the First Deputy Mayor, described the plan as a "creative but feasible way" to stem the growing population of special education students, who now number more than 130,000.
"We think it's a good proposal," Mr. Powers said. "It's one that warrants further study by the board. It's certainly worthy of them trying to take it to the next step. You've got to look at the endgame. The endgame is to do the best job of educating children who need it, and if you can keep children mainstreamed that is a good thing."
The system now consumes more than 22 cents of every education dollar in New York City, includes one quarter of all school employees and funnels a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic boys into dead-end, segregated classrooms. About 60 percent of children classified in special education are segregated, three times the national average.
Susan Amlung, a spokesman for the United Federation of Teachers, said the high expense of the plan "might, in fact, be its death knell." Much of the plan hinges on changes in state financing formulas that currently reward schools for placing mildly and moderately handicapped children in special education.
The plan also recommends negotiating a state waiver to maintain the system's current spending for at least five years. The report also calls for extra money to train teachers and school staffs to handle an infusion of special education students.
"Reform is rarely cheap," the report's authors wrote. "Systemic reform of the magnitude that we propose will help to enrich students' lives but is unlikely to save money."
The report envisions a system that would shift special-education money to regular schools, which would use that money for extra teachers and aides to help children with mild and moderate disabilities. The special-education bureaucracy would shrink to serve only the most severely handicapped children.
Most special education students in the system are not deaf, blind or classified with any other readily defined disability. Instead, 70 percent are labeled "learning disabled" or "emotionally handicapped," terms many academics say are loosely applied and provide cover for a teacher who wants to get rid of a troublesome student. Once referred to special education, students almost never return to regular education.
The panel has added a section in the report on protecting the most severely disabled children, including the autistic, blind and multiply handicapped, representing about 5 percent of special education children. Efforts to redesign the system have been fiercely opposed by a litigious group of parents of these children.
The plan has received cautious support from the teachers' union and parent and student advocates who have resisted previous attempts at reorganizing special education.

HEADLINE: Orders for Computer Chips Fall Along With Book-to-Bill Ratio

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 11

 BODY:
New orders for computer chips declined in November, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today, indicating that demand could be slowing.
The trade group's book-to-bill ratio, a closely watched gauge of demand for computer chips, fell to 1.14 in November from 1.18 in October. 
 The ratio had been expected to decline slightly as sales of some computers slowed and inventories rose before the holiday sales season.
The ratio measures the strength of the chip industry in North America by comparing the value of new orders to the value of chips shipped each month. A ratio of 1.14 means that for every $100 in orders shipped by chip makers, they received $114 in new orders.
The ratio is computed using a three-month moving average and is seasonally adjusted. A ratio higher than 1 means that the market is expanding.
Orders in November fell 1.5 percent from October, to $5.03 billion from $5.11 billion. Orders were up 54 percent from the $3.27 billion reported for November 1994.
Shipments in the month rose 2.2 percent from October, to $4.41 billion. Shipments in November were up 43 percent from a year earlier.
The worldwide market for computer chips is expected to increase 26 percent in 1996, a slower rate than the 44 percent increase expected for this year, the trade group said.
The industry will see sales rise to $185.1 billion next year from an expected $146.4 billion this year, according to World Semiconductor Trade Statistics, which gathers the data for the semiconductor association.
The North American market is expected to increase 40 percent, to $47.1 billion in 1995 from $33.5 billion last year.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 444 words

HEADLINE: Budget Games

 BODY:
Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican Party, thinks he has found a rhetorical device to fend off White House attacks on the G.O.P.'s proposed cuts in Medicare. People should focus, he says, not only on how much the two sides want to cut but on how much each wants to spend. The G.O.P. wants to spend $1.65 trillion over the next seven years. The White House would spend $1.68 trillion. Mr. Barbour concludes that the difference -- $30 billion or about 2 percent -- is too small to matter and that President Clinton's vicious attacks on the Republican plan amount to demagoguery.
Mr. Clinton has wrongly ridiculed the G.O.P. for proposing modest hikes in subsidized premiums. But Mr. Barbour's rhetorical thrust is little better. The two plans differ by amounts that the $30 billion figure does not begin to capture. 
 Consider the following example. The White House and Republicans agree to spend the same amount, say $300 billion, on Medicare in 2002. But they disagree now much Medicare will cost in that year under current law. The Republicans estimate Medicare will cost $500 billion. The White House estimates $400 billion. Despite Mr. Barbour's contention that the two plans are the same because they will spend the same, the Republicans would have to cut Medicare by twice what the White House would cut to hit the common target.
These very different economic projections, in turn, would require quite different cost-cutting strategies. Once those policies are in place, they would hit hospitals, physicians and enrollees no matter whose projections turn out to be more accurate. Indeed, the G.O.P.'s plan would cut payments to hospitals and physicians by about $100 billion more than the White House's would.
Can the gap between the two plans be bridged in time to reach a budget agreement this year? A compromise is within reach. Mr. Clinton could, for example, agree to the G.O.P. plan to raise premiums by about $50 billion. The Republicans, in turn, could agree to cut hospital and physician payments less -- with a "look-back" procedure that would increase those cuts if budget targets were exceeded.
The Congressional Budget Office announced yesterday that budget-cutting can be about $135 billion less onerous than previously estimated in order to reach balance in seven years. Most of the windfall ought to be used to save Medicaid, food stamps and tax credits. Some could also be used to bring the White House and G.O.P. together on Medicare.
The fight over Medicare is not, as Mr. Barbour argues, over scraps. But Congress and the White House are unlikely to find compromise if one side insists the differences do not exist.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Officials' Remarks Curb Gain in Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday, as comments by Federal Reserve officials held back buying.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 4/32 , to 11115/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.05 percent on Friday. 
 Many market participants chose not to take any large positions amid budget talks in Washington and ahead of a policy meeting of the Federal Reserve next Tuesday.
Gains yesterday were limited by comments from two Fed officials, which dampened expectations that the Fed will lower short-term interest rates this month or next. A Fed governor, Edward W. Kelley Jr., in an interview with the Dow Jones news service, said he thought the economy was very strong.
But another Fed governor, Susan Phillips, told reporters yesterday afternoon that "the U.S. is starting to experience some firming of wages, but that it is not pronounced."
With Fed governors giving mixed opinions, Doug Bourtnick, a fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that "there is nothing to hang your hat on."
In addition, traders and analysts were awaiting a number of important economic reports this week. Today the Government is scheduled to release its Producer Price Index for November. In October, producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent, and analysts expect the November index will show an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent.
Tomorrow the market will get a glimps of retail sales and on Thursday the Government will report on inflation at the consumer level in November.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Franicsco, said trading was quiet yesterday, with the market waiting for some news from Washington about a budget accord. "We've gotten some encouraging reports recently, but the market was not trading on any fundamentals today," he said. "Right now it is only on the lookout for a Fed easing or a budget deal."
A number of short-sellers sought to cover positions ahead of the producer prices report, Mr. Hale noted. A short-seller sells a borrowed security hoping to buy it back at a lower price, and thus make a profit. But if prices rise, instead of fall -- which is what has tended to happen after recent weaker-than-expected producer price reports -- the seller must still buy back securities to limit his losses.
At the Treasury's weekly sale of new three- and six-month bills, rates were up slightly, with solid retail demand. The average discount rate rose one basis point, to 5.30 percent for the three-month bill and 5.20 percent for the six-month bill. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
While supply is thin this week with only bills available, the Treasury does plan to announce tomorrow the size of next week's auctions of two- and five-year notes. Mr. Hale expects the Treasury to increase the amounts of the auctions to get a leg up on the huge jump in maturing issues expected next year.
Following are the results of yesterday's three- and six-month Treasury bill auctions:

HEADLINE: Staff Cuts at Sizzler

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Sizzler International announced today that it was reducing its administrative staff by 30 percent, or 72 workers, in a revamping intended to save $5 million a year. The low-price restaurant chain, which grew rapidly for decades, has suffered in the 1990's, in part because of weakness in the California economy and locations too close together. The company operates or licenses 592 Sizzler restaurants worldwide; 91 Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants and one Italian Oven restaurant in Australia, and seven Buffalo Ranch restaurants in the United States.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Money's Funny Ways

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Everybody with enough sense to look over his shoulder when walking down a dark alley is now familiar with the stock market's spooky response to news that a lot of human beings have been fired in another industrial "downsizing."
The stock market booms. 
 From this you might sensibly reason that a new high for the Dow Jones is terrible news. (More people out of work, more unpayable consumer debt, fewer buyers for the products of capitalism's great engines.)
So why are rises in stock-market indicators always treated as good news? Television's network anchors faithfully announce each day's Dow Jones average as though it told us something important. What this might be is seldom explained. On banner days, though, when the Dow Jones breaks 3,000, or 4,000, or 5,000, the anchor always manages to sound as though something splendid has occurred.
Here is one of the mysteries of economics which explain why it used to be called "the dismal science" before governments and newspapers began taking economists as seriously as economists took themselves. The mystery in this case is one of those "plain-as-the-nose-on-your-face" exercises.
Wherever you go nowadays you meet people worried about their jobs. Economists of course don't care much for the testimony of people. "Anecdotal evidence," they call it, suggesting it is worthless listening to mere people.
However, there are polls -- serious, scholarly, scientific polls free of odious anecdotal taint -- and they tell the same story: people fearful, unable to keep up, discouraged about the future.
Then there are statistics. Everybody loves statistics. The statistics show people, in fact, are not keeping up. What's plain as the nose on your face is that the economy is in the dumps.
So why are these ever-rising market averages hailed as good news? The market would seem to be cheering about another 10,000, or 15,000, or 25,000 workers being fired by yet another great American corporation.
It's all right for markets to cheer the advance of human misery. Markets are supposed to be tough guys, steel-whiskered guys, take-no-prisoners guys. It takes insouciance, though, for most of us to applaud the Dow's latest leap when it so obviously honors another mass firing.
You hear Tom, Dan or Peter tell of another great Dow day in Wall Street, and it's tempting to not cheer at all, but to think, "By George, they might get me in the next batch."
Ah, the mysteries of economics . . .
For instance, do these Washington budget-balancers really believe they can plan seven years ahead with any chance of not being 10,000 percent off their estimates when Time and Chance doth get through happenething to us all?
You and I, friend, may not be Methuselahs, but we have seen enough to know that seven years will almost always produce so many unanticipatable changes that this talk of seven-year budget-balancing schemes must be childishly innocent.
How long did it take for the oil embargoes to destroy the old dollar and produce the tremendous inflation that changed the character of American economic life? It was done in a couple of brutal years. The amazing Reagan budget deficit that haunts us still was designed and adopted in a single Congress.
These preposterous economic upheavals happen constantly. Expecting the preposterous to restrain itself from happening for the next seven years is surely asking a lot of whimsical Miss Destiny.
It's a lively possibility, in fact, that a single year or two may see the public passion for budget-balancing run out of steam as voters go back to asking their statesmen, "What have you done for me lately?" In the enduring words of Fats Waller, "One never knows, do one?"
Another mystery: All Americans supposedly yearn to scalp and pickle any politician who dares raise taxes. So would somebody please explain the readiness of politicians to slather public money on professional sports-team owners?
These birds of prey are ever ready to move their sweaty assets wherever a fresh batch of rubes is ready to empty the treasury for the joy of having professional jocks in town. Only the wretched, perhaps, deserve to be kept away from the booty.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Big Labor Can Only Dream of Higher Wages

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Dec. 7 news article on John J. Sweeney, the new president of the A.F.L-C.I.O.: 
 Mr. Sweeney went before 400 business executives to plead for a "social compact" between America's corporations and workers. Mr. Sweeney suggests that corporations voluntarily raise workers' wages. Does he really think any would do that? In this highly competitive market economy, it would be corporate suicide. Who will volunteer to be the first to jump overboard?
Mr. Sweeney talks about building bridges between labor and management. While French workers man the barricades, Mr. Sweeney begs at the corporate altar. Does he really think it will make a difference?
Mr. Sweeney is the former president of the Service Employees International Union. He now boasts of how his low-paid janitors blocked a bridge in Washington in September to protest low wages. That's like the captain of the Titanic boasting of his good aim. His aides say he is going to focus on the growing wage gap. It would be interesting to know the gap between his wage and that of the janitors.
 
WILLIAM COMISKEY
Edina, Minn., Dec. 8, 1995

HEADLINE: New York's SoHo Is on the Verge of Losing Its Cultural Flavor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While the rest of "America Realizes the Arts Attract Tourists" (Arts pages, Dec. 5), New York presumably has a leg up on other cities "because culture has always been central to its image." You are wrong that "no one needs to promote SoHo." Perhaps not to the rest of the world, but someone needs to remind New York City not to look a gift horse in the mouth. 
 SoHo, a cultural asset, is close to losing what makes SoHo what it is.
SoHo was a gift to the city. Artists' "sweat equity" transformed this derelict neighborhood into a vibrant part of the city's economy and a world-class example of urban renewal at its best.
Now the neighborhood is under siege. Mall retailers are rapidly replacing galleries and other arts-related businesses, and by night this once-quiet residential neighborhood is being mindlessly transformed into a noisy bar strip for Generation X.
Meantime, the City Planning Commission contemplates a zoning change that would facilitate this transformation. SoHo's resource has been its artist residents. Rather than reward artists for their pioneering efforts, the city plans to strip away their sweat-equity investment in SoHo with a regulation that would severely devalue their improvements.
If the city continues to turn a blind eye to this cultural asset and to its artist residents, tourists will awaken to the fact that they don't have to travel to SoHo to find the same mall shopping and bar strips they have at home. Where goes the art, go the tourists.
 
MARIE DORMUTH
SEAN SWEENEY
New York, Dec. 8, 1995
The writers represent, respectively, the Lower Manhattan Loft Tenants Association and the SoHo Alliance.

HEADLINE: Panama Doesn't Need U.S. Forces to Remain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Dec. 4 news article suggests that continued occupation of Panamanian territory by United States military forces after the year 2000 would be beneficial to that country's economic and political stability. A recent University of Panama debate showed such thinking to be misguided. 
 University economists, using World Bank and United States Southern Command data, observed that the $300 million the United States military "pumps" into Panama's economy amounts to less than 5 percent of the national gross domestic product. This is hardly an indispensable contribution, particularly since the bases constitute such a poor use of valuable land area.
The Colon Free Zone, an import-export facility run by Panama within the canal area, occupies less than 1 percent of the land area occupied by the U.S. military yet generates 6 percent of G.D.P. The much-touted job opportunities the Southern Command provides were also shown to be minuscule: the bases provide 1 percent of formal sector employment.
You do not mention the costs of military occupation, such as the billions of dollars in environmental damage resulting from hazardous wastes and lethal weaponry dumped throughout canal defense sites over the past 50 years. It is also worth noting that the cost to Panama of the Bush-Noriega "divorce" exceeded $2.5 billion, more than seven years' worth of U.S.military "investment."
It is the North American military presence that destabilizes Panama's political structure. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's long collaboration with United States military and Central Intelligence Agency officials allowed him to brutalize civil institutions; his fall led to the death of perhaps thousands of Panamanians at the hands of United States forces.
The University of Panama debates showed no lack of dedicated individuals and organizations capable of articulating a rational development plan, free of military influence. The Panamanian people are not dependent children; further United States military occupation of their country impedes their aspirations to sovereignty and economic development.
 
KURT DILLON
BEATRICE STERN
Newburgh, N.Y., Dec. 6, 1995

HEADLINE: Arming Bosnians Adds to Violence

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re " 'Neutrality' Won't Protect Our Troops" (Op-Ed, Dec. 7): 
 Richard N. Perle, former Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration and adviser to the Bosnian delegation at the Balkan peace talks, argues that the United States must "arm and train the Bosnians so that American forces can be honorably withdrawn in a year."
The Dayton peace agreement partitions Bosnia 49 percent-51 percent between a Serbian Republic and Muslim-Croat Federation. By implication, Mr. Perle would arm only the Muslim-Croat Federation.
Arming this half of the partitioned nation would provoke an immediate response in the other half, which would seek support from other Slavs, including Russia.
It would be impossible to create a balance that both sides would recognize as equitable and stable.
A 600-year history of instability and conflict in the region, capped by the barbaric savagery of the last four years, guarantee that more arms on both sides would not improve future prospects for peace.
The best that can be hoped for if more arms are introduced is an unstable armed truce in which the parties face each other across the zones of separation to be established and patrolled by NATO forces.
Since a one-year NATO presence cannot possibly resolve the fundamental political, ethnic, economic, religious and historic problems that drive the conflicts in Bosnia, withdrawal of these forces will unleash renewed violence at even higher levels of destructive force with new weapons.
Mr. Perle is correct to decry the fact that the planned NATO occupation of Bosnia will not bring enduring peace, but to add to the problems there by fomenting an arms race that will set the stage for even more violence would be the wrong thing to do.
 
EUGENE J. CARROLL JR.
Rear Adm., U.S. Navy (Ret.)
Deputy Director
Center for Defense Information
Washington, Dec. 7, 1995

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bill limiting shareholder suits is seen as only incremental change.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
PEOPLE in Washington describe securities legislation now on President Clinton's desk as a radical change that should deter frivolous lawsuits by investors who in the past have won billions of dollars from companies they say defrauded them.
But after analyzing the bill, the product of a four-year effort that brokerage houses pushed for, with major accounting firms, insurers and high-technology companies, many on Wall Street say that the changes are simply incremental. 
 The view on Wall Street is that the number of class-action suits will probably diminish over time. And while the bill is meant to encourage companies to divulge more information, Wall Street considers its application very limited. The bill's clearest effect is likely to be on the Big Six accounting firms, whose liability in class-action suits has been sharply reduced. They are expected to feel freer to take on some customers they formerly shunned.
The bill is a "modest improvement over current law," said Richard F. Ziegler, a securities lawyer with the firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. "But it is not worth the ballyhoo that has accompanied it."
Stuart Kaswell, general counsel for the Securities Industry Association, characterized the legislation as a "thoughtful and modest step forward for investors, consumers and the economy as a whole." He said it was essentially "an attempt to curtail frivolous suits by lawyers trying to line their own pockets."
The bill was overwhelmingly passed by both houses of Congress last week, and President Clinton is to decide this week whether to sign it. He is considered likely to go along.
But despite Wall Street's characterization of the measure as a modest change, its opponents say that it will significantly limit well-founded suits by investors.
And there are some executives who wish that the measure deterred suits more aggressively.
"The risk is that the legislation does not go far enough," said Richard C. Breeden, who from 1989 to 1993 was chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and is now an international financial-services executive at Coopers & Lybrand. "No one since 1933 has trimmed back the relentless march of shareholders' litigation."
The protection the bill provides to big accounting firms makes it more likely that those firms will take on technology companies as clients, a group they had largely abandoned because of the potential risk of the accountants' being sued.
Vincent M. O'Reilly, executive vice chairman of Coopers & Lybrand, said the measure "will allow us, like the management of the companies we audit, to focus on our business, and not divert time and effort to defending ourselves against frivolous lawsuits."
As protection against suits, the Big Six firms have been adding a risk premium to their fee structure. Mr. O'Reilly said the bill, if signed by President Clinton, would have "some impact" on a decision to reduce charges to clients.
Experts said it remained to be seen how effective the measure's "safe harbor" protection would be against suits stemming from corporate forecasts on earnings, new products or other matters. In return for that provision, the bill's supporters hope that companies will increase the flow of information to the investing public. But Wall Street is not so sure.
"Most of these provisions are a series of small speed bumps, which cumulatively will make litigation less attractive," said John C. Coffee, a professor of securities law at Columbia University, who advised the White House on the bill. "It will mean that in the marginal case, plaintiffs will be less likely to sue."
Mr. Ziegler of Cleary, Gottlieb said the "safe harbor" provision was subject to so many qualifications that its usefulness was questionable. The protection does not apply, for example, to statements made in initial-public-offering documents, or to statements made in a tender offer, or to beneficial-ownership reports under Section 13d of the Securities and Exchange Act.
"The safe harbor provision applies to a narrow subset of existing securities transactions," he said. "This does not affect many types of class-action lawsuits."
But Mr. Breeden, the former S.E.C. chairman, hoped that the added protection would ultimately encourage companies to be more forthcoming.
"The net result of the current system can be less disclosure rather than more," he said. "There is a lot to be gained if we can move forward. The only way to do that is to take some steps to try. If we don't try, we can never move forward."
Even though people on Wall Street contend that passage of the bill should not concern investors, it has attracted sharp criticism from some current and former state Federal and state regulators and consumer advocates.
"In my view, the changes proposed in this bill are not incremental, but fairly monumental," said Richard Roberts, a former S.E.C. commissioner who is now a managing director at PVR Securities, a Princeton, N.J., venture-capital firm.
As written, the legislation "definitely stacks the deck against the vast bulk of the investing public," Mr. Roberts said, "because it will be very difficult for anyone less than a substantial investor to initiate most cases. That will be a monumental difference."
And Philip A. Feigin, Colorado's Securities Commissioner, said that no matter how limited, the safe harbor provisions in the measure would make it "a lot harder to hold people accountable for things they say."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What Beijing Fears

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The top-ranked academic sent by Beijing to a conference of intellectuals from around the world asked for the floor to explain his Government's policy on human rights.
Shuqing Wu, president of Beijing University, spoke only five or six minutes, but with careful clarity. 
 By the time he finished it was utterly plain that the Chinese Communist Government was flat-out determined not to allow the Chinese people to take part in the historic movement spreading in Asia: the simultaneous development of prosperity and political freedoms.
This was what he had to say:
In colonial wars and imposed peace, the West brutalized China. In Shanghai, Europeans posted a sign at the gate to a park: "No dogs or Chinese." China had been prevented from developing economically. Now the task was economic development. Without that, there was no use speaking about developing what the West called human rights.
Early in the conference on "The Future of Hope," sponsored by the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity and by the Japanese daily Asahi Shimbun, everybody had come to understand that this man only spoke officially. He never winged a word.
And outside the conference building, in the reality of Asia, was the proof that the Chinese rigidity toward human rights did not come from the injustices of the past but fear of the future.
No city in China, none in the world, was destroyed as was Hiroshima. Few countries were as devastated as Japan. But Hiroshima, Nagasaki -- the "other" city hit by an atomic bomb -- every Japanese city bombed out in World War II is glistening with modern buildings, commerce and technology. They make a New Yorker feel like a country boy.
They were rebuilt within political democracy. No forced prison labor, no gulag, no torture cell was part of the rebuilding of Japan -- as all have been for the half-century the Communist Chinese have been in power.
Political democracy and economic development are siblings in more and more countries in Asia. Ten years ago I traveled in countries that had been stagnating under despotism for decades, among them South Korea and the Philippines.
In 1961 I was in Seoul, watching the military overthrow of the country's first democratically elected Government. The U.S. looked on passively. Now South Korea is politically free and economically burgeoning and is arresting past presidents on charges of corruption and massacre.
In the Philippines, a democratic candidate supported by the U.S. ended the reign of Ferdinand Marcos, husband of the lady with the shoes. In Tokyo now, I read in The Wall Street Journal that Philippine workers are turning out the best cars made by Honda in Asia outside Japan, and the work force of the country has shaken off its "manana" reputation.
On Taiwan, the long dictatorship of the Chinese Nationalists is over. The campaign earlier this month for a new legislature was free and boisterous, which infuriated China. So is the economy. The cement mixer should be Taiwan's official flower.
India chose both national and political freedom on Aug. 15, 1947, the day of its birth. Unlike the Chinese, India does not impose abortion or vasectomies to deal with its biggest problem -- population growth that eats up economic progress. Still, its economy grows and India's computer specialists are among the world's finest.
Asians are proving -- if it ever needed proof except in the condescending West -- that they can handle economic and political growth at the same time, thank you.
But in Hiroshima there was Beijing's emissary letting 10 Nobel Prize winners and other scientists, writers and politicians know that while the Chinese are clever and able enough to leap into the high-tech age, the Politburo feels that dealing with a little freedom at the same time would be beyond them.
They know better, the Chinese Communists. But like all dictatorships they live in fear that their people will demand political and economic freedom -- together. When the Beijing Politburo members look out the window at Asia, it is not the past and foreigners but the future and their own people that chill the souls of the Politburo and the careful messenger they sent to Hiroshima.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ebbs in Thin Trading; Many Await Central Bank Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar declined modestly against the German mark and the Japanese yen in thin trading yesterday as dealers waited to see whether central banks in the United States and Europe would soon lower interest rates.
Trading stayed in a tight range against the mark and the yen, with the dollar moving just three-quarters of a pfennig and roughly half a yen. It finished mixed against other major currencies. 
 Dave Glowacki, a senior trader in Detroit with the NBD Bank, estimated volume at 30 percent of normal.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 101.09 Japanese yen, down from 101.30 yen late Friday. The dollar changed hands at 1.4443 German marks, down from 1.4475. However, the Canadian dollar lost ground to the United States dollar, selling at 72.377 cents, down from 72.648 cents on Friday.
In what another trader called "one of the slowest days we've seen all year," investors had no economic data, signs of political unrest or other explanations to guide their currency bets. They were also waiting for United States inflation data, to be released this week, and for the Friday deadline on a new Federal budget.
The only real move of the day occurred after comments in Zurich by Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers. He said he was "more optimistic about the U.S. economy than at any other time in my career."
This bullish sentiment helped move the dollar upward, even as the Swiss central bank and Government said the Swiss franc was too strong, hinting at a possible rate cut. That spurred selling of European currencies across the board, said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
"This plays into the idea of lower rates going forward in Europe," Mr. Solin said, referring to anticipation of rate cuts by the Bundesbank and the Bank of England this week, followed next week by the American Federal Reserve.
Central banks lower rates to spur growth and borrowing, but that tends to reduce demand for a country's currency as investments denominated in the currency become less attractive.

HEADLINE: At Hotels, Fewer Holiday Discounts

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
While toy makers, clothiers and distillers live for the holiday season, the period from Thanksgiving through Christmas can be the dead est of times for the hotel industry. Occupancy rates in December typically tumble to about 50 percent, compared with a year-round average of 65.2 percent in 1994, and would fall even further without a wide array of discounts and other enticements.
Many of those enticements, often including free parking and free breakfast, are widely available again this holiday season. 
 But there are fewer discount rates than usual, and almost none in New York, Chicago and other cities where business and leisure travelers have filled hotel rooms for weeks on end recently. In New York, for example, most of the 65,000 rooms have been booked solid all fall, with the occupancy rate soaring to 91.9 percent in October, the city's second-highest monthly rate ever, according to PKF Consulting, which tracks the hotel industry.
Thus the hotel industry's determination this holiday season, after seven or eight bad years, to expunge the widespread perception that discounts are a permanent feature of booking a room.
"The discounting that hotels have had to do has confused customers, led to unrealistic expectations and weakened bottom lines," said Brian Stage, executive vice president of sales and marketing for the Radisson hotels, a unit of the Carlson Companies. "So our strategy during the slow season is to create value-added packages to attract customers who wouldn't ordinarily stay in the hotels."
Indeed, hotels are offering everything from room upgrades and transportation to and from airports and shopping malls to discounts for food and beverages and gift certificates toward items in lobby shops.
Because business travel slows during much of the holiday season, a prime target of hotels is couples and families within a radius of about 50 miles. Not to mention partygoers.
At the venerable Seelbach Hotel in Louisville, Ky., where the fictional Tom Buchanan rented an entire floor before his wedding to Daisy Fay in F. Scott Fitzgerald's "The Great Gatsby," December is filled with Christmas parties, weddings and local social events. "This evening alone," Viola Sanders, the Seelbach's sales manager, said in a recent interview, "we have seven corporate Christmas parties."
As states have cracked down on drunken driving, partygoers are increasingly staying over at hotels -- and often qualify for some of the remaining discount rates.
"If they had their party here," Ms. Sanders said, "they would get a discount rate of $69 a night," compared with the usual corporate rate of $137. Similarly, most Radisson hotels offer party guests rooms at half price.
To fill their rooms, hotels are also trying to entice more holiday travelers to stay with them, rather than with family or friends.
The Loews Santa Monica Beach Hotel in Santa Monica, Calif., has been aiming at affluent families with radio and television ads proclaiming, "Your Guest House for the Holidays." Radisson hotels in Minneapolis, Atlanta and Arlington Heights, Ill., have all run ads with the headline "At Radisson, Uncle Fred Can Snore as Loud as He Likes."
Group discounts are viewed in a more favorable light by hoteliers than discounts for individual travelers, because most groups stay longer, rent meeting rooms and spend more on food and beverages. In fact, group business is so sought after, especially during slow seasons, that sales and marketing departments refer to it as Smerf -- an acronym for social, military, ethnic/educational, religious and fraternal groups.
The Radisson Sand Piper Beach Resort in St. Petersburg, Fla., not only solicits family groups, soccer associations and youth football leagues. "At Thanksgiving time, we're always looking for Canadians who don't celebrate the holiday," said Drew Toth, the hotel's director of sales and marketing.
The trend away from discounting also does not normally extend to weekend rates at hotels that cater to business travelers, who are scarce on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. On the contrary, weekend rates are regarded as providing incremental revenue from rooms that otherwise would have been empty.
So weekend rates abound, including during the holiday season. Almost 150 ITT Sheraton properties in the United States and Canada are offering 6 to 25 percent off their usual weekend rates, with some restrictions.
The Cincinnatian Hotel in Cincinnati's downtown business district has long offered weekend rates (currently $125 a night, compared with the $160 corporate rate). But the hotel does not further lower those rates for the holidays, although at Christmas it offers an array of amenities that include holiday meals and afternoon tea.
"We would rather leave a room empty than lower the rate too far, and risk losing our image as a luxury hotel," said Marjorie Hermann, a spokeswoman for the Cincinnatian. "And in a luxury hotel there are costs beyond turning a key and opening a door. There's the wear and tear on the room."
The Cincinnatian is not alone in thinking it necessary to protect its image, and hotel analysts say that belief is likely to spread -- at least until the next economic slowdown.
"Nothing is more perishable than an unoccupied hotel room," said Stanley Turkel, a hotel consultant in New York who is generally critical of the policy of accepting unoccupied rooms rather than offering lower rates.
Still, some luxury hotels are offering holiday rates well below normal. The Ritz-Carlton Huntington in Pasadena, Calif., for example, offers a holiday package for $115 a night that includes two cocktails and a room that regularly costs $165. "But we end it Dec. 28," said George Lysak, director of sales and marketing, "because we're sold out for the Rose Bowl and Rose Parade" on Jan. 1.
One of the most unusual marketing efforts is that of the 527-room San Francisco Airport Hilton, which through Jan. 15 charges guests the same rate as the lowest temperature in the city that day.
"It's a real bargain for guests," said Laura Jung, the hotel's director of sales and marketing, who noted that the temperature was often in the 40's during last year's promotion. The hotel's regular corporate rate is $140.
"We drew about 250 people because of it," Ms. Jung said, "most of them from around here. And when you include what they spent on food and drinks, the hotel made out O.K."

HEADLINE: Israel Sells Out Bond Offering, First Without U.S. Guarantee

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After a whirlwind roadshow with American investors, David Brodet of Israel's Ministry of Finance was able to announce that Israel had sold all of its new bond offering, its first since the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin and its first without the backing of the United States Treasury.
The sale was an important test of whether Israel could raise money in the world's capital markets after Mr. Rabin's assassination and the continuing political turmoil among Israelis and Palestinians over the Prime Minister's policy of trading Israeli land for Palestinian pledges of peace. 
 "We are very pleased and we think it quite significant," Mr. Brodet, who is director general in the finance ministry, said in an interview on Friday at the Israeli Consulate in Manhattan. "The legend of the Israeli economy is coming true."
The outcome of the first market test last month of Israel's capacity to raise money was unclear. Koor Industries, a major conglomerate, sold $120 million of stock in an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange, somewhat less than expected but probably because of the overall weakness of the Israeli stock market.
In the bond sale completed on Thursday, Israel raised $250 million, more than the $200 million originally planned, but far less than the $750 million that investors wanted, according to Salomon Brothers, the lead manager for the sale. Thirty-five large investors in the United States bought bonds.
Moreover, the sale of what are known as "Yankee bonds" was the first such sale backed only by Israel. Previously, investors could enjoy high interest rates from the bonds, plus the backing of the United States Treasury against default.
The 10-year bonds carry an interest rate of 6.49 percent, far lower than previous offerings because Standard & Poor's, the Wall Street bond rating service, raised Israel's rating to A- from BBB+. Similar United States bonds yield about 5.7 percent and are rated AAA.
Such changes in ratings are significant because of the interest savings involved. Mr. Brodet estimated that Israel saved as much as $5 million in interest costs because of the improved rating.
Mr. Brodet said that Israel's economy was still somewhat hobbled by high interest rates, but that inflation and growth trends continued to improve. Inflation in 1996 is expected to match 1995's rate of 8 percent, but is still above the Government target of 3 to 5 percent.
Israel's gross domestic product is expected to total about $88 billion this year, up from $78 billion in 1994, Mr. Brodet said.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Constance C. R. White 

 BODY:

High-Tech Attraction
A growing number of fashion retailers and designers are turning to computers and interactive television to draw customers. Last night, Macy's previewed its new Tommy Hilfiger shop, which features CD-ROM's and interactive television.
Mr. Hilfiger, from his television studio at his headquarters in Manhattan, conducted a 30-minute show with Don Nelson, the Knicks coach; the singer Jon Secada, and Russell Simmons, the entertainment executive. The show went on live in Macy's Herald Square and Macy's in San Francisco. Customers were able to speak with Mr. Hilfiger. 
 On Feb. 1, Saks Fifth Avenue will use satellite transmission to introduce Isaac, the new bridge collection by Isaac Mizrahi. An appearance by Mr. Mizrahi in the store here that evening will be simulcast to 18 other Saks branches. Saks introduced the format in September with Donna Karan. And J. C. Penney, after testing the concept in four stores earlier this year, began using computer kiosks this fall to sell bodywear in 14 stores.
But is there a future in luring reluctant shoppers electronically, or are the technological gizmos only a carnival sideshow?
Rose Marie Bravo, the president of Saks, said Ms. Karan's television appearance in 12 stores helped sales. "We know the same thing will happen with Isaac, and he will drive business and sell merchandise by explaining the philosophy of what the Isaac line is about," she said. "People want to know."
The idea is to entice shoppers with new-age toys, to save them time and to put them in touch with designers. "It will keep expanding because of the economics," said Robert Shavelson, the managing director of fashion for National Video, which develops retail concepts for video and computers. "Designers can reach a number of customers they couldn't in a month's worth of traveling."
 
Creative Director for New Line
Benny Lin, whose last job as fashion director for Macy's East had him straddling the worlds of high-concept fashion and value-conscious style, has been named creative director for the new Lauren-Ralph Lauren line.
As fashion continues its fascinating slide toward cheap chic, Mr. Lauren, the quintessential promoter of high living, is trying to interpret his designer style for the masses with Lauren, where a jacket will cost less than $200. For Mr. Lauren, who has exhibited a monk's devotion to marketing with admirable results, the step down will be a tricky balancing act. Over the years he has projected the life of the patrician, and his products -- with the exception of some Chaps items for men -- for the most part have had prices to match. Apparently, Mr. Lauren now recognizes that customers have never been readier for Ralph Lauren on the cheap, as it were.
Lauren is licensed to Jones New York and will be sold in stores like Macy's, Bloomingdale's and Lord & Taylor. Mr. Lin will be based in Jones's New York offices and will oversee the development of in-store shops and co-ordinate merchandising for the division. "Mr. Lauren's products have tremendous appeal to a large segment of the population, and with these prices more people will be able to enjoy them," Mr. Lin said. "It's the next growth area."
 
Buying American
Clothing auctions have become a reliable indicator of the direction in which the fashion wind is blowing. A sale at the William Doyle Gallery in Manhattan last week provided one more signal that interest is slipping away from French fashion toward American sartorial tastes.
"Until recently, people were primarily interested in haute couture and elaborate eveningwear," said Caroline Rennolds Milbank, a fashion historian and consultant to William Doyle. "Now, they're interested in good tailoring. We have more people coming in to see seaming or how a sleeve is set, and tailoring is one of the hallmarks of American fashion."
The auctions are held twice a year; in recent seasons the work of Charles James, the late American couturier, has been among the most popular. A coat by him fetched a top price of $8,000 on Wednesday. Designers Claire McCardell and Adrian were among the top sellers.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
2 Families, 4 Years After the Layoffs

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The flow of good jobs out of America to cheap-labor countries has become a fact of American life, and "Living on the Edge" tells what that means for a few of the men and women left behind. Tonight's edition of "Frontline" grew out of "Minimum Wages: The New Economy," Bill Moyers's 1991 report on layoffs in Milwaukee. The producers returned in 1993 and again this year to see what was happening to two blue-collar families; they found some improvements at substantial costs.
Tony Neumann and Claude and Jackie Stanley are three of the thousands of workers laid off in recent years by Briggs & Stratton, Milwaukee's biggest employer. Tony and Terry Neumann are white, the Stanleys are black, but they have a lot in common. Since losing the jobs that had kept them in the fairly comfortable, seemingly secure middle class, they have been scrambling to stay afloat. It's been years of hard work, disappointments and a realization that things will never again be what they were a few years ago; once realistic expectations now seem wishful. 
 Despite current campaign noise, the problems of the Neumann and Stanley households have nothing to do with "family values." Those values seem remarkably intact considering the buffeting the families have been taking. The Neumanns have faced the possible loss of their home and for one bad patch were reduced to accepting charity. The Stanleys and their five children have all been working as hard as they can yet not advancing much.
The program chronicles their efforts to find new incomes, eke out time for the children from the increased time needed to support them and keep up spirits despite constant rebuffs. With two jobs and a lot of overtime, the Neumanns are earning more these days but are seeing less of their three children. Mrs. Stanley has had to borrow to keep her oldest son in college, and Claude, who now waterproofs basements, sees no prospect of ever retiring.
Yet even with the unremitting pressures, their energy and initiative do not seem to have flagged. They also hang onto the hope or faith not so much that things will get better but that they will not get any worse. Maybe they are overly optimistic: the hour ends with the news that Briggs & Stratton is eliminating 2,000 more jobs and that real wages are still going down around the country.

HEADLINE: As Crime Soars, South African Whites Leave

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 11

 BODY:
At the end of this month, Heidi Moller will move from South Africa to Germany, leaving the country she was born in without a hint of regret. Her husband's business was not doing well. The school system, she says, is disintegrating. But most of all, she says, she is leaving because fear had come to overwhelm her family.
Last year, her husband, Hans, a surveyor, was shot at from a passing vehicle while working in a Johannesburg suburb. A few months later, he was forced off the road by hijackers and was shot in the leg. One of Mrs. Moller's best friends was shot and her husband killed in front of their children. Her brother-in-law was shot at in his driveway as four men tried to steal his car, while his family watched helplessly from the house. 
 If she and her husband had tried to leave two years ago as South Africa was preparing for its first free elections, Mrs. Moller says her friends would have called them cowards and accused them of running away. But these days, she says, "All we find is that people are envious."
Experts say the white, wealthy and educated are leaving South Africa in growing numbers, draining the country of expertise when it is desperately needed. Most often, the move is a response to the rising violent crime that seems to have touched almost everyone.
While most of those departing have several reasons, and a bleak view of the role that white people can have in this country's future, it is violent crime that seems to lead the list. Reported crimes in some areas and categories have increased by as much as 75 percent in one year.
Much of the new terror is confined to the white suburbs of Johannesburg. These areas were well protected under the old government and the residents worried about crime little more than suburban residents do in the United States.
But these days, every house is a fortress, with burglar bars on the windows and a steel "rape gate" separating the bedrooms from the rest of the house for extra protection at night. Garden walls are topped by ever-evolving forms of razor wire, "cactus" spikes or electric wires that deliver a jolt as they set off an alarm. And, carrying a gun is ever more commonplace.
Dinner parties have become a frenzy of horror stories. Some are tales of what has happened to the well-known and powerful. Recently, for instance, a radio personality was held up during a daytime stroll with his daughter through Houghton, the wealthy suburb where President Nelson Mandela has a house. The robbers, apparently to amuse themselves, made them strip and left them naked. But most often the tales are first person. People talk softly of how their self-images have changed after they have cringed or begged or nursed a bullet wound.
"Someone close to you gets hurt and you think it could happen to me," said Ron Stern, who has a business selling window and doors, and who says he is considering leaving. "Should I stick around and risk my children's lives? You are in a constant state of limbo trying to figure this out. That's our daily existence. That's what we do."
The exodus has hit hard at some professions, perhaps none more than medicine. One doctor recently sent the photograph of his 1984 graduating class to a local newspaper, showing that at least 76 of the 186 graduates had emigrated. But moving-company executives say that whites from all backgrounds are leaving.
Government figures, collected from departure forms filled out at airports, show that peak emigration was in the first half of 1994, just before the elections, when the fear was of rioting or civil war. But recent statistics show that the exodus is hardly fading. During the first half of 1995, 6,030 people said they were emigrating, about twice the number of five years before.
Experts say those statistics vastly underestimate the problem because people lie on their departure forms, partly to evade restrictions on taking money out of the country. Moving companies and relocation specialists say they haven't been this busy since the late 1970's, when a wave of brutal riots started what is known in the business as the first "chicken run."
"When they give the statistics in the paper, I always laugh," said Estelle Sachavitz of Stuttafords Removals, one of the leading moving companies here. "Most people don't say they are leaving for good. As soon as they say that, their funds are blocked and things get very complicated. So people just go."
The long-term consequences for South Africa are unclear. Some emigrants will return, unable to make a go of it elsewhere. But for a country finally trying to improve the lives of a population and in need of jobs, health care and good schools, the loss of the educated elite is a blow. At a recent meeting with black executives, President Mandela said that accommodating whites is in the country's best interest.
"Why should we not pacify them?" Mr. Mandela said. "In putting aside the quarrels of the past we have a country which has the opportunity to acquire education, skills and expertise in many fields. We want this."
Mr. Mandela's administration has taken steps to address the crime issue. The police department, which functioned largely as a brutal enforcer of the apartheid laws under the old government, is being completely reorganized in an effort to turn it into a crime-fighting agency.
But with little money for training of officers and a shortage of vehicles that often delays officers responding to emergencies, the force remains largely ineffective.
To be sure, crime is not the only reason whites leave. Mrs. Moller said her husband is having a harder and harder time getting people to pay their bills and feels the whole country is becoming lawless. And there is talk of revamping property laws, in ways that will diminish the need for land surveyors.
At the same time, Mrs. Moller, says that her 5-year-old daughter, Melissa, will not be able to get a good education, now that the Government has ended segregated schools. The change has meant that some youngsters coming from the inferior system created for blacks are not as well prepared as their white counterparts. "The public schools are lowering their standards to accommodate the blacks," Mrs. Moller said. "They expect that everyone will come down to their level."
Most white South Africans go to Australia, England, the United States, Canada or New Zealand. Many have quietly kept up dual citizenship to make the departure easy.
Many of those who want to leave understand that their wealth will shrink overseas. But they say they are willing to trade small mansions, full-time maids and the employer-provided Mercedes for a sense of safety and the possibility that their children will be able to ride bicycles in the driveway.
"We'll never be able to match this," said one accountant, sweeping his hand across his property -- a five-bedroom house with a pool in the Bryanston suburb of Johannesburg. "We will have a basic house and a basic motor vehicle."
Still the accountant and his wife are determined to go to Australia. Last year, she was wrestled out of her car by four young men as she backed out of her garage. The incident began when one of them tapped frantically on her window.
"I thought someone was in terrible trouble -- he looked so panicked and I was ready to get out and help. And then, stupid me, I realized the only person in trouble here was me.
"You know," she continued, "last year I was so elated -- standing in the queues to vote was the most incredible feeling. It was the first time I could walk around and look everybody in the eye. I was acquiring my freedom too. But then with the hijacking I got my first taste of fear.
"For a whole lot of people, the changes in this country are going to be great. Life will get better. But not for us. And I'm not prepared to sacrifice my future and my children's future. I just don't want to live with this fear. To be so tense. To go out of the driveway and think: Is the alarm on? Is there anyone behind me?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Wall Street Plays Down
Effects of Securities Bill
Wall Street sees the securities bill that passed Congress last week as a mild step toward quelling frivolous investor suits, not the radical advance as portrayed in Washington.
Lawyers, accountants and others say that the number of class-action suits will diminish somewhat, and that other aims, like greater disclosure, will have a limited application. Market Place. [Page D10.]
 
Administration Plans to Cut Time
Employers Hold 401(k) Money
The Clinton Administration proposed to reduce the time companies could hold workers' contributions to 401(k) retirement savings plans before turning it over to mutual funds or other investments.
To protect employees, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich proposed that the 90-day holding period be cut to the same time companies hold Social Security money -- generally one day to a month, depending on payroll size. [D2.]
 
Hoteliers Seek
Holiday Cheer
The holiday season is generally less than merry for the nation's hoteliers. Occupancy rates in December typically tumble to about 50 percent, compared with a year-round average of 65.2 percent in 1994. Consequently, hotel keepers are offering an array of discounts and other lures to guests. [D5.]
 
Bristol-Myers Squibb to Cut Costs
Bristol-Myers Squibb announced a three-year $2.5 billion cost-savings plan. It will involve closing an unspecified number of plants and result in a charge of $250 million to $300 million against fourth-quarter earnings. [D7.]
 
Orders for Computer Chips Decline
New orders for computer chips fell 1.5 percent in November from October, to $5.03 billion, an industry group reported. [D6.]
 
More Optimistic Revenue Projection
The Congressional Budget Office forecast that the Government could reap a $185 billion windfall over the next seven years, as a result of a stronger-than-expected economy. The forecast gave the Administration and Congress more room for maneuvering in their negotiations to balance the budget. [D22.]
 
Loyalty and Federal Express
A pilots union's slowdown at Federal Express, aimed at forcing management to make a better contract offer, could backfire. Rather than winning converts to labor's cause, it has led most employees to embrace the company even more tightly. [D22.]
 
Machinists to End Strike at Boeing
Negotiators for machinists and Boeing reached a tentative agreement to end a 67-day strike, the union said. Members are to vote on the four-year contract, which includes bonuses, pay increases and protection on subcontracting on Wednesday. [D22.]
 
Israel Sells
New Bond Offering
Israel sold its entire new bond offering, the first since the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and its first without the backing of the United States Treasury. The sale was an important test of Israel's standing in world capital markets. Salomon Brothers, the lead manager for the sale, said Israel raised $250 million. [D4.]
 
Book Advertising on the Upswing
Book publishers are figuring out new advertising methods. Television ads are becoming popular with cost-effective techniques like computer imaging, and the expansion of cable channels allows publishers to seek specific audiences. Advertising. [D9.]
 
Ziff-Davis and Yahoo Link Planned
Ziff-Davis, a leading publisher of computer magazines, and Yahoo, one of the most popular directories on the Internet's World Wide Web, are expected to announce a partnership today, executives familiar with the deal say. Ziff-Davis's quarterly, Internet Life, is to be renamed Yahoo! Internet Life, and a Web site called ZD/Yahoo! Computing is planned. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Climb, With Dow Up by 27.46

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended higher yesterday, bolstered by a strong rally in oil stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.46 points, to 5,184.32, recovering part of the ground lost in the two days since closing at a record 5,199.13 on Dec. 6. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.04 points, to 619.52, just short of its Dec. 6 record of 620.18. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 0.91 point, to 1,061.50. 
 Shares of oil companies rose after frigid temperatures in the Midwest and Northeast briefly sent the price of oil past $19 a barrel to a six-month high. The crude oil price later retreated to $18.66 a barrel. The weather, coupled with the companies' above-average dividends, led investors to bet oil stocks may outpace the rest of the stock market this winter.
The rally sent the Standard & Poor's International Oil Index up 13.34, or 2.5 percent, to a record 529.91. During the last six months, the index gained 12.6 percent, lagging behind the 16.7 percent gain of the S.& P. 500.
"Step outside -- there's probably some decent demand for heating oil," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist at Dean Investment Associates of Dayton, Ohio, which oversees about $3.7 billion.
Among oil issues that reached records, Exxon rose 2 3/8, to a record 84 1/8; Chevron surged 19/16 , to an all-time high of 52 3/4; Amoco rose 2 1/2, to a record 71 1/4; Texaco Inc. gained 3/4, to a record 79 1/8 and Mobil rose 3 1/8, to a record 113 5/8.
The gain in oil stocks was partly offset by losses in paper issues. Paper stocks fell amid concern that increased production to take advantage of high prices will eventually flood the market with too much product and cause prices to fall.
International Paper fell 1/2, to 36 1/2; Bowater Inc. fell 1, to 35 1/4; Georgia-Pacific lost 2 1/4, to 71; Champion International shed 1 5/8, to 42 7/8, and Louisiana-Pacific dropped 5/8, to 24 7/8.
Banking issues fell amid concern interest rates may not decline soon. When rates fall, banks can borrow money for less and keep more of the money they take in from loans.
Citicorp fell 21/16 to 67 3/4; Norwest fell 7/8, to 33 1/8; Nationsbank dropped 5/8, to 73; Fleet Financial Group fell 5/8, to 41 1/4, and Bank of Boston gave up 7/8, to 46 5/8.
Maybelline surged 5 1/4, to 36 1/4. L'Oreal S.A. of France said it had agreed to buy the company for $36.75 a share, or about $598 million.
Earth Technology rose 161/64 , to 753/64 . Tyco International signed a merger agreement under which it would make a tender offer for the environmental consulting company at $8 a share, or about $70 million.
Glenayre Technologies rose 5 3/4, to 59. The telecommunications equipment maker was raised to medium-term "above average" from "neutral" by Joseph Bellace, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company.
Microwave Power Devices Inc. jumped 1 7/8, to 13 1/2. The maker of power amplifiers said it had won a $20.3 million contract to produce and supply amplifiers for use in satellite communications systems.
Advancing issues outpaced decliners 1,207 to 1,133 on the New York Stock Exchange, where 344 million shares traded hands, up from 327.9 million on Friday.

HEADLINE: Gingrich Draws Protest to Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Inside a warm, plush ballroom of the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan last night, about 400 revelers at the annual Louis Marshall Award Dinner greeted this year's keynote speaker with raised wine glasses, craned necks and discreet applause.
But outside, in the freezing cold, more than 250 protesters accorded him a reception that matched the harsh weather, hollering that he had no right to command the podium at one of the most important annual social events in the Conservative movement of Judaism. 
 House Speaker Newt Gingrich was in town, and controversy was typically fast on his heels.
"We believe that everything Newt Gingrich stands for -- the politics of blame and meanness, the destruction of the social safety net -- flies against the Jewish ethical tradition," said Rabbi Michael Feinberg, program coordinator for a nonprofit group, Jews for Racial and Economic Justice, that organized the protest at a fund-raiser for the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.
"Last year, the speaker was Elie Wiesel," the rabbi noted. "How do you go from that to Newt Gingrich?"
That question has triggered considerable dissent and even a few diatribes from seminary students and leaders of liberal Jewish organizations since seminary officials announced the selection of Mr. Gingrich about nine months ago.
And last night, that question boiled over into a strident demonstration across Fifth Avenue from the Pierre, on the edge of Central Park.
Protesters said that Mr. Gingrich's staunchly conservative social policies are anathema to the traditionally liberal positions of many Jews on issues like poverty and immigration and that the seminary officials had given Mr. Gingrich what could be perceived as a Jewish seal of approval.
But seminary officials said Mr. Gingrich was invited not as a measure of endorsement but as a recognition of the important, influential niche he currently occupies in American politics. "He needs to be heard," said Gershon Kekst, the seminary chairman. Mr. Gingrich's supporters at the dinner further argued that some of Mr. Gingrich's core concerns -- for better education, for stronger families -- are also held dear in the Jewish community, and they praised his fierce advocacy for Israel.
"Newt Gingrich is one of Israel's best friends in the United States Congress," said Mayer Mitchell, chairman of the board of the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee.
Seminary officials acknowledged that they chose Mr. Gingrich in part because they felt he would be a potent and lucrative draw. They were right: the roughly 400 people who bought tickets for last night's dinner represented the largest crowd for the annual event in at least five years, and the $1.2 million that the dinner was expected to raise for the seminary was about $200,000 more than usual.
In response to an outcry from students over the invitation, seminary officials negotiated a half-hour meeting last night, from about 6:30 to 7:00 P.M., between Mr. Gingrich and about 16 representatives of the student body.
Gathering in a small annex of the ballroom just before the dinner, the students and Mr. Gingrich engaged in a polite airing of sometimes opposing views that was rendered even more amicable by the students' palpable humbleness in his presence and Mr. Gingrich's professorial patience with them.
While most of the students took issue with his policies, focusing alternately on welfare cutbacks, the environment and prayer in schools, a few applauded his conservative reforms.
Toward the end, Mr. Gingrich confessed, "I sat here almost with my stomach in knots."
His speech at the dinner touched on such topics as evil, personal responsibility and government bureaucracy. At one point, in what was clearly a planned gesture, a young man and a young woman shot out of their seats to shout at him, but guards hustled them away quickly.
The Louis Marshall Award, named for a widely respected Jewish leader who served as chairman of the seminary's board of directors from 1904 until his death in 1929, is bestowed annually by the seminary on men and women who have demonstrated outstanding commitment to their communities. Last night's honorees were Alex J. Mandl, an executive vice president of AT&T, and Dr. Sue Bailey, director of women's outreach for the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign.
The fund-raiser that has evolved around the award is a swank black-tie affair that features crepes and caviar and commands a price of at least $1,000 a plate, with many attendees donating more.
Back in September, after hearing that Mr. Gingrich would deliver the keynote address, one of Louis Marshall's grandchildren, Jonathan Marshall, wrote a letter to Rabbi Ismar Schorsch, the seminary's chancellor, asking that Mr. Marshall's name be removed from the dinner this year. Rabbi Schorsch denied that request.
In a subsequent telephone interview, Jonathan Marshall, who lives in Phoenix, said of seminary officials: "They're using my grandfather's name to raise money for a cause that is fine, but with a person he would find despicable. Mr. Gingrich is such a loud, abrasive person. My grandfather was subtle."
