HEADLINE: Bill Would Cut Medicaid-Welfare Link

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Congressional experts today issued a brighter economic forecast that gave the Clinton Administration and Congress more room for maneuvering in their budget negotiations, but less flexibility than many had hoped.
The forecast, prepared by the Congressional Budget Office, predicted that the Government could reap a $135 billion windfall in new revenue and savings over the next seven years from a stronger-than-expected economy. That is considerably more than the $100 billion that Congressional officials had said would accrue from the revised forecast. 
 The extra money would shrink by one third the $400 billion gap separating the plans that Republican leaders and President Clinton have offered to erase the Federal deficit over that period.
But, by a numerical twist of fate, the money might be worth less to the bargainers than that figure suggests. The bulk of the windfall would occur at the start of the seven-year span, and the remainder would dwindle over time until no new money would be left in 2002, the year the Government should be in fiscal balance.
That is the opposite of what the negotiators need, since their plans rely on spending cuts and savings that start small and accumulate to huge sums by the end of the period. The deputy director of the budget office James Blum, said tonight that perhaps $100 billion of the $135 billion might be usable by the negotiators. But the negotiators themselves did not seem so sure.
"The new numbers may help a little, but not a great deal," said the principal Democratic negotiator for the House, Representative Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, after bargainers were briefed this afternoon.
The chief negotiator for the Senate Republicans, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, was slightly more sanguine. "Let there be no doubt: This has not put us in a position where we're cutting off negotiations," he said. But the forecast, he added, was a combination of "good news and bad news."
The director of the budget office, June O'Neill, said the added money comes largely from changes in this year's economic picture. They include higher corporate profits, and thus more tax revenues, and lower inflation and interest rates, which ease the cost of Government debt and some inflation-adjusted programs. Some of the gains were offset, though, by a slower growth of the workforce, Ms. O'Neill said.
The budget talks are aimed not just at erasing the deficit, but avoiding another shutdown of the Federal Government like the one that occurred last month. That shutdown ended after six days when the two sides agreed to pay for most Government operations until this Friday while they hash out their fiscal differences.
But while the deadline is almost here, little has been hashed out. Congress sent Mr. Clinton a bill financing the military's 1996 budget, which he reluctantly signed. But six other 1996 spending bills for agencies including the Departments of Commerce, State, Veterans Affairs, Housing and Urban Development and Labor remain mired in disputes between the House and Senate.
Congress also sent Mr. Clinton a seven-year budget bill that radically changed benefit programs like Medicare, Medicaid and farm subsidies. But Mr. Clinton vetoed that bill last week, saying it did not reflect his "values," and told Congress not to send it back until it did.
There matters stand. Technically, Mr. Clinton does not even have to sign the seven-year budget bill, because it revises programs that would continue unchanged should the bill not become law. But Republicans say they will not send Mr. Clinton any more spending bills, which must be signed by Friday to keep the Government running, until there is agreement on the seven-year budget.
Congress could enact another temporary spending measure to keep offices open while negotiations continue, and in fact, Republicans are preparing such a bill now. But Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chief negotiator for the House Republicans, said today that that measure will contain conditions limiting how the money can be spent. Mr. Clinton has promised to veto any spending bill that is too restrictive.
Republicans also could attach the spending bill to a new seven-year budget package that they are drafting this week, and hope to enact by Friday. That would present Mr. Clinton with a take-it-or-leave-it option: sign the entire package into law, or veto it and throw some 350,000 Federal workers off the job at the peak of the holiday season.
The weeks of talks have amounted to a collection of momentary highs followed by prolonged lows. After days of bickering over the agenda, the bargaining seemed to pick up on Thursday, when Mr. Clinton offered his own version of a seven-year balanced budget. It immediately slowed again when Republicans rejected the plan, saying it fell $400 billion short of balance, and threatened another Government shutdown should negotiators fail to make rapid progress.
The Congressional Budget Office will apply its new economic forecast to Mr. Clinton's seven-year proposal, making it directly comparable to the Republican plan, Ms. O'Neill said. But that may take time, because the Administration has not yet provided enough details of its proposal to allow a thorough evaluation.
Negotiators plan to meet again on Tuesday to mull over the new economic forecast. But there was little indication today that the fits-and-starts nature of the talks is about to change.
On one hand, Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, were said to be buoyed after President Clinton called them on Sunday to discuss the deadlocked budget talks.
But on the other hand, the Administration's principal bargainer, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said today that he doubts that a budget agreement can be struck this week. And he said the President will probably not take a personal role in budget talks this week, despite Republican requests, because he is preparing for a trip to Paris on Wednesday for the signing of the Bosnia peace treaty. 
 Because of a technical error, the article carried an incorrect headline in some editions. The headline, "Bill Would Cut Medicaid-Welfare Link," was intended for an article about new welfare legislation.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 13, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about budget negotiations between Congress and the White House misstated President Clinton's action on a military spending bill. He let it become law without his signature earlier this month; he did not sign it.

HEADLINE: Exemption Set In Clinton Plan For Crackdown On Tax Deals

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, which proposed last week to close what it said were billions of dollars of tax loopholes used in Wall Street financing, retreated ever so slightly yesterday.
Among the Administration's proposals was to deny tax benefits to corporate bonds issued for maturities longer than 40 years and to hybrid securities that go by names like MIPS and combine characteristics of debt and ownership. 
But in a three-paragraph clarification yesterday, the Treasury Department said companies that sold 100-year bonds and exotic securities the Clinton Administration seeks to eliminate could keep the tax benefits, provided that the companies had binding deals by last Wednesday.
The statement lifted a cloud over more than half a billion dollars of corporate securities sold on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday last week.
But the fate of several deals that were not quite complete, including a $500 million offering by the Pacific Telesis Group, the California and Nevada regional Bell company, remained uncertain.
Last week's announcement by the Treasury Department characterized 100-year bonds and various exotic securities as abusive practices outside the normal realm of corporate finance.
Yesterday, the Public Securities Association defended these financing instruments, saying they were neither abusive nor abnormal.
"These proposals represent an attack on capital formation at a time when this nation should be focusing its attention on increasing savings and investment," Robert B. McKnew, the securities association chairman, said in a statement. The association called the exotic securities innovative aids in strengthening the economy.
The association said that proposing major tax changes "outside the context of comprehensive tax reform is wholly inappropriate in our view." The Treasury Department has been careful to limit its drive on tax deductions to Wall Street, which, with its penchant for multimillion-dollar bonuses, may not have much sympathy from many Americans. "Everyone is going have to share in the burden of deficit reduction, not just working mothers making $30,000 a year," said a Treasury official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Officials at four Wall Street investment houses agreed yesterday that whether a particular security was equity or debt was a legitimate subject for debate. But all took the same line as Mr. McKnew in saying that the issue should be handled as part of an overall debate on tax revision.
The definition of debt and equity has been at issue since the adoption of the 16th Amendment, which authorized income taxes. The Internal Revenue Code grants the Treasury Department authority to define equity and debt for tax purposes through rules and regulations.
Kenneth H. Heitner, a leading tax expert with the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, said that "MIPS and the others are very popular instruments on Wall Street today because the bankers have convinced everybody that they are a relatively low-cost form of capital."
When a company sells bonds it can deduct the interest payments before calculating its Federal income tax liability, but dividends paid to equity owners are not deductible, he noted.
The hybrids have attracted buyers who want to mix the benefits of ownership, principally a higher return if the company prospers, with the predetermined interest paid on debt.
Mr. Heitner said that while the transitional relief helped some companies whose deals were priced before last Thursday, "I am aware of a number of issues that were ready to go to market that were deferred." He said those deals must now be redone and would result in higher costs for the capital raised.
Michael Schler, a tax partner at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, said that he was concerned about deals that were partly completed on Thursday, when the Clinton Administration made its proposals public. But he said he had hope that the Administration might look favorably on these deals because the transitional relief announcement included a promise to "work with Congress to determine the extent to which additional transitional relief is appropriate."
Two companies whose financings last week appeared to be in question said yesterday that they were satisfied they had been "grandfathered." Johnson Controls of Milwaukee sold $125 million of debentures with a 50-year term, a decade longer than the new rules would allow.
"We feel confident that we were grandfathered," said Ben C. M. Bastianen, the company treasurer. He said the securities were priced and sold on Tuesday.
At IES Utilities, the electric power company for much of northern Iowa, officials said they were also comfortable that their deal was safe. "This is debt and it's less than 40 years," said Bill Cherrier, a company financial analyst.
The Treasury may look on the deal differently because not only is the debt last in line, after $573 million of more senior debt, but also that company can stop cash interest payments for up to five years, provided it suspends dividend payments on common and preferred stock. Those terms may make the Treasury look upon the "quarterly debt-capital securities" as equity, especially since they were described in the prospectus as "shares."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: December 29, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Dec. 12 about the Clinton Administration's proposal to end favorable tax treatment of some corporate fi nancings included a company official's erroneous reference to certain securities being offered by IES Utilities. The securities are described in the company's prospectus as junior subordinated deferrable interest debentures; they are not shares.

 BODY:

Conferees Back TV Chip To Block Violent Shows
House and Senate conferees agreed to require television makers to include a computer chip in all new TV sets that would enable parents to block violent programs. The chip would require the broadcasting and entertainment industries to devise a rating system for violent shows within one year. 
 The idea has proven popular with parents and hard to oppose politically. [Page A1.]
 
NBC Gets 3 More Olympics
NBC bought the television rights to the 2004 Summer, 2006 Winter and 2008 Summer Olympics, for $2.3 billion. The sale of broadcast and cable rights came even before the sites had been selected. [A1.]
 
Moody's Warning on Wal-Mart
Moody's said it might lower the debt ratings on Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, because its growth is expected to slow. Wal-Mart has $8.6 billion of long-term debt. [D3.]
 
Internet Study Is Faulted
A Nielsen survey that found there are more than 24 million highly educated and affluent adult users of the Internet may have "significantly inflated" its findings, the study's principal academic adviser says. [D5.]
 
Doctors' Network Grows in Size
Medpartners/Mullikin agreed to buy Pacific Physician Services for $332 million in a tax-free stock transaction. They provide doctor networks to health plans. [D3.]
 
Kimberly to Sell Some Scott Assets
Kimberly-Clark agreed to sell Scott Paper's facial-tissue and baby-wipes businesses to settle antitrust concerns about its $9.4 billion acquisition of Scott. [D2.]
 
Stocks Pull Back
Stocks declined, depressed by a slide in technology shares and new economic reports that dampened hopes for a cut in interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average eased by 9.40, to 5,174.92, while the Nasdaq composite dropped 9.43, to 1,051.75. [D8.]
 
More Tobacco Testimony
A former Brown & Williamson executive is to testify before grand juries in Washington today and in New York on Monday. [A21.]
 
Optimism in Budget Talks
White House and Congressional negotiators were optimistic that they could avert another partial shutdown of the Government and eventually reach a budget agreement. [B10.]
 
Trade Deficit Shrinks
The nation's trade deficit shrank 8.7 percent in the summer as exports rose and imports fell. But the deficit for the year is high. [D2.]
 
Boeing Strike May End
Union leaders predict that Boeing workers will approve a new contract, ending a 67-day strike. The workers surprised negotiators last month by turning down a previous offer. [A21.]
 
A Regional Bell Enters Its Prime
Of the seven Baby Bells spun off from AT&T in 1984, SBC Communications, formerly Southwestern Bell, may have grown up the fastest, thanks in part to a favorable regulatory climate in its home turf of Texas and neighboring states. Now, analysts say its growth could outstrip that of MCI, Sprint or even AT&T. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Shopkorn Joining Moore Capital
Stanley Shopkorn is closing his hedge fund, Ethos Capital L.P., and signing on with Moore Capital Management Inc., a $2 billion hedge fund managed by Louis Moore Bacon. [D8.]
 
Forest May Be Preserved
A huge wilderness in New York and New Jersey may escape development. Washington might help the states buy the 20,000-acre property, Sterling Forest. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Bank of Boston and Baybanks To Merge in $2 Billion Deal

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The Bank of Boston Corporation said last night that it would buy Baybanks Inc., the leading consumer bank in New England, for $2 billion in stock.
The combined bank, with assets of $55 billion, will be the largest bank in Massachusetts and the 15th largest in the nation. 
 The banks said that they would eliminate 2,000 of their 24,500 jobs, half through layoffs and half through attrition, and close 85 of their 400 combined branches.
The Bank of Boston agreed to exchange 2.2 of its shares -- worth $99.72 at yesterday's closing price -- for each share of Baybanks. Yesterday Baybanks' stock closed at $85, up 75 cents. Bank of Boston's stock closed at $45.325, down $1.25. The merger was announced after the market closed.
The merger agreement, which was signed at 4:15 P.M. yesterday in Boston, caps a year in which the Bank of Boston tried and failed to merge with a number of large banks including the Corestates Financial Corporation, the Mellon Bank Corporation, the Fleet Financial Group and the Bank of New York.
While Bank of Boston has successful operations in Latin America, it decided its domestic operations were too small to compete with the growing banking giants, especially Fleet, which bought the Shawmut National Corporation in January, forming the largest bank in New England.
Baybanks has long been the most obvious acquisition for Bank of Boston, which has lagged in serving the consumer market. In contrast, over the last 20 years, Baybanks' ubiquitous green sign and vast automated teller machine network have captured the business of Boston's university students, many of whom have stayed with the bank as they have grown to be affluent professionals.
Many other large regional banking companies have similarly had their eyes on Baybanks, and several, including Corestates, have made overtures.
All of these have been sternly rebuffed by William M. Crozier Jr., the crusty 63-year-old banker who has been chairman of Baybanks for 21 years, and styled its lively marketing more on the model of L.L. Bean than the stodgy examples set by other banks. He had long said that were he to sell, he would prefer an out-of-state buyer to Bank of Boston, in order to protect employees' jobs.
In an interview yesterday, however, Mr. Crozier said that in the current environment protecting jobs was less important to him.
"Times change," he said. "There will be job losses, but today we are growing, and the economy here is growing, and so protecting jobs is less important." Mr. Crozier emphasized that this deal would preserve another large banking company based in New England.
Mr. Crozier owns about 120,000 shares of Baybanks, worth about $12 million in the deal, and he has options to buy about 134,000 more shares.
Mr. Crozier will be the chairman of the combined banking company through 1998, and will look after its retail operations. Charles K. Gifford, 53, the chief executive of Bank of Boston will be chief executive and president until taking the chairman's title when Mr. Crozier retires. All of the top Baybanks executives will have senior jobs in the combined company.
The deal was initiated by Mr. Gifford, who became chief executive of Bank of Boston in August when his predecessor, Ira Stepanian, was forced out by the board of directors. Mr. Stepanian's abrasive style was blamed for the collapse of the previous merger discussions.
"We looked around and saw a combination with Baybanks as the No. 1 strategic option because it would combine what I think is the top consumer bank in the country with our strong corporate and international banking," said Mr. Gifford, who is known as Chad.
In talks that began last month, Mr. Gifford agreed to a number of concessions that smoothed the negotiations with Baybanks. The deal was arranged quickly and secretly, in deliberate contrast to Bank of Boston's highly public failed merger with Corestates.
Mr. Crozier said that the most important issue to him was the name and logo of the new company. The banks' branches throughout New England will go by the Baybanks name, displayed in its trademark green combined with the Bank of Boston's eagle logo. The holding company and the foreign and corporate banking operations will use the Bank of Boston name.
The price, of course, was lucrative as well, representing 2.2 times Baybanks' book value, relatively high for bank deals. The deal would give Baybanks' stockholders ownership of 30 percent of the combined company's shares.
Analysts said, however, that the price was not too high for Bank of Boston and that its per share earnings would increase as a result of the deal, once the cost savings were realized.
"The price is actually a little under what I thought Baybanks would go for," said Nancy Bush, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman who was critical of Bank of Boston's earlier proposed deals. "When you look at the options for Bank of Boston, this is far and away the best one," she said.
The acquisition is expected to eliminate $190 million in expenses, 11 percent of the combined banks' spending in the United States. The banks also expect $50 million in increased revenue. Bank of Boston will take a $140 million charge for the merger, which is expected to be completed in the middle of next year.
One potential problem that Bank of Boston will have in this deal is convincing the Justice Department that that there are no antitrust concerns. After this deal, Fleet and Bank of Boston will be by far the dominant banks in New England, with the next largest institutions -- State Street Boston and the Boston Company unit of Mellon -- focused on serving institutions rather than consumers.
Bank of Boston executives insist that the combination does not violate the Justice Department's rules. But some banking experts say that this interpretation requires the Government to treat all the savings banks in the region as equally competitive to commercial banks, an approach that is not always taken.
While some shareholders of Bank of Boston may be upset that it did not choose simply to sell itself to an out-of-state banking company, Mr. Gifford defended the acquisition.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
$2.3 Billion Deal To Give NBC Rights To Future Olympics

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
NBC cornered the Olympic television market yesterday by agreeing to spend $2.3 billion for the broadcast and cable rights to the 2004 Summer, 2006 Winter and 2008 Summer Olympics even before the sites of the Games have been determined.
The deal is the richest in television sports history, provides a stream of highly rated programming for NBC into the next decade and is a financial legacy for Juan Antonio Samaranch, the International Olympic Committee's president. 
 The deal pre-empted bidding from NBC's three rivals, further cementing the cozy relationship between the network and the I.O.C. NBC's payments of $793 million for the 2004 Games, $613 million for 2006 and $894 million for 2008 could have been higher if ABC, Fox and CBS had been allowed to bid.
The I.O.C. confidently swapped its removal from competitive bidding with a promise to split revenues with NBC after the network's advertising sales exceed the cost of buying and producing the Games. The arrangement is a variation on the formula adopted for next year's Summer Olympics in Atlanta, in which the I.O.C. started sharing when NBC's advertising sales topped $615 million. The I.O.C. has already begun collecting its share, and ad sales have reached $650 million.
The extraordinary spending promised by NBC comes just five months after it agreed to pay the I.O.C. $1.25 billion for the television rights to the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, and the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.
The talks that spawned yesterday's deal began the day that the August package was announced. The I.O.C. executive board approved it last week.
NBC's enthusiastic Olympic futures trading means that by 2008, the network will have shown six consecutive Summer Olympics and five straight Winter or Summer Olympics, unprecedented even when ABC Sports ruled Olympic telecasting.
The maneuver will keep CBS, which was just acquired by Westinghouse, Capital Cities/ABC, which is in the process of being acquired by the Walt Disney Company, and Rupert Murdoch's Fox Network out of the bidding picture for a long time. The only coming Olympics that won't be shown by NBC will be the 1998 Winter Games from Nagano, Japan, for which CBS is paying $375 million.
NBC moved so quickly that the other networks may have been caught by surprise.
"They may have done some planning, but they weren't doing any talking," said Dick Pound, the chairman of the I.O.C.'s television negotiations committee.
David Hill, president of Fox Sports, said, "By pulling us out of the equation, it lets us strengthen our relationships with the N.F.L., N.H.L. and major league baseball." ABC and CBS declined comment.
NBC's rights fee is paid in several installments for each Games. First, the United States Olympic Committee gets a 10 percent cut of the total, or $79.3 million, for example, for the 2004 Olympics. The I.O.C. receives three payments: 30 percent, or about $214 million, four years before the Olympic flame is lighted, then up to 35 percent, or $249.7 million, one month before the Olympics start, and the remaining $249.7 million one month after the flame is doused.
NBC's wager is that the power of Olympic programming outweighs the risk of its future payments. With aggressive backing from General Electric, NBC's parent company, the network combined its experience in selling commercial time for the 1988, 1992 and 1996 Summer Olympics, predictions about the advertising market, inflation, income from its stations and the value the Olympics add to the network's cable holdings, CNBC and America's Talking.
"But in the end, you're piling assumptions upon assumptions," said Bob Wright, the president of NBC. "It's a definite risk. There are scenarios where we'd be in a loss situation with a negative advertising situation."
Neal Pilson, the former president of CBS Sports, said NBC smartly removed the Olympics from the competitive bidding that has forced steep increases in sports rights fees. He added: "The effect on the bottom line is not the question. It's the promotional value, the coupling of the NBC and G.E. names with an event that has known nothing but success for the past decade."
Jack Welch, the G.E. chairman, enthusiastically supported NBC's bid, Mr. Wright said. "He doesn't do a lot of flinching," he said.
NBC is counting on major I.O.C. sponsors to buy commercial time, yet such purchases are rarely made a decade in advance, said Steve Grubbs, senior vice president of BBDO New York. However, he said the Olympics' importance to advertisers will grow "because of their uniqueness."
The I.O.C.-NBC relationship is very close, largely because of NBC's Olympic bankroll: from 1988 to 2008, it will total $4.7 billion. Mr. Pound lauded NBC for its "corporate and cultural" devotion to the Olympics. One long-term connection between the two entities is Alex Giladi, an NBC Sports vice president who also serves as Israel's member of the I.O.C.
"We've carved out a love affair with the I.O.C.," said Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports. "In August, we got engaged. Now it seemed reasonable to get married and open up a joint checking account."
Yesterday's deal continues the fiscal policy the I.O.C. began with last August's two-Olympics deal with NBC: swap potentially larger bounties from future negotiations for the financial stability promised by NBC's money.
"It enables us to plan ahead more effectively," Mr. Pound said. "It provides certainty for organizing committees; they'll know in advance what they'll get."
The I.O.C. distributes money to the host cities' organizing committees, national Olympic committees and international athletic federations.
The I.O.C. also accepted the inflation adjustments that swell NBC's huge payments: the $793 million payment for 2004 was determined by adding four years of 3 percent inflation over NBC's $705 million fee for the rights to the Sydney Games; the $613 million payment for 2006 is a similar adjustment from NBC's $545 million Salt Lake City fee; the $894 million fee is adjusted similarly from $793 million.
"We were willing to trade on inflation for revenue sharing," Mr. Pound said.
But one industry executive familiar with Olympic television negotiations said: "The I.O.C. is mortgaging its future. They're going for the sure thing rather than ride the marketplace. Multiple network competition has been driving the marketplace, and there's no reason to think the competition will decrease."
The I.O.C.'s deal with NBC coincides with a change in how the I.O.C. distributes its television money to local organizing committees, such as the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games.
Each organizing committee now receives 60 percent of the fee. But starting in 2004, that distribution will be shaved to 49 percent, giving Mr. Samaranch more money to pass out to his constituencies, which cannot harm his chances for re-election if he decides to run in September 1997.

HEADLINE: Singing the Steelworker Blues;
A Mini-Mill Deal at LTV Leaves Union Feeling Jilted

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: MIDDLEBURG HEIGHTS, Ohio

 BODY:
For seven long years, the steelworkers here say, they stood by the LTV Corporation as it fought its way back from the brink of collapse. Thousands lost their jobs, and the survivors made numerous wage and benefit concessions to ease LTV's load.
Today, with the company prospering again, the workers say they are reaping the fruit of their collaboration: betrayal. 
 The source of their anger lies 600 miles away, in Decatur, Ala., the heart of right-to-work country, where unions have never gained a firm foothold. There, LTV is joining two foreign steel giants in building a $450 million mini-mill, a high-technology wonder that will be able to produce 2.2 million tons of sheet steel a year with only 300 workers.
The company says nonunion mini-mills -- which do not require hot blast furnaces and eliminate many of the costly and labor-intensive aspects of steelmaking -- are the wave of the future and its only hope for staying competitive in the global economy. But the local steelworkers' union, based in this Cleveland suburb, sees it differently. It says LTV never consulted the union about the investment and is purposely pursuing a policy that will eventually lead to the shutdown of its aging mills in Cleveland and East Chicago, Ind., which together still employ 8,500 workers.
Many of the union's members are furious at what they view as LTV's greed and ingratitude. "When they were in trouble, the company called us 'brother' and was glad to have our help," said George Lapp, a member of Local 1098 of the United Steelworkers of America. "Now they are trying to stab us in the back."
Whatever its outcome, the dispute has wider implications than just the future of LTV's work force. Management and labor, particularly in the steel and automobile industries, made hard-won strides toward collaboration that helped revive industrial productivity and competitiveness during the free fall of American manufacturing in the 1980's. If workers widely judge that path to have been fruitless, analysts say, it could add ammunition to those in the labor movement who are preaching a new militancy to reverse decades of membership decline.
In October, the 13-million-member A.F.L.-C.I.O. elected a new president, John J. Sweeney, who vowed to take a much more aggressive approach to promoting workers' interests than his predecessor, Lane Kirkland. Mr. Sweeney promised to "pour our resources into organizing at a pace and scale that is unprecedented."
The United Steelworkers, whose membership has plummeted to 140,000 from 380,000 in 1979, is likely to prove a receptive audience to Mr. Sweeney's message.
For the moment, there does not seem to be much the union can do about the mini-mill in Alabama, which is scheduled to open in 1997. Michael Scarver, a former local union president in Cleveland who is now on the national organization's staff, says workers are following a rule-book strategy to slow production and are staging noisy demonstrations in Cleveland and Alabama to alert steel buyers that labor relations in the older plants are poor.
But LTV, cheered on by the rest of the industry, is determined to move forward with its plans. David H. Hoag, chairman of the company, said the joint venture would enable the company to cope with foreign competition and the technology revolution that together have forced the restructuring of American industry during the last decade. "It is important that this company grow, and grow profitably," he said.
LTV holds a 50 percent stake in the mini-mill venture, called the Trico Steel Company L.L.C., while Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd. of Japan and British Steel P.L.C. each own 25 percent.
LTV is the first large American steel company to switch to mini-mills from the old integrated plants that have been the norm since the turn of the century. And analysts leave no doubt that its strategic reasoning is sound.
"Not only are these new mills less capital intensive, but they have production cycles measured in hours, rather than days," said Michael F. Gambardella, a steel analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. "That makes them more flexible in meeting shifts in the market."
He added that other traditional steel companies in the United States would have to move in a similar direction if they wanted to remain competitive.
The new mill could have a formidable cost advantage. Based on its planned output and announced manning level, Trico should be able to produce steel with less than half a man-hour of labor per ton. Even the most efficient integrated mills require at least two man-hours per ton.
LTV says that overall wages and benefits will be roughly the same for its workers in Alabama but that the pay package will be more flexible, with a lot of pay tied to incentives related to production. But if both companies pay $35 a hour in pay and benefits, Trico would have a labor cost of $17 a ton, compared with about $70 for a traditional steelmaker like LTV. With a product that sells for about $300 a ton, that arithmetic provides a compelling argument in favor of mini-mills.
Union officials argue that the new mini-mills are crowding into a business with too much production capacity already, particularly during the industry's periodic downturns.
"Mini-mills represent 25 percent of the capacity for making steel in the United States," said George Becker, president of the steelmakers' union. "The new mills are being built to take business away from the integrated companies and shut them down." While the industry is thriving now, that could happen in the next big downturn, union officials say.
For Mr. Becker, the company's abandonment of its workers would be the worst sort of ingratitude. LTV spent nearly seven years operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, paring away nearly 60 percent of its work force before emerging from bankruptcy in June 1993. In 1986, LTV's workers agreed to a wage cut of $1.60 an hour from an average wage then of $12 an hour and gave up a week of vacation and other benefits. The cuts were rescinded starting in 1992 and the company says that subsequent profit sharing has made up more than half the lost income.
"LTV survived the 1980's with the help of the workers," Mr. Becker said. "If the union had not convinced workers to give concessions, the company would not be in existence today."
Mr. Scarver echoed his boss's bitterness. He contends that the company has reneged on a solemn compact. "We worked out partnership agreements with LTV," he said. "We were going to get away from adversarial relationships and move into the 1990's."
But the company says the labor leaders are misguided. "The decision to invest in Trico had nothing to do with the union," said Mr. Hoag, the chairman. He said the products made at Trico, at least initially, would be low-priced sheet steel, which has little overlap with the more highly processed coils from the Cleveland and Indiana plants.
LTV officials acknowledge that the union's work-to-rule campaign is souring the atmosphere at the two Midwestern plants, but maintain that the protest is having little impact on production. "The most troubling part is that local presidents are not working with us to improve the productivity of our facilities," said A. Cole Tremain, the company's vice president for industrial relations. "They will not even come to safety meetings, which is shortsighted."
Though they say they deplore the deterioration of labor relations, LTV executives are refusing to support the union's efforts to organize workers at the Alabama mill. "The union ought to compete and make an effort at organizing Trico," Mr. Hoag said. "Unions have to be competitive like everybody else."
For Mr. Becker and others in the steelworkers' union, that stance adds insult to injury. They say big corporations in general have grown sophisticated in thwarting organizing drives, especially by screening out workers with pro-union attitudes. And they fear that the traditional antipathy in the South to unions can only play into the hands of LTV's management.
"A company that is willing to spend enough money can bust up an organizing drive," Mr. Becker said.
Contrary to the union's contention, Trico will produce a form of sheet steel that will not directly compete -- at least initially -- with LTV's products. But it may nibble away at the edges of the only market left to the integrated producers: the high-quality sheet metal that goes into automobiles and appliances.
LTV is the first American integrated steel company to get into the mini-mill business, but it is not the first to recognize the advantages of the process. Dofasco Inc., an integrated producer in Canada, is one of the investors in Gallatin Steel Inc., a mini-mill that began making sheet steel in northern Kentucky early this year. And Broken Hill Proprietary, an Australian steelmaker, is a partner in a mini-mill being built near Toledo, Ohio, that is to go into operation late next year. In all, more than a dozen new sheet-making mini-mills are in operation or under construction in the United States.
According to Mr. Hoag, it was the threat from the new mills plus a desire to get on the technology bandwagon that drove LTV to form Trico, despite a personal appeal from Mr. Becker not to build the mill. Under the terms of the latest contract between LTV and the union, which was adopted in 1994, the union has the right to name a member to the board of directors and to address the board on important issues.
"Within the next 20 to 30 years steel will be made by entirely different methods," Mr. Hoag said. "We are in a transition away from the capital-intensive ways of the past."
These methods may include making steel in one step from treated iron ore rather than relying on the multiple steps needed now, and casting liquid steel into its final shape, eliminating the costly rolling mills currently in use.
LTV has longstanding links with Sumitomo, one of its partners in Trico. The company operates two electrogalvanizing mills in Cleveland and Columbus, Ohio, that use the Japanese company's technology.
British Steel already operates a mill in Alabama, Tuscaloosa Steel, and is planning to move two iron ore preparation mills from Scotland to the Mobile area. The output of those plants, which is called direct reduced iron, could be used in the electric furnaces of Trico.
The Trico project is being closely watched by steel industry executives, particularly those in the older mills where the union is strong. "If Dave Hoag can stand up to the union and pull this off," said the chief executive of another company, who requested anonymity, "the whole industry will be in his debt."

HEADLINE: Environment Fight Kills Plan For Bridge to Carolina Island

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 12

 BODY:
A South Carolina coastal development agency today refused to allow the construction of a private bridge to Sandy Island, one of only two remaining South Carolina islands that bridges do not link to the mainland.
The decision, by the state's Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management, was a victory for environmentalists and some residents, who had raised fears that the bridge would promote extensive development detrimental to the island. 
 The outcome followed a three-year effort by the owners of 7,000 acres of wooded land on the island to obtain a permit allowing them to build the bridge, which, the owners had said, would be used solely to transport timber harvested there to the mainland. But opponents had remained skeptical of that stated purpose, calling it a ruse that would lead to construction of houses, condominiums and golf courses on the island.
The egg-shaped, 9-by-12-mile Sandy Island is nestled in the delta of the Waccamaw and Great Pee Dee Rivers on the coast, along a strip between Myrtle Beach and Georgetown that is experiencing some of the state's most explosive growth.
The island is currently home to some 135 black residents who are largely the descendants of rice-plantation slaves and who now travel by boat between the island and the mainland. The two-lane, 750-foot-long bridge, across a narrow inlet, would have led to the island's northern part, site of undeveloped land owned by a group that includes Roger Milliken, a textile magnate, and E. Craig Wall Jr., a wealthy South Carolina timber man.
In denying the permit today, the coastal management agency said Sandy Island Associates, the company representing Mr. Milliken and Mr. Wall, had repeatedly refused to survey the entire island for the bridge's effect on colonies of red-cockaded woodpeckers, an endangered species, and to develop plans to protect the bird's habitats.
The landowners, who had insisted that law required them to assess environmental impact only in the area of the proposed bridge and its approaches, refused to provide any further information to the coastal management agency or to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, whose satisfaction the state had required before issuing a permit.
"Because of the applicants' continued refusal to survey for endangered species beyond the project site," the state agency said today, "the project remains inconsistent with the policies of the Coastal Zone Management Program."
Christopher Holmes, a lawyer for the landowners, said his clients had not decided whether to appeal the agency's decision to the courts. He said environmentalists had tried to defeat the project in hopes of buying the land "at bargain-basement prices" to create a wildlife preserve in the area.
Joe Carter, a former developer in the region who is now a supporter of establishing a wildlife preserve in the Waccamaw Neck area, which includes the island and some of the mainland, said Sandy Island would sell for about $2,000 an acre without the bridge but for as much as $10,000 with it and other infrastructure development.
Sandy Island lies amid some 500,000 acres of colonial-era rice plantations and virginal blackwater swamps called the Winyah Bay Focus Area, which Mr. Carter, a number of environmental groups and some Federal agencies would like to see protected from extensive development. Roger Banks, an official in the Charleston office of the Fish and Wildlife Service, is a supporter of the plan, and his office repeatedly found the Sandy Island application incomplete.
David Farren of the Southern Environmental Law Center, a lawyer who represented residents challenging the bridge proposal, applauded the denial of the permit. He said the plan to build a $2 million bridge to transport timber with a value of $1.5 million a harvest had been all a trick to pave the way for extensive development.
"The owners took a narrow view of the process and just wanted to look at the environmental impact of the bridge footings and approach ramps, while we always took the position that you had to look at the impact of it on the entire island," Mr. Farren said. "We're pleased the agency finally saw it our way and now the bridge is dead in the water."

HEADLINE: As Mill's Ruins Smolder, Massachusetts Dream Is Doused

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: METHUEN, Mass., Dec. 12

 BODY:
Ever since Aaron Feuerstein moved his grandfather's sweater manufacturing business here 40 years ago, the Malden Mills textile complex has been a symbol of hope and pride in the blue collar mill towns of the Merrimack Valley. It was the anchor of the economy of northeastern Massachusetts and turned out one of America's most profitable lines of winter wear.
But on Monday night, wind-driven flames from an explosion sent Mr. Feuerstein's dream up in smoke and flame, and left Methuen and dozens of other small towns in the area in a state of shock and despair, barely three weeks before Christmas. 
 The furious blaze not only injured 25 people, nine of them critically, but left more than 1,400 workers out of jobs indefinitely. Like mourners, officials from the offices of Gov. William F. Weld to United States Senators John Kerry and Edward M. Kennedy made the sad trip to Methuen today, to examine the smoking ruins, and pledged to do whatever they could to support those suddenly out of work.
Governor Weld declared the fire a state emergency and praised Mr. Feurerstein, the owner of the mill, as "a great American hero" for promising to rebuild the factory in Massachusetts.
The fire also left the clothing industry wondering how it would manage to satisfy next year's demand among clothiers for Malden Mills' most famous product, Polartec, the popular fabric used by companies like L. L. Bean and Patagonia to line ski jackets and make other winter wear.
In recent years, when other textile plant owners packed up and moved their operations to the south, Mr. Feuerstein and Malden Mills remained committed to Massachusetts, and his workers remained committed to him.
Like other textile factories, Malden Mills suffered its share of slumps, including a spell in bankruptcy, but it persevered and in the early 1980's, its research and development team came up with "polarfleece," and then Polartec, the advanced fabrics that became the rage among skiers, hikers, campers and others who needed light-weight, but very warm, clothing.
Business boomed, and with $425 million in annual sales and upwards of $65 million in annual payroll, Malden Mills became the mainstay of the local economy and an anchor of community redevelopment.
In Washington this afternoon, the state's two Senators organized a meeting that included Labor Secretary Robert E. Reich and Andrew Cuomo of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. They telephoned Mayor Dennis A. DiZoglio of Methuen.
Mayor DiZoglio said Mr. Reich had released $1 million in emergency aid for the unemployed workers. He said Mr. Reich had also assured him of support for waiving the two week waiting period for receiving unemployment benefits. Mayor DiZoglio said the officials also promised to look into extending unemployment benefits because of the extraordinary circumstances.
The fire started at about 8 P.M. Monday with an explosion near the boiler room in a century-old textile building used for flocking, the first of several steps to turn fibers and chemicals into fabric. Within moments, the building, which lies along the Spicket River at the northwest corner of the mill complex, was engulfed. The flames, fanned by fierce winds of up to 45 miles an hour, bore down on three other buildings that sit in a row.
Chief Ken Bourassa of the Methuen Fire Department said the explosion knocked out the factory's sophisticated sprinkler system. More than a hundred fire fighters came to assist from neighboring towns but they were largely powerless.
"It was just a blow torch with that west wind coming in," said Walter Bickford, Malden Mills' director of environment, health and safety.
Company officials estimated that 400 to 500 people were on the job when the fire broke out. Most of them escaped unharmed, some were treated locally and the most seriously injured were taken by helicopter to hospitals in Boston and Worcester.
The fire was brought under control by morning but continued to burn throughout today as shell-shocked workers wondered collectively how they would make mortgage and car payments, put food on the table and presents under the Christmas tree.
At a news conference with Governor Weld, Mr. Feurerstein, who who will turn 70 next week, said that long ago he decided not to move his company to the South or to Asia as many other textile mills had done.
Mr. Feurerstein said the business, which was founded 90 years ago by his grandfather Henry, "will do everything in its power to get back in operation as soon as possible."
He predicted that at least some operations could be running within two weeks.
An account for contributions was set up by the Methuen Co-operative Bank, and George Whyte, the president of Dakotah Inc., a company in Webster, S.D., that is one of Malden Mills biggest customers, immediately donated $30,000 donated from himself and his workers.
Spokeswomen for several producers of outerwear that use the synthetic fleece said it was too early to gauge the long-term impact of the blaze.
This season, supplies of garments are complete, but next year becomes uncertain.
The stock price of a competing textile company, the Dyersburg Corporation, rose sharply today. Shares in the Dyersburg., Tenn., concern climbed as much as 35 percent during trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops by 9.40 and Other Indexes Also Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A slide in technology stocks, combined with diminished hopes for an interest rate cut by the end of the year, kept stock prices in negative territory yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.40, to 5,174.92. Broad market indexes also fell. Eastman Kodak, Allied Signal, United Technologies and Union Carbide all fell a point or more. 
 "The Dow has been up over 450 points in the last six weeks," said Alfred E. Goldman, vice president at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. "It came a long way in a short time, and now we are seeing a little correction. It's a pause to refresh."
Declining issues led advances by 13 to 9 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled 349.9 million shares as of 4 P.M., against 344 million on Monday.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index fell 0.37, to 329.80, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 0.74, to 618.78, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 0.11, to 535.54.
Weakness in technology issues sent the Nasdaq composite index down 9.43, to 1,052.07.
A barrage of weak economic reports in recent months has led many investors to believe the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates when its policy-making committee meets on Dec. 19, a move that would make stocks more attractive relative to fixed-return investments like bonds. Lower rates would also cut corporate financing costs and thus push earnings higher.
But a Labor Department report yesterday showing a higher-than-expected gain in wholesale prices for November raised fears about inflation and in turn dampened hopes that a rate cut would soon come.
While lower rates would spur economic growth, they could also aggravate inflationary pressures.
The inflation "numbers at first gave the market the jitters," said Arthur Hogan, head of equity trading at Dean Witter, Discover & Company in New York. "Then people started looking at the facts and figures behind the numbers, and it didn't seem as bad."
"But many people are wondering if the Fed has enough evidence to lower rates," he added.
In addition, investors will be watching the budget talks in Washington and the release of a number of United States economic reports as indicators of whether the Fed will ease rates.
Banks and brokerage firms, which are sensitive to interest-rate fluctuations, were lower. Citicorp fell 2, to 65 3/4, Republic Bank of New York dropped 1, to 63 3/8, and Morgan Stanley fell 1/2, to 85.
The market also came under pressure from a decline in technology shares, following the Semiconductor Industry Association's report late Monday that demand for computer chips fell slightly in November but remained ahead of last year's levels.
The technology group was also hurt after Soundview Financial Group, which tracks high-technology issues, reportedly said that pricing of memory chips could be weakening.
Intel was down 1 1/4, to 62 1/4; Motorola dropped 1/2, to 61 1/2, and Texas Instruments fell 1 3/4, to 54 1/2.
Paper and forest product stocks tumbled after Georgia-Pacific, the nation's largest maker of building materials, said that fourth-quarter profits would not meet analysts' forecasts because of soft prices and weak demand for pulp and containerboard.

HEADLINE: Attacks Against Asian-Americans On the Rise, Especially in California

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12

 BODY:
He chose his course of action matter-of-factly, as if he were deciding which color shirt to wear. "I'm going to kill me a Chinaman," is how Robert Page put it in his written confession to the police.
A few hours later, as Eddy Wu carried a bag of groceries from a supermarket in Novato, Calif., to his car, Mr. Page attacked, leaving Mr. Wu, 23, with stab wounds to his back and shoulder, and a punctured lung. 
 "He was looking for a victim based on his white supremacist beliefs," Jim Laveroni, a police sergeant in the affluent suburb about 30 miles north of San Francisco, said at Mr. Page's court hearing last month.
The assault on Mr. Wu is the latest in a series of recent race-based incidents directed against Asian-Americans, particularly in northern California.
A study released in July by the National Asian Pacific-American Legal Consortium, an organization representing 40 groups, calculated that there was a 35 percent increase in anti-Asian hate crimes nationwide to 452 incidents last year, up from 335 incidents, in its audit for 1993. In Northern California, the increase more than doubled to 83 last year, from 39 the year before.
The State Attorney General's first hate-crimes report, which was released today, counts 57 hate crimes against Asian-Americans in the last six months of 1994, involving 72 victims.
The crimes, as reported to various Asian-American organizations and to the police, include racist-graffiti on the offices of the Japanese-American Citizens League in Sacramento, an attack on a Chinese-American family in a Vallejo, Calif., amusement park, where they were taunted and told to return to China, and the fire-bombing of the home of a Chinese city councilman in Sacramento. In a significant number of incidents, attackers say, "Go home," or "Get out of my country," the report said.
The attacks have largely baffled the police in places like Novato, whose middle- and upper-middle class community is widely regarded as liberal and tolerant. And, compared with the rest of California, it has a small Asian-American population -- not large enough, residents suggest, to pose a threat to anyone.
The incidents have heightened fears among many Asian-Americans that increasingly blatant race-based harassment is on the rise and that those who commit these crimes seem to hate Asians without drawing distinctions between newly arrived immigrants and native-born Americans, or between Chinese, Japanese, Cambodians and other Asian nationalities and ethnic groups.
"Like most minority groups, we're accustomed to dealing with subtle forms of racism," Thanh Ngo, a lawyer with the Asian Law Caucus in San Francisco said about the attack Mr. Wu. "But it's striking to see such a blatant act. A lot of people are very frightened."
Like many of the more recent crimes, the attack on Mr. Wu involved a young white man.
Still at issue is whether Mr. Page is competent to stand trial. A psychologist hired by the public defender's office told a judge last week that Mr. Page was seriously disturbed, and a hearing has been set in January to determine his competency. Meanwhile, Mr. Page, who is being held in the Marin County Jail, has been charged with attempted murder with bail set at $1 million.
In another incident in May, across the bay in Los Altos, John Lee, 28, an American of South Korean ancestry, stopped at a gas station. There he was approached by a white man, Justin Adams, who began taunting him by putting his hands together and bowing "Buddha-like," squinting his eyes and mimicking an Asian accent. According to police and court records, Mr. Lee confronted Mr. Adams and two other whites, saying his antics were not amusing. Mr. Adams then punched him several times, kicking Mr. Lee to the ground. One Mr. Adams's companion's kicked Mr. Lee in the head, and the third man punched Mr. Lee as he lay on the pavement.
The three men were later arrested. Two pleaded guilty to battery. Mr. Adams pleaded innocent to charges of committing a hate crime. The case, which went to trial in October, resulted in a hung jury. The local District Attorney's office has announced plans to try Mr. Adams again.
National Asian Pacific-American Legal Consortium said in its report: "Many incidents begin as simple name-calling and escalate into further violence resulting in serious or fatal injuries. Further, racist hate messages alone cause real psychological and emotional damage on their victims."
Elaine H. Kim, a professor of Asian-American studies at the University of California, Berkeley, and chairwoman of the comparative ethnic studies department, said Asian-Americans have faced a distinctive type of racism in the last 100 years, a feeling on the part of the white population that "you can't be here."
"My mother came to Hawaii in 1903 as an infant, and she could not become a citizen until 1952," Professor Kim said. "I think it's always tied to resentment. If you don't make it, you get kicked down. And if you make it, you get kicked down. It's really a Catch 22."
What is particularly unnerving for many Asian-Americans, community groups say, is that success has not bred tolerance; they have assimilated into many communities but are still the objects of hate. Rather, their financial and educational achievements may have engendered a new generation of hate crimes directed at them disenfranchised whites who are jealous.
One factor that may be fueling the upsurge in hate crimes, especially in California, has been the unparalleled influx of Asian-American immigrants in recent years. In San Francisco County, for example, Asian-Americans are now the largest minority group, exceeding in numbers the black population and people of Hispanic descent combined. Data from the 1990 census show that the 337,118 white residents of the county constitute 46.6 percent of the population; Asians, whose numbers total 205,686, constituted 28.4 percent; Hispanics totaled 100,717, or 13.9 percent; blacks were 76,343 or 10.5 percent, and the rest were American Indians, Eskimo's and Pacific Islanders.
But even as Asian-Americans are integrated into their communities, changing the character of those communities, they are still considered to be interlopers by some, and thus legitimate candidates for harassment. The consortium complained in its report, for instance, that "in best-selling novels and blockbuster movies, Asian-Pacific-Americans continue to be cast as untrustworthy foreigners, devious economic competitors or martial arts experts."
Perhaps an even bigger factor inciting anti-Asian sentiment, experts say, is what many see as growing nativism and racial intolerance exemplified by Proposition 187, the immigration-control proposal that has become one of California's biggest political disputes.
Diane Chin, a lawyer and co-chairman of the Intergroup Clearinghouse in San Francisco, a nonprofit group that assists victims of hate crimes, said that with Governor Pete Wilson's promotion of Proposition 187, "There has been a climate created by the established political leadership that devalues people of color, and gays, lesbians and bisexuals; they've established a climate that allows hate violence to exist."
Michael Wong, the co-chairman of Break the Silence, a San Francisco-based group that documents hate crimes against Asians and provides assistance to victims, suggested that the increase in anti-Asian hate crimes is linked to the Congressional debate over welfare cuts. "At a time when public benefits are being curtailed, there's a lot of talk of not having enough space and resources to protect our communities," Mr. Wong said. "There's a lot of scapegoating and pitting populations against one another."

HEADLINE: Wave of Optimism Lifts Budget Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Their differences narrowed by a new economic forecast, negotiators from the White House and Congress expressed optimism today that they could avert another partial shutdown of the Government this weekend and eventually reach an overall budget agreement.
But today's sunny mood was not based on the slightest progress in resolving their policy differences. Both sides cautioned that they were by no means out of the woods. 
 The most conciliatory note in a day of much talk and little action came from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. After he and Speaker Newt Gingrich spoke with President Clinton on the telephone, Mr. Dole said he would agree to a one-week extension of the Government's temporary authority to spend money to give the budget negotiators breathing room.
Under the agreement last month that ended the six-day partial shutdown of the bureaucracy, the Government's spending authority will end at midnight Friday. Unless an extension is approved, the many departments and agencies whose appropriations have not yet become law will have to close down beginning this weekend except for essential services.
Senator Dole's position, however, may not be the determining one. Republicans in the House are taking a harder line. Representative John R. Kasich, chairman of the Budget Committee, suggested that Republicans would make considerable demands on the President in return for agreeing to a continuation of spending authority.
Mr. Kasich said Republicans would send the President on Friday a measure that would keep the Government open and be "consistent with our plan to balance the budget."
"The burden of whether the Government stays open is not on our shoulders," Mr. Kasich added. "It's on their shoulders."
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said that Mr. Clinton still wanted an extension of spending authority until Jan. 26 but that he would take a shorter one if that was all he could get from Congress.
On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is expected to tell the House that he plans to sidestep the national borrowing limit in January by giving the Civil Service Retirement Trust Fund an i.o.u. instead of $14.5 billion in Federal securities as an interest payment. Under the quirky accounting rules that govern the debt limit, that i.o.u. does not count against the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling.
That maneuver will give Mr. Rubin enough operating room to make it through January. But after that, his easy options for avoiding default will be largely exhausted, and he will have to find other strategies, and other Government-held funds, to keep paying the Government's bills. Treasury officials say they are still working to devise techniques that could withstand legal challenge from Republicans who hope to use the debt limit crisis to win on the budget.
The problem is that 6 of 13 bills to provide money for the operations of the Government in this fiscal year have not become law. Among them are measures to finance the Departments of Health and Human Services, Commerce, State, Veterans Affairs, Labor and Housing and Urban Development.
The Republicans who control Congress are insisting that these bills be considered in the overall budget negotiations along with the long-range budget legislation President Clinton vetoed last week. That measure is supposed to balance the budget in seven years while reducing taxes and limiting spending on Medicare, Medicaid and dozens of other benefit programs.
In some cases, the Republicans have not been able to agree among themselves on the spending bills. In other cases, they do not want to give Mr. Clinton the positive publicity he might get for vetoing measures that would cut spending for popular programs like those involving education and the environment.
Negotiators from the White House and Congress met for two hours this morning to review a new economic forecast released by the Congressional Budget Office on Monday.
The new projections narrow somewhat the difference between Congress and the White House over how much spending must be limited in order to balance the budget by 2002. Both sides said today that the new figures gave them hope that a deal could be struck.
As usual, the negotiators met today in a closed room. But as has become their practice, they trooped to a bank of television cameras afterward and offered their assessments.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said he was encouraged by the new economic projections and believed "we made some progress today."
Mr. Kasich was also upbeat. He and Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said the Republicans would work on a new proposal taking the new economic figures into consideration.
"There are additional resources now on the table," Mr. Kasich said. "They afford us the opportunity to improve our product."
But both sides acknowledged that big differences remained and that little progress had been made in settling them.
Mr. Panetta, for example, said President Clinton was dead-set against the Republican plan to let the states set the eligibility standards and benefit levels for Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor.
And Mr. Domenici said, "We're still fairly far apart."
Later, in an interview, Senator Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, one of the Democratic negotiators, said nothing happened today to justify optimism. "We have not begun any negotiations," he said. "If this were a trip, we'd still be at the starting line."
While the official negotiations are under way, according to Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, a group of about 15 moderate senators from both parties have been meeting regularly to see whether they can find a way to split the differences between their more ideological colleagues.
Even if the negotiators can ultimately reach a budget agreement among themselves, there is no guarantee it will become law.
One reason is that a filibuster in the Senate is now possible. Normally, under the rules, budget legislation cannot be filibustered. That means that measures can be passed in the Senate by a simple majority.
But parliamentarians say that the bill to which the no-filibuster rule applied is now dead because of the Presidential veto and that any new budget measure is subject to a filibuster that would take 60 votes to overcome.
A compromise could also be blocked in the House if the most conservative Republicans and the most liberal Democrats vote against it on the ground that their principles were being abridged. That is what happened in 1990 to the first compromise on the budget struck by President George Bush and the leaders of the Democrats who then controlled Congress.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Jump but Quirk Is Seen in Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
In a report that proved more startling than worrisome, Government figures showed today that wholesale prices jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in November, the heftiest increase since January.
The advance, which was about twice as much as expected, initially jolted the bond market because it seemed likely to dim prospects that an inflation-conscious Federal Reserve would ratify a cut in short-term interest rates at its policy meeting next Tuesday. 
 But closer study largely reassured economists and traders. The price surge was heavily concentrated in new cars and trucks, the new models of which, to the consternation of Government statisticians, were placed on sale a month later than usual this year. Moreover, analysts suggested, automotive sales have been so sluggish that rebates and other incentives are likely to erode posted prices significantly.
"The jump in producer prices does not indicate that inflation is suddenly coming back as a major problem," said Lynn Reaser, senior vice president and chief economist for First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
In addition to the aberration in motor vehicles, she pointed to no change in the price of goods at the intermediate stage of production and to a second straight sizable decline in raw materials other than food and energy.
Nonetheless, Ms. Reaser added, today's report could raise doubts among Fed officials inclined to press for a December rate cut, especially if it is followed this week by reports of brisk retail sales for November and a burst in prices at the consumer level.
Ried, Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm, told clients that "arguments for and against a modest easing at next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting are still balanced."
Separately, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its semiannual economic forecast that members expected prices they pay for goods to rise a scant five-tenths of 1 percent during 1996, far under the 3.1 percent projected for 1995.
In the new year, 59 percent of the group's members predict an average increase of 3.2 percent, with the tobacco, textiles, primary metals, leather and printing and publishing industries experiencing the largest. The 29 percent of members expecting lower prices predict a 4.5 percent decline.
Over all, the purchasing managers project slower growth in 1996, with company revenues up 4.8 percent in current dollars compared with a 7.4 percent rise this year.
The Labor Department's report today of a November increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods reflected a 1.2 percent surge in food prices as well as bursts of 1.6 percent for light trucks and 1.3 percent for passenger cars.
Fresh eggs soared 22.6 percent while increases also accelerated for processed fruits and vegetables and roasted coffee, the report showed.
Finished energy goods declined five-tenths of 1 percent as gasoline fell 3.8 percent, its sixth straight decline, to offset an upturn for home heating oil and an acceleration for residential electric power.
The so-called core Producer Price Index, which excludes food and energy, typically the most volatile components, rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, also the highest since January, the report showed.
Among intermediate goods, such as a bolt of cloth, prices were unchanged over all, with plywood and other durable items used in manufacturing down six-tenths of 1 percent and basic organic chemicals and other nondurables down nine-tenths of 1 percent.
As for crude goods, or raw materials, there was a jump of 1.6 percent over all but this was heavily concentrated in food and energy. Without these categories, crude materials tumbled 2.1 percent, the fifth straight monthly decline. Wastepaper plunged nearly 25 percent after a 32 percent dive in October.
"If the economy remains sluggish into 1996, consumers and businesses may do again what they've done consistently for the past three years -- refuse to pay significantly higher prices for goods," Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, declared. The finished-goods Producer Price Index gauges what the group's members pay the producers from whom they buy.
Still another report today, from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, showed its index of industrial activity declined further last month, to minus 13.1, with the prices received and prices paid indexes among the several declines.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Higher as Traders Foresee a Rate Cut in Germany

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday as traders speculated that slowing German economic growth would lead the Bundesbank to cut interest rates at its council meeting tomorrow.
The German Government said last week that the economy expanded 1.9 percent in the year that ended on Sept. 30, down from 2.5 percent in the year that ended on June 30. And the Bundesbank, the German central bank, reported yesterday that inflation in western Germany fell to an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the six months that ended in November, from 1.6 percent in the period that ended in October. 
 "Anticipation of a German discount rate cut is supporting the dollar," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York.
Lower interest rates hurt a currency by making bank deposits denominated in it less attractive.
The dollar was quoted at 1.4475 marks, up from 1.4443 marks on Monday in New York. It also rose against the Japanese yen, moving to 101.76 yen, up from 101.09 yen on Monday. The British pound slipped to $1.5330 from $1.5345 in New York.
There was talk in the market that the dollar was aided against the yen by dollar purchases from Caltex Petroleum, Mr. Spence said. The company, an oil refiner partly owned by Texaco Inc., last week said that it had agreed to sell its half-interest in a Japanese oil-refinery venture to its partner, the Nippon Oil Company of Tokyo, for 200 billion yen. Caltex officials were not available yesterday to comment on the speculation.
The dollar had dipped early yesterday after the Government reported that producer prices rose an unexpectedly high five-tenths of 1 percent in November. That gain was the biggest since January and exceeded economists' average forecast of a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent.
"It's a big surprise and may bring jitters into the market for the dollar," said Karl Halligan, a trader at CIC Bank New York. "We could get stagflation, and that is the worst thing you could have."
Stagflation refers to slow economic growth combined with high inflation. The economy grew at an annualized rate of 4.2 percent in the third quarter; analysts say that the rate this quarter has decelerated to a level between 2 and 3 percent.
Still, the economy is growing enough to keep the dollar rising, especially given the economic weakness in Europe, said Bob Gruber, senior currency salesman at Chemical Bank.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Shrank Over Summer

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit, which climbed to worrisome levels in the spring, shrank in the summer as American businesses were able to sell more overseas and Americans bought fewer foreign goods.
The Commerce Department reported today that the deficit in the nation's current account narrowed to $39.48 billion in the July-September quarter. 
 That was an 8.7 percent improvement from the April-June period, when the deficit had surged to $43.27 billion.
The current account is the broadest measure of America's trading performance, measuring trade in merchandise, services, investment flows and a category that includes America's foreign aid payments. Analysts were encouraged by the report, which reflected trends already evident in the Government's less-inclusive monthly trade reports.
Through the first nine months of the year, the current account is running at an annual rate of $162 billion, close to the worst deficit of $167.1 billion set in 1987.
But analysts said most of that deterioration reflected the severe economic problems of Mexico, an important export market. Many said they believed the second quarter represented the low point for the trade gap. Because the economy has slowed, demand is dropping for imported products.
Bruce Steinberg, economist at Merrill Lynch in New York, said he believed the trade deficit would continue to shrink at least through 1998.
"Exports have been growing a lot faster in the United States in recent years than in many other industrialized countries," Mr. Steinberg said. "That goes back to the rising competitiveness of U.S. companies and the leading roles they are playing in many technology industries."
The deficit in merchandise trade in the third quarter shrank by $5.37 billion, to $43.43 billion, as exports climbed by 1.7 percent, reflecting gains in sales of both manufactured goods and farm products.
America's surplus in services, including tourism and consulting fees, climbed to $15.9 billion in the third quarter, up by $545 million from the second quarter.
While merchandise trade and services contributed to an improvement in the overall deficit, the other two categories showed higher deficits in the summer.
The difference between what Americans earn on their overseas investments and what foreigners earn on their American holdings rose to $4.2 billion in the third quarter, up from $2.6 billion in the second. And America's deficit on unilateral transfers, the category that includes foreign aid, climbed to $7.8 billion in the third quarter from $7.2 billion.
