HEADLINE: Kareem Brunner's Lesson

 BODY:
Kareem Brunner, a black security guard at Freddy's clothing store in Harlem, died last Friday with six co-workers in a fire set by a lone gunman who was apparently deranged by his hatred for white businesses on 125th Street. But Mr. Brunner still speaks. In an affidavit describing harassment by protesters picketing the store, he tells of being called a "cracker lover" and a "traitor" to his race.
The Freddy's affidavits describe a poisonous atmosphere, in which protesters shrieked about "bloodsucking Jews" and threatened to burn the store. Yet until the disaster, few people outside of 125th Street knew about the protests. Aides to local politicians contended that the demonstrations were so small they scarcely noticed them. "The only thing that came to us was a landlord-tenant dispute," said Representative Charles Rangel. 
 The protests were apparently not too small to inspire Roland Smith, a former street vendor, to shoot four men and set Freddy's on fire, killing himself along with seven workers. If this grim event teaches us nothing else, it should serve as another reminder that words of racial hate often lead to deeds of racial violence. Rantings that would incite only the deranged cannot be ignored, because the deranged live among us.
The outrage at Freddy's occurred at a time of encouraging economic signs in Harlem. But at the same time, racial tension has been climbing. The weakest entrepreneurs -- the sidewalk vendors -- were all black, and they had been swept away. Small black-owned businesses like Sikhulu Shange's Record Shack were being pressured out by rising rents. In their place came larger, better capitalized, mainly white and Asian businesses.
Every political leader or street cop in Harlem knew this story, and should have been aware that serious problems would arise. Community activists who wanted to protest the eviction of black business owners had a responsibility not to let their legitimate complaints turn into a racial vendetta against non-black merchants. Yet almost all of them targeted the white-owned clothing store as the culprit in the Record Shack's eviction, ignoring the fact that the building's owner, a black church, was the more important player.
Harlem politicians held a press conference yesterday to say that they would stage a show of support this weekend for Bargain World, another white-owned store on 125th Street that has been the target of protesters. The community leaders also pointed out, rightly, that the hatemongers were few in number and often "outsiders" who do not live in Harlem. The excuse of "outsiders" is irrelevant, however, if the community itself does not shun the troublemakers when they arrive. Harlem must make hate unwelcome, echoing the words of the Democratic leader Cedric McClester, who promised yesterday that he would "not let that happen again. I will speak up, no matter how unpopular it might make me for the moment."
Leaders of the Police Department made it clear yesterday that they had been discouraged by the owner of Freddy's from making arrests at the picket line. The police might not have been able to stop the crime with the utmost vigilance, since it occurred when the protesters were absent. But the police also did not reach out to any other city agency to warn them of problems on 125th Street. When protesters staged a similar demonstration in 1990 against a Korean fruit stand in Brooklyn, Mayor David Dinkins sent several agencies into the neighborhood to do community outreach. The demonstrations dragged on forever, permanently damaging Mr. Dinkins's reputation for leadership. But they did not result in any violence.
A grand jury will begin hearing evidence in the Freddy's case. If there was illegal behavior by protesters, it will be up to the police and the District Attorney's office to identify them. The rest of us will be left to contemplate Kareem Brunner's story, and find ways to avoid a repetition.

HEADLINE: Have Schools Failed? Revisionists Use Army of Statistics to Argue No

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
Though conventional wisdom holds that the nation's educational system is in persistent, debilitating decline, a dissident chorus has of late been making an intriguing but unfashionable argument: Maybe American schools are not so bad after all.
Almost no one contends that American schools, particularly poor urban and rural ones, do not need improvement. Few doubt that the worst of those schools are a disaster. 
 But, in an escalating debate clouded by a blizzard of conflicting statistics and the currents of politics, a vocal core of scholars and educational revisionists has created a stir by arguing that there has been no broad decline in American education and that the notion that schools are failing miserably has as much to do with politics as reality.
Finally, they say, the undeniable and alarming failings that do exist in some schools are less the fault of incompetent educators or lax standards than of underinvestment in education and of broad social ills like poverty and urban decline.
At issue is not just the argument over the quality of schools, but also the steps needed to improve them at a time when rising concern about education is colliding with budget pressures to cut spending on it.
On the one side are those who argue that the notion of a broad crisis in American education was overblown from the start and has unfairly undermined confidence in that education. The attacks on education, these critics say, are part of a conservative effort to pave the way for vouchers for private schools or other conservative education policies.
"There's a marvelous indoor sport of attacking the schools that goes back to the turn of the century," said Bruce J. Biddle, director of the Center for Research in Social Behavior at the University of Missouri and co-author with David C. Berliner of "The Manufactured Crisis -- Myths, Fraud and the Attack on America's Public Schools (Addison Wesley, 1995).
"People have consistently said how rotten the schools are, and somehow we've built the atomic bomb, we've gone to the moon, we've become the dominant power in the world. It's utterly mind boggling what we've done despite the fact that we've had such rotten schools. And the reason is the schools were never rotten to start with."
Those on the other side say the alarms sounded most conspicuously in the Department of Education's 1983 report, "A Nation At Risk," were on target and that the country would ignore them at its peril. The report called American education "an act of unthinking, unilateral educational disarmament imperiling the nation's economic health."
"Ever since 'A Nation at Risk,' " said Chester Finn, a fellow at the Hudson Institute research group and a former official in the Reagan Education Department, "there's been this little band of wishful thinkers and revisionists who've denied there's been a problem and who have been enormously popular within the education profession because of that denial. They get lots of prizes and speaking engagements from educators, but everyone else ignores them completely."
Revisionists argue that for more than half a century critics of the schools have harkened to a mythical golden age of learning.
Gerald Bracey, a psychologist and former director of research and development with the Virginia Department of Education, likes to point to one of the critics' examples of how little American students know, a report that found that "a large majority of students showed they had virtually no knowledge of elementary aspects of American history."
But, Mr. Bracey said, the report was based on a test of college freshmen conducted in 1943 by the history department of Columbia University.
A similar assertion that American schools were failing was made in the early 1950's, the revisionists note, and peaked in the aftermath of the Soviet Union's launching of the Sputnik satellite in 1957.
Mr. Bracey and others point to statistics that bolster their case. For instance, they make these points:
*Scores on seven of the nine trends in the widely respected National Assessment of Educational Progress in reading, mathematics and science are at all-time highs.
*The proportion of students scoring above 650 on the Scholastic Achievement Test mathematics test is at an all-time high, even before the scores were adjusted upward last spring. Much of the decline in scores registered in the 1960's and early 1970's has reversed.
*The number of students taking Advanced Placement tests, a measure of course difficulty, has risen to 448,000 in 1994 from 98,000 in 1978.
*American 9-year-olds had the second-highest average score among 31 nations in a 1992 international comparison of reading, conducted by the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement, a research group.
The revisionists agree that S.A.T. scores declined markedly in the 1960's and early 1970's -- central to the case against the schools -- but they say that was mostly due to a rapid expansion of the pool of students taking the test as a college education went to a broad-based phenomenon from an elite one.
Similarly, they note that the reported decline of American education has come at a time when the percentage of Americans who graduate from high school has risen to 82 percent in 1993 from 34 percent in 1950, meaning that a much broader array of Americans are being educated than ever before.
Those who defend "A Nation at Risk" and the attendant sense of crisis say the point is not whether Americans are doing better. It is whether they are doing well enough.
"If you say the schools are doing as well as they were 20 years ago, so what?" asked Diane Ravitch, a senior research fellow at New York University and a former Assistant Secretary of Education.
"The world has changed in 20 years, and the schools 20 years ago were considered to be in a state of crisis. We have very serious problems in our schools, and it's a tremendous misrepresentation to say that our students are out-achieving their parents. They're not."
Ms. Ravitch and others marshal their own statistics:
*S.A.T. verbal scores fell from a high of 478 in 1963 to the low 420's by the late 1970's and stood at 423 in 1994. In 1972, 116,585 students, or 11.4 percent of test takers, scored above 600 on the verbal test. In 1994, only 79,606 or 7.6 percent did.
*A series of international assessments in math and science showed American students performing poorly, seldom rising above the median, and often scoring near the bottom.
*American students have shown dismal results on recent national tests in geography and history. On the National Assessment of Educational Progress history test, for example, 57 percent of 12th graders were unable to reach even the "basic" level of achievement.
In fact, given the multiplicity of tests and the enormous variety of the United States' decentralized and wildly disparate schools, there is truth in both arguments.
Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley said that the direst view of education decline ignored the remarkable shifts in the 1960's in which educational opportunity expanded as schools integrated and rates of graduation rose. In that sense, Mr. Riley said, the notion of a precipitous drop in standards and achievement is unfair and inaccurate.
But the Secretary also said the alarms of the "nation at risk" report reflected a changing society in which the blue-collar jobs of the past were disappearing and the schools were not adequately training students for new ones.
"Whether there was as much of a crisis as some said or not," Mr. Riley said, "I don't think was as important as what the needs of the nation were. What we needed was to notch up education, increase standards."
He said American students had increased by one full grade on national tests in math and science since the 1983 report, although they still fared poorly on most international comparisons.
The worst failing of the "nation at risk" report, some critics said, was that it wildly overstated both the nature of the problem and the schools' impact on the nation's economic health.
Lawrence Cremin, an educational historian at Columbia, has said that the nation's economic competitiveness rests overwhelmingly on decisions about monetary, trade and industrial policy. Blaming economic decline on the schools, Mr. Cremin contends, is "at best a foolish and, at worst, a crass effort" to distract attention from those most in control.
Some defenders of the nation's schools also cite a recent study showing that the vast majority of the increased spending on schools has come in special education. That, they say, is a powerful refutation of the argument that the nation has thrown money at its schools with little to show for it.
The revisionists' idea of a right-wing effort to discredit schools is less compelling, most experts in education say. "If you think that Clinton and Bush and the National Governors' Association and Al Shanker put their heads together and conspired to concoct a crisis," Ms. Ravitch said, "then I have a bridge I want to sell you."
And many of the same experts say nothing would be worse for the country's schools than a sense of complacency, which they contend the revisionist argument could engender.
"What you're hearing is an argument not to reform," said Jeanne Allen, president of the Center for Education Reform, a private research group. "The 'nation at risk' report was a wake-up call that change within the system would not work unless you start holding kids accountable, holding schools accountable, holding educators accountable and putting consequences there for people who don't succeed."
Still, with the fixation on test scores and economic productivity, some skeptics wonder whether the real purpose of education is still being lost by both sides.
"What's going to hold this nation together isn't the G.N.P. or cyberspace and computers," said Richard Gibboney, a professor of public policy at the University of Pennsylvania. "It's really the democratic quality of our society.
"We should be talking about the cultivation of intelligence, but as soon as I say that half the people listening would fall asleep. Basically, our society has the schools it wants, ones that credential, certify, grade and sort people. But we're still tapping a small percentage of the brain power and emotional power that kids have. We're still boring them to death."

HEADLINE: Who's Queen of the Met? Her Fans Know Who

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
On Monday morning at the Metropolitan Opera, a tour group of students walked through the Dress Circle promenade, looking at costumed mannequins in display cases and listening to a guide tell stories of the company's glorious past.
Yet at that moment, living history was standing just one flight below. For the first time in almost 20 years, Renata Tebaldi, one of opera's near-legendary sopranos, was back in America, back at the company that was her primary artistic home during the height of her career. 
 Some of the students peered down over the railing, wondering who that lady was on the Grand Tier staircase posing for a photographer. For Miss Tebaldi, now 73, it was a very emotional experience, as she later explained.
"As soon as I walked in," she recalled, "I said to myself, 'This is my theater!' For many years I was 'la regina' here. The queen. It was sad. But I know how to dominate my feelings."
Few people who know about the matter would contest that during Miss Tebaldi's years at the Met -- from 1955, when she made her debut as Desdemona in "Otello," with Mario Del Monaco in the lead and Leonard Warren as Iago, until 1973, when she sang her final Met performances in the same opera, with a still-green 29-year-old maestro named James Levine on the podium -- she was indeed "la regina."
As a singer, Miss Tebaldi was thought to have had it all. Her solid musicianship was built on years of studying the piano in her youth. (Her mother did not want her to be a singer, Miss Tebaldi said: "She thought the theater was a place of perdition!") Miss Tebaldi also had stylistic understanding, temperament and one of the most lustrously beautiful lirico spinto voices ever. Her acting, though not demonstrative, was effective. "What made her performances so moving," Mr. Levine said recently, "was the generous presence that she exuded. As Desdemona, she honestly projected that character's innocence and tenderness."
What brings Miss Tebaldi here is the release of a biography by Carlamaria Casanova, published by Baskerville Press, and a week of attendant events organized by the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Yesterday afternoon some 1,200 people showed up at the Met's gift shop, where Miss Tebaldi signed copies of the book and her many recordings on the London label. At one point, the line stretched out the Met, across the plaza and up Broadway to the 66th Street subway station.
There will be two more autograph sessions: tomorrow from 2 until 4 P.M., at HMV Records on Fifth Avenue at 46th Street; and on Saturday from 3 until 5 P.M., at Barnes & Noble in Lincoln Square. Yesterday she received a proclamation from that longtime Tebaldi fan at City Hall, Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani. Tomorrow she will attend the Met's production of "Un Ballo in Maschera." But she is saving quiet time to see some old friends, Carol Burnett and Van Cliburn. And on Friday she will meet students and faculty at Juilliard.
It's a busy week and the weather is bitter cold, but Miss Tebaldi is in radiant good health and enjoying it all. Over coffee at the offices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild the other day, she reflected on her life since retirement, on her new book and on the state of singing today.
In recent years Miss Tebaldi has been living quietly in Milan, tending to her home, seeing friends and listening to her own records, something she could never bear to do during her active career. "I cry when I hear the records," she said. "Now I understand what happened during my performances. I feel the same thing. Not because I know I am Renata Tebaldi, but because I can be objective."
As for the new book, even from its title, "Tebaldi: The Voice of an Angel," one gathers that it is not exactly a hard-hitting analysis. "Renata loved dogs and wanted one of her own," begins one section. In a question-and-answer chapter, Miss Tebaldi fields such questions as, "From an economic standpoint, should a singer have a manager?"
Yet the book includes a valuable list of her complete performances, a discography, a generous selection of photographs and a CD offering some rare early performances (for example, a 1949 performance of the "Jewel Song" from "Faust," sung in Italian, with scintillating coloratura.)
Unlike many similarly puffy biographies, this one provides some revealing accounts of matters Miss Tebaldi has seldom discussed in public: her near-fatal bout with polio as a child; her father, who abandoned the family and showed up only after his wife had died, a stranger seeking reconciliation with his now famous daughter; and a frank account of her affair with the inconstant Arturo Basile, an opera conductor whose workaday career briefly prospered because of Miss Tebaldi's loyalty.
Her long success, she feels, was due to her ability to draw limits, an ability she says today's singers lack.
"They want to sing everything right away!" she said. "One night they sing 'La Sonnambula.' The next they pretend to sing 'Aida.' This is impossible. You must move step by step, and never sing roles unsuited to your voice."
Another self-imposed limitation that she does not regret is remaining single. "I was in love many times," she said, laughing at the memories. "This is very good for a woman. You have to test everything. But how could I have been a wife, a mother, and a singer? Who takes care of the piccolini when you go around the world? Your children would not call you Mama, but Renata. This I could not do. I could not sing if my mind was in another place."
The book recounts the rivalry, stoked for years by the opera press, between Miss Tebaldi and Maria Callas, a singer who was the "first one to make this mistake of thinking that everything is possible." But in person Miss Tebaldi grew wistful remembering their last meeting.
It was 1968. Miss Tebaldi had just finished a performance of "Adriana Lecouvreur" at the Met. Rudolf Bing asked if she would greet an old friend. Into the dressing room walked a teary Maria Callas, whose singing career was basically over even though she was one year younger. This was just after Callas had suffered the humiliation of being rejected by Aristotle Onassis, who wanted to marry Jacqueline Kennedy.
"It was very sad," Miss Tebaldi said. "We embraced. Maria said I must come see her in Paris. After her career was over, she was very sad and very gentle with me. But I never saw her again."
Knowing when to stop was critical to Miss Tebaldi's great legacy. She was just 54 when she gave her last performance in New York, a recital at Carnegie Hall in February 1976. "Did you hear my last concert?" she asked, expectantly. "It is now on CD. It is wonderful. They had to cut the applause, there was so much."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Renata Tebaldi at the Metropolitan Opera, the scene of many triumphs. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: TEBALDI: THE VOICE OF AN ANGEL (BOOK)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (72%);

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
NBC's Triple Play Bolsters the I.O.C. and Its Chief

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
NBC's $2.3 billion shopping spree yesterday has lent financial certainty to the International Olympic Committee for a dozen years and given additional political security to the committee's 75-year-old president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, should he decide to run for re-election in 1997.
Since assuming the presidency in 1980, Samaranch has worked vigorously to rid the modern Olympics of any vestige of amateurism, from participants to marketing. College stars are out in basketball and ice hockey, professionals are in. Corporations pay $40 million each to become worldwide sponsors of the Winter and Summer Games. 
 Samaranch has drawn criticism for the ills of greed, corruption and doping that tarnish the Olympic luster. But he can also point to the undeniable success of economic strength in the private sector at a time when governments are increasingly unwilling or unable to write a blank check to be host for the Winter and Summer Games. The Olympics have no host cities for the 2004, 2006 and 2008 Games, yet they have guaranteed television money from the movement's financial power, the United States.
"This provides a tremendous vote of confidence in the strength and future of the Olympic movement," Michael Payne, the I.O.C.'s marketing director, said in a telephone interview from Lausanne, Switzerland. "In 1980, most commentators questioned whether the Olympic movement could survive, whether it was too big, too political and had no mechanism to finance it to the end of the century. Fifteen years later, we have a classic turnaround."
Under a worldwide marketing program that involves all 197 Olympic committees, Samaranch has made the Olympic rings "the most widely recognized symbol outside of a religion," said John Krimsky, the chief fund-raiser for the United States Olympic Committee. And with a view toward the financial horizon, Samaranch has turned the bidding for television rights from a quadrennial auction to a long-term package deal.
Cities bidding on the 2004, 2006, and 2008 Games will know exactly what is available from their largest single source of income -- American television. And Samaranch knows there will be more money for the I.O.C. to spread around to various international sports federations and Olympic committees that it nourishes. A point worth noting: beginning in 2004, host cities will receive only 49 percent of the international television money, instead of the current 60 percent.
With his political support shored up by yesterday's announcement, Samaranch, the former Spanish ambassador to the Soviet Union, now seems certain to run for a fourth term in 1997. Last summer, he maneuvered to have the mandatory retirement age for I.O.C. membership raised from 75 to 80 and has become the most formidable figure in Olympic circles since the late Avery Brundage, who served as I.O.C. president from 1952 to 1972 and resisted opening the competition to professionals.
"He's staying," one prominent Olympic official who asked to remain anonymous said of Samaranch. "If there was any confusion, this should clear it up."
Samaranch's unfulfilled ambition is a Nobel Peace Prize. His supporters have campaigned as if he were running for office. If he can bring the Olympics to Africa for the first time, or open up China to the world through the Summer Games, his chances of a Peace Prize would markedly increase, his supporters say.
"He has believed for some time the Olympic movement deserves it," said Anita DeFrantz, one of two I.O.C. members from the United States.
Beijing has until Jan. 10 to bid on the 2004 Summer Games. Samaranch has said that he does not expect a bid from China, which lost narrowly to Sydney, Australia, as host of the 2000 Summer Games. The 2004 Games will be awarded in September of 1997. This will be a sensitive time for China, as it gains control of Hong Kong from Britain and is sure to face increased scrutiny over human-rights issues. Beijing may be reluctant to bid and lose again, I.O.C. officials said. But perhaps NBC's guarantee of $793 million will prove too alluring to ignore.
Absent Beijing, Cape Town has been considered the leading contender. But South Africa's need to rebuild society may prove more urgent than the need to build sports facilities, I.O.C. officials said, delaying that nation's chances until 2008. That may leave Rome, host of the 1960 Summer Games, as a leading contender for 2004 in a field that includes: Buenos Aires; Istanbul, Turkey; Rio de Janeiro; Seville, Spain; St. Petersburg, Russia, and, perhaps, San Juan, P.R., Stockholm and Lille, France.
"If you're NBC, Rome has the history, architecture, European boulevards and ambiance that Americans loved about Barcelona," one Olympic official said.
NBC will have no say in determining Olympic sites, said Dick Pound of Canada, the I.O.C. member who negotiates television rights in North America.
"I think today will end being neutral in the selection process," Pound said. "The event is at a point where it surpasses the location."

HEADLINE: Yale Teaching Assistants Vote for a Grade Strike

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10

 BODY:
An organization of Yale's graduate teaching assistants has voted not to submit grades for this term, raising the possibility that some undergraduates will not receive grades on time and that some seniors might have incomplete transcripts with their graduate school applications.
Yale officials stressed that they would not tolerate a grade strike, and did not rule out the possibility of seeking to expel teaching assistants who withhold grades. 
 The group, the Graduate Employees Students Organization, has been seeking to become a labor union for graduate students in the humanities and social sciences since 1990. It wants higher teaching stipends, lower health care costs, smaller class sections and their own grievance procedure for complaints against the university. Graduate students normally receive stipends of $4,970 for each semester of undergraduate teaching, and 90 percent of them receive fellowships for full Yale tuition.
As at most large research universities, graduate students at Yale teach and grade undergraduates in almost every discipline. While professors handle most smaller courses, generally known as seminars, graduate students have the main responsibility for teaching discussion sections and grading students enrolled in large lecture courses. In some cases, graduate students teach their own courses.
Because of heavy workloads, the organization said, graduate students spend 25 hours a week on teaching, rather than the 17 1/2 hours the stipend was intended to compensate. "Yale has grown to depend on us for a lot of work," said Thomas Thurston, a Ph.D. candidate in American Studies from Albuquerque, N.M., "and that's where we're in a position of strength."
But Yale has been firm in refusing to negotiate. "The graduate school provides fellowships and stipends, and the students are supposed to grade and teach," said Jonas Zdanys, associate dean of the graduate school. "We don't intend to compensate every single nickel and dime of their cost of living."
It was not clear this week how many students would be affected by a grade strike. Classes ended last week, and final examinations begin Friday.
Professors and administrators said they would do all they could to make sure students received grades. Students said that in some classes, professors had asked them to complete forms listing their grades from earlier tests and papers.
The graduate group is seeking to formally represent Yale's 1,500 graduate students in the humanities and social sciences, 389 of whom are teaching assistants this semester. The organization has threatened a full strike next semester, and leaders of the two unions representing Yale's 3,600 clerical, maintenance and technical workers said they expected to honor any picket line set up by the group. A strike by those unions in 1984 virtually shut the campus down for 10 weeks.
On campus here this week, there seemed to be little support for the grade strike.
"I find it unfortunate, lamentable and completely inappropriate," said Mary Miller, the chairwoman of the art history department. "These graduate students have a responsibility to the undergraduates, and teaching is part of their training as future faculty."
Ms. Miller said that graduate students from her department who participated in the grade strike would probably not be hired again as teaching assistants.
A dozen students studying for final exams in Cross Campus Library were unanimously unsympathetic to the planned grade strike.
"A lot of people sacrifice a great deal to come to Yale, whether it's financially or the amount of work they do," said Darin Johnson, a junior from Neighborville, Ill., who is majoring in political science and economics. "It seems unfair that after all these efforts, that you may not be able to get grades at the end of the semester."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yale undergraduates like Pia Luedtke, front, and Billie Gastic, at the Cross Campus Library, may not get all this semester's grades on time if a group of graduate assistants carries out its threat not to file course results. (Carl David Labianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports A Rebound In Retail Sales

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Retail sales rebounded last month, the Government reported yesterday, but analysts said consumers remained anxious and they continued to predict a brutally competitive Christmas for retailers.
According to the Commerce Department's early estimates, retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, more than expected, to a seasonally adjusted $197.9 billion. 
 But the impact of the increase, the largest monthly gain since June, for the most part was offset by downward revisions for the previous two months. October's figure was revised to four-tenths of 1 percent, and September's to one-tenth of 1 percent.
Given those revisions, and the volatility inherent in the initial data, analysts warned that the size of the increase reported yesterday might ultimately be pared.
"I am very hesitant to cheer," said Susan Herring, a senior economist at Salomon Brothers. "Looking at the average of the past three months, retail sales are slowing, from more than a 4 percent rate of growth in the third quarter to less than 2 percent now. But at this stage of the business cycle, I don't think people should be shocked if consumers adopt a more conservative posture."
Most analysts had projected that the report would show that retail sales rose by six-tenths of 1 percent, and initially the stronger-than-expected figure was not well received in financial markets. But the stock market shrugged off the numbers and the Dow Jones industrial average soared to a record high of 5,216.47, up 41.55 points. Bond prices were down only slightly for the day.
While Wall Street analysts were skeptical, representatives of the nation's retailers said the figures were a hopeful sign for the critically important holiday shopping season.
"We are encouraged," said Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, a trade association.
The spending statistics are "an indication the consumer is beginning to get into the holiday spirit," Ms. Mullin added. "We think consumers are shopping a little later in the season, and that that trend is continuing."
Thus far, however, analysts said December sales had been disappointing.
"Holiday sales have been weak," said Robert Buchanan, senior retailing analyst at NatWest Securities. "And absent a further round of discounting, which we very well may see, they are likely to remain that way."
Among individual categories, colder weather and aggressive discounting helped to bolster apparel sales, which rose by 2.8 percent in November. But analysts said the gain did not signal a revival.
"Apparel sales went up because everything is being sold at distressed levels," said Sandra Shaber, a senior vice president at the WEFA Group, economic forecasters in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. "This is not the start of a new trend."
Elsewhere, the Commerce Department said that car sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November after a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in October. Excluding autos, retail sales climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent, after a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in October.
Economists are not expecting big things from consumers because in addition to high debt levels, growth in the labor force is slowing and anxiety about potential layoffs remains.
"Consumers are tapped out; they have borrowed as much as they can," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc. "Credit is not going to be a source of growth in terms of spending power."
Mr. Yardeni, who figures the odds on a recession at about 1 in 3, said policy makers at the Federal Reserve Board should not view yesterday's figures as an excuse for not cutting interest rates next week.
It may take bigger rate cuts than might otherwise be seen as prudent or necessary to induce consumers, including baby-boomers, to start spending again, Mr. Buchanan of NatWest Securities said.
"Consumer debt is a problem, but it has been a problem for some time," he said. "What is new now is that the boomers have many more commitments than they once had, and don't have a lot left over to spend on an extra sweater. Because of the changing demographics, I think it will take a lot deeper rate cuts to get things moving than it has in the past."
Ms. Herring at Salomon Brothers said, "We have been counting on some moderation in consumption, based on the notion that the level of interest rates to consumers is still a little on the high side." Loans based on bank prime rates are still high, he said, "and relief on auto loans is still quite small."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed Amid Sales Data And Interest-Rate Cut by Britain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose slightly against the German mark yesterday after Britain lowered its official lending rate, heightening expectations that Germany might follow with a cut of its own today.
The dollar also drew some support from a stronger-than-expected report on retail sales, which could discourage the Federal Reserve from lowering interest rates. 
 "We have a lot going on in the background of this market, but many of the issues have not come to a head yet," said David Solin of Foreign Exchange Analytics in New York. "Many people are taking cautious positions just in case."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4500 marks, up from 1.4475 marks on Tuesday.
The British rate cut had little effect on the pound, which ended the day unchanged at $1.5327.
And the dollar dipped to 101.68 Japanese yen from 101.76 yen.
Lower American interest rates tend to make dollar-denominated holdings less attractive to investors, but lower rates outside the United States are likely to make assets denominated in dollars more appealing.
The Bank of England, in lowering its lending rate to 6.5 percent from 6.75 percent, led some traders to believe that the German central bank would ease rates at its meeting today. "The rate cut in England was in line with the general expectations that there will be rate cuts around Europe," said Steve Flanagan, vice president at Credit Agricole in New York. "And the next cut to come will probably be Germany."
The prospects for an American interest-rate cut next week dimmed today as the Commerce Department said retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, higher than analysts' estimates. The report followed a report on Tuesday that wholesale prices rose an unexpected five-tenths of 1 percent last month, stirring inflation worries.
With both reports in hand and the Federal budget debate continuing in Washington, Mr. Flanagan said that "U.S. rates may stay put" when the Fed's policy-making committee gathers next Tuesday.
Russian elections and a European Union meeting to discuss the single currency, both occurring this weekend, also kept some traders on the sidelines. "We have several big events to deal with in upcoming days," Mr. Flanagan said. "Each of them could have their own impact on this market. Some people are just watching their moves with these things in mind."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Decline After a Surge In Retail Sales

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices retreated yesterday after the Government reported an unexpected surge in November retail sales.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond dropped 14/32 of a point, or $4.38 for $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.07 percent from 6.05 percent. 
 Bond prices tumbled immediately after the Labor Department reported a jump of eight-tenths of a percent in sales at retail stores for November. But the market recovered somewhat after a closer look showed the retail industry was not as strong as figures seemed to show.
The Government revised downward initial estimates of retail sales for the two previous months -- to declines of four-tenths of a percent in October and one-tenth of a percent in September.
"The relative strength in November's numbers was offset by the downward revision to both September and October," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets.
Still, bond prices resumed drifting lower in a lightly traded market that was increasingly uncertain if Federal Reserve policy makers would cut interest rates at their meeting next Tuesday.
Until recently, a rate cut seemed quite likely. But mixed reports on the strength of the economy and uncertainty over budget negotiations between President Clinton and Congress could prompt the Fed to wait on any rate cut, analysts said.
Of particular concern to investors was the cumulative impact of recent economic news. The report on November retail sales came one day after the Labor Department reported that producer prices shot up an unexpectedly sharp five-tenths of a percent in November as food and motor-vehicle prices soared.
Today, the Government will report on consumer prices in November, and investors are concerned that further hints of inflation combined with signs of economic strength will discourage the Fed from cutting rates at this time.
Uncertainty over Washington budget bargaining has kept bond market trading quiet in recent days, as negotiators struggle to avert a partial shutdown of the government.
Also, many investors are hesitant to stake out new market positions before the end of the year.
Elsewhere in the market, prices of short-term Treasury securities dropped 1/32 point and intermediate maturities ranged from 3/32 point to 1/8 point lower, Dow Jones Telerate Inc., a financial information service, reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, dropped 1.67 point, to 1,285.85.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.26 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills rose two basis points, to 5.20 percent. The discount rate on one-year bills rose one basis point, to 5.06 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 12017/32 , down 3/16 from late Tuesday. The average yield to maturity was 5.70 percent, up from 5.68 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Planned Cutback at Refinery Lifts Unleaded Gasoline Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices for unleaded gasoline jumped yesterday after the Tosco Corporation said that it expected to cut output by 20 percent at the 190,000-barrel-a-day refinery it planned to buy from British Petroleum P.L.C.
On other markets, soybeans and coffee rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index gained 0.68 point, to 244.65. 
 Tosco's move to cut production at the refinery in Marcus Hook, Pa., was part of a plan to raise the refinery's profit, and would leave 130 of the plant's 525 workers without jobs.
Negotiations with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International union are deadlocked over the issue, and B.P. said it would shut down the refinery on Jan. 1, when it transfers ownership to Tosco, if the two sides do not reach an agreement.
Even a temporary closing could upset the market, with inventories close to their lowest in 24 years. Gasoline stockpiles in the United States are now 17.7 million barrels, or 7.6 percent, below a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute said.
Unleaded gasoline for January delivery soared 1.97 cents a gallon, to 57.55 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange. January crude oil prices rose 27 cents, to $19 a barrel, the highest price since June 14.
Heating oil prices gained after the Colonial Pipeline Company said it had halted new shipments of heating oil from Texas to the Eastern United States because of high demand.
January heating oil rose 0.88 cent, to 57.69 cents a gallon, the highest price since March 25, 1993.
Soybean prices rose, extending a two-week rally on concern a drought in Brazil would lower output there, the world's second-largest grower of the crop after the United States.
The market "just isn't going to go down until it rains" in Brazil, said Joel Karlin, vice president of commodities at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago. "We're talking about a good 10 million tons that are in jeopardy," the equivalent of 17 percent of the entire United States harvest.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A lot of money spent on nuclear arms was wasted, a study shows.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
NUCLEAR deterrence has worked for a half century: no atomic weapon has been detonated in anger since 1945. But did America get its money's worth from 70,000 warheads, 67,000 missiles, 4,000 bombers, 59 strategic missile submarines and 1,041 test explosions, plus the equipment to keep track of enemy nuclear arms and to prevent accidental war?
The Central Intelligence Agency's disclosure last week that KGB disinformation had led Washington to overestimate the Soviet threat implies that not every last penny was well spent. And a preliminary report by the U.S. Nuclear Weapons Cost Study Project, excerpted in the fall 1995 Brookings Review, goes further. A close look at the quarter of all defense outlays that has gone into nuclear weapons suggests that a good portion was wasted. 
 In the early 1950's, The Bomb was seen as the way to get more bang for a buck. "If we mass- produce this weapon," Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, said at the time, "the cost of a single atomic bomb will become less than the cost of a single tank."
As nuclear weapons got cheaper and tanks came to resemble props from the "Star Wars" movies, Senator McMahon's prediction almost came true: a mere $5 million buys a hefty warhead these days. But the Senator and just about everyone else at the time underestimated how many bombs the armed forces would want. In 1957 the Army alone asked for 151,000. And while the military settled for less, the total bill for warheads has reached $375 billion. (This and other figures are in 1995 dollars.)
More important, they underestimated how much more expensive the razor would prove than the blade. Since World War II, America has spent $200 billion on strategic bombers. An additional $371 billion went into 50 varieties of nuclear missiles, including 3,160 ICBM's and 2,975 strategic sea-launched missiles. Missile-carrying submarines came to a bit less than $100 billion. Adding most of the cost of the vast "dual purpose" aircraft and ship fleet to the nuclear column brings the total above $2 trillion.
Controlling these weapons and defending against nuclear attack probably cost another trillion. Command, control and communications ran to $182 billion. Strategic air defense and antimissile systems -- remember the DEW line? -- cost a bit more than $400 billion. Spy satellites clock in at $270 billion, while other intelligence-gathering came to $230 billion.
The study estimates that the cost of retiring obsolete nuclear weapons and coping with nuclear waste will ultimately add $400 billion to the total. Throw in weapons security, antisatellite projects, civil defense and antisubmarine warfare, and pretty soon you are looking at real money -- $4 trillion to be inexact.
The emphasis is on "inexact." Critics of the study could no doubt identify a trillion dollars or so of questionable allocations -- for example, investments in intelligence and dual-purpose weapons delivery that serve nonnuclear as well as nuclear defense.
But the largest error in the nuclear accounting probably goes the other way: the failure to count the full "opportunity cost" of resources committed decades ago. A billion dollars diverted to nuclear weapons in, say, 1970, would have doubled if it had been invested in assets with a real economic return of 3 percent. "We went out of our way to be conservative," said William Weida of Colorado College, the project's economist.
The accounting itself is striking. It does not, however, go to the heart of the matter -- the portion that was wasted.
With hindsight, it is clear that dozens of weapons programs -- among them, the antiballistic missile defense, the B-70 bomber, the nuclear-powered bomber, the nuclear depth charge -- were nonstarters. And it is likely that even the most useful nuclear weapons cost too much to build for the same reasons the Pentagon pays too much for toilet seats and canned ravioli.
But by far the largest questionable sums went into awesome redundancy of bombs and delivery capacity. In part, "overkill" was part of a plausible strategy for deterring a Soviet first strike. But most of it was committed on the questionable assumption that a nuclear weapon would be needed to vaporize every Soviet cow pasture that could serve as an emergency landing strip.
"In 1985, there were 16,000 designated targets," said Bruce Blair, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and a former Minuteman launching officer. "Sixty were pointed at Moscow alone."
Why, to this day, is there no serious debate over how many nukes are enough? Everyone claims expertise on welfare reform, trade policy and Medicare, but defense policy is seen as, well, rocket science. "Government is too big, government is irresponsible," said Stephen Schwartz, a guest scholar at Brookings and the author of the preliminary report. "But with defense you can never spend enough."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
British Trim Key Interest Rate; Germany's Bank Meets Today

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
With economic growth apparently weakening and inflation restrained, Britain lowered its official lending rate today to 6.5 percent from 6.75 percent.
The reduction in the Bank of England's minimum lending rate to commercial banks came a day before policy makers at Germany's central bank are to meet and six days before the rate-setting committee of the United States Federal Reserve gather. Like their British counterparts, they will consider whether to ease credit at a time when statistics indicate that their economies are losing steam and inflation is under control. 
 Today was the first time in 22 months that Britain lowered interest rates. The Bank of England, this country's central bank, had raised rates three times since February 1994, from 5.25 percent, in an effort to keep inflation in check while the economy grew.
Even if the central banks of Germany and the United States do not reduce their own lending rates over the next week, economists said they would almost certainly do so in the next month or two.
"All these decisions are linked by the simple fact that the world economy has slowed down," said Michael O'Hanlon, an economist with Kidder, Peabody in London. "On both sides of the Atlantic, the impact of fiscal restraint is a major issue. If you don't have much fiscal flexibility, the only way to relieve economic pressures is monetary policy."
The British economy grew 4.1 percent last year and is estimated by the NatWest Group to be growing at a 2.4 percent rate this year. Inflation is running at 3.4 percent and is projected to slow to 2.6 percent in 1996.
In addition to the economic arguments for a cut, the Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major was under intense political pressure to reduce rates. The Conservatives badly trail the opposition Labor Party in the polls, and are counting on a healthy economy with low interest rates and low inflation to swing voter sentiment in their favor before the next election, which could be called in the next year and must take place within 18 months.
In Britain, unlike the United States and Germany, monetary policy is controlled by the Government. Today's decision to cut the lending rate was made by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke. The governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, supported the quarter-point reduction.
The central bank here does have influence, its role that of a monitoring and advisory agency. Mr. Clarke and Mr. George clashed earlier in the year, when Mr. George recommended raising rates again to choke off inflation and Mr. Clarke refused to do so.
The interest-rate cut today, which was matched by reductions in the minimum lending rates of commercial banks, had been widely anticipated in the financial markets, although most economists expected a bigger reduction -- of half a percentage point. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues closed with a gain of 7.50 points, at 3,662.40. The pound, which the Bank of England feared might fall sharply if lending rates were cut half a point or more, rose slightly with the reduction kept to a quarter-point.
The decision to keep the rate cut small suggested that British policy makers maintained at least some doubt about just how much the economy had slowed and about the outlook for inflation. The Government reported today that the unemployment rate fell slightly in November, to 8 percent from 8.1 percent in October, the lowest level in four and a half years. Other recent statistics, including retail sales, also suggested that the economy was not weakening as quickly as some believed.
"I was satisfied that one-quarter percent was right in all the circumstances," Mr. Clarke said.
In Germany, the Bundesbank has been gradually lowering the securities-repurchase rate, the chief money market rate. Although it did not push that down further today, it did inject more cash into the money markets than had been expected.
This step added to some speculation in the financial markets that the bank's policy-making council would reduce official interest rates when it meets on Thursday. But others predicted that the Bundesbank would put off a rate cut until January.
The discount rate, which sets a floor under German money market rates and effectively dictates interest-rate levels elsewhere on the Continent, stands at 3.5 percent. The Lombard rate, the ceiling on money market rates, is 5.5 percent.
Because interest-rate cuts in a country tend to weaken that country's currency, any easing by the Germans on Thursday may help the French franc, which traded today at its lowest level against the German mark in a week. The franc has been badly hurt by nationwide strikes by French public workers and concern that Prime Minister Alain Juppe would bow to union demands to abandon the proposed changes in social-service and pension payments that set off the strikes.
In the United States, the Federal Reserve's key committee is to meet next Tuesday amid speculation that it, too, will reduce interest rates. On Tuesday, the Labor Department reported that wholesale prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent in November, more than expected. Although the size of the increase was viewed as an aberration, some analysts said it could increase doubts among some at the Fed who had been inclined to press for a rate cut next week.

HEADLINE: Stocks at Record Again, With Dow Rising 41.55

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks reached another record high yesterday as computer-driven buy programs lifted prices ahead of Friday's triple expiration of options and futures contracts.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 41.55 points, to 5,216.47, topping a record close of 5,199.15 set last Wednesday. Two broader indexes also rose to new highs. 
 "The gains are concentrated in the big-name stocks, and that typically is somewhat symbolic of program trading," said Don Hays, the director of investment strategy at Wheat First Butcher Singer, Inc. in Richmond. "The broad market is just barely up. It's not a wonderful day, unless you're in the big blue-chip stocks."
Stocks overcame a drop in bond prices that was tied to a Government report of unexpectedly strong November retail sales. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32 and the yield rose to 6.07 percent from 6.05 percent.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancers led decliners by 3 to 2. Volume was moderately heavy at 415.3 million shares, up from 349.9 million Tuesday.
Blue-chip stocks are often volatile ahead of the quarterly "triple witching" expiration of stock options, stock index options and stock index futures, which often prompts investors to buy or sell the entire Dow index.
The Dow industrials were led higher by Boeing, up 2 1/8, to 76 1/2; AT&T, up 1 7/8, to 68 1/8; Allied Signal, up 1 3/4, to 49 1/2; Merck, up 1 7/8, to 65 1/8, and Philip Morris, up 2 1/4, to 91 7/8.
Investors were anticipating an end to a two-month-old strike at Boeing.
The Big Board's composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500 composite both rose to record levels, with the New York Stock Exchange index up 1.37, to 331.17, and the S.& P. up 2.91, to 621.69.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.47, to 1,056.54. The American Stock Exchange's market value index rose 3.32, to 538.86.
Stocks floundered early in the session, after the Commerce Department said retail sales rose eighttenths of 1 percent in November. Analysts had expected a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent.
The report followed Tuesday's news that wholesale prices rose an uncomfortably high five-tenths of 1 percent last month. Both reports stirred investors' fears that the economy may be growing too fast to justify an interest-rate cut next week by the Federal Reserve.
Bonds sank sharply on the retail sales report, recovered most of their losses but then dipped again.
But stocks recovered and kept going, amid aggressive buying of big-company and blue-chip names.
Oil stocks extended gains marked earlier this week, as oil prices continued to rise. A Dow industrials component, Exxon, rose 1 3/8, to 85 7/8; Chevron added 5/8, to 53 3/8, and Texaco gained 1, to 80 1/8.
Despite the rise in oil prices, airline stocks made strong gains, pushing the Dow transportation average up 13.76 points, or 0.66 percent, to 2,084.54. The gains were led by airline freight companies. Federal Express, was up 1 3/8, to 81 5/8, and Airborne Freight rose 1 1/4, to 29. Federal Express said after the market closed that its second-quarter profit rose to $1.57 a share from $1.53 a year ago.
In addition, the overall sentiment on airline stocks has been quite strong because of high margins, good demand and strength from restructurings, said Leon Brand, global markets strategist at NatWest Securities.
Computer-related stocks were mixed. On the Big Board, I.B.M. fell 7/8, to 94 1/2; Hewlett-Packard dropped 2 3/8, to 80 3/4, and Seagate Technology lost 1 7/8, to 51 1/4.
But Micron Technology gained 1/2, to 53 5/8, in heavy volume of 5.8 million shares, even after a lawsuit was filed contending that Fidelity Investments improperly touted the stock even as it was selling it this fall.

HEADLINE: VERDICT IN BEIJING: THE OVERVIEW;
Beijing Sends a Strong Warning With Long Sentence for Dissenter

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 13

 BODY:
By convicting Wei Jingsheng in a closed trial today of "conspiring to subvert the Government" and sentencing him to 14 years in prison, China again silenced the most powerful pro-democracy voice in the country and sent a strong warning about the limits of dissent.
Mr. Wei, 45, a onetime electrician at the Beijing Zoo who helped father China's democracy movement in 1978, was also denied his political rights for three years beyond the prison term. The harsh sentence drew expressions of anger and indignation from members of Mr. Wei's family, human rights organizations and governments around the world. 
 [The Clinton Administration criticized China but stopped short of threatening specific retaliatory action. But some members of Congress warned that Mr. Wei's imprisonment could lead to renewal of the linkage that Washington once made between trade privileges for Beijing and its rights record. Page A20.]
The verdict comes at a time when China's Communist Party leadership has reached a peak of sensitivity and defensiveness in foreign and domestic affairs, in part related to a struggle for pre-eminence among potential successors to Deng Xiaoping, China's 91-year-old paramount leader, who is in extremely frail health.
Over the last 12 months, Beijing has taken increasingly belligerent or intransigent positions on a range of issues from human rights and trade negotiations, to religious freedom in Tibet and political developments in Hong Kong and Taiwan. In the case of Taiwan, China has threatened more explicitly to go to war to recover its estranged province than at any time in decades.
The judgment against Mr. Wei sends a powerful signal to a nation in the midst of an economic revolution that any public talk of political revolution, democratic reforms and democracy can be considered seditious.
To many in China, these constraints are not as burdensome as they seem to many foreigners. Free speech, even criticism to senior leaders, is tolerated as long as it is private. Millions of Chinese crave stability and are not interested in the politics of confrontation that marked the democracy movements of the 1980's.
Outside of intellectual circles, Mr. Wei may be less a symbol and more a curiosity, but the Communist leadership fears that his attack on Communist rule and passion for democracy could take hold among the millions of disaffected Chinese who are not taking part equally in the fruits of China's economic boom.
Thus, Mr. Wei is the largest and most obvious target for this new Government crackdown.
His mordant style first drew public attention and outraged some party leaders when he scrawled it on a poster and hung it on a stretch of wall in Western Beijing that came to be known as Democracy Wall. Mr. Deng was among the first to feel his barb in 1979, and Mr. Deng is believed to have ordered Mr. Wei jailed and Democracy Wall torn down.
After serving 14 1/2 years of an initial 15-year sentence, Mr. Wei emerged in September 1993 with the same fearlessness to take on Mr. Deng again, as well as his potential successors.
"The present leaders were the most outspoken group of men, shouting their support of human rights and democracy before they ascended to power," he wrote in an essay on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times in November 1993. "But their subsequent dictatorship made clear that they have no intention of making good on the promises they once made to the masses."
In April 1994, after a number of run-ins with the authorities, Mr. Wei was rearrested.
With the dispatch of Mr. Wei back to a prison cell, where he has spent all but six months of the last 16 years, China's security services have now jailed or placed under close control all of the prominent pro-democracy leaders who remain from the Democracy Wall or Tiananmen periods.
Wang Dan, a student leader of the pro-democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square in Beijing in 1989, whom the Bush Administration invested great effort to free, has been held without charge since May. So has the writer Liu Xiaobo.
Chen Zeming, one of the so-called "black hands" behind the Tiananmen uprising, was released in May 1994 as a special concession to President Clinton, but Mr. Chen, who is suffering from cancer, was abruptly jailed again last June. Another student leader who was released last summer, Liu Gang, lives as a virtual prisoner in his home in Liaoning Province.
In Beijing today, many democracy campaigners awoke on the day of Mr. Wei's trial to find themselves under house arrest.
At a courthouse swept by the first snow of winter here, Mr. Wei made an appearance at the Beijing No. 1 Intermediate People's Court and spoke on his own behalf during the six-hour trial. Although Mr. Wei was represented by a respected private attorney, Zhang Sizhi, and was allowed to present his defense, the verdict was preordained by the Communist Party leadership, Chinese and Western experts say.
"Wei was defended by a lawyer hired by Wei's relatives, and was allowed to represent himself fully," a Government statement said tonight. "After debate between the opposing lawyers, Wei made his closing statement."
Under today's ruling, Mr. Wei would not be able to publish another essay about democracy in China, criticize the Communist Party regime or speak to a foreign reporter until the year 2012, assuming that he survives another long prison term.
No record of today's proceedings at the No. 1 Intermediate People's Court was made public, but tonight, China's Government-run central television and press agency issued a statement that was extraordinary in its acknowledgment that Mr. Wei was engaged in nothing more sinister than publishing and fund-raising activities in support of China's democracy movement.
"The court's investigation showed that Wei, in attempting to overthrow the Government, developed a plan of action," the Government statement said, "which included establishing an organization to raise funds to support democratic movement activities, purchasing newspapers, setting up a company in charge of organizing cultural activities, and organizing non-governmental painting exhibitions, performances and publications with the aim of setting up a propaganda and liaison base, attempting to raise a storm powerful enough to shake up the present Government."
The Government statement made no assertion that Mr. Wei had formed a group, or written a charter or manifesto with the stated aim of toppling the Communist Party or overthrowing the Chinese Government. Moreover, there was no assertion that Mr. Wei advocated violence or any activity beyond publishing and cultural performances in support of democratic reforms in China.
"The trial and sentence are an outrage, and a clear effort by Beijing to subvert the rule of law," Human Rights Watch said in a statement.
Outside the courthouse, several dozen foreign reporters and photographers gathered in hopes of witnessing the proceedings, or at least recording the coming and going of the unidentified few Chinese who were allowed to witness it. But Public Security officers kept foreign journalists more than 100 feet away from the gate of the courthouse.
Some members of Mr. Wei's family were allowed to attend the trial, but their telephones were not working afterward.
Two of Mr. Wei's personal friends who came to the courthouse despite earlier warnings by the police to stay away were arrested after they mingled with journalists and expressed their concern for Mr. Wei's fate.
"As Wei's friends, we are concerned about him," Jin Cheng said. "I think all dissidents are deeply concerned about the trial. If Wei is convicted, we don't know what's going to happen to us."
Mr. Jin chatted as plainclothes policemen, who later arrested him, stood close by seeking to overhear or record his comments to reporters.
"What is more important," he continued, "is that Wei is the symbol of China's democracy movement and we are concerned about the fate of the movement."
Reached in Washington, one of Mr. Wei's sisters also expressed her alarm over the verdict.
"This verdict shows how shameful the Chinese Government is," said Wei Shanshan, who is lobbying for White House and Congressional support on her brother's behalf.
"The only thing he did was speak out his thoughts, and this is not a violation of the Chinese Constitution," she said, adding, "he hasn't formed any anti-Government organizations or engaged in any anti-Government activities."

LENGTH: 874 words

HEADLINE: With Iraq's O.K., a U.S. Team Seeks War Pilot's Body

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
A Pentagon team is on a secret mission to Iraq, searching the desert for the remains of the first American pilot downed in the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
The mission, undertaken with the approval of President Saddam Hussein, represents a small but potentially significant step in Iraq's attempts to end its deep isolation. Since the end of the gulf war, Iraq has been an international pariah, subjected to strict economic sanctions. 
 Though the mission is under the leadership of the International Committee of the Red Cross, it represents the first official visit of American military officers to Iraq since the war's end. American military and diplomatic officials acknowledged that the Iraqi Government had made a humanitarian gesture by allowing 11 American military officers to join 4 Red Cross officials on the search.
The search began this week in a remote section of western Iraq, where a Navy FA-18 fighter-bomber crashed on the first night of the gulf war nearly five years ago. The pilot, Lieut. Comdr. Michael Scott Speicher, 33, was the first American combat casualty of the war. He left a wife and two infant children.
Commander Speicher took off from the aircraft carrier Saratoga in the Red Sea on the night of Jan. 16, 1991, flying northeast toward Baghdad. Shortly after he entered Iraqi airspace, his plane disintegrated in midair. Navy intelligence officers were never sure why. They later concluded that he either had a freak midair collision with an Iraqi MIG-25 or that the enemy plane shot him out of the sky.
He crashed in a wasteland, far from civilization. Though Commander Speicher's status was changed from missing in action to killed in action in 1991, he remains the only American pilot downed in the war whose body has not been recovered.
In the fall of 1994, an American spy satellite photographed the crash site. Intelligence officials conveyed the images to the P.O.W./M.I.A. office at the Defense Department. Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Pentagon officials then approached the Red Cross, which has an office in Baghdad, and sought its help.
"This whole mission is a humanitarian effort," said Frederick C. Smith, Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security affairs. "The reason we undertook this was our commitment to determine the fate of all missing U.S. service members lost in conflict."
The Red Cross notified Iraq's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and on March 1 the Iraqi Government approved the request that a Red Cross team with Pentagon personnel be allowed to search the site. After months of haggling over details of the mission, final approval came last month. Defense Department officials said they believed the request was personally approved by President Hussein.
American officials offered a very slight tip of the hat to Iraq today.
A State Department official called Iraq's decision "a positive humanitarian gesture." But he added: "They did the right thing, but they did it for reasons of self-interest. If they think it's the first building block in a grand edifice of better relations, they need to think again."
Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat who helped win the release of two Americans held prisoner in Iraq in July, said he had been discussing the mission with Iraqi officials since then. "Now, hopefully, they will start dealing more aggressively with other issues, such as the nuclear issue and human-rights concerns," he said.
Iraq's efforts to build weapons of mass destruction remain a sticking point with the United States and the United Nations.
With the go-ahead from Iraq in hand, 11 military officers gathered last week at the Army Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii to prepare for the trip. The team, led by a forensic anthropologist, has conducted several expeditions in Southeast Asia to identify the remains of American servicemen missing in the Vietnam War. Using technologies including DNA identification techniques, high-gauge magnification instruments and computerized dental X-rays, such teams have identified missing servicemen using no more than a fragment of bone or tooth.
The team flew to Amman, Jordan, last weekend and crossed the border into Iraq, traversing the Amman-Baghdad highway and turning off into the desert toward the site, whose exact location remains a secret. They located the site through the Global Positioning System, a constellation of satellites that tells users precisely where they are on an electronic map of the world.
The team made camp and began staking out the site, spreading out in a radius of a mile and a half from the point of impact. Commander Speicher's jet was traveling at several hundred miles an hour when it crashed, and thousands of pieces of debris from the crash are scattered through the desert. Like archeologists on a dig, the searchers are sifting through the ground, looking for shards of metal and bone.
They are expected back in Amman on Friday. Pentagon officials said they were awaiting word on whether the mission was a success.
Commander Speicher lived in Jacksonville, Fla., where he grew up, went to high school and later taught Sunday school, near a base that is home to hundreds of Navy fliers.

HEADLINE: Saudi With Key Role in War Calls for End to Iraqi Sanctions

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
A senior member of the Saudi royal family who played a leading role in the war against Iraq in 1991 called today for ending sanctions on the country because, he said, they have only reinforced President Saddam Hussein's hold on power while starving the Iraqi people.
The criticism of the sanctions and a call for alternatives came from Prince Khalid bin Sultan, a nephew of King Fahd and son of Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister. 
 "The sanctions have not achieved their aim and we must look for another way," Prince Khalid said in Cairo after meeting with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who has also indicated his desire for a review of the sanctions with the goal of ending them.
"I am not against ending the sanctions on Iraq, but they are based on United Nations conventions and resolutions."
The world "intervened to save and feed the people of Somalia," Prince Khalid continued, "so why don't we think of something to save the Iraqi people?"
His comments were made against a backdrop of growing debate among Arab nations about the direction of relations with President Hussein nearly five years after the Persian Gulf war.
Calls for an end to the sanctions were made two months ago by the leaders of two other countries that were staunch allies of the United States in confronting Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990: Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, President of the United Arab Emirates, and Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, the Emir of Qatar.
Prince Khalid made similar comments this year when he published his memoirs of the gulf war, in which he served as joint commander with Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, with principal responsibility for supporting the allied troops based in Saudi Arabia.
Calls for revising the sanctions or establishing a schedule for ending them have also come from Syria, Yemen, Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia
Within the gulf region, only Kuwait, with some lukewarm support from Saudi Arabia, argues that sanctions must continue against Iraq until it fulfills all United Nations resolutions.
The stand is widely seen as a desire to use sanctions as a method of bringing down the Iraqi Government -- a position shared by the United States.
Despite Washington's repeated efforts to scotch any talk of lifting sanctions on Iraq, the issue has resurfaced time and again in the last six months as a majority of Arab countries appear to be leaning toward an end to them.
In the past, Prince Khalid's statements were dismissed as a solitary and maverick position, influenced by his irritation at being removed from decision making after the gulf war by King Fahd, who essentially pushed the prince to retire instead of putting him in command of the Saudi Army.
But they also do reflect, according to well-informed Saudi officials, a view that is shared within the Saudi ruling establishment by a growing number of princes.
Their fear is that the miseries reportedly inflicted on the Iraqi people by the sanctions are now building up hatred of the gulf countries among Iraqis that could come back to haunt Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
