HEADLINE: CLINTON'S RATINGS OVER 50% IN POLL AS G.O.P. DECLINES

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
President Clinton has emerged from the Federal budget standoff with his highest public ratings in nearly two years, while House Republicans, particularly Speaker Newt Gingrich, have lost much of the good will they enjoyed after their sweep of Congress last year, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Virtually every finding showed striking evidence of renewed political strength for the President: Mr. Clinton's job approval level has broken 50 percent for the first time in The Times's polling since February 1994. Americans have begun to give him more credit for a healthier economy. And they perceive Mr. Clinton as far more earnest than the Republicans in trying to find a solution to the budget impasse. 
 And in more heartening news for the President, his rebound has come at the expense of Republicans. The Democrats have, at least for now, succeeded in convincing many Americans that Republican budget remedies would carry harsh consequences for the public. Still, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader and leading candidate for President, appears relatively unscathed; it is Mr. Gingrich whose standing has plummeted.
Sixty-one percent of Americans say Mr. Clinton is really trying to find a solution to the budget crisis; only 43 percent say the Republicans in Congress are really trying. And 47 percent approve of the way Mr. Clinton is handling the economy, up from 41 percent in October.
One of the most significant findings is that the Republicans' long-held advantage as the party most trusted for balancing the budget has completely dissipated. The public is evenly divided, with 41 percent trusting the Republicans in Congress and 41 percent trusting Mr. Clinton.
But just a year ago, after the Republican triumph in the midterm elections, 60 percent said they trusted the Republicans more in balancing the budget and Mr. Clinton drew only 28 percent. In the poll, 1,111 adults nationwide were called Dec. 9 to Dec. 11. The poll's margin of sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.
The reputation of Congress has, in fact, fallen close to the levels it was at before Democrats were ousted from Congress in 1994. Twenty-six percent approve of how Congress is handling its job; in November 1994, 20 percent approved of how Congress, then controlled by Democrats, was handling itself.
The slide in approval for the Republican Congress has roughly paralleled Mr. Gingrich's ratings, which are the lowest since he has been Speaker. Only 29 percent of Americans approve of how Mr. Gingrich is handling his job, down from an already low 34 percent in October.
One reason for Mr. Gingrich's declining fortunes is that many Americans are uncomfortable about the Republican agenda. Fifty-two percent say the Republicans' proposed Medicare changes would be bad for the country; 27 percent say they would be good.
Specifically, a sizable proportion of Americans believe the Democrats' contention that Republicans are driven to reduce growth in Medicare spending as a way to cut taxes. Thirty-six percent say cutting taxes was the Republicans' overriding motivation; 34 percent to balance the budget and 16 percent to preserve Medicare. Republicans say they are mainly trying to save Medicare. There is far more support for the Republicans' welfare proposal, with 48 percent saying it would be good and 30 percent saying it would be bad.
In the budget battle, 54 percent of the respondents said Mr. Clinton was more concerned about doing what is best for them and their families, while only 36 percent gave such credit to Congressional Republicans. This is important given that the battle for President next year may be waged over the loyalties of middle-class swing voters.
But the negative ratings of Mr. Gingrich and Republican lawmakers in general seem not to have rubbed off on Mr. Dole, who may in fact look appealing when contrasted with the unpopular Speaker. Fifty-two percent of the public approves of the way Mr. Dole is handling his job, up from 45 percent in October. And the Senator remains the front-runner for the nomination with 47 percent support among registered Republicans; the other Republican candidates are in single digits in the nationwide matchup.
Despite Mr. Dole's relatively strong showing, Mr. Clinton appears in an even better position as the Presidential primaries approach early next year. Fifty-two percent of registered voters say if the general election were held today, they would vote for Mr. Clinton, while 40 percent favor Mr. Dole. This represents a turnaround for Mr. Clinton since August, when Mr. Dole led Mr. Clinton, 48 percent to 42 percent. Even with Mr. Clinton's new-found popularity, the poll shows that Americans remain evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans in the House of Representatives.
Democrats should not be too jubilant, however: Four years ago President George Bush seemed safely ahead of a "generic Democrat" opponent, but his advantage dwindled, and then evaporated, by early 1992.
Even as Mr. Clinton's ratings climb, most people still think it is Congressional Republicans who are setting the issue agenda in Washington. Fifty-eight percent say Republicans will have more influence over the direction of the country; 32 percent said Mr. Clinton will. Opinions are mixed about changes Republicans are trying to bring about: 40 percent say they are good, 34 percent say they are bad.
Yet, people worry about Republican proposals to cut or slow the growth of many social programs in an effort to reduce the deficit. Forty-nine percent say these proposals go too far; 11 percent say not far enough and 32 percent say they are about right.
On the issue of Medicare, Americans accept the idea that the Government should do more, but resist specific proposals that affect their pocketbooks. Seventy-eight percent of Americans say they agree with the proposal, advanced by Republicans, that people with higher incomes pay a greater share of their medical costs. In addition, as both parties encourage Medicare recipients to enter health maintenance organizations or other managed care programs, 60 percent say that would be acceptable.
But only 31 percent find acceptable a Republican plan to raise the monthly Medicare premium by the year 2002 to about $90 a month from the current fee of $46.10.
The one sign of trouble for Mr. Clinton in the poll was in Bosnia. Only 36 percent say Mr. Clinton's sending American troops to enforce the peace agreement there was the right thing. Even so, the Bosnia situation does not seem to be significantly hurting Mr. Clinton's popularity.
The poll also found that even as Ross Perot has formed a third party, his public appeal has further diminished. In a hypothetical three-way contest, Mr. Perot draws 16 percent of registered voters, with 44 percent for Mr. Clinton and 32 percent for Mr. Dole. But Mr. Perot has a growing negative image with the public; 53 percent say they have an unfavorable opinion of him, a notable increase from 36 percent unfavorable in August.
Mr. Clinton's approval rating of 51 percent was significant because it was the first time since February 1994 that he had registered so high in the Times/CBS poll. (He has had temporary surges over 50 percent in several one-night quick reaction polls taken separately by CBS News after dramatic events like the Oklahoma City bombing and the President's speech on Bosnia last month.)
The Republican Presidential field appears to be set, as Friday is the deadline for candidates to compete in the New Hampshire primary. But while the poll found that people say they are beginning to focus on the Presidential race, they are not particularly aware of the Republican field except for Mr. Dole.
Among Republicans, 47 percent say they have a favorable opinion of the Senator.
Yet, Mr. Clinton is now even more popular in his party. Seventy-five percent of Democrats say they have a favorable opinion of the President -- his highest rating in his own party since he was elected. Perhaps realizing that no challenger has emerged within the party, 75 percent of Democrats say Mr. Clinton should be renominated, a 12-point jump from August.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 9 to 11 with 1,111 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of active residential exchanges in the country. The list of more than 36,000 residential exchanges is maintained by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for either Democrats or Republicans taken as a group and six points for independents.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Poster Boy For a Drop In Crime;
The Out-of-Town Press Makes Bratton a Hero

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
He was a brassy, bigger-than-life Police Commissioner until last February, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vetoed his idea of a police parade down Broadway on his birthday, cut his press staff in half and made it clear that he should reduce his public profile.
But while William J. Bratton now projects a more modest profile in New York, limiting reporters' access to his activities and allowing the Mayor to take credit for the city's drop in crime, the Commissioner has still managed to become something of a national and international media star. 
 His face has recently appeared in news magazines and newspapers in Australia, Japan and Norway and on television in Brazil and Italy. In the last few weeks, Mr. Bratton has made a series of speeches in Boston, Washington and Bermuda, and his aides say he wants to make a European tour to tout his crime-fighting accomplishments. The Europeans certainly seem impressed. "He has brought a new lexicon to law enforcement," an article in the British magazine The Economist said, comparing Mr. Bratton to Theodore Roosevelt, New York's Police Commissioner in the 1890's.
Mr. Bratton has been host to a Saudi Arabian prince and Government officials from around the world at his twice-weekly crime strategy meetings, with the hope that his techniques would serve as a model well beyond the five boroughs. He invited journalists from China, Hungary, Germany, Switzerland, Portugal, the Netherlands, Israel and Belgium to the highly restricted police Operations Room for a personal briefing.
"Let the word go forth," said Peter LaPorte, a Deputy Police Commissioner who acts as Mr. Bratton's liaison to national and international news organizations.
"The word" is shorthand for a crusade Mr. Bratton is waging to convince criminologists and fellow police executives that the success of his strategies in reducing murder, auto theft and robbery by better than 30 percent since 1994 can be applied by every police department, in North America and beyond.
For their part, the out-of-town reporters and guests have expressed a near-endless fascination with the story of how a city known for mayhem has managed to drive down crime to levels not seen in the city since the early 1970's. And Mr. Bratton seems happy to tell the story, not only because he loves the limelight. Some have speculated that he may be promoting himself as a model manager -- The Economist called his style "N.Y.P.D. Inc." -- because he has made no secret that he would like eventually to move into the corporate world.
"This is not self-projection or aggrandizement," Mr. Bratton said in an interview this week. "You can take our strategies anywhere."
Mr. Bratton explained that strategy in a paper he delivered to a conference of the National Institute of Justice in Washington several weeks ago. "Contemporary criminology maintains a longstanding belief that police activities have little or no appreciable effect upon crime," he wrote. "What we have done in New York City is to radically alter the face of policing by empowering the agency and its officers. If we start to use police resources strategically and efficiently, we can cut crime by 20, 30 or even 50 percent in the space of several years."
The Commissioner's crusade comes as Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Bratton have reached an uneasy truce over their respective public profiles. On arriving in New York from Boston in 1994, Mr. Bratton took his cue from Mr. Giuliani's campaign to improve the city's "quality of life." He immediately made a splash by tossing a panhandler from the subway his first week. And he turned the scandal in the 30th Precinct in Harlem into a positive media event for himself when, before television cameras, he personally confiscated the shields of officers accused of corruption. A stream of glowing profiles followed, which police officials said rankled the Mayor.
It took many months for Mr. Bratton and Mr. Giuliani to patch up their relationship after John Miller, Mr. Bratton's Deputy Commissioner for Public Information, quit in protest of staff cuts last February. Tom Kelly, who was handpicked by Mr. Giuliani, replaced Mr. Miller.
These days, publicity shots of Mr. Bratton clinking glasses with his aides at Elaine's or sitting courtside at Madison Square Garden no longer appear in local newspapers.
In times of crisis, like the investigation of last week's arson case in Harlem, Mayor Giuliani shares center stage with his Commissioner. But when good news is announced, or when police strategies are unveiled, news conferences are held at City Hall, not Police Headquarters.
Mr. Bratton's senior aides conceded privately that they were nervous about Mr. Giuliani's reaction to the recent global attention accorded the Commissioner. One, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said City Hall officials raised objections before Mr. Bratton's trip last month to speak before leaders in Bermuda.
Anticipating such friction, the aide said police officials notify City Hall only at the last minute before Mr. Bratton takes such a trip.
"We don't send things over in a timely fashion," the aide said. "It's the most political environment I've ever seen."
Mr. Bratton, on the other hand, said that Mr. Giuliani supported his attempts to promote New York City as an exciting laboratory for better policing. He said any perception that there was tension between him and the Mayor was subjective, and that the Mayor deserves much credit for the drop in crime.
While the Mayor's press office did not return calls seeking comment, the First Deputy Mayor, Peter J. Powers, said he was behind Mr. Bratton's efforts. "Any time New York City gets publicity for the good things, including the historic reduction in crime, it's a good thing," he said.
Mr. Bratton is not the first New York Police Commissioner to project himself outside of New York. Lee P. Brown, Mayor David N. Dinkins's first Police Commissioner, was known inside the department as "Out of Town Brown." But Mr. Bratton is perhaps the most intrepid.
Police executives around the country acknowledge the gathering impact of Mr. Bratton's emphasis on mapping crimes by computer every day, deploying officers to crime hot spots and focusing on chop shops and fences to attack car theft and burglary.
"The message big-city police chiefs are getting from Bratton is that crime analysis works," said Lawrence Sherman, a University of Maryland criminologist, "and driving police operations in a military fashion based on clearly identified and mapped targets is the best way for police to reduce crime."
Mr. Sherman said that police departments in Washington, Boston, St. Louis and Maryland are already copying from Mr. Bratton's playbook.
The Indianapolis Police Department has studied the strategy meetings, in which precinct commanders are challenged to come up with tactics to solve specific problems. The Indianapolis Police Chief, Donald E. Christ, said he planned to institute a similar exercise in his city.
"He's become the leader challenging other city administrators and police commissioners to look at crime in a different light," he said.
Such accolades have also become a staple of news articles in publications from Sydney to Rio de Janeiro about the drop in New York crime. According to an article in The Sunday Times of London, "In a city famous for its murders, muggings, ghetto gunfights, subway anarchy, drug gangs, junkies, rapists, winos, pickpockets and every other form of seething urban desperado, Bratton is turning the tide."
The international attention has instilled a conspicuous headiness among Mr. Bratton's inner circle. Noting that five senior South African police officials flew to New York just to attend a strategy meeting last month, John Maple, the Deputy Police Commissioner of Crime Strategies, said: "South Africa would be a ground ball. They're ready for us."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
If the Yankees Leave, Mayor Faults Ferrer

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
They play baseball only from April through October, but politics lasts all year long.
With the fate of Yankee Stadium hanging in the balance, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx have spent much of the last few days attacking each other over the city's efforts to keep the Yankees in the Bronx, or at least in New York City. 
 At a town hall meeting at Lafayette High School in Brooklyn on Tuesday night, Mr. Giuliani accused Mr. Ferrer of making it "much more difficult" to persuade the Yankees to stay by criticizing the team's owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d. And he even suggested the blame would fall on Mr. Ferrer if the Yankees moved away.
The attack on Mr. Ferrer, a Democrat who, it just so happens, has started raising money for a possible challenge to the Republican Mayor in 1997, came as Mr. Giuliani offered perhaps the clearest indication yet that the Yankees are intent on finding a new home after 72 years in Yankee Stadium.
"I can't guarantee, although I would like to, that I can keep them in the Bronx," he said. "One of the main reasons I can't guarantee it is because of the attitude of the Borough President."
Mr. Ferrer, in turn, yesterday accused the Mayor of "insulting New Yorkers' intelligence" by trying to blame him for what he sees as the administration's failures. He said that the Mayor was bowing to Mr. Steinbrenner's desire to move the Yankees out of their longtime home while at the same time refusing to acknowledge the fact for fear of political fallout. "I thought it was fairly disingenuous," he said of Mr. Giuliani's remarks. "If the Mayor is the midst of negotiations to move the Yankees to another site, he should be candid and say so. He's looking for a fall guy. And I'm not it."
Nothing new has happened in the city's courting of the Yankees to provoke this latest squabble. Election Day, however, is only 23 months away. And Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Ferrer appear eager to try out a few planks in their platforms.
The Yankees' future has enormous economic and cultural significance for a city that lost the Dodgers and the Giants, not to mention the Jets and the Giants football teams. But it also has political significance that could come to haunt Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Steinbrenner has set a deadline of Opening Day next April -- well before the Mayor's presumed re-election campaign -- to decide where the Yankees will play once the team's lease expires in 2002. He has already rejected 13 proposals by the city to renovate the stadium and is talking with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority about a new stadium in the Meadowlands.
In October, the city and the state agreed with the Yankees to review the feasibility of building a new stadium at three other sites, two in the Bronx and another in the West 30's of Manhattan that is now said to be a front-runner. That study is under way and expected to be completed in the next couple of months.
Losing the Yankees to New Jersey would unquestionably scar Mr. Giuliani, a champion of economic development and a devout Yankee fan since his boyhood in Brooklyn. He himself alluded to the political risks, noting that the city would build a new stadium if that was what it took.
He also pointed out that New York had lost the Brooklyn Dodgers to California in 1957 because the city refused the request by the late Walter O'Malley, the team's owner, to build a stadium. "I guarantee you," he said, "we learn from the mistakes in the past."
But keeping the Yankees could come at a price, too. Moving them to Manhattan risks dismaying nostalgically inclined fans and outraging residents of the Bronx, including a large Hispanic bloc that Mr. Ferrer represents and Mr. Giuliani hopes to court.
Mr. Ferrer, who has criticized Mr. Steinbrenner before, started the fight on Sunday when he appeared on the WNBC-TV program "News Forum" and declared that the Yankees had been "playing New York politicians like a violin" by threatening to move to New Jersey.
He said the city should make a best offer to renovate the stadium and refuse to spend taxpayer dollars on a new stadium in Manhattan or anywhere else. "That's too much to pay for vanity," he said, a barely veiled barb at Mr. Steinbrenner.
The Mayor said remarks like that simply undercut the city's efforts.
"Despite what you think of George Steinbrenner or the Yankees, they're a business organization," he said. "And if they think they're going to be in a place where the political leadership of that place is going to attack them, this is a very, very valuable franchise that a lot of places would like to have."
The Yankees, for their part, remained above the fray. "I don't think it's useful for the Yankees to get caught up in whatever rhetorical skirmish took place," said David W. Sussman, the team's executive vice president and general counsel.
Prof. Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, played down the politics of a move, saying other factors could sway more voters. "It's more important," he said, "for the Yankees to win the pennant."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
On 125th St., Patrons Reject Race Boycotts

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
EVERY now and again, something happens in New York City that brings to mind that old children's game, the one that asks, "What's wrong with this picture?" The evolving story in Harlem is the latest such event.
If the residents of Harlem are so hostile to whites, if the racial tensions on 125th Street run so deep, then why was Freddy's -- the store destroyed in a murderous attack that took eight lives -- intent on expanding? And why are Korean-, Hispanic- and Jewish-owned stores routinely attracting black customers? 
 Several hours on 125th Street this week suggest an answer: that the racial animosity directed against the Jewish-run Freddy's clothing store by black protesters did not reflect deep-rooted racism in Harlem. Rather, it expressed the sentiments of about a dozen protesters.
Harlem surely has its quota of racism and anti-Semitism and politicians who need the prod of a mass murder to denounce prejudice. But most people on 125th Street do not go around demanding a merchant's pedigree. "If blacks only shopped in black-owned shops, all the others would be out of business, right?" said Phyllis Locus, the black manager of black-owned Rainbow Music. "I think that was an isolated incident."
WAS it? That is always the question when there is a racially tinged eruption in New York. For instance, the Crown Heights violence in 1991, set off when a black child was accidentally killed by a Hasidic driver, was no shock. It reflected a deep and longstanding split between blacks and Hasidic Jews.
There is a long history of racial friction in Harlem, too, where blacks for generations suffered the insults of discrimination by white store owners. But now a recent survey showed that of 322 stores on West 125th Street, 158 were black-owned. The rest are owned by Asian, Jewish and Hispanic storekeepers. And so many black people work in the stores that it is difficult to tell who owns what.
Not that most customers seem much to care. When several black shoppers were asked the other day if they thought about the race or religion of storekeepers, they looked puzzled, as if to say, get real.
"As long as you got the item I want and got the right price, I don't care what color you are," said Robert Witherspoon, who was buying his daughter a down jacket at the Jewish-owned H and M Sneaker Center. Of course, people are going to be on their best behavior after a tragedy, especially talking to a white reporter. Still, the response was the same at the Ecuadorean-owned Garces Shoes, and in a Korean grocery store nearby, and at Bargain World, another Jewish-owned store that has been picketed by the same group of black protesters as Freddy's. "If there's something I like, I'm going to buy it," said Michelle Denson, in Bargain World.
Larry McNeely, a business consultant, said: "I'm not into that much race relations. It's a commodity being sold. It's ludicrous what this guy did, this maniac." He was referring to Roland J. Smith, who the authorities said shot himself to death after setting the fire at Freddy's.
ARTHUR ROSEN, whose father started Bargain World in 1938, insists he has never felt himself a target of anti-Semitism in Harlem. "In all countries, you have people who go off the deep end," he said. "There's one here, one in Israel, one Unabomber."
Mr. Rosen called the destruction of Freddy's "the result of a lot of things compounded -- the rabble-rousers, the Sharptons, the Powells," referring to Morris Powell, a leader of the protests, and the Rev. Al Sharpton, who must not have done his homework before joining the protest against Freddy's expansion into a space occupied by a black-owned record shop next door. A black church owns the building.
Mr. Rosen suggested that greed motivated the protesters. Mr. Powell's interests are not just racial. He has an economic stake. He and other vendors sell goods in a store next to Bargain World and may well look upon picketing as a profitable sideline. A flier urging a black boycott of Bargain World -- citing Mr. Rosen's support for moving street vendors off 125th Street -- directs shoppers to Mr. Powell's business next door. "Buy black," the flier urges.
Horace Sao doubts many will follow that dictate. "All I know is people love bargains and good prices," said Mr. Sao, who sells Happy Kwanzaa cards and Million Man March T-shirts at Mart 125, an indoor mall. He said he understands the charge that shopkeepers take money out of the community, even figures that points to him (he lives in the Bronx). But racial shopping? No.
"They don't go asking about color," he said. "To most people I know, it's all about shopping."

HEADLINE: Douglas Corrigan, 88, Dies; Wrong-Way Trip Was the Right Way to Celebrity as an Aviator

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Douglas Corrigan, a brash, errant aviator who captured the imagination of a Depression-weary public in 1938 when he took off from Brooklyn on a nonstop solo flight to Los Angeles and landed his improbable airplane in Dublin a day later, died on Saturday at a hospital in Orange, Calif. He was 88 and had been lionized for more than half a century as Wrong Way Corrigan.
The few people who were at Floyd Bennett Field when Mr. Corrigan took off at 5:15 on the morning of July 17, 1938, were baffled when the 31-year-old aviator turned into a cloud bank and disappeared to the east. 
 According to his flight plan, he should have been heading west.
As they and the world learned when his jerry-built, overloaded secondhand airplane touched down at Dublin's Baldonnel Airport 28 hours and 13 minutes later, Mr. Corrigan had not only known what he was doing, he had also flown straight into the hearts of the American people.
"I'm Douglas Corrigan," he told a group of startled Irish airport workers who gathered around him when he landed. "Just got in from New York. Where am I? I intended to fly to California."
Although he continued to claim with a more or less straight face that he had simply made a wrong turn and been led astray by a faulty compass, the story was far from convincing, especially to the American aviation authorities who had rejected his repeated requests to make just such a flight because his modified 1929 Curtiss-Robin monoplane was judged unworthy of more than an experimental aircraft certification.
Unmoved by evidence that he had not checked weather reports for the North Atlantic before his flight and had carried charts showing only his supposedly planned route to California, the authorities deemed his plane so unsafe and his flight so illegal that it took a 600-word official telegram to detail all the regulations he had violated.
But if Mr. Corrigan had such a twinkle in his eye when he told his story that he appeared to be trying to suppress a wink, the authorities had trouble stifling a wink of their own.
Although his pilot's license was instantly suspended, Mr. Corrigan, who returned to the United States by ship, did not miss a minute of flying time. He served the entire suspension at sea. The license was reinstated as soon as he and his crated-up plane sailed into New York Harbor aboard the liner Manhattan on Aug. 4, and received a tumultuous greeting.
There was an even larger welcome the next day when an estimated one million New Yorkers lined lower Broadway for a ticker-tape parade that eclipsed the one given for Charles A. Lindbergh after his solo flight to Paris in 1927.
Mr. Corrigan's 3,150-mile flight was an immediate sensation, pushing depressing economic news and grim international reports aside on the front pages of American newspapers and dominating radio broadcasts across the country.
Although half a dozen well-known pilots, among them Amelia Earhart and Wylie Post, had made solo flights across the Atlantic since Lindbergh had blazed the trail in the Spirit of St. Louis in 1927, none struck such a chord with the American people as Mr. Corrigan did.
That was partly because he was seen as an engaging and impish young pilot who had boldly thumbed his nose at authority, then baldly denied it, and partly because he had made the flight not in a state of the art aircraft with cutting edge instruments, but in a rickety plane so precariously patched together that it was variously dubbed an airborne crate and a flying jalopy.
Among other things, Mr. Corrigan, who had bought the plane in New York as a wreck for $310 in 1935 and nursed it cow pasture by cow pasture back to California, had ripped out the original 90-horsepower engine and replaced it with a 165-horsepower model cobbled together from two old Wright engines. He had also installed five extra fuel tanks, which completely blocked his forward view, and various parts, including the cabin door, were held together with baling wire.
Mr. Corrigan, who was born in Galveston, Tex., and grew up in Los Angeles, had been dreaming of a flight across the Atlantic for a long time. Enchanted with aviation at an early age, he had become a barnstorming pilot, flying instructor and an aviation mechanic who helped build Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis in San Diego. It was Mr. Corrigan, in fact, who pulled the chocks away from the wheels when Lindbergh took off from San Diego on his flight to New York in 1927.
Mr. Corrigan, who had speculated openly with friends about making an unauthorized trans-Atlantic flight, flew his plane to New York on July 10, 1938, setting a solo nonstop record of 27 hours, 50 minutes for the 2,700-mile flight.
When he took off a week later, ostensibly to return to California after accepting his failure to win permission for a trans-Atlantic flight, he carried a few chocolate bars, two boxes of fig crackers and a quart of water.
Within months of his feat he had made a triumphant American tour, endorsed wrong-way products like a watch that ran backward and signed lucrative contracts for an autobiography and a movie, "The Flying Irishman," in which he played himself.
He was a test pilot during World War II and later operated an air freight service. In the 1950's, he bought an orange grove in Santa Ana, Calif., but was forced to sell most of it in the 1960's. His wife, Elizabeth, died in 1966.
After a son was killed in a plane crash on Catalina Island in 1972 he became increasingly reclusive, until 1988 when he was lured back into the limelight by an offer to display his plane at an air show.
Mr. Corrigan, who had taken it apart in 1940 and stored it in his garage, was so enthusiastic that the show's organizers became alarmed.
Although Mr. Corrigan had not flown since 1972, the organizers found it prudent to station guards on the plane's wings during his appearance at the exhibition and even discussed anchoring the tail of the plane by rope to a police car.
He is survived by two sons, Douglas, of Santa Ana, and Harry, of Apex, N.C., and a sister, Evelyn, of Santa Ynez, Calif.

HEADLINE: U.N. Says North Korea Faces Danger of Famine

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 13

 BODY:
North Korea is in danger of a widespread famine, but so far most Western nations have been unwilling to pledge aid to prevent it, United Nations officials said today.
The World Food Program, a United Nations agency, said it would have to stop emergency delivery of food to North Korea if Western countries did not quickly pledge funds. 
 North Korea issued its first appeal for help from the international community after floods devastated farmland in August.
United Nations officials estimated that 1.5 million tons of grain were lost in the floods, which they called the worst in 100 years.
Last week, United Nations relief officials in North Korea described scenes of hungry residents foraging for roots to eat in plowed paddy fields, and children barely surviving on weak corn porridge.
Some 500,000 people were left homeless by the floods, and sub-zero winter weather is approaching.
"Because of acute food shortages, Government rice and cabbage rations have been drastically reduced and famine conditions have already begun to take hold in some of the worst-hit provinces," the agency said.
Those provinces are Chagang and North Pyongan, in the rural northwest, and North Hwanghae in the west.
So far, the World Food Program's appeal for $8.8 million in food aid has yielded little more than $200,000 from Denmark and Finland.
Japan and South Korea have also given North Korea aid on their own this year.
A South Korean newspaper reported today that Chinese leaders think the famine and other economic difficulties could prompt North Korea to start another war with South Korea to divert potential unrest.
The Chosun Ilbo newspaper cited a Chinese Government report suggesting the deteriorating economy and failing health of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il could prompt the North into military adventurism.
Francis Mwanza, a spokesman for the Rome-based agency, said that if one last appeal for donations fails, the agency will start shutting down its North Korea operation next week.
"It's a very worrying situation," he said. "There are still a half-million people in need of food. There's going to be starvation."
The United Nations agency already borrowed more than $2 million from an emergency fund to pay for an initial aid shipment.
Mr. Mwanza said his agency's program was the first time North Korea allowed any international group to monitor relief supplies.
Michael Ross, a World Food Program spokesman in New York, said agency workers in North Korea were dealing well with the North Koreans.
"If we pull out, we will be missing a very rare opportunity to break down the last 'Berlin Wall' in the world," he said. "It appears the international community does not want to pay for the ladder."
Nearly 17 months after the sudden death of North Korea's longtime ruler, Kim Il Sung, his son Kim Jong Il has failed to take full power, triggering speculation of challenges and health problems.

HEADLINE: Whitman Ties Cigarette Tax To Coverage For Children

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that she would seek to enroll nearly 100,000 uninsured children in a state-subsidized health insurance program financed in part by an increase in the state's cigarette tax.
The program now offers subsidized health insurance to 18,000 New Jersey residents who do not have employee-sponsored coverage and are not eligible for Medicaid. Under the Governor's proposal, the state would enroll no additional adults but instead would sign up uninsured children in a program emphasizing preventive care. 
 Governor Whitman said the proposed increase in the cigarette tax -- 25 cents a pack -- was needed to help pay for the expanded children's insurance program and also to help replenish the state fund that pays for hospital care for the poor.
The Governor and the state Legislature are facing a Dec. 31 deadline to come up with money for that fund, which distributed $400 million this year to reimburse 84 hospitals for charity care. Authorization to draw on the state's Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund for this purpose is expiring, and organized labor and the business community are both pressing the state to find alternatives.
By publicly announcing that the focus of the state's subsidized insurance program would change to emphasize children, Governor Whitman is seeking to build support for her plan to bring money in to the charity fund by raising the state cigarette tax to 65 cents from 40 cents.
"I am well aware that some people have criticized me for using a cigarette tax to help us pay for the Children First and charity care," the Governor said at a news conference at United Hospital Medical Center/ Children's Hospital of New Jersey in Newark. "I have a very, very simple response for them: This tax will help us bring our children in out of the cold and into the health care mainstream."
While departing Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian, a Republican from Warren County, joined Governor Whitman yesterday to show his support of the tax increase to pay for charity care, her plan is facing opposition in the Republican-controlled Senate. In general, New Jersey politicians are reluctant to support any new taxes since the Democrats lost control of the Legislature for approving former Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package in 1990.
The Whitman administration and the State Legislature are seeking to come up with $300 million for charity care and an additional $100 million for the subsidized health insurance program.
Under the Whitman administration proposal, which needs legislative approval, the tax increase would pay for $125 million of the state's charity care program. The remaining $275 million would come from the Unemployment Insurance Fund.
The Assembly minority leader, Joseph Doria, a Democrat from Hudson County, said: "The Governor should not be pitting children against adults, while pushing through a bill that raises taxes and raids a trust fund for the unemployed."
Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman for the Senate Republicans, declined to comment on the proposal.
Under the state's present six-month-old program to provide subsidized health insurance, a family of four with an income up to $37,875 is eligible to purchase insurance. There are an estimated 700,000 uninsured individuals in New Jersey. State officials said that almost 18,000 people have obtained health insurance through the program, which cost the state $50 million this year.

HEADLINE: European Parliament Admits Turkey to Its New Customs Union

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Turkey's long campaign to enter into a customs union with Europe ended in victory today, as the European Parliament voted by a wide margin to lift remaining trade barriers with Ankara.
The vote in Strasbourg, France went far beyond the economic benefits the trade union is expected to bring both sides, and was closely watched in Washington, where Turkey's bid had strong support. 
 For Turkey, the customs union was a test of its acceptance by Europe as a political as well as economic partner, and as a possible step toward full membership in the European Union. For critics of Turkey, it was seen as an endorsement of a human rights record that, while improved, still falls short of European standards.
The intense lobbying campaign that preceded the vote had focused not on economic issues but on human rights, particularly the Turkish security forces' campaign against Kurdish separatists.
But in the final debate, a majority of European parliamentarians were swayed by Ankara's argument that rejection would jeopardize Turkey's recent democratic reforms, and encourage an anti-Western mood on the eve national elections, scheduled for Dec. 24.
The customs union, which is due to go into effect on Jan. 1, is expected to produce a boom in European imports to Turkey, and double exports to Europe of Turkish textiles, now one of the country's largest foreign currency earners. Business interests in Europe, as well as Turkey, actively campaigned on Turkey's behalf, lobbying their governments and appealing for popular support with full-page newspaper ads.
The Turkish Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, who had put acceptance of the trade deal at the heart of her party's platform, triumphantly broadcast the news of the Strasbourg vote from loudspeakers atop her campaign bus in Istanbul today. The final vote was 343 to 143 with 36 abstentions.
"Now we have begun a national struggle on the road to full membership in the European Union," she told a crowd of cheering supporters.
For Turkey, a secular nation with a population that is 99 percent Muslim, the custom unions vote became a kind of test of national identity. Although regarded as an economic boon overall, it could threaten some of Turkey's heavily protected state industries, and many voters, now feeling the crunch of the Government's austerity plan, may be ambivalent about its value once it takes effect.
In addition, European pressure on human rights has been deeply resented by some Turks, who viewed the West as being insensitive to Turkey's precarious position in a volatile region. Others welcomed the pressure for reforms.
Last summer, the Turkish Parliament adopted a series of constitutional amendments that broadened political participation, and in the fall, it amended an anti-terrorist law that had been widely used to silence critics of the government's 11-year-old battle with Kurdish separatists in southeastern Turkey.
The customs union deal has been supported by a succession of Turkish Governments ever since it was first broached in 1963. Turkey formally applied for European Union membership in 1987 but it is not included on the list of countries that have been told they can join the union in the near future.
Even so, diplomats say the customs union will bind Turkey more closely to its European partners, by expanding the number and level of regular contacts.

HEADLINE: Jordanian Has a Goal: Shirtmaker To the U.S.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: AL MUKHABLAIN, Jordan, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Jad Maqdah, a shirtmaker, hopes that his "made in Jordan" label will find a place at the base of thousands more American necks.
In this resource-barren country, Mr. Maqdah must import every button, thread and shred of cloth that his Jordan Clothing Company needs to produce a simple cotton shirt. But of the more than one million shirts cut and sewn this year in his rudimentary factory here on the outskirts of Amman, more than one in four was destined for the United States. 
 Until the Persian Gulf war of 1991, Jordan relied almost wholly on a very different market, oil-rich Iraq. But with that outlet still barred by United Nations sanctions, this country and its entrepreneurs like Mr. Maqdah now look on stores like Macy's, a unit of the Camdev Corporation, and Kmart as potential routes to new prosperity.
At best, the record remains mixed. While Jordan's new peace with Israel has won a powerful American endorsement for its quest for development, new investors and contracts have been slow to materialize. Within the Middle East, potential trade routes to neighbors like Syria remain largely blocked by trade barriers.
Even for Mr. Maqdah, whose company is Jordan's largest retailer, the transformation has required adjustments. In Jordan, the company is licensed to make and sell high-quality shirts under the Van Heusen label owned by Phillips-Van Heusen, but it has found a steady American buyer only for cheap flannel garments.
But Jordan, not blessed by the oil that has enriched its Arab neighbors, is in no position to be picky. After five years in which the official closing of the Iraqi market has sent the unemployment rate to an estimated 25 percent, the unexpected flow of shirts to American shelves has given rise to hopes that the country's low labor costs and relative stability may hold some economic promise.
Mr. Maqdah, 44, the company's managing director, described the 300,000 shirts that his company sent to the United States last year as "only the beginning" of its export drive.
"To establish your credibility," he said of the company's willingness to concentrate for now on low-end politics, "sometimes you have to start from the bottom up."
Established in 1949 by Mr. Maqdah's father, the Jordan Clothing Company has long been the country's largest retailer, with 20 stores in Amman. Along with robes, T-shirts and pajamas, it still sells 60 percent of its shirts in Jordan.
But now nearly 500 workers, most of them veiled women from Al Mukhablain itself, work every day but Friday in the six-story factory to keep pace with the surge of export business, 70 percent of it to the United States.
Mr. Maqdah's mother, Suhaila, has taken over as the company chairman, and his two younger brothers, Samir and Mazen, have hurried home from jobs abroad to help manage the export boom.
Made from cotton imported from Pakistan and thread from Sri Lanka and stitched on German-made machines, the flannel shirts that Mr. Maqdah makes for an American middleman for as little as $50 a dozen are Jordanian only by toil. With a "made in Jordan" tag and a Woodlawn label, most are sold in Kmart and other budget stores.
With a major port in Aqaba and labor costs among the lowest in the region, just one-tenth those of neighboring Israel, Jordan is seen by many economists here as well positioned to become a light-manufacturing center.
Only two years ago, it did not export a single shirt to the United States. But now its textile exports total $40 million a year, and diplomats like to compare Jordan to the Israel of 20 years ago, before that economy exploded into the fastest-growing in the Middle East.
Among Jordan's four million people, there also remains a widespread yearning for simpler days, and many here still clearly hope that the search for new opportunities need only be temporary. Before the gulf war, some 80 percent of Jordan's exports went no further than Iraq, a trade so lucrative that the United Nations sanctions against Baghdad have cost Jordan $300 million to $400 million a year. Even now, with Jordan adopting a tougher line against the Iraqi Government, it has continued to call for a lifting of those trade barriers.
At the factory in Al Mukhablain, some of the nostalgia for more profitable days was renewed by an American buyer's offer that would have doubled the company's exports, but at an unacceptably low price.
In conversations, members of the Maqdah family wondered how their company could compete in the long run with manufacturers from the Far East, where labor is even cheaper and materials closer at hand.
"Back when we used to sell to Iraq," Suhaila Maqdah said, "things were very very good."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Jumps 41.55 Points On Another Record Day
Stocks rose to new records as computer-driven buy programs lifted prices in advance of Friday's triple expiration of options and futures contracts. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 41.55 points, to 5,216.47, eclipsing a record close of 5,199.15 set Dec. 6. Two broader indexes also rose.
Blue chips in general were strong, as were oil and airline stocks. But computer issues were mixed. [D8.]
 
Bausch Chairman Quits; Stock Jumps
Daniel E. Gill, the executive who built Bausch & Lomb into an optical giant and then steered it into rough waters, said he was retiring by year's end after 13 years as chairman. A permanent replacement is to be chosen within a few months. A leading candidate is William M. Carpenter, who was named president. The stock jumped $2.625, to $39.75. [D4.]
 
Kimberly-Clark to Lose 6,000 Jobs
Now that it has completed its $9.4 billion acquisition of Scott Paper, Kimberly-Clark plans to cut 6,000 jobs by next summer. The changes will result in a big charge but could save the company $1.2 billion by 1998. Kimberly shares rose $1.375, to $79.875. [D2.]
 
Vote Ends Boeing Strike The machinists' union voted overwhelmingly in favor of a new contract at Boeing, ending a strike. Work should resume today. [A22.]
 
 
Judge Keeps Prodigy Ruling
A New York judge stood by a ruling that Prodigy could be liable for comments subscribers post on its electronic bulletin boards. He said he would not rehear the case, though new arguments have been made. [D2.]
 
 
Federal Express Net Rises 4%
Federal Express earnings rose only 4 percent in the latest quarter, to $89.9 million, held down by a work slowdown by its pilots' union and declining international profit. [D7.]
 
 
 
A Big New Lot in Hollywood
Dreamworks plans to build the first new studio backlot in Los Angeles in a half-century, a 100-acre campus complete with the latest technology. The project by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg approximates a huge community. [C11.]
 
 
 
Sumitomo Pursues Daiwa Assets Sumitomo Bank is asking the Federal Reserve for permission to buy Daiwa Bank's American operations, a Fed official said. [D6.]
 
 
 
Court Upholds Cable TV Rules
A Federal court in Washington upheld rules that require cable television systems to carry local broadcast channels. [D5.]
 
 
Britain Cuts Lending Rate
Britain lowered its official lending rate for the first time in 22 months, a day before Germany is to consider a rate reduction. [D7.]
 

Lotus Adds to Notes and Cuts Price
I.B.M.'s Lotus unit is changing its Notes program to let users read and create information for the World Wide Web. Most of the changes will be in a version of Notes on sale Jan. 1. Lotus also cut some prices. [D20.]
 
 
Argentine Hard Rock Cafe Shut
Argentina seemed like a perfect place for another Hard Rock Cafe -- that is, until local businessmen said they had exclusive rights to the name. The cafe's British developer is losing business, and is angry at the nation's judicial system. [D6.]
 
 
 
 
S.E.C. Trips Up Marriage Counselor
A marriage counselor was charged with insider trading linked to secret talks between Lockheed and Martin Marietta. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Russia's Unruly Democracy

 BODY:
The course of reform in Russia has been disorderly, and there is no reason to think it will be less so after Sunday's parliamentary election. A dizzying array of parties and candidates is competing for the 450 seats in the State Duma, or lower house. Many of them are committed to slowing reform, some are sworn to ending it. The Communist Party, so recently disgraced, seems positioned for a comeback. Nationalist candidates look strong in many districts. The centrist political party of President Boris Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin seems as sickly as its leader.
This is not the straight line to stability that Russians might have wished for when the Soviet Union disintegrated four years ago, or that Americans might have imagined as they watched Russia discard centuries of autocratic rule. 
 But as some of Russia's erstwhile allies in Central Europe have already shown, the passage from tyranny to democracy is going to be long and uneven, and democratic elections will not always produce democratic leaders. Communists of one stripe or another have returned to power through elections in Bulgaria, Hungary and, most recently, in Poland. Russia could be next.
This is cause for concern, but not despair. Russia is not in danger of slipping back to Stalinism, nor is the cold war about to resume, even if the Communists win the largest bloc of seats on Sunday. Political and economic reform has already transited sufficient ground to make some change virtually irreversible, including the transfer to private ownership of much of Russia's economy and property.
For better or worse, every major political party has a stake in the widespread redistribution of wealth that is going on in Russia. As John Lloyd of The Financial Times observed at a recent symposium organized by Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, the election is really about who will control that redistribution, not whether it will stop.
The elections themselves are the surest sign that reform is sticking. The Communist Party will only do as well on Sunday as Russian voters say. That is not a system Lenin would have endorsed.
Russians, like Americans, are anxious about economic uncertainty, and there is much to be uncertain about in Russia today. Although inflation has stabilized and the economy shows some signs of growth, income inequities are glaring and widening. Some Russians have made a fortune in the free market or through the acquisition of government assets. Many others live austere lives, and too many, especially the elderly, have fallen into desperate poverty.
The discontent over economic hardships has been compounded by a loss of national pride as Russia's international status has slipped from superpower to second-rate power. Crime of all kinds is rising. Add to that Mr. Yeltsin's erratic leadership, particularly his disastrous military campaign in Chechnya, and it is not hard to see why many Russians would be drawn to the soothing promises of Communists and nationalists, who preach order and a revived empire.
Under Russia's new Constitution, Parliament is overshadowed by the presidency. Unless one party or a coalition of parties can control two-thirds of the seats, the number required to override presidential vetoes, the legislature cannot itself change the direction of Moscow's domestic and foreign policies. But in tandem with presidential elections scheduled for next June, the vote this Sunday will help determine whether Russia is ready to accelerate or slow reform.

HEADLINE: David Marshall, 87, Opponent Of Singapore Authoritarianism

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 14

 BODY:
David Marshall, one of the founding fathers of Singapore and one of the last Singaporeans brave enough to speak up against the authoritarian Government now running the city-state, died on Tuesday at his home in Singapore. He was 87.
He had been suffering from lung cancer, a family spokesman said. 
 Mr. Marshall, who gained early fame for his passionate oratory as a criminal defense lawyer, was chief minister in Singapore's first elected Government in 1955. He resigned the next year when talks broke down with Britain over terms for self-government for the former British colony.
Although he lost his parliamentary seat a few years later and eventually returned to the law, Mr. Marshall remained a stinging critic of the People's Action Party, which took power in 1959 under the leadership of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.
Mr. Lee retired as Prime Minister in 1990 but in his new role as Senior Minister he is still considered the most powerful man in Singapore, and his party retains a tight hold on the reins of Government, silencing critics through defamation suits and other forms of intimidation.
While Mr. Marshall was always careful in public settings to praise Mr. Lee and his party for converting Singapore into one of the most prosperous nations in Asia, he would also condemn their repressive tactics, using language that few others in Singapore would dare even consider.
"I stand in awe, genuine awe, of what they have achieved," Mr. Marshall said last year of the People's Action Party. But the country's economic progress was achieved at the cost of a sense of humanity, he said, describing Mr. Lee as "at base a fascist" and Singapore as a nation with a "plastic heart."
Mr. Marshall was one of only a handful of Singaporeans willing to criticize the Government publicly over the caning last year of an American teen-ager, Michael P. Fay, who had pleaded guilty to vandalism. He said the lashing was "grossly excessive."
He often belittled Mr. Lee's assertion that there should be different standards for human rights in Asia and the West. In a letter last year that the Government-run newspaper, The Straits Times, refused to publish, Mr. Marshall noted that authoritarianism had repeatedly brought chaos to China.
"We should keep in mind the horrors of the Cultural Revolution, brought about by the cult of subservience to authority and primacy of society over the individual, before we point the accusing finger at those who believe that respect for the individual is the basis of human civilization," he wrote.
Mr. Marshall, the son of Orthodox Jewish immigrants from Iraq, was born in Singapore in 1908 and earned a law degree in Britain. A soldier in the colonial army in World War II, he was taken captive by Japanese forces in 1942 and was forced to work in the coal mines of Hokkaido, Japan.
He was freed in 1945 and returned home, where he was quickly recognized as the most effective criminal defense lawyer in Singapore, winning over juries in what appeared to be hopeless cases.
It was commonly said in legal circles that "Marshall never loses," and his success in the courtroom was cited by the People's Action Party when it eventually decided to abolish the jury system.
His involvement in the movement against British colonial rule led him into politics, and in 1955, he came to power as chief minister when his Labor Front party swept to power in elections for a transitional government.
He remained active in opposition politics until 1972, when he was accused by the local bar association of misconduct -- supporters said the case was entirely trumped up -- over his defense of a group of newspaper executives detained under Singapore's draconian internal security laws.
It was a sign of the high regard still held for Mr. Marshall that in 1978 he was made Ambassador to France, a post he held until two years ago, when he returned to Singapore and returned to work in a law firm. Many Singaporeans say Mr. Marshall was given the post in France in order to get him out of the country -- and away from political debate.
There was an outpouring of tributes to Mr. Marshall this week, including several from members of the People's Action Party. "He has contributed much in the service of Singapore," said Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, who praised Mr. Marshall for his "wit, insight and eloquence." Deputy Prime Minister Tony Tan said Mr. Marshall was "a great man."
Mr. Goh's predecessor, Mr. Lee, was notably silent. A spokesman for Mr. Lee said today that the former Prime Minister had so far issued no statement about the death of his great rival.
Mr. Marshall is survived by his wife, Jean, and their four children, Ruth, Sara, Joanna and Jonathan.

HEADLINE: Environmental Study Center Created to Honor Late Senator

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The family of the late Senator H. John Heinz 3d has donated $20 million to establish a research center in his name where experts from universities, industry, government and advocacy groups will join to seek firmer ground for environmental policies in science and economics.
The sponsors said the gift was one of the largest single philanthropic grants ever offered in environmental circles. 
 They said the new center, the Heinz Center for Science, Economics and the Environment, would offer nonpartisan, innovative and credible ideas in a field constantly riven by politics, where government policies are often masterminded by muddling through.
Already, the center has won support -- and drawn members of its fledgling board of directors -- from quarters including the Environmental Defense Fund and the Nature Conservancy, the Aluminum Company of America and the Enron Corporation, and four major universities: Carnegie Mellon, Cornell, Princeton and Stanford.
Its president is William J. Merrell Jr., an oceanographer and former vice chancellor of the Texas A & M University System. The professional staff, ensconced in a downtown Washington office, is expected to grow to about a dozen this year, with a budget of $1.7 million, he said.
But the real strength of the organization, its founders said, will be drawn from companies, schools, environmental groups and the government, whose experts will assemble to work on knotty, emerging problems that the center believes will move to the forefront of the policy agenda in two to five years.
The founders said that they were keenly aware of the intensely political nature of environmental decision making and that the center would remain independent, even as it reached out to all sectors involved in the environmental debate.
Teresa Heinz, the widow of Senator Heinz and chairwoman of the Heinz Family Philanthropies, said in an interview that she believed the intense drive by Republicans in the 104th Congress to radically reshape environmental policies would wane and a more centrist approach would emerge.
"When that happens, there have got to be some well-thought-out alternatives," she said.
Senator Heinz, a moderate Republican from Pennsylvania who died in a plane crash in 1991, first sought in the 1980's to develop a bipartisan effort to harness market forces for environmental protection, an idea he pursued along with Senator Tim Wirth, a Democrat who now is the Assistant Secretary of State for Global Affairs, the top environmental post at the State Department.
Mrs. Heinz, who this year married Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, is an active environmentalist and vice chairwoman of the Environmental Defense Fund, a nonprofit advocacy group that has made a mark developing approaches, like the trading on financial markets of pollution permits, that use financial incentives to lower the costs of protecting the environment.
Mrs. Heinz controls a family fortune worth several hundred million dollars, originally derived from the Heinz food company.
The donation to establish the Heinz Center comes from the Vira I. Heinz Endowment, one of the Pittsburgh-based philanthropies, with combined assets of about $1 billion, associated with the family.
The board of the Heinz Center includes Mrs. Heinz; Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund in New York; Kenneth L. Lay, chairman of the Enron Corporation, an energy company; Simon A. Levin, a biologist and director of the Princeton Environmental Institute at Princeton University; Robert Mehrabian, president of Carnegie Mellon; Paul H. O'Neill, chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, and John C. Sawhill, president of the Nature Conservancy.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Confession Of Weakness

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
In a cynical time, we Americans long for heroes. If we were less parochial, less culture-bound, we would see one: a man of extraordinary vision and courage. On his own, alone, he has challenged the greatest tyranny on earth. Though he had little formal education, he brilliantly expounded the meaning of freedom. Imprisoned, brutalized, silenced, he will not yield.
Wei Jingsheng is his name. Because he is Chinese, relatively few Americans recognize his heroism. But he is as remarkable a figure, in his way, as Andrei Sakharov was in the years of Soviet tyranny or Nelson Mandela under apartheid. 
 In 1978, when he was an electrician at the Beijing Zoo, he wrote an essay on democracy that was posted on the so-called Democracy Wall. Reading it today, one can only marvel at its understanding -- and its daring.
"In our People's Republic," he wrote, some people "live like gods and hold dominant power." Instead, "we want to be masters of our own destiny. We need no gods or emperors."
For that essay he was sentenced to 15 years in prison. At his trial in 1979 he explained that his aim was "free, unrestricted inquiry, seeking the truth from facts."
"Leaders are only human," he said. "It is only when they are brought under the critical supervision of the people that they will make fewer mistakes. . . . Criticizing unreasonable people and things is the intrinsic right of every citizen, and is also his unavoidable responsibility."
To an American, that language rings of the democratic theory of Alexander Meiklejohn, who said the citizen in a democracy had the duty to criticize. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. embraced the idea in 1964 in his opinion for the Supreme Court in New York Times v. Sullivan, speaking of the duty of "the citizen-critic of government."
Wei Jingsheng was released from prison in 1993. Again he called for democracy. Six months later he was re-arrested. Now, in a mockery of a trial, he has been convicted of trying to overthrow the Chinese Government and sentenced to 14 more years in prison.
The trial was closed to foreign correspondents and diplomats. Afterward the Government described it in a statement. Investigation, it said, showed that Wei Jingsheng had engaged in "purchasing newspapers, setting up a company in charge of cultural activities and organizing nongovernmental painting exhibitions, performances and publications with the aim of . . . raising a storm powerful enough to shake up the present Government."
Organizing painting exhibitions: There is a dangerous crime. As thus described, the trial was an unwitting demonstration of how weak and vulnerable the Communist Chinese oligarchy feels. Prof. Merle Goldman of Boston University, a China scholar, put it:
"A 14-year sentence for Wei shows you how fragile the present leaders' grip on power is. They have no legitimacy. It's absurd to think that one individual could possibly destabilize a country of 1.2 billion people."
The second trial of Wei Jingsheng sends a signal about the nature of the regime in Beijing. Many have hoped, or even believed, that economic liberalization in China would lead to political liberalization. But the regime, we know now, fears that even one free voice would threaten its power.
What can we do about the Chinese tyranny? Some believe the Beijing Government does not care what the world thinks, but that is plainly wrong. It eased up on dissidents when its most-favored-nation trade status in the United States seemed threatened -- and has been much more brutal since President Clinton de-linked the two issues last year.
Mr. Clinton should speak out himself about Wei Jingsheng's new imprisonment, as he has not yet done: That is one thing. His Administration should begin now to rally votes in the United Nations Human Rights Commission to condemn China -- a condemnation that Beijing urgently wants to avoid. It should oppose financing for Chinese projects in the World Bank.
Most of all, we should get over the notion that we must not offend China. Speaking truth to its power will in fact help those inside the regime who oppose its growing intransigence.
It is time to show our indignation at the brutalities of Beijing. It is time to respect the courage of Wei Jingsheng.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Nonprofit Sector Needs Professionals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Woeful '95 Leads U.S. Charities to Introspection" (news article, Dec. 10): 
 I was astounded to read that nonprofit organization leaders are concerned about increased professionalism in the field. Your article suggests that participants at a New York conference questioned the role of professional managers in running nonprofit hospitals and foundations, citing loss of the small volunteer managerial ethic as a problem.
It is not surprising that the nonprofit sector, of which I am a part, is in trouble with thinking like this. Professionalism is what the nonprofit corporate world needs to regain the organizational and spiritual respect of the public.
The nonprofit community and the public must accept that hospitals, educational facilities and social service and arts organizations are big businesses that need to be run efficiently in order to fulfill their societal mission.
The public should not confuse philanthropic scandals with attempts to bring more professional, bottom-line managers into the nonprofit sector: just the opposite, it is the lack of professional, experienced financial and organizational managers that creates a breeding ground for scandal and abuse.
If an individual is intent on taking advantage of an organization, what better opportunity exists than in an organization that is in the dark ages of organizational management and financial accountability?
To maintain its role in American society, the nonprofit community had better accept the managerial principles the rest of the country respects.
 
RUSSELL POMERANZ
Director, Finance and Personnel
Meet the Composer
New York, Dec. 12, 1995

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Retiring at 37 to Travel and Write: It's Risky

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

INVESTMENT BIKER
On the Road With Jim Rogers
By Jim Rogers
Illustrated. 402 pages. Random House. $25.
Memorializing a journey is like investment counseling in one sense: if you're going to do it, you have to do it well to make it worth the risk to your clients. Jim Rogers, who made "millions" (as he puts it) as a Wall Street fund manager and retired at the "ripe old age of 37," must be a brilliant investor. In his literary endeavors, however, this account of a two-year globe-girdling motorcycle trip with his girlfriend pays off occasionally but not nearly often enough to make the reader very rich. 
 The first hundred or so pages, which take Mr. Rogers and his friend, Tabitha Estabrook, east across Central Asia and China, then west through Siberia, are so full of astonished banality that the account nearly becomes a parody of itself. One problem is that Mr. Rogers's writing is unexceptional and pedestrian. Another is that he is overimpressed by the depth of his insights.
 "I realized as we came down out of the mountains and onto the plains," he writes, as though making a great discovery, "how often borders followed geographical features and changes such as rivers, mountains, lakes, deserts."
"The other thing Tabitha and I noticed throughout the Central Asian republics were the number of Muslims," Mr. Rogers adds somewhat later, hastening to suggest that everyone would be surprised. "In America we tend to think Muslims are a people centered in the Middle East, not realizing that they run from Morocco to the Philippines."
When he gets to China, Mr. Rogers continues to share his putatively deep knowledge of history and the world. His quick analysis of the Tiananmen Square student demonstrations in Beijing in 1989 reveals him as a man who does not know that he does not know. When he arrives in the Central Asian republics of the former Soviet Union, he provides more trailblazing insight: "The real crime here was the perversion of human nature, the original Communist notion that the natural way of trade and commerce that had existed throughout the world for thousands of years was somehow evil."
The idea of Mr. Rogers's worldwide jaunt is to combine a good time, the adventure of a lifetime, with professional observations of local economies and a search for investment opportunities. And so, as he and Ms. Estabrook roar through countries on their BMW's, Mr. Rogers expatiates on economic conditions, more often than not bemoaning the stupidity of governments that try to control prices or the flow of goods and currencies.
Mr. Rogers's lessons on the international economy are easy to digest and might well be interesting and even useful to those with little knowledge of these matters. They would seem elementary to any reader of the Wall Street Journal editorial page, which follows a similar free-market philosophy, though what Mr. Rogers often does well is link that philosophy to concrete illustrations.
"Gas here wasn't expensive, simply unavailable, the way it had been cheap and hard to get in Siberia and Russia," Mr. Rogers remarks after several failed attempts to fill up at Zairian gas stations. "But this made sense: fix a price too low, and no one wants to supply it -- not individuals, not corporations and not governments." When Mr. Rogers and his friend take their bikes to Africa for the Tunis-to-Cape-Town run, his skills as a diarist improve, in part because he simply tells, in a breezy, conversational style, what he saw and what happened rather than interpreting the meaning of it all. In Africa, too, the travelers have a few genuine adventures. In Zaire, a once-rich country wrecked, as Mr. Rogers notes, by the regime of the strongman Mobutu Sese Seko, the motorcyclists, forced off their bikes by flooded roads, spend 13 days in a convoy of 11 barges being pushed by a single tugboat down the Congo River, which provides Mr. Rogers with a rare occasion to write interestingly about local life.
Also in Zaire, he comes into conflict with a young Frenchman he hired in North Africa to drive a truck accompanying them as they make their way on their motorcycles toward Cape Town. The Frenchman, a randy bon vivant, is always asking for more money, and Mr. Rogers finally cuts off the flow. This leads the Frenchman to chase Mr. Rogers through the grounds of a missionary compound with a bowie knife, which lands all three foreigners in the viselike grip of local officials who extort money from them.
When Mr. Rogers, trapped and unable to leave without paying up, tries to send a letter to the American Embassy asking for help, the postman coolly tells him: "You can't mail this. We don't send letters to that embassy." Giving in to local custom after several days, Mr. Rogers dips into his capital.
As he and Ms. Estabrook make their way along their 65,000-mile route through Europe, Asia, Africa and the Americas, an odd fact becomes increasingly clear: their trip, at least from the reader's point of view, is more absorbing when they are not on their motorcycles. Or perhaps that is not so odd. Motorcycles are fun. They are exhilarating. But they are, almost by definition, isolating instruments that get you close to but not into the lives of the people who live in the places you are visiting. From the literary point of view, trains, buses and barges are better.
