HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;
Balkan Foes Sign Peace Pact, Dividing An Unpacified Bosnia

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 14

 BODY:
In somber silence, the leaders of Bosnia, Serbia and Croatia signed a peace agreement today, even as scattered violence in Bosnia made clear that real peace was not yet at hand.
Today's ceremony, presided over by President Clinton and other international sponsors, cleared the way for the deployment of 60,000 NATO peacekeeping troops and the commitment of hundreds of millions of dollars to rebuild the country after nearly four cruel years of war. 
 "My Government is taking part in this agreement not with any enthusiasm, but as someone taking a bitter potion of medication," President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia said after the formal signing of the accords reached with American mediation in Dayton, Ohio, last month.
Though the agreement preserves his country in name, it also ratifies the ethnic division of Bosnia that Mr. Izetbegovic's Muslim-led Government had fought to prevent, dividing the territory between Government and Croatian forces on one side and Serbs on the other.
The plan signed today, with its calls for a new confederation of the rival parties and free movement of peoples within, represents a desperate gamble that peace can be forged from this savagely splintered remnant of the former Yugoslavia.
Before the signing, President Jacques Chirac of France said, "Real peace remains to be built in people's hearts and minds, along with democracy, human liberty and reconciliation."
Mr. Clinton, who flew in for the ceremony in the chandeliered ballroom of Mr. Chirac's residence, Elysee Palace, this morning and flew out this evening, told the former belligerents: "You have seen what war has wrought. You know what peace can bring. Seize this chance and make it work." [Excerpts from speeches, page A20.]
On paper, the 19-page accord leaves the multi-ethnic Bosnian state whole, and it was officially recognized as Bosnia and Herzegovina today by the Serb-dominated Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. But on the ground, the NATO peacekeeping force provided for in the accord will have the job of keeping apart the forces of Bosnia's two newly created components -- a Muslim-Croat federation and a Bosnian Serb republic.
Most of the NATO force, including 20,000 American troops, will be in place in northern Bosnia by February. As those troops keep the peace, the United Nations and other groups will take on such tasks as rebuilding the economy and resettling hundreds of thousands of refugees.
There were no tears of relief, no emotional scenes of reconciliation as Mr. Izetbegovic, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia filed in under the gilded cherubs in the Elysee ceiling to seal the accords.
They signed without saying a word, put the caps back on their fountain pens and shook hands perfunctorily, staring straight ahead and seldom applauding as speakers urged them to think of the tens of thousands of people killed by followers of these same men after the collapse of the Yugoslavia in 1991.
Then Mr. Clinton and the leaders of France, Britain, Germany, Russia and the European Union signed as sponsors, and Mr. Clinton shook hands with the three Balkan leaders.
It was the first time he had met Mr. Milosevic, who encouraged the Bosnian Serbs in their violent attempt to carve out a piece of Bosnia for themselves. [Later, in an interview on CNN, he said of the handshake, "I'm reminded of what my friend, the late Prime Minister Rabin said, 'You don't make peace with your friends.' "]
More than any of the others, Mr. Clinton has tied his political fate to the success of the agreement, by committing American soldiers to the NATO force over considerable opposition from Congress and at the start of his campaign for re-election.
In Bosnia, sporadic violence today underscored the potential risks. There were reports of explosions in Sarajevo -- apparently shells fired by Serbs who feel betrayed by the agreement -- while Government troops fired on a French United Nations helicopter and Croatian forces clashed with pro-Government Islamic fighters. There were no reports of casualties.
Mr. Clinton assured the three Balkan leaders in meetings before the signing ceremony that the NATO force, commanded by Gen. George A. Joulwan of the United States, would act impartially. He also asked them to do all they could to insure that the NATO peacekeepers were not attacked as the United Nations peacekeepers so often were, American officials said.
Mr. Milosevic of Serbia warned, "The key to success in the mission is even-handedness, even as the basis of its failure is partiality."
He and the Bosnian Serb forces -- which he had initially sponsored, then broke with after suffering years of international economic sanctions -- were blamed for setting off the war in early 1991 to create a Greater Serbia out of the ruins of Yugoslavia. Mr. Milosevic accepted terms today that fell far short of that.
Mr. Tudjman, whose army drove more than 100,000 Serbs out of Croatia last summer and set the stage for the American negotiating push that led to the peace agreement, spoke in terms that brooked no admission of responsibility for the war.
The former Yugoslavia, he said, had collapsed for deep historical reasons. Summarizing nearly two thousand years of events culminating in the Versailles Treaty that created Yugoslavia after World War I, he said: "It was established within the scope of the Versailles order from peoples belonging to different cultural spheres, in an area which first witnessed, in ancient times, the division of the Roman Empire, followed by the rift between the Western-Roman and Eastern-Byzantine parts of the Christian world, and, in the Middle Ages, partial Islamization occasioned by the Ottoman invasion."
Under the agreement, which was largely brokered by Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, Bosnia and Herzegovina remains one country with its existing international borders. An elected group presidency is to be established, along with a national currency.
But reflecting battlefield reality, the territory will be divided into two sub-entities, with about half governed by a Bosnian-Croatian federation and half by a Bosnian Serb republic. Among the major questions are whether the Bosnian Muslims and Croats -- former enemies -- will cooperate with each other, and whether the Serbs will in effect secede, joining the Serbian motherland.
In a country where more than a million people have been forced from their homes, the plan also lays out ambitious, some think fanciful targets for rapid elections, repatriation of displaced people, compensation for property losses, protection of human rights and economic rebuilding.
Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Izetbegovic exchanged letters in Mr. Clinton's presence at the American Ambassador's residence here this morning, an American official said, pledging to exchange ambassadors between Mr. Milosevic's Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and Mr. Izetbegovic's Bosnia and Herzegovina within 60 days.
But Croatia and Yugoslavia, which now consists of Serbia and Montenegro, did not recognize each other today. The leaders did agree to choose Jacques Klein, an American diplomat, as head of the United Nations transitional authority in the Serb-occupied Croatian province of Eastern Slavonia, which the Serbs have agreed to give back to Croatia.
Because of tremendous traffic jams created by a three-week-old public transport strike, dignitaries had to helicopter in from Orly Airport and make their way to a lunch at the French Foreign Ministry.
Mr. Chirac insisted on having the signing ceremony at Elysee Palace despite the strikes, in part to stake a French claim to credit for the agreement. France has lost 56 soldiers in Bosnia, and French diplomats complained that Mr. Holbrooke had run roughshod over his European colleagues in Dayton.

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: THE OUTLOOK;
History vs. History: Foes in Bosnia Invoke the Past

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The Bosnian war was long sustained by the manipulation of history, used by the parties to justify acts of barbarism and by Western powers to explain their prolonged inaction. Today, as a treaty was signed here to end the worst conflict in Europe since World War II, history was once again a theme and the varied allusions to it suggested the fragility of the peace.
President Clinton, abruptly changing his views on Bosnian history, tried to portray a society long distinguished by understanding between different ethnic and religious groups. "Bosnia," he said, "once found unity in its diversity," adding that the lives there of Muslims, Orthodox Serbs, Catholic Croats and Jews were "woven together by marriage and culture." 
 It was a remarkable turnabout for the President who, as recently as the June summit of the world's major economic powers in Canada, portrayed the Bosnian war as intractable because rooted in hatreds going back "at least to the 11th century."
In fact, the truth about Bosnia lies somewhere between the history of harmony elaborated today by the President and his earlier allusions to a 1,000-year-old war. It would take a considerable stretch of the imagination to see Bosnia's past as a natural beacon to peace.
A terrible civil war, which took hundreds of thousands of lives, was fought within Bosnia during World War II. Revolts racked the area in the 1870's. The movements of Croatian and Serb nationalism that have marked Balkan history over the past two centuries have long caused moments of unease as the Croats and Serbs of Bosnia wrestled with their identity.
Above all, the country has no recent independent history of peaceful existence on which to build: for centuries it has been ruled by outside imperial powers or by the Communist authorities of Yugoslavia.
Thus the settlement today is really an attempt to usher a new country into being. Independence in April of 1992 led immediately to war: the state never came to life because it immediately came under assault from the Serbs. This war has destroyed and polarized a unique society, one that has indeed known the harmony President Clinton described, but also one that has not governed itself in peace for centuries.
This reality gives a measure of the challenge facing the 20,000 American troops who are going now to Bosnia as part of a NATO force to police the peace. Even greater, perhaps, will be the challenge facing the international civilian authorities who will try organize democratic elections and put in place a police force that can assure security for refugees returning home.
They will be working in a Bosnian state that officially has two armies -- one Serb and one of the Muslim-Croat federation -- but in reality has three: one Serb, one Croat and one mainly Muslim. They will be also working in a state where words like "democracy" and the "rule of law" are more slogans than conditions that people understand. After World War II, Germany was there to be rebuilt; after this war, Bosnia has to be formed.
The reluctance of these different forces to come together to form the single multi-ethnic Bosnian state backed by the United States and western Europe was evident in the words of Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian President. At a moment of peace, he chose to devote almost all his speech to an account of Balkan history that dwelt heavily on division and violence.
Thus, he dismissed the former Yugoslavia as a failed attempt to bring together "peoples belonging to different cultural spheres." These divergent spheres, he argued, were evident as early as the the Roman Empire, whose line of division between what he called "Western-Roman and Eastern-Byzantine" parts ran through the Balkans.
In plain English, what Mr. Tudjman was saying was that the Catholic Croats and Eastern Orthodox Serbs never belonged in the same state and were culturally incompatible.
That, in Mr. Tudjman's argument today, is why Yugoslavia fell apart during World War II and why only the Commuist authority of Tito could hold it together after that. Communism's collapse in Europe led in turn to what Mr. Tudjman called a "Yugo-Communist aggression" aimed at creating "a Greater Serbia" that swooped down on Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Turning to his nominal allies, the Muslims of Bosnia, Mr. Tudjman was disparaging. He described them as a religious group that had been reinvented as a "separate ethnic entity" by Tito in an attempt to use them as a buffer between Serbs and Croats. This attempt, he added, was a failure.
The bits of history that Mr. Tudjman left out were perhaps as interesting as those he chose to dwell on. These included the genocidal assault on Serbs by the Nazi puppet Croatian state during World War II and his own provocations to Croatia's Serb minority before the Croatian war. But all the history -- averred and unspoken -- scarcely suggested a future of Balkan harmony.
Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, was less concerned with history, but nonetheless ready to edit it to his ends. Having roused Serbs into a violent national fervor in the late 1980s and so destabilized Yugoslavia, he declared today that only "civil and humane" means should be used to settle disputes "at the end of the 20th century."
Just four years ago, in March 1991, as Yugoslavia was disintegrating, Mr. Milosevic declared, "If we have to we will fight," adding that Serbs may not "know how to work and do business but at least we know how to fight."
Alija Izetbegovic, the Bosnian President, said he would work for peace but suggested that the historical struggle for a united Bosnia was not over. The bitter history of the war would not lead to a quest for vengeance, he said, but "the guilty must be punished because guilt does exist." His words were full of a bitterness reflecting the deep suffering of Bosnia's Muslims and suggesting that conflict still lurks just below the surface.
As for the French, the hosts to the signing in the Elysee Palace, they have been engaged in their own argument over history with the Americans. This has centered on who should take credit for the peace agreement, hammered out in Dayton, Ohio, and forged by Richard Holbrooke, an Assistant Secretary of State. The French object to the fact that the settlement is widely referred to as the "Dayton Accords."
Today, Mr. Chirac praised the Americans but dwelt more heavily on the sacrifices of French soldiers -- 56 of whom died as peacekeepers in Bosnia -- and on the work of Alain Juppe, the Prime Minister, whose ideas, he said, laid the basis for the success in Dayton.
The French President also tried to make a historical point through the exploitation of protocol. He placed Mr. Holbrooke in the fourth row, an anoymous figure toward the back of the gilded room. Such a figure, the French were saying, could not have been the central figure in the successful push for peace.

Hospital Care Bill Is Stalled

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A bill backed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman that would have financed hospital care for indigent patients was stalled yesterday in the Assembly Budget Committee when Democrats opposed raising cigarette taxes by 25 cents. Republican committee members had enough votes to pass the bill, but they wanted to share responsibility for a tax increase, said Assemblyman Walter Kavanaugh, a Republican of Somerville, who heads the panel. 
 The Legislature has until Dec. 31 to find a way to pay for charity care, which is now financed by diverting money collected through the unemployment insurance fund.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Germans Reduce Both Key Interest Rates

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Germany's central bank cut its main lending rates to their lowest levels in more than seven years today, taking a step that could help sputtering European economies and make it easier for the Federal Reserve to ease credit in the United States.
The Bundesbank said it lowered the discount rate and the Lombard rate half a percentage point each because growth in the German money supply had fallen far below the bank's target, there was no danger of rekindled inflation, and the mark was strong. 
 Bank officials denied that the rate reduction was directly aimed at stimulating the German economy. But by lowering the cost of borrowing, economists said, the bank would prevent the economy from stagnating in 1996 and keep the country's troublesome unemployment from rising faster.
At the same time, the economists said, the impact of the central bank's action would be felt across Europe. Because Germany's economy is the biggest in Europe, the Bundesbank essentially sets monetary policy for all of Europe.
"You have inflation under control in Germany; you have a struggling business, a weak labor market," said Holger Fahrinkrug, an economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland here. "So why not cut rates?"
The Bundesbank reduced its discount rate to 3 percent from 3.5 percent and the other key index, the Lombard rate, to 5 percent from 5.5 percent. The discount rate, which is charged on loans the central bank makes to commercial banks to meet their liquidity needs, sets a floor under German money market rates. The Lombard rate is charged on emergency loans made to banks and acts as a ceiling.
The central bank also cut the securities-repurchase rate, a money market rate at which it does most of its lending to commercial banks, to 3.75 percent from 3.98 percent. In the last few months, it has been pushing down the repurchase rate gradually.
Announcing the rate cuts, the bank raised its target for growth in the broad measure of the German money supply to a range of 3 percent to 7 percent next year, from the current range of 3 percent to 6 percent.
After the German rate reduction, the central banks of Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, Austria and Ireland lowered their interest rates. The Bank of Switzerland cut interest rates today before the Bundesbank acted, and Britain trimmed its official lending rate on Wednesday.
Today was the third time this year the Germans reduced their key interest rates. In March and August, they lowered rates one-half a percentage point.
In taking such action, the bank hopes to make borrowing by businesses and consumers less costly, stimulating economic activity. Because lower interest rates make the mark less attractive, the Bundesbank is also hoping to weaken the strong currency, which has made German exports expensive in terms of other currencies.
However, the dollar fell against the mark after the rate cut was announced yesterday. The Bundesbank's action had been widely expected, so currency levels already reflected lower German rates. Traders also said they thought that today's action would be the Bundesbank's last cut for some time.
Besides Germany, one of the immediate beneficiaries of the rate cut is likely to be France.
Lower German interest rates will allow the French central bank to lower its own rates at a critical time. France has endured more than three weeks of strikes by public employees over planned tax increases and cuts in social spending to reduce the nation's deficits. Lower interest rates will make it easier for President Jacques Chirac's officials to meet budget goals, reduce unemployment and generate tax revenue.
The cut also comes at a propitious time for Europe more broadly. The national leaders of the 15 European Union countries are to meet in Madrid on Friday and Saturday at their semiannual conference. At the top of the agenda will be how quickly they can move toward creating a single currency in Europe, in particular whether France and other nations will be able to reduce their budget deficits enough to be included in the first round of monetary union.
Lower rates will presumably reassure them that the Bundesbank is not about to work against their efforts and that there may be a chance of meeting the Jan. 1, 1999, deadline.
However, Hans Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank's president, insisted today that the rate cut had nothing to do with the Madrid meeting or with France's problems. "We decide when we think it's correct," he said at a news conference. "The E.U. summit had no influence. We don't base our decisions on the reaction in any country."
In three previous meetings, Mr. Tietmeyer said, bank policy makers had discussed whether to cut rates and had decided to hold off until they were able to readjust the target for money-supply growth at the same time. He emphasized the Bundesbank's independence, saying there had been no formal agreement with other countries' central banks about when it lowered rates. Mr. Tietmeyer added, though, that Bundesbank officials were in "constant contact" with those institutions.
While the German central bank had a reputation in the early 1990's of being insensitive to the economic problems of neighboring European countries, under Mr. Tietmeyer it has shown more of a sense that it is part of a greater Europe.
Still, Germany's guiding concern is its own lagging economy. While the year began with great hopes of growth above 3 percent, output is now rising at an annual rate of only 1.5 percent.
Economists expect similar growth through much of 1996, and some predict that the economy will enter a mild recession by the end of the year. With the mark strong, German businesses have entered an oddly grim period in which measures of pessimism are near record highs and unemployment is rising.
Mr. Tietmeyer denied that there was any prospect of a recession. "Various indicators point to the fact that a recession is not threatening," he said. "We expect the continuation of economic growth. This rate cut should contribute somewhat."
While economists said the Bundesbank's rate cuts would not figure directly in any decision by the Federal Reserve, the American central bank, to lower rates, it underscored a general agreement among central bankers that inflation was under control and that the primary threat was too little growth, not too rapid growth. The Fed's rate-setting committee will consider reductions at a meeting starting on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rate Outlook Keeps Bond Prices Steady

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Bond prices were steady yesterday as economic reports failed to raise expectations that the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates next week or early next year.
The Treasury's 30-year bond was little changed, as its yield edged up to 6.08 percent, from 6.07 percent Wednesday. 
 Bond prices initially rose after the Government said consumer prices were unchanged last month for the first time in almost five years. But they pulled back after other reports reflected enough economic growth to raise doubts over whether the Fed would take action at its policy-setting meeting next week.
"There's really no reason to shift one direction or the other until we see what happens," said Jan Faller, who helps manage $4 billion in bonds at Panagora Asset Management in Boston.
Optimism about a possible interest rate cut fostered a bond market rally that drove Treasury yields to a two-year low of 6.02 percent by Dec. 4 and handed bond investors the best returns in a decade.
"If we don't get a rate cut now, you can't continue to have this kind of market," said Tom Seay, who manages $500 million of bonds at the Lexington Management Corporation in Saddle Brook, N.J.
The Federal Reserve is to hold its last policy meeting of the year on Tuesday and its following meeting on Jan. 30 and 31. Members of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy arm, have not cut interest rates since July, when they lowered the target for overnight loans between banks a quarter percentage point, to 5.75 percent.
Expectations that the Fed will cut rates were bolstered by the Bundesbank's decision yesterday to lower German bank rates and Wednesday's rate cut in Britain. "You have people thinking the Fed is the next one to fall into place, and that global interest rates are heading down," said Joseph LaVorgna, a money market economist at Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York.
Moreover, he said, inflation is restrained enough to keep it from becoming an immediate issue at Tuesday's Fed meeting. "If you wanted to use the C.P.I. to make your case against cutting rates, you can't do that now," Mr. LaVorgna said.
But other analysts said the Fed could be dissuaded from cutting rates by a Labor Department report that claims for unemployment benefits tumbled 37,000 last week, more than the 6,000 drop anticipated and the biggest decline in almost five months.
"In light of this resurgence in the labor market, it will be very difficult" for the Fed to cut interest rates, said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus Ohio.
In another sign of brisk economic growth, the Fed reported that output at factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November, more than the steady reading economists expected. Production declined three-tenths of 1 percent in October.
"The economy isn't rolling over, so there's no momentum to drive the bond's yield through 6 percent," Mr. Seay of Lexington said.
And Kevin McClintock, head of taxable fixed-income investments at the Dreyfus Corporation, said the inability of bond yields to drop below 6 percent, even with yesterday's good news on inflation, suggested that "we're close to the end of the bond market rally."

SECTION: Section D; Page 5; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Profit Taking After German Interest-Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday in what was regarded as a round of profit taking, after the German central bank reduced its key interest rates, a move many traders had anticipated.
The action by the Bundesbank would typically give the dollar a lift, since lower rates often hurt a currency by making investments denominated in it less attractive. 
 But the opposite happened yesterday because traders had already assuming a German rate cut by early next year at the latest. And the prospect that the Federal Reserve might cut rates in the United States next week left little incentive to buy dollars, analysts said.
"The interest-rate differential for the dollar has gotten as good as it will get in the near term, and so it fell," said Richard Koss of MFR Inc., a money-management and consulting firm.
The dollar was last quoted in New York late yesterday at 1.4377 German marks, down from 1.45 marks on Wednesday. The dollar also slid to 101.50 Japanese yen from 101.68 yen. The declines were exaggerated by low trading volume.
In other currency dealing, the British pound rose to $1.5433, from $1.5327 on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.1633 Swiss francs from 1.1751 francs and to 4.9519 French francs from 5.0061 francs.
The Germans reduced their discount rate, which sets a floor under their money market rates, by half a percentage point, to 3 percent, the lowest level since July 1988. The Lombard rate, its ceiling for money-market rates, was also cut half a point, to 5 percent.
In Washington, a Government report that American consumer prices were unchanged in November for the first time since March 1991 also encouraged speculation that the Federal Reserve would cut rates when its policy-setting panel meets on Tuesday. With numerous signs that economic growth is flagging in the United States, the absence of a significant risk that inflation might accelerate could persuade the Fed to act, analysts said.
While that would narrow the interest-rate difference with Germany, the overall economic outlook for the United States -- steady, if slow growth with low inflation -- could make the dollar more attractive.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
Banner Year for Hotels
This holiday season in New York, hotel rooms are as hard to come by as cabs in the rain. Given a bolstered economy, a weak dollar overseas, cheap air fares and an event-filled fall season, the entire city was effectively sold out the first two weekends in December. [Page A1.]
 

Man Arrested in Subway Fire
An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested in last month's fatal attack on a subway token clerk in which the killers set fire to his booth after spraying it with a flammable liquid. As many as four others are still being sought in the attack. The man told the police that robbery was the sole purpose and that he knew nothing about a similar incident in the movie "Money Train," officials said last night. [B1.]
 
A Death and a Diary
A grand jury indicted George Delury of Manhattan on manslaughter charges for helping his chronically ill wife commit suicide last summer. The charge itself was unusual, but still more remarkable was the release of Mr. Delury's diary, a three-month chronicle of his agonizing deliberations on how to deal with the partner who had become the focus and burden of his existence. [B1.]
 
Voice of Vendors' Leader
Morris Powell, a vendor of pies and oils on 125th Street in Harlem, has long cried out to be heard. In language that veers between reason and polemic, he argues the need for Harlem's black community to embrace its own and support black-owned businesses. Now his words are being listened to, closely, by investigators of the fatal arson attack on Freddy's clothing store. [B1.]
The emergency water supply to the sprinkler system had been disconnected before the store was set afire, officials said. [B6.]
The Jewish Action Alliance has emerged at the forefront of the controversy swirling around the fire in Harlem. [B6].
 
City Cloaked in Indifference?
The coat in the basement no longer fit. These things happen. So Kenneth Piech left it with New York Cares, at its dropoff point in Penn Station, to be given to the homeless and others in need. By New Year's, the agency hopes to hand out 75,000 of them. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Repeated Hospital Stays
The homeless man charged with stabbing a child with a hypodermic needle spent time at two psychiatric institutions after escaping from a third hospital upstate, the Manhattan District Attorney said. [B3.]
 
The Mayor Takes a Thrashing
It happens these days at every town meeting and on every radio show: Mayor Giuliani gives his explanation of how mayors and Council members and commissioners have not had a raise in eight years, but the crowds have heard it all before and are not buying it. [B3.]
 
The Most Eligible Highchair
Much of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis's personal property, including the desk on which a nuclear test-ban treaty was signed in 1963, a 40-carat diamond ring she received from Aristotle Onassis and John F. Kennedy Jr.'s highchair, is to be auctioned at Sotheby's beginning April 23. [C3.]
 
REGION
 
Surprising Superintendent
Lottie L. Taylor, a respected educational consultant, was at the center of a bitter dispute between the Roosevelt Board of Education and the state panel overseeing the district's recovery -- and then she emerged as Roosevelt's interim superintendent. [B5.]
 
Authority to Keep Airport
The Port Authority decided not to turn Newark International Airport over to a management company, saying none had experience in running such a large airport. [B5.]
 
A Slog for Commuters
Even though only an inch or two of snow fell in most parts of the metropolitan area, turning to rain in many places by early afternoon, commuters faced a slog. [B5.]
 
Insanity Defense Rejected
A former probation officer, Ray J. Macaro Jr., 52, accused of faking insanity for almost seven years, was convicted of killing his father and two elderly aunts in their Westchester County home. [B5.]
 
Pataki Proposing Job Cuts
Governor Pataki's new budget is to propose reducing the state workforce by 7,400 employees, mainly through buyouts and early retirement programs, which his aides say may save at least $225 million. [B4.]
 
An Offer They Didn't Refuse
What if a company made a buyout offer to its employees and everybody took it? That is nearly what happened at the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is in a hurry to trim its work force before a merger early next year. [D1.]

HEADLINE: A Gambling Boom Pits a Church Against Biloxi

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: BILOXI, Miss.

 BODY:
Thirty-two years ago, Back Bay Mission waded into controversy when its staff tried to help integrate this resort city's whites-only beaches. Vandals broke the mission's windows, someone burned a cross outside, and members deserted its church, which soon closed.
The mission itself, a church-affiliated provider of social services, survived, but controversy has found it again. This time, in a sign of how much life on Mississippi's Gulf Coast has changed since the state legalized dockside gambling in 1990, the issue is not race but real estate, and gaming's importance to this city. 
 Specifically, in a local economy that has suddenly been thrust into high gear by the legalization of casino gambling, what fair price should the mission receive in exchange for surrendering its property to a big new casino, scheduled to open next summer, and to a municipal government eager to see that casino thrive?
So broke five years ago that it could not afford new tires for its police force, Biloxi, a melange of graceful beachfront homes and tourist-trapping T-shirt shops, now boasts eight casinos, built atop immense barges moored to the shore. Together they paid local taxes of about $11.5 million in the last fiscal year, nearly a fifth of the city's budget. These days Biloxi is flush enough to buy 82 new police cruisers.
A mile north of the beaches, the mission's modest compound sits well away from most of the action. Founded in the 1920's to give medical care to poor families who worked in seafood processing factories, the mission, affiliated with the 1.5-million-member United Church of Christ, no longer holds religious services and does not house the homeless. Instead, it is a charitable incubator that creates and nurtures nonprofit social service centers: a health clinic, a shelter for battered women and a counseling center for people with H.I.V.
But what the mission is now best known for is its location, on two acres of land next to a bayside tract owned by Imperial Palace of Las Vegas, which is erecting a $120 million casino complex including a 29-story hotel that will be the tallest building on the Gulf Coast between Tampa, Fla., and New Orleans.
The battle of Back Bay Mission began when the casino tried to buy about 80 percent of the mission's acreage, and the city, wanting to widen the road into the casino's parking lot, exercised its power of eminent domain by claiming the rest.
The mission resisted. The bottom line was not so much morals as money: the mission, citing the rise in local land values that gambling had brought, said the offers -- $1.2 million by the casino, under $500,000 by the city -- were far too low.
Talks between the mission and the casino ultimately ended. But the city pursued its claim in a county court, and a jury earlier this year settled on a price of $514,000, little more than what the city had offered in the first place. Now bulldozers engaged in the road-widening project have moved in and demolished two of the mission's nine buildings, only four of which are to be left standing under the city's plans.
The mission remains defiant. While pursuing an appeal to the State Supreme Court, it says that regardless of the outcome it will hold on to its remaining property, which it values at some $3.2 million, and continue operations in the shadow of the casino.
"It's not going to be a pleasant place for them to be," said Britt R. Singletary, a local lawyer for Imperial Palace. "There's going to be 16,000 cars a day going by that place."
The mission's lawyer, Virgil Gillespie maintains that "the city has not gone about this in the right way" and that indeed "this mission has been abused."
"Of course they would sell if the price was right, if they could make themselves whole at another site," Mr. Gillespie said. "But the advent of the gaming industry has made it so that buying a piece of comparable property can't be done for a song today. They need more money to move."
But Mr. Singletary argues that the mission and other Biloxi landowners have "gone crazy as far as market values -- whatever people think they can extort from a casino."
The drama here is one of many played out around the country as a result of gambling's rolling from coast to coast during the last decade. Once banned by the Federal Government, lotteries are now offered by 37 states. Casinos, once limited to Nevada, have sprung up on city blocks, riverboats and Indian reservations in more than 20 other states. With gross revenue of $40 billion a year, gambling is being eyed hungrily by communities as an eminently taxable growth industry.
Here in Biloxi, officials jumped at the Imperial Palace project, which planners say will bring more than 2,000 jobs and about $4 million in annual tax revenue.
The man offering the city these riches is a colorful Las Vegas entrepreneur, Ralph Engelstad. A former North Dakota contractor, Mr. Engelstad built the Imperial Palace 20 years ago and turned it into a money machine that generates an annual cash flow of $50 million. Last year Forbes magazine listed him among the 400 wealthiest Americans.
Mr. Engelstad, whose collection of classic automobiles includes the 1938 Mercedes-Benz that was Hitler's parade car, acquired brief notoriety nearly seven years ago, when Nevada's Gaming Control Board determined that he had hurt that state's image by holding parties for his Las Vegas employees on Hitler's birthday in 1986 and 1988. At the time, Mr. Engelstad denied that he held Nazi sympathies and apologized for what he called "theme" parties intended to boost employee morale. But he agreed to pay $1.5 million in fines.
What no side in the Biloxi battle disputes is that gambling has changed the face of the city.
Casinos have rendered Biloxi a place of visual paradoxes, with a waterfront that juxtaposes upper-crust Southern graciousness with come-all Nevada-style glitz. Beauvoir, the neatly preserved estate of Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederacy, stands within sight of the flashing neon lights of the President Casino.
Gambling flourished here once before, but on a smaller scale and without legal sanction. Thirty years ago Biloxi served as a shady playground for New Orleans, the sort of place where a friendly bartender could guide eager day-trippers to slot machines and backroom card games. Federal investigations shut that down, with help from Hurricane Camille, which turned Biloxi's beachfront to matchsticks in 1969. Tourism took a nosedive and stayed down for 20 years.
Now, city officials say, the Gulf Coast is roaring back on a gambling boom, drawing tourists from Florida, Louisiana and Texas. Building permits are up, unemployment is down, and Mississippians who quit the coast during its long recession to make a living in Las Vegas are flocking home.
Among them is Bruce Nourse, a Gulf Coast native who is senior vice president for government affairs and compliance at Casino Magic, a 100,000-square-foot operation on the city's oceanfront.
"The City of Biloxi," he said, "has done a very good job of being a partner with this industry and understanding our needs and getting adequate infrastructure in place."
Mr. Nourse is a former investigator for the Nevada Gaming Control Board and also former executive director of Mississippi's gaming commission. In 1992, that commission issued a report predicting that legalized gambling would bring $100 million in capital investment to the state. Instead, Mr. Nourse said, casino companies have now built properties worth $2 billion, with more to come.
The resulting rise in land values has not escaped the notice of Back Bay Mission's president, the Rev. Paul E. Baumer of Columbus, Ohio, who earlier this fall wrote Mr. Engelstad's chief aide in Las Vegas to tell him that the mission property not already claimed by the city was worth $3.2 million, not the $1.2 million Imperial Palace was offering.
Talk of a sale ended there. But next to the mission, work on the casino goes on. A sign out front promises that 100 of Mr. Engelstad's classic cars will be on display.
In the meantime, the war between the mission and the city continues. The mission's appeal to the State Supreme Court maintains that the city's eminent-domain action violated a Federal law, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993, which provides that governmental interference with religious practice must demonstrate a "compelling interest."
The appeal also maintains that eminent domain was improperly exercised in this case because it was invoked on behalf of a private interest, the casino. Not so, said David Nichols, Biloxi's chief administrative officer. "The bottom line is a public safety issue," he said. "That's the only reason we're widening the road."
The dispute has left all sides frustrated.
For his part, Mr. Nichols said he had "lost sympathy" for the mission. "They're using us to facilitate their financial gain," he said, "and I'm tired of it."
The mission's executive director, the Rev. David E. Stephens, responded by saying: "Any private landowner would have been expected to get the best price. But somehow the church was seen as behaving in an unseemly way by trying to get the best price. It comes across as, 'You're trying to cheat this poor casino out of money.' "
Mr. Stephens said he would advise the mission's directors to keep it operating on what will remain of its property, essentially continuing its work in Imperial Palace's front yard.
Casino officials too feel frustrated, at their inability to reach accord with their neighbor. "There's a number out there that should be acceptable to both parties," Mr. Singletary said. "But I don't know that it exists."

HEADLINE: A Bountiful Season for New York City Hotels

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
The Samuelson family, visiting from Boston, had set aside an entire week to see friends in New York and go to the theater. But they were not able to get reservations for either of the weekends they planned to be in the city. So they have been splitting their time between the Marriott Marquis in Times Square on the weekdays and hotels in Stamford, Conn., on the weekends.
"It wasn't a big deal," said Robert Samuelson, a 25-year-old graphics designer who is in town with his parents, about the inconvenience. "We know people in Connecticut. I probably wouldn't do it again, though." 
 What the Samuelsons are experiencing is no different from what thousands of others are enduring this holiday season in New York, where hotel rooms are as hard to come by as cabs in the rain.
Indeed, New York hotels are finishing what looks to be a banner year. And with a confluence of factors in its favor -- a bolstered economy, a weak dollar overseas, a rash of cheap air fares and an event-filled fall season -- the holiday season, hoteliers say, may be the best in more than a decade.
Since the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau began keeping track of occupancy records in 1988, "there's never been a holiday season like this in New York," said Steven Morello, president of the bureau.
The entire city was effectively sold out for the first two weekends in December, according to the bureau. With holiday shopping, this is traditionally a strong time anyway. But the last two weeks of the month -- ordinarily a slow period because business travel declines during the holidays and many leisure travelers want to be at home -- are looking rosier than usual: reservations indicate that the drop-off that occurs at this time will be less precipitous this year.
A peak season telephone line established in October by the visitors' bureau to help travelers find rooms has been taking more than 800 calls a day.
"We're busier in our traditional downtimes," said Paul O'Neil, the managing director at both of Manhattan's Sheraton hotels. "When typically in the week before Christmas it would be very, very slow, now we're just going to be slow. And between Christmas and New Year's, when it would traditionally be extremely slow -- historically, we run 50 percent occupancy -- we're going to be busy, closer to 75 percent."
A year ago, the occupancy rate for the entire month of December, 76.2 percent, was the highest December figure in the 1990's, and this year, reservations are running high enough that hoteliers say they expect that figure to be surpassed.
While firm statistics for November and early December have yet to be compiled, analysts say that so far this month more than 90 percent of the city's 58,000 or so hotel rooms have been slept in -- or at least paid for. And it is likely that November will top last year's record 82.2 percent. In October, the city's 231 hotels reported an occupancy rate of 91.9 percent, the second-highest monthly figure ever.
This season, hotels have been helped partly by the calendar; both Christmas and New Year's Day fall on Mondays, giving people the chance for long holiday weekends. But it's also true, hoteliers say, that visitors are coming later than they might have because they were not able to find a place to stay earlier, with the city crowded because of events like the papal visit, the New York City Marathon and the 50th anniversary of the United Nations.
Continuing the turnaround that began in 1994, when the hotel occupancy rate for the year leaped nearly sixpercentage points over the previous year, hotels in New York are predicting that the final figure for 1995 will increase another percentage point, to 76.5 percent, even as the average room rate rose $6, to $150 per night.
"It's the best occupancy New York hotels have had in 15 years," said Robert Diener, president of Hotel Reservations Network, a reservations service that books more than 150,000 room nights in the city annually.
Jonathan M. Tisch, president and chief executive of the Loews hotel chain, which has four hotels in Manhattan, concurred.
"In the early 90's, we hoteliers were looking at each other wondering if we should check into each other's hotels," he said, adding that this year, rates increased from 5 to 12 percent at all his New York properties -- the Loews New York, the Regency Hotel, the Howard Johnson and Days Inn -- and all have become more profitable.
Other businesses, of course, have also benefited from the influx of visitors. According to the entertainment trade weekly Variety, attendance at Broadway theaters the week after Thanksgiving (the most recent figure available) was up 5 1/2 percent over the same week a year ago. At the Rainbow Room, the restaurant and nightclub high above Rockefeller Center, business since Thanksgiving is up 27 percent.
The reasons for the overall upturn are manifold, industry experts say. For one, the weakness of the dollar abroad has lured foreign tourists. For another, the message that both the tourist industry and the Giuliani administration have been striving to get out -- that crime is down and the city is one of the nation's safest -- is indeed getting out.
There was also a proliferation of low airline fares to New York this year, spurred by the emergence of smaller carriers like Carnival Air, Kiwi Air and Tower Air. And last, but probably not least, is the reduction of six percentage points in state and city taxes on hotel rooms that took effect last year, which has helped the city sell itself as a destination to businesses, which tend to negotiate bulk rates at hotels for their employees and convention attendees.
Julie Marker, a Baltimore travel agent who could not find a hotel room for two top clients, can testify to the surge.
"We needed four nights, Dec. 5 through Dec. 9," Ms. Marker said, "and a week prior, we tried easily 60 hotels, and then beginning on Monday I'd call at least 25 every morning. I managed to find my clients rooms for two nights. But then they were stuck out in East Rutherford, N.J., for the last two."
In the end, Ms. Marker landed two rooms for the last two nights at the New York Helmsley, for $320 a night per room. "These people were willing to pay whatever, for a suite, whatever," she said, "and when the sky's the limit, well, I've been in the business six years and I've never had that problem."
One afternoon this week at the Marriott Marquis, there were rooms available for the night, but desk clerks did not expect that to last: more than 500 reservations had not yet checked in.
Irene Diekmann and Berndt Fuhrmann, first-time visitors to New York from Germany, said they had made reservations in October and the Marquis was the last of the 20 or so hotels they tried.
"It was so terrible," said Ms. Diekmann, a college professor from Potsdam. "I asked them all, 'Why is it so hard?' and they said it was because this was shopping time in New York. I didn't understand, but now I do. Everyone is shopping."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

GERMAN CUT OF 2 KEY RATES COULD AID AN EASING BY FED
The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, cut its main lending rates to their lowest levels in more than seven years, a step that could help sputtering European economies and make it easier for the Federal Reserve to lower rates in the United States. 
 The Bundesbank cut the discount rate and the Lombard rate half a percentage point each, saying that growth in the German money supply had fallen far below the bank's target, that there was no danger of rekindled inflation, and that the mark was strong.
 
The Bundesbank move would typically have given the dollar a lift, but traders had already assumed a German rate cut. In New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.4377 marks.
 
NBC FINDS AN ALL-NEWS ALLY IN A DEAL WITH MICROSOFT
Microsoft paid NBC $220 million for a half-stake in a new cable channel intended to challenge the Cable News Network and in an interactive on-line news service. But plenty of questions remain, ranging from whether the cable industry will embrace a direct competitor to CNN to whether there is enough audience to support two all-news networks.
 
John F. Welch Jr., chairman of General Electric, is enthusiastic about ventures with Microsoft.
 
A HEALTH-CARE MERGER UNRAVELS
Wellpoint Health Networks and Health Systems International said they were discussing "mutual termination" of their agreement to create a giant managed health care company with $6 billion of annual revenue.
 
HEALTH PLAN SETTLES AIDS SUIT
In a groundbreaking settlement of discrimination charges against a health plan that limited medical payments to people with AIDS, a construction workers' union welfare fund in New York agreed to pay a total of about $1 million for their medical bills and emotional distress.
 
PREPARING FOR BUDGET SHOWDOWN
White House officials and Republican leaders in Congress met separately to plan strategy and develop opening bids for budget negotiations that are to begin today.
 
EX-DAIMLER OFFICIAL FOUND DEAD
Daimler-Benz A.G. said that Gerhard Liener, its former No. 2 official who was dismissed earlier this year, was found dead in his apartment, apparently in a suicide. Mr. Liener, who was at one time one of Europe's most influential executives, was 63.
 
STOCKS RETREAT; DOW FALLS 34.32
Stocks fell sharply, led by technology shares, as investors ignored bullish economic news and aggressively sold their holdings to book year-end profits. The Dow industrials fell 34.32 points and the Nasdaq, 18.35..
 
SOMETHING LOST IN TRANSLATION?
Nokia, the Finnish maker of cellular phones, has got a lot of explaining to do to Wall Street. Investors are fuming because in recent statements, Nokia executives had been saying that business in key market segments was healthy. Yesterday, though, Nokia informed investors that it was restructuring a consumer electronics business it called a likely money-loser, and that growth in its mobile phone business was "slightly weaker than predicted." Nokia's American depository receipts dropped $10.75, to $35.50. Market Place.
 
FORMER AGENCY HEAD RE-EMERGES
Alvin Chereskin ended his retirement. The linchpin of the Estee Lauder account at AC& R Advertising, where he served as chairman, chief executive and executive creative director, is opening an advertising and marketing consulting company in New York. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.
 
CHINA ENTRY TO TRADE GROUP OPPOSED
Clinton Administration officials said it would be politically impossible to support China's demand for admission to the World Trade Organization while it continued to repress dissent and ignore a key trade accord with the United States.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Flat In November

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Consumer prices remained unchanged in November, the first time since the end of the 1990-91 recession that American households suffered no inflation, Labor Department figures showed today.
The report, in contrast to one earlier this week that showed producer prices surging last month, helped restore the confidence of a number of economists that the Federal Reserve would relax monetary policy next Tuesday at its final meeting of the year. 
 Several recent economic measures have shown that the economy is slowing markedly, with the Commerce Department adding fresh evidence today with a report that business inventories climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest rise since April, to the highest point relative to sales in two years.
"With the really good inflation news and the decelerating economy, the Fed has plenty of latitude to ease," said Veronika C. White, an economist at First Fidelity Bancorporation in Philadelphia. She predicted the Fed would cut it target rate for overnight bank loans by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, and repeat this action at the following meeting in January.
Two additional sets of figures published today were a bit stronger than expected, however, and a sizable group of analysts remains unconvinced the Fed will act, especially before Congress and the Clinton Administration reach a budget agreement.
"It's a close call," said Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro in New York. "But I don't think the Fed will want to provide stimulus with the economy growing at a moderate rate" and unemployment only about 5.5 percent.
Industrial production, the Fed reported today, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November following an October downturn, while first-time claims for unemployment insurance dropped by 37,000 last week.
Although the consumer prices report was surprisingly positive, today's economic news had little lasting impact on the bond and stock markets, since many investors are now waiting to see what the Fed will actually do. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond edged up slightly, to 6.08 percent from 6.07 percent. [Page D13.] And stocks fell in late trading, pulled down by a selloff in technology issues. [Page D6.]
Although the price of items in their unvarying market basket did not rise last month, many consumers are increasingly pinched. The Labor Department calculated today that real average earnings fell four-tenths of 1 percent last month on a combination of shorter weekly hours and a slight decline in hourly earnings.
Indeed, Lawrence B. Lindsey, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed uneasiness about consumer debt today at a forum of the House of Representatives. While praising what he called the democratization of consumer credit, Mr. Lindsey pointed to households, many of them newer recipients of credit cards, that may be overextended.
Among the five reasons he cited for being "troubled" were depressed income growth, a smaller share of spending on goods that enhance wealth, high numbers of distressed consumers at a time of general prosperity and a mismatch between people making big profits in the stock and bond markets and the people who are most indebted.
Two of the major factors that kept the Consumer Price Index from rising for the first time since March 1991 were a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in the price of energy and a 4 percent skid in airline fares.
Air fares jumped 20.4 percent in the first half of the year but have now reversed course and fallen 7.6 percent since June.
New cars, with 1996 models picked up by the statistical system over a three-month period, rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent. By contrast, cars and trucks contributed heavily to the jump of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index published Tuesday.
Food prices were lower by one-tenth of 1 percent after rising an average of four-tenths of 1 percent in September and October.
The core Consumer Price Index, which excludes the erratic energy and food components, edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, the best performance of the year, the report also showed.
New York City's higher subway fare helped push overall prices in the metropolitan area up one-tenth of 1 percent last month to a level that was 2.8 percent higher than in November 1994, slightly higher than the 2.6 percent 12-month increase posted by the nation at large.
The Commerce Department report of higher inventories for October, combined with an upward revision for September and a four-tenths of 1 percent decline in business sales, lifted the inventory-sales ratio to 1.43 months, matching July's two-year peak.
"The accumulation in inventories is involuntary," commented Debbie Johnson of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C. J. Lawrence. "Look for production cuts up ahead."
The Fed's report of a two-tenths of 1 percent rise in industrial output last month was buoyed by the response of utilities to the demands of unusually cold weather but held back by the strike at Boeing. Factory output moved up two-tenths of 1 percent, reversing October's decline of that size.
Industry operated at 83.1 percent of capacity last month, down one-tenth of a point for the month and two full points below the peaks of last December and January.
The drop in first-time jobless claims was to 341,000 from 378,000 in the week ended Dec. 2, with the four-week moving average down 7,250, to 366,000. While analysts could not point to particular quirks in this notoriously volatile series, they said they doubted that it reflected actual strengthening of the labor market.
The Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers, which now stands 53.6 percent above its 1982-84 average, showed services up two-tenths of 1 percent in November and running at a 2.9 percent annual rate for the latest three months compared with 3.1 percent for the three months ending with August.

HEADLINE: U.S. Again Tries a Trade Issue as a Carrot and Stick for Beijing

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
With pressure growing to respond to China's imprisonment of its best-known dissident, Clinton Administration officials said today that it would be politically impossible to support Beijing's demands for admission to the new World Trade Organization while it continues to repress dissent and to ignore a key trade accord with the United States.
In interviews today, a day after the one-day trial of Wei Jingsheng, who was sentenced to 14 years in prison for his advocacy of democracy, Administration officials continued to defend their policy of "constructive engagement" with China. They insisted that their decision not to link trade issues to an improved human rights record last year remains the best hope for influencing China's behavior over the long term, although that policy has come under renewed attack in Congress. 
 As a matter of practical politics, President Clinton's aides said, China's increasingly belligerent positions on human rights and trade issues are effectively linking the two subjects anyway.
With Congress threatening to revoke China's preferential trade status with the United States, officials said that the Administration is not likely to make the case that China should be given the ultimate economic reward: inclusion in the worldwide trade agreement that went into effect at the beginning of this year.
"It may be a moot issue, because China has still not met the commercial standards for admission," said one senior official, who insisted on anonymity. "But we are now sending them the message that while human rights is not explictly part of the negotiations, it is part of the atmosphere, and they are ignoring that at their peril."
The decision not to link human rights and trade was an emotional and hard-fought battle within the Administration in early 1994.
Those supporting the decision argued that stronger links between China and the West would ultimately encourage the democracy movement by bringing commerce, fax machines, computers and the Internet to the Chinese population -- forces the central Government would not be able to control.
But the results in the last 18 months have not been encouraging. More dissidents are imprisoned now than at any time since the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989. Inside and outside the Clington Administration, opponents of the policy are beginning to stir.
For Beijing, admission to the World Trade Organization has become a major goal. While Washington is only one voice in the decision, it is the most influential, and so far it has blackballed China's candidacy while expressing a willingness to negotiate.
Among other steps, it has insisted that China must open its markets dramatically and enforce existing agreements -- including a hard-fought accord with the United States to protect music, software and movies, among other goods, from piracy. China has periodically responded that the American stance was part of an effort to contain Beijing's growing economic power.
Until a few weeks ago, Administration officials were saying they were encouraged by China's efforts to change its ways. But in the last few weeks, that optimism has been reversed. Now Mr. Wei's sentencing has changed the politics of the trade issues.
"We feel we went out on a limb for the Chinese, and they sawed it off," a senior official who advises Mr. Clinton on economic issues said today. "They refuse to get the message."

HEADLINE: It's Time to Reinvent Freud

BYLINE: By Richard A. Shweder; Richard A. Shweder, professor of human development at the University of Chicago, is currently a fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences.

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
There is a panic inherent in the anticipation of professional extinction that is the dread of Freud's disciples these days.
The announcement by the Library of Congress that it would shelve an exhibition titled "Sigmund Freud: Conflict and Culture" coincided with the winter meeting of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis, prophetically titled "Is There a Place for Psychoanalysis in Contemporary Culture?" -- thereby confirming the fear of many psychoanalysts that the answer may be "no." 
 The library's half-hearted decision to put the great guru in cold storage left some analysts in a sweat, feeling defensive, unloved and full of self-doubt about their prospects in the intellectual and economic marketplace. The delay is probably less important than it seems. The authority of curators to be unchallenged arbiters of taste has evaporated over the past decade. In this age of "identity politics" and hotly contested points of view, the very idea of "public culture" has become an oxymoron.
And one does not need a degree in economics to figure out that if exhibitors cannot be highly selective, discerning and partial, then any display or narration about a controversial subject is probably going to be too expensive to mount. The library was just spineless and poor.
The declining mental health of our nation's psychoanalysts, however, is a real matter for concern. Is there a place for psychoanalysis in contemporary culture? What should we tell them to do about their dread?
For starters, let's not deny their reality. Freud has many intellectual enemies. And they are far more numerous and varied than the 42 critics (including Gloria Steinem and Oliver Sacks) who signed a petition urging the Library of Congress to shower the Viennese doctor with venom rather than just glory.
Here is the short version of the enemies list. Sociobiologists don't like Freud because they think family members have no sexual interest in one another. Cognitive scientists don't like Freud because they think the "unconscious mind" is a rapidly firing network of widely distributed neurons, with no mind of its own. Behavioral geneticists don't like Freud because they really think biology is destiny and that early childhood experience has very little to do with your life.
Postmodernists don't like Freud because they think that interpretation is merely free association, while Freud believed that by studying free association he might uncover the true meaning of a "text." Feminists don't like Freud because they think he discounted reports of sexual abuse, disparaged the female body and collaborated with his buddies against his female clients. They think Freud was a patriarch.
Even academic psychologists and philosophers of science don't like Freud. The academic psychologists think that the study of the mind has nothing to do with sex, religion, literature, mythology or the history of civilizations, while Freud, bless his heart, made those topics the core of his curriculum. And the philosophers of science come in two kinds: those who think Freud's tenets are untestable and hence unworthy of scientific consideration, and those who think his tenets are testable and have been shown to be false. So the rap on Freud is not very good.
The word is out in the medical world. It takes too long to "know thyself." Increments of personal insight are hard to measure or reimburse. Moreover, medical interns get nervous when they have to speak to their patients. They know all too little about the body and even less about a broken heart, or the history of civilization, which is why we need Prozac. Freud once wrote: "However philosophy may bridge the gap between physical and mental, it still exists for practical purposes, and our practice on each side of it must differ accordingly." Freud may have underestimated our practicality and overestimated our sense of purpose, but he was right to worry that the marriage of psychoanalysis to medicine would one day end in disaster.
He might even have been pleased to discover that in contemporary American culture the major interest in psychoanalysis is found in schools of theology and on Broadway. Psychoanalysis has a popular appeal, not because it is a form of medicine or alternative therapy but because it is a secular religion that tries to address the deeper meanings of life. This is a time for psychoanalysis to discover its true identity. It is time for a divorce from medicine. It is time for a remarriage with theologians.
Freud taught that to be happy one must maximize pleasure (the id), be moral (the superego) and survive (the ego). I am not worried about the survival of psychoanalysts. I think their fears of extinction are largely irrational. I just hope they have the guts to do the right thing.

HEADLINE: Plume of Hope Rises From Factory Ashes

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: METHUEN, Mass., Dec. 15

 BODY:
The wind-blown fire that destroyed much of the Malden Mills textile complex here on Monday night and put 1,400 people out of work barely two weeks before Christmas was a reminder that in some parts of America, a factory and its workers are still everything to each other.
In Methuen and in the surrounding blue-collar towns of the Merrimack Valley near the New Hampshire border, this has been a week of heartbreak and heroism, of hopes dashed and raised. And no one knows the ups and downs better than Jeffrey Marks, a 23-year-old machine operator from Derry, N.H., who works on the Malden Mills flocking line. 
 Last Sunday, Mr. Marks was looking ahead to a long work week with lots of overtime that he had asked for so he could earn extra money for Christmas presents. On Tuesday, after the fire, Mr. Marks, whose fiancee also works for Malden Mills, wondered how he would pay his rent, feed their 2-year-old daughter and make car payments.
On Thursday, he sat in the crowded gymnasium at Central Catholic High School in Lawrence, Mass., and cheered as the owner of Malden Mills, Aaron Feuerstein, promised to keep the paychecks coming for at least another month.
This morning, Mr. Feuerstein, stood before another crowd of several hundred employees and promised, as he has done countless times in recent days, that everything would be all right.
In the four days since the fire gutted three factory buildings and crippled Malden Mills, which makes one of the country's most popular fabrics for winter wear, Mr. Feuerstein has captivated the hearts and imaginations of his workers and much of Massachusetts with his enthusiastic resolve to rebuild and his pledge to continue paying salaries for as long as possible.
Hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations for those out of work have been pouring in from across the state. There have also been donations of Christmas presents for children, frozen turkeys and tickets to see the Nutcracker.
Gov. William F. Weld declared the destruction of Malden Mills a state emergency and the State Legislature passed an emergency waiver of the two-week waiting period normally required to receive unemployment benefits. And the Federal Department of Labor has prepared a $3.7 million aid package for career counseling, job retraining and other emergency assistance.
But all week long, Mr. Feuerstein has promised that Malden Mills will get back on its feet. And fast. His pledge has been the latest sign of his loyalty to Massachusetts and his workers. The workers know that the fire presented only the latest opportunity for Mr. Feuerstein to move his operations elsewhere.
Methuen, which was founded in 1726 and prospered as a mill town throughout the 1800's, began to fade in the early half of this century as mill owners seeking cheap labor headed south and then on to Asia. In fact, when Mr. Feuerstein moved his grandfather's sweater manufacturing business to Methuen 40 years ago, he took over an abandoned mill.
"When people saw the devastation on television, they were positive that the 70-year-old owner would collect whatever insurance he could and say 'bye-bye,' " Mr. Feuerstein told the crowd of mid-level managers and other nonunion employees this morning. "We don't operate that way. We are going to continue to operate with whatever strength that we can until we have again established Malden Mills as the leader in the industry."
The path to the top of the industry is one that Mr. Feuerstein has followed before. In 1981, after a major decline in the fake fur industry, Malden Mills filed for bankruptcy. The company was millions of dollars in debt. Hundreds of workers were laid off. But the company persevered. Its research and development team designed "polarfleece" and later Polartec, an advanced fabric that is used to make extremely warm but lightweight clothing. Today Polartec accounts for half of Malden Mills' $425 million in annual sales and Polartec items are sold by major clothiers like L. L. Bean and Patagonia.
On Monday night, as he watched flames devouring the business that his grandfather, Henry, started almost 90 years ago, Mr. Feuerstein said he had to remind himself again and again not to cry. "I told myself no tears, no crying," he said. "Crying isn't going to help myself." Instead, he said, he thought of Shakespeare's King Lear, who promised that his heart would "break into a hundred thousand flaws" before he wept. "I was telling myself I have to be creative," he said. "Maybe there's some way to get out of it."
No one had to remind him that shutting down the factory would mean putting entire families out of work. Like so many of his workers, Mr. Feuerstein has relatives in the business. His wife, Louise, heads an upholstery division. His sons, Daniel, 41, and Raphael, 39, and his son-in-law, David Greenberg, also work for Malden Mills.
Mr. Feuerstein's 37-year-old daughter, Joyce, has been visiting about a dozen workers who were injured in the fire and remain hospitalized. In all, 25 workers were injured in the blaze, which started with an explosion near the boiler room in a century-old factory building.
Teams of investigators are working to determine the cause of the explosion, including officials of the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, and the Massachusetts State Fire Marshals. The officials have not classified the fire as suspicious but are investigating to determine if Malden Mills followed all required safety rules.
Recent snowstorms have hampered the investigation. "Due to weather conditions and conditions at the fire scene, we have not yet been able to go in and examine all of the physical evidence," said Robert Fawcett, the factory's director of corporate security. He said investigators had interviewed more than 70 people and were waiting to interview some of those who were still in the hospital.
With 2,500 employees, Malden Mills is the largest employer in Methuen. And nearly everyone in town feels any changes that happen at the factory. Perrault's Diner, across the street from Malden Mills, used to be open 24 hours a day, said Francis Dumont, the manager of the diner. But he said that when Malden Mills opened a cafeteria in the 1960's, the diner had to cut back its operation.
The cafeteria burned down in the fire, so places like Perrault's and Motta's Broadway Pizza and Subs down the street, are doing more business now.
Mr. Feuerstein has said that Malden Mills will resume manufacturing Polartec by Jan. 2. Keeping the union employees on the payroll will cost about $1.5 million a week, he said. The decision to continue to pay the workers and to extend their health benefits for at least 90 days was met with surprise and appreciation.
"This my father told me as a little boy," Mr. Feuerstein said, quoting Hillel, the ancient rabbi. "In a situation which is devoid of morality, try to be a man and do something worthwhile."
Mr. Feuerstein, who grew up in Brookline, Mass., and still lives there, is an observant Jew. And this afternoon, as his staff continued to plan how to get the business moving again, he left to observe the Sabbath.
Outside the factory, Jim Sweet, a 48-year-old director of safety in the woven fabric division, was shouting to friends about a flatbed truck that had arrived with new equipment. "Did you see the two shears on the truck?" he asked. "They just brought in two P & W Shears. It's a joy to see the shears come in. We can say we're going to rebuild but when you see two shears coming in, that's reality. We are going to be all right."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Workers from the fire-ravaged Malden Mills applauding the owner, Aaron Feuerstein, who pledged yesterday to pay salaries for 30 days. (Associated Press); Aaron Feurstein arriving at a meeting in Lawrence, Mass., where he told his workers he would seek to soften hardships from a fire. (Associated Press)
