SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1174 words

HEADLINE: New Push for Budget Accord Dissolves in Finger-Pointing

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Stepped-up negotiations between the White House and Republicans to balance the budget by 2002 ended in acrimony only hours after they began yesterday, with each side angrily criticizing the other's proposal.
Within hours of the breakdown, efforts to work out a deal for a temporary spending bill to replace one that expired at midnight also fell apart, and various Government agencies prepared to shut down today for the second time in a month.[Page 12.] 
 Both sides said they hoped to return to the negotiating table and were willing to do so at any time over the weekend. But neither side said when that might occur, and each blamed the other for the impasse.
While the stakes are high, involving questions as broad as the role of Government in American life and as specific as whether wealthy investors will get tax cuts, both sides also have much to gain or lose politically. For purposes of next year's elections, Republicans need to show, at least on paper, a balanced budget by the year 2002. Democrats are determined to be seen by voters as protecting Medicare and Medicaid from destruction. [Page 12.]
Demonstrating that, both sides took to the microphones to unleash a war of words yesterday. On the floor of the Senate, there was angry partisan sniping, with several Republicans coming close to calling Mr. Clinton a liar and Democrats leaping to their feet to defend him.
In a late-afternoon appearance in the White House press room, President Clinton blamed the Republicans for breaking off the talks.
"They wanted us to agree to deep cuts in Medicare and Medicaid just as a condition to talk," Mr. Clinton said. "Once again, they are threatening to shut the Government down if I do not accept their deep cuts.
"The idea that we should abandon the commitment we made and they agreed to as a condition of talking is wrong and we will not do that."
The President's comments brought an irritated response from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican majority leader.
"I don't think he's telling the American people the truth," Mr. Dole said on the Senate floor, "and if he thinks he is engaged in serious budget negotiations, he ought to look at the budget."
Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, rose to challenge Mr. Dole's account of the negotiations.
"His version of the truth and mine could not be more different," he said. "My version is that it was the Republicans this afternoon who got up and walked out of the room."
The Republicans said at mid-afternoon that they would step up separate budget negotiations over the weekend with conservative Democrats in the House and in the Senate. Those informal talks have been under way for a week.
As for a new temporary spending bill, called a continuing resolution, to keep the Government operating, the Republicans set a condition. They said it would come only when Mr. Clinton called to say that he was ready to offer a budget that would be brought into balance in seven years, based on a Congressional Budget Office analysis of the country's financial picture.
"The minute we get that call, we will voice-vote a C.R.," Representative John R. Kasich, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, said yesterday. "After midnight tonight, it is up to the President to come to us in good faith."
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff and the leader of the Democrats' side in the budget negotiations, said that the White House offered yesterday to reduce spending by $125 billion, compared with the budget it submitted last week. He said the Democrats' offer also included a guarantee of a five-year tax cut in the seven-year plan, with tax cuts in the two final years tied to the performance of the economy.
"They said essentially that the price for continuing these negotiations would be the Administration putting cuts in Medicare and Medicaid on the table," Mr. Panetta said, "and that is not a price we are willing to pay."
But the Republicans said the White House budget was bogus. A principal negotiator -- Senator Pete V. Domenici, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee -- said the offer the Democrats brought to the table included a $75 billion deficit in 2002, the seventh year of the plan.
"We are right back where we started," Mr. Domenici said at a news conference. "They just want to use optimistic and rosy assumptions and to cook the books. We cannot find anything they did serious."
The biggest changes proposed by the Republicans yesterday involved Medicaid and Medicare.
New calculations released this week by the Congressional Budget Office showed that the budget measure approved by the Republicans and vetoed by the President last month would have saved $226 billion in Medicare costs and $133 billion in Medicaid costs over the next seven years. Earlier calculations had put the savings higher, at $270 billion for Medicare and $164 billion for Medicaid.
The proposal that the Republicans offered yesterday, which they distributed, reduced their demand for savings in Medicare to $200 billion and in Medicaid to $119 billion. It called for cutting $5 billion of the proposed $245 billion tax cut.
The Congressional Budget Office also identified $135 billion in additional savings over the next seven years. Republicans offered to allocate $25 billion of that money for additional spending for education, environmental programs, veterans' health care and job training.
"We have responded to their concerns only to find out that they showed up and didn't keep up their end of the bargain," Mr. Kasich said.
Shortly after Mr. Dole delivered his assessment of the negotiations, about a dozen stern-faced Republicans huddled around Mr. Domenici on the Senate floor as he briefed them on the breakdown in the talks.
As the budget negotiations were getting started, Republicans were pressuring the President to sign one of the more politically contentious spending bills for the 1996 budget year, the $12.2 billion appropriation for the Interior Department. The Republicans said yesterday that they would send the Interior bill to the White House today.
Mr. Clinton has threatened to veto the bill, along with the $80.6 billion spending bill for the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which Congress sent to him last night. Congress sent a third spending bill, for the Departments of Commerce, Justice and State and for the Judiciary, to the White House on Thursday. The Administration objects to the Interior bill because it includes cuts in environmental and Indian programs.
President Clinton has signed 6 of the 13 spending bills for 1996, covering the Departments of Agriculture, Transportation and Energy, the Treasury, Congress and military construction. The national security and defense appropriations bill became law on Dec. 1 without the President's signature.
Based on the seven spending bills that have become law and the jobs that are deemed essential, about 300,000 Federal workers are expected to be affected by the shutdown.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Off Nearly 5% On Signs of Growing Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper futures prices plunged nearly 5 percent in New York yesterday on signs that near-term supply problems were easing.
The London Metal Exchange reported a sharp increase in warehouse inventories of copper, particularly in the United States, prompting speculation that the bull market in copper was over. 
 "This basically gave people the impression that maybe things aren't as tight as they had been, that there is metal starting to move to the market in greater quantities at a time that demand is maybe starting to pull back," said Stephen Platt, an analyst at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
On other commodity markets, crude oil prices surged. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities fell 0.86 point, to 244.95.
Copper for December delivery plunged 6.75 cents, to $1.3315 a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, a drop of 4.8 percent. January deliveries sank 4.35 cents, to $1.301 a pound.
Prices tumbled after the London Metal Exchange, the world's largest copper futures market, reported that copper in exchange-monitored warehouses had surged 13,100 metric tons in a week. The exchange reported sharp increases of 5,100 metric tons in its warehouses in Long Beach, Calif., and 2,100 metric tons in St. Louis.
The gain reversed a long-running decline in the exchange's stocks and eased concerns about availability. Copper traded at a six-year high of $1.461 a pound in July.
Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst at Prudential Securities, said the sharp rise in warehouse stocks suggested copper prices had risen high enough to prompt selling by users with excess supplies on hand.
Elsewhere, oil prices rose after OPEC estimated its output fell in November to 24.81 million barrels a day from 25.17 million in October. January deliveries of light sweet crude oil leaped 40 cents a barrel, to $19.51, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading, Aided by Europe Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against other leading currencies yesterday, benefiting from interest rate cuts in Europe, where more signs of an economic slowdown are emerging.
Trading was relatively light, as many traders were waiting for a resolution of the budget dispute between the White House and Congress. 
 "I believe the markets have put on their little Santa hats and focused elsewhere," said Kevin Lawrie, vice president and manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4432 German marks, up from 1.4377 late Thursday. The dollar was also changing hands in New York at 102.00 yen, up from 101.50.
The British pound, meanwhile, fell to $1.5360, from $1.5433.
The dollar strengthened despite news that the European Union had settled a contentious part of its plan for a unified currency by selecting a name: the euro. The decision might have bolstered European currencies, given the previous squabbling this fall about whether all countries would meet strict monetary criteria to form a monetary union.
But France's general strike makes that country a "wild card, creating havoc for unity," said Charles Spence, director of treasury sales at Standard Chartered Bank.
"When you have people rioting to save their social programs, that doesn't bode well for France meeting the stringent qualifications," Mr. Spence said. "Without France, you might as well call the E.U. 'Germany.' "
Europe's economic weakness was further evident yesterday when two more countries, France and Portugal, cut important interest rates, following two days of rate cuts by six other countries, including Britain and Germany. Central banks cut their rates to spur lending and growth.
But lower interest rates in those countries make investments denominated in their currencies less attractive to international investors. Moreover, the weakness in Europe's economies makes the currencies of stronger economies like the United States' more attractive to many investors.
"As you go around the globe, you see the U.S. still performing O.K. from an economic standpoint," Mr. Spence said. "The U.S. looks like one of the safer places to invest right now."

HEADLINE: Bonds Little Changed in Budget Uncertainty

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended a quiet trading session with little change yesterday, as the breakdown in the Federal budget negotiations added to the bond market's uncertainty over whether the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates next week.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond slipped 5/32 of a point, or $1.56 for $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposition direction, rose to 6.09 percent from 6.08 percent late Thursday. 
 Budget talks between the Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans broke off abruptly yesterday, setting the stage for another partial Government shutdown.
The on-again, off-again negotiations have unnerved buyers of Treasury bonds.
"The market sold off after the budget talks broke down," said Dan Bernzweig, a money market trader at the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York.
But, he added, "The way politicians go, they say one thing one minute but within the next hour or day they have positions completely reversed."
Trading was slow as investors held back from taking new positions ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy-making meeting on Tuesday.
"Everybody is kind of sitting and waiting to see what the Fed will or won't do on the 19th," said Marilyn Cohen, a California-based money manager of about $60 billion in bonds.
Expectations that central bankers will cut interest rates to invigorate a sagging economy has fueled a powerful bond-market rally in recent months. But bond prices stalled this week as new reports portrayed a mixed picture of the economy.
Inflation at the wholesale level surged last month, but consumer prices remained tame. Retail sales, an important measure of economic growth, jumped sharply in November but so far the Christmas shopping season has turned out to be disappointing.
Moreover, the Fed may hold back on any interest rate reductions until the White House and Congress agree on a plan to reduce the Federal deficit.
Still, some market participants expect a modest reduction in short-term interest rates of about one-quarter percentage point, which would give a small spur to the economy.
Elsewhere in the market, prices of short-term Treasuries rose 1/32 point and intermediate maturities were unchanged to down 3/32 point, Dow Jones Telerate Inc. reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.04, to 1,285.80.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 5.81 percent, down from 5.82 percent late Thursday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Europeans Choose Name And Timetable for Currency
 European leaders picked the name Euro for the unified currency they are struggling to achieve for the 21st century. They also agreed on a timetable for introducing it by 2002. The agreement reflects a growing momentum among many European leaders to forge a single currency and a broader economic and political integration of the Continent that they hope will invigorate its flagging economy and insure greater political stability and peace. The Euro is to replace many of Europe's main currencies eventually, but many skeptics doubt the single currency will ever be issued. 
 The blueprint commits governments to slash spending and raise taxes by the end of 1997. For many Europeans leaner budgets will bring cuts in social programs. [Page 1.]
 
French Rail Workers End Strike
 French railway workers voted to end their three-week-old strike, signaling an end to the country's most serious labor unrest in a decade. The crisis eased after the Government made significant concessions this week in its austerity plan, especially to the railway workers, who played an important role in paralyzing the nation. [1.]
 
Budget Talks Become Angry
 Stepped-up negotiations between the White House and Republicans over a seven-year, balanced budget ended in acrimony only hours after they began. Within hours of the breakdown, efforts to work out a deal for a temporary spending bill also fell apart. Various Government agencies prepared to shut down operations for the second time in a month. [1.]
 When President Clinton failed to present a plan for a balanced budget and when the Republicans insisted on big Medicare savings, the negotiations screeched to a halt. [12.]
 The breakdown of budget talks added to the bond market's uncertainty over whether the Federal Reserve would cut rates next week; Treasury prices ended with little change. [42]
 
Utilicorp Seen in Merger Talks
 Utilicorp United, a utility based in Kansas City, Mo., with businesses in natural gas and independent power, is said to be in merger talks with Kansas City Power and Light, a more traditional utility that supplies electricity to 429,000 residences. [43]
 
A TV Executive for Disney
 Capital Cities/ABC hired Geraldine B. Laybourne from Viacom's Nickelodeon to run its cable television programming. When Disney's purchase of Cap Cities is completed next year, Ms. Laybourne will become president of Disney/ABC Cable Networks, assuming responsibility for all nonbroadcast programming except ESPN, including the 24-hour cable news network that ABC plans to create. Ms. Laybourne built Nickelodeon/Nick at Nite from an obscure cable channel to one that will have 1995 revenue estimated at $380 million. [41.]
 
A Familiar Look to Christmas
 Christmas shoppers seem to yearn for tradition. The hottest products this year mostly involve cuddling up and sitting around the table playing board games. Cashmere is popular again. Grapefruit bath gels are selling well. And Monopoly is making a comeback. [41.]
 
Sprint Plans Are Approved
 The F.C.C. approved plans for Sprint to sell a 20 percent stake to two phone companies in Germany and France for $4.1 billion. Sprint shareholders are to vote on the deal on Jan. 12. The F.C.C. attached conditions intended to protect competitors and telephone customers in the United States. [42.]
 
Copper Prices Plunge
 Copper prices fell nearly 5 percent on signs that near-term supply problems are easing. The London Metal Exchange reported a sharp increase in warehouse inventories of copper, particularly in the United States, prompting speculation that the bull market is over. [38.]
 
Dollar Advances on Rate Cuts
 The dollar moved higher against other leading currencies, benefiting from interest rate cuts in Europe, where more signs of an economic slowdown are emerging. Trading was relatively light, as many traders were waiting for a resolution of the budget dispute between the White House and Congress. [38.]

HEADLINE: Utilicorp Said to Be in Talks To Buy Kansas City Power

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Utilicorp United Inc., a utility based in Kansas City, Mo., with businesses in natural gas and independent power, is in merger talks with Kansas City Power and Light, an industry official familiar with the discussions said yesterday.
The official, speaking anonymously, said that a merger announcement could come in the next few days. Sally McElwreath, a spokeswoman for Utilicorp, said yesterday that the company would not comment on rumors about mergers and acquisitions. Officials of Kansas City Power could not be reached for comment. Turner White, Kansas City Power's senior vice president for retail services, said, "We never comment on these kinds of things." 
 Don Scotto, a utility industry analyst at Bear, Stearns, said that Kansas City Power, which serves electric customers in the Kansas City area, had long been a top takeover candidate among analysts because of its reputation as a producer of low-cost electricity. Mr. Scotto said Utilicorp had been considered a logical partner because the companies' businesses mesh without much overlap.
There has been a wave of mergers and acquisitions in the industry, which is preparing for more competition when states open up their utilities to competition from peers and independent power producers, beginning in the next several years. Many utility company managers believe that to survive, utilities must cut costs and increase in size to take advantage of economies of scale.
In recent mergers -- the union of Puget Sound Power and Light and Washington Energy is a good example -- the parties typically have cut costs mostly by consolidating headquarters and compatible divisions. In the Puget Sound-Washington Energy deal, management estimated that the combined company would save about $370 million over 10 years, mostly because of an 8 percent cut in the combined work force of 3,550.
Utilicorp reported revenues of $1.5 billion last year, while Kansas City Power had revenues of $868 million.
Utilicorp has been aggressive in coming up with new marketing strategies and in diversifying, including experience in the deregulated energy market in Britain.
The company is a major supplier of natural gas and owns a pipeline subsidiary. Utilicorp supplies natural gas to 780,000 customers in eight states and has interests in 16 independent power projects in the United States and Jamaica.
About a year ago the company adopted an unusual strategy of seeking to market its energy products and services nationwide under the brand name Energy One.
In Britain, Utilicorp has been selling natural gas, taking advantage of the fact that customers can now shop for power.
Utilicorp has also been shopping for one of Britain's profitable regional power transmission companies, some of which have already been bid for by other United States utilities.
Compared with Utilicorp, Kansas City Power is a more traditional utility, supplying electricity to 429,000 residential customers.
Kansas City Power is able to offer low-cost electricity because it produces three-fourths of it in coal-fired plants. This puts it in a good position to compete for customers in a deregulated market.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Behind the Budget Deadlock: '96 Election Strategy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The stakes in the last-ditch budget negotiations that began today could hardly be higher.
They involve such momentous questions as whether the place of the American Government in the lives of its citizens will be substantially diminished, whether social policies developed over the last three decades will be reversed and whether middle-income families and wealthy investors will have their taxes cut. 
 But important as those questions are, their resolution will probably turn more on partisan politics than on substance.
Each side has one overarching political imperative. It was their refusal to budge on these points that led the budget talks to break down again today.
For Republicans, the imperative is that policies be adopted that can be shown on paper to produce a balanced budget in the year 2002.
If a budget agreement is reached, Republicans must be able to argue that they forced the hands of profligate Democrats. If talks collapse, Republicans need to be able to blame the Democrats for refusing to control their appetite for overspending.
For Democrats, the essential element is that they be seen by voters to have protected Medicare and Medicaid from destruction by the Republicans.
If a deal is struck, Democrats must be able to say that it resulted from their demand that Republicans retreat on health care programs. If there is no agreement, Democrats want to be able to blame Republicans for trying to pay for tax reductions for the wealthy by spending less for Medicare and Medicaid.
So when President Clinton failed to present a plan for a balanced budget and when the Republicans insisted on big savings in Medicare and Medicaid, the negotiations today screeched to a halt.
Looked at from afar, the emphasis that both sides are placing on these issues hardly seems justified. But their strategy for winning next year's elections relies on the hard line they are taking.
On the matter of balancing the budget, most economists believe that for the long-term strength of the nation's economy, the Government must indeed close the gap between the amount of money it spends each year and the amount it receives in taxes and other revenue.
But Republicans would be hard-pressed to find a single economist who believes that balance must be achieved in precisely seven years -- not five or six or eight or ten.
The notion of reaching a balanced budget in seven years was developed by Republicans in 1993 to demonstrate that the goal could be accomplished by the turn of the century.
Then, Republicans made a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget in seven years the cornerstone of their Contract With America, the platform most Republican candidates for the House ran on last year.
After the proposed amendment failed to get the required two-thirds majority in the Senate this year, Republican leaders decided to try to achieve their goal in the budget process.
Asked last month why seven years was so important, Speaker Newt Gingrich responded, "Seven is the longest period in which you can maintain the discipline to insist on it happening."
And what is the basis for that view?
"Intuition," he replied.
If that seems to fall somewhat short of a principle to live or die on, so does the Democrats' stance on Medicare and Medicaid.
Even the most devoutly Democratic budget analysts understand that the taxpayers cannot continue to sustain the Medicare and Medicaid systems as they exist today. While private health costs have leveled off in the last couple of years, the cost of Medicare and Medicaid, virtually the last bastions of traditional fee-for-service medicine, has continued to grow by about 10 percent a year.
The latest data from the Congressional Budget Office made public this week forecast that unless the law is changed, the cost of the two health programs will rise to $664 billion in the year 2005, or 26.9 percent of the entire Federal budget that year, from $293 billion, or 18.2 percent of the budget this year.
By the second or third decade of the next century, when large numbers of baby boomers retire and many go into nursing homes, Medicare and Medicaid will be swallowing such a large share of the budget that little will be left for anything else.
That is why in his own latest budget, the President proposed changes in the law that would save $97 billion over seven years in Medicare, the program for the elderly, and $37 billion in Medicaid, the program for the poor -- proposals the Administration rarely mentions now.
The comparable figures in the latest Republican proposal, put forward today, are $200 billion in Medicare savings (down from an initial offer of $270 billion) and $119 billion in Medicaid savings (down from $164 billion).
One might think that the two sides could split the difference. It amounts to about $26 billion a year, hardly an asterisk in a budget that is expected to exceed $2 trillion by 2002.
But Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said after the talks ended this afternoon that the Administration would not compromise at all on this issue -- just as the Republicans drew the line on the question of a balanced budget in seven years.
Medicare was the Democrats' crowning achievement in the Great Society, an enormously popular program that is largely responsible for making this generation of retired people ever so much more independent than their parents were at the same age.
When the program was created 30 years ago, most Republicans opposed it. And ever since, whenever the Democrats have needed a political lift, they have accused their opponents of threatening the well-being of the elderly.
But both parties believe that the outcome of next year's elections will depend on making their charges stick -- the Republican charge that Democrats tried to block a balanced budget and the Democratic charge that Republicans tried to gut Medicare and Medicaid.

HEADLINE: Who Is Really Cooking the Books?

BYLINE: By Richard McGahey; Richard McGahey, former executive director of the Joint Economic Committed of Congress, is senior fellow at the Center for National Policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As the battle over the budget goes into extra innings, issues of economic analysis and forecasting have become central to any deal. The Republicans have kept up a steady drumbeat against the Clinton Administration, calling for "honest scorekeeping" by the Congressional Budget Office and accusing the Administration of cooking the books with their own economic forecasts.
But the public should not be fooled. The Administration's economic forecasts are in the mainstream of all such projections, including those of private and corporate economists. 
 Although forecasting is an arcane art, the Administration's figures have been more accurate on such key variables as real and nominal economic growth rates, unemployment and long-term interest rates. For example, the Administration's estimates of economic growth have been about 20 percent more accurate than the C.B.O.'s for 1993-95.
Unlike the rosy economic outlooks from the Reagan White House -- projections that overestimated growth and tax revenue, contributing to the explosion of the deficit by overestimating economic growth and tax revenues -- the Administration has had an excellent track record on honest and conservative economic forecasting. Both Business Week and The Wall Street Journal have run editorials urging Congress to use its growth projections.
The point was underlined last week when the Congressional Budget Office belatedly released a revised forecast that moved much closer to the Administration's figures on inflation and other indicators. (The old C.B.O. forecast for inflation was 3.2 percent, but the new forecast dropped to 3 percent.)
But it is hard to know what to make of some C.B.O. findings, like its puzzling forecast that higher long-term interest rates will coincide with lower inflation and slower growth. There is also its claim that the Administration's plan is still $365 billion out of balance. And the office has not provided estimates for the costs of the proposed Republican tax cut beyond 2002, when many analysts think that revenue losses will soar.
Republicans promised to discuss these technical issues as part of the negotiations, but detailed discussions never took place. Indeed, the C.B.O. issued its forecast without real consultation, in violation of the Republicans' agreement.
In fact, the deficit has fallen for three years in a row, the first time since Truman was President that this has happened. As a percentage of G.N.P., the deficit is back to where it was before the national debt exploded in the 1980's. And the Government is being radically downsized; Federal employment, as a percentage of total employment, is at its lowest level since the mid-1930's.
These huge reductions have come under the Administration's 1993 deficit reduction plan, which passed without a single vote from Republicans. Nevertheless, the Administration has agreed to an arbitrary seven-year time frame to balance the budget (a period justified by Speaker Newt Gingrich based on "intuition"). Having given in, the Administration has every right to stick to its guns on the remaining issues, though it is again trying to negotiate, with yet another plan to balance the budget.
But its should stop this one-sided negotiation until the Republicans enter into serious consultation on the economic forecasts, as they agreed, and drop the misleading rhetoric about "honest scorekeeping" in favor of a truly honest discussion.

HEADLINE: An Era Is Fading in Greece

 BODY:
The curtain is drawing on an Aegean melodrama, featuring Greece's aging lion, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, and his second wife, Dimitra Liani, a former airline hostess. The 76-year-old Prime Minister is hooked to a respirator, deferring key decisions to his wife, whom he has named chief of staff. He has yet to propose a successor and has rebuffed calls for his resignation, while Mrs. Papandreou tries stoically to ignore a tabloid barrage of old photographs in which she appears topless.
It is a sad, undignified twilight for a leader who has dominated Greek politics for a generation. Despite high unemployment and a potentially worrying budget deficit, these have been good times for most Greeks. Sobered by Balkan turbulence, Athens this year wisely tempered its fervid nationalism. It recently lifted a self-injuring trade embargo against Macedonia, or Skopje, as Greeks call the former Yugoslav republic. Moreover, Greece threw no roadblocks against Turkey's bid for a customs union with the European Community. 
 This stable interlude could dissolve overnight with the passing of Mr. Papandreou. The scramble for power has already begun in his Socialist party, Pasok, and in the equally divided conservative opposition party, New Democracy. Greece's friends in Europe and America should make plain their support for the pragmatic course begun in Mr. Papandreou's final year, and press for new initiatives to settle old differences.
Highest on the list of old disputes are the quarrel with Turkey on Aegean air and water rights, and the deadlock over Cyprus, which began in 1974, when Turkey invaded and the island was partitioned. Cyprus is a quarrel ripe for resolution if Athens and Ankara can be nudged toward a settlement of wider issues in the Aegean.
Americans can only contemplate with sadness the anticlimactic finale of Andreas Papandreou's remarkable career. He helped restore democracy to Greece after the rule of the colonels and presided over the modernization of his country.

HEADLINE: Domestic Poverty Is a Human Rights Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The New Attack on Human Rights" (editorial, Dec. 10): You correctly chastise Indonesia, China and Singapore for accepting only those rights that suit their cynical purposes, and find it "patronizing, indeed almost insulting to Asians and others, to suggest that citizens in developing countries should not have the same rights as those in more developed lands." 
 But you would do well to recognize that the United States continues to repudiate economic and social rights -- half of the rights guaranteed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights -- and has stonewalled the majority of human rights treaties.
At this year's preparatory meetings for the United Nations Conference on Housing, the United States stands alone in refusing to accept the internationally recognized right to housing.
Where is your indignation for the daily violations of dignity and human rights in Harlem, where living standards match those of Bangladesh? Is there nothing "insulting" about the richest country in the world responding to its urban wastelands by rushing to deny its citizens their few remaining social entitlements? Is it coincidental that the only industrialized country to reject economic and social rights also boasts the highest disparity between rich and poor?
Economic and social rights are not alien to Western values. Education, Social Security and a minimum wage have long held the status of rights in this country. Franklin D. Roosevelt championed "freedom from want" as strongly as "freedom from fear," on the understanding that "true individual freedoms cannot exist without economic security and independence."
As citizens of the former Soviet Union have discovered, voting rights and free speech are of little value to those with neither the education nor economic clout to make them meaningful. Poverty, sickness and illiteracy undermine human dignity as effectively as military thugs.
Growing domestic and global economic inequalities represent the gravest threat to civil liberties, if not international security. The United Nations estimates that less than 10 percent of the world's population participates fully in the political, economic, social and cultural institutions that shape their lives.
If Western media and human rights groups continue to ape the United States Government's two-tiered approach to human rights, their voices will be increasingly irrelevant to the human rights problems of most of the world's people.
 
CHRIS AF JOCHNICK
Legal Director, Center
for Economic and Social Rights
New York, Dec. 12, 1995

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Franchises In Canada Are Likely To Get Aid

BYLINE: By CHARLIE NOBLES 

DATELINE: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 15

 BODY:
The National Hockey League took a major step today toward establishing a form of revenue sharing for financially ailing teams in Canada.
The Board of Governors' eight-person committee on revenue and currency recommended the use of league-generated funds to help qualifying Canada-based teams deal with a disparity in the Canadian and United States dollars. 
 To qualify, a team would have to be in the lower half of the league in gross revenues, despite doing a good job of selling season tickets and suites, as well as merchandising.
"We want to make sure that this is a joint partnership," said Commissioner Gary Bettman, who expects league-wide approval of the plan before the N.H.L. All-Star Game next month. "If a team is going to get the support that it needs from the local community, the league is going to help the rich to try and keep the smaller revenue-generating clubs in Canada in their markets."
Among those franchises likely affected are Edmonton, Calgary and Ottawa. Calgary's part-owner Harley Hotchkiss was beaming after the committee's meeting.
With the Canadian dollar worth just 73 United States cents, Hotchkiss, a member of the revenue and currency committee, argued that Canadian teams were at a distinct disadvantage, particularly in player procurement.
"Before, when the dollar was, say, 85 cents, and our costs were lower, the problem was livable," he said. "Lately it's become a more serious problem for us, and not one we can do anything about.
"We're trying to be competitive and we're at a significant disadvantage."
Bettman said today's development in no way signaled the start of more extensive N.H.L. involvement in revenue sharing.
"Gate-sharing and local television sharing, when you have an economist do all the charts, doesn't work," he said. "Because there are some clubs in small markets that have very, very strong gates, and others with strong television contracts. The last thing you want to be doing is taking money from those clubs and giving it to teams in bigger markets that may have other revenue sources that they don't."
The committee, besides Hotchkiss, was made up of representatives from Anaheim, Chicago, Boston, Washington, Edmonton, Montreal and Vancouver.
"Does this solve all the world's problems?" Bettman said. "The answer is no. But it does address a very important issue that has imposed a hardship on many of the clubs."
Turning to another matter, Bettman said that if the N.H.L. expanded again, it would be in North America, not Europe.
"I think we can strengthen our footprint and strengthen this sport in North America before we worry about the rest of the world," he said. "While we like to take a long-term view, we don't want to look so far. You ever try walking while you're looking through binoculars? You're destined to trip."

LENGTH: 2305 words

HEADLINE: Parent Power

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

DATELINE: UNION

 BODY:
FOR years, from the time they were installed in 1983, the high, heavy thermal-pane windows in her kindergarten classroom drove Gail Signorelli nuts. Like nearly all the windows in Washington Elementary School here, they stuck, permanently. Some teachers strained their backs tugging at them. One custodian hurt his back so severely he was out for months.
As a result, Ms. Signorelli's classroom, like the others, was usually stifling. It faced south, overlooking the playground blacktop, from which heat rose. "The heat made children cranky," Ms. Signorelli said. "In the afternoon they'd fall asleep." 
Furthermore, a chemical in the glass reacted with the sun, darkening the windows so they looked filthy. "Those windows were miserable, ornery," said Robert Jeranek, the principal.
It took 12 years for Washington School officials to get the approval to spend $250,000 for new windows. Were it not for the local PTA, they'd still be waiting and, come spring, the children still sweating. No one would have dealt with the sporadic complaints that only occasionally reached the school board. Somebody had to take charge: rallying people, shuttling complaints to the board, making a show of power.
That was a job, clearly, for Washington Elementary's PTA, for its 600 mothers, fathers, grandparents and teachers -- 10 more PTA members than there are children in the school. Many Parent-Teacher Associations confine their efforts to annual cookie sales for new hockey jerseys. "You hear PTA, your image is cliquey cupcake bakers," said Pat Pastore, Washington PTA's president.
But a strong, organized PTA can do much more. At Washington School, if a teacher needs somebody to read aloud, if a child needs tutoring or is out sick for a while or the playground equipment is rusting, if the Legislature is contemplating cuts in special education, parents and teachers turn to the PTA. Usually, it dispatches tutors or get-well stuffed bears, news of the state government or addresses of local lawmakers.
In other words, it practices politics at its most local, concrete and satisfying -- and at its purest. Nobody stands to make money. Everybody is in it to make schools and children's lives better. Whatever parents' skills, they are welcome. One father, a police officer, gives safety talks. Others bring in people who can perform for assemblies: actors, magicians, wildlife experts exhibiting birds of prey. "Everybody does a little something," said Mrs. Pastore. "Put together, it adds up to a lot."
Furthermore, the Washington PTA is organized like a small business. It is overseen by a few mothers who treat the responsibility like a full-time job. An artistically inclined parent, for instance, asked to design a logo, drew five children holding hands, which another had printed on mugs, pins and sweatshirts for members. Small as this is, it creates the feeling of an inclusive club.
In Union, which residents describe as "typical blue-collar middle class," adults spend a lot of free time coaching or cheering the huge soccer, baseball and football teams or the marching band or rifle club. An evening out may well be bowling at the PTA's family fun night.
So typical a town is Union (population 50,723 in 1992) that for nearly 40 years every major Presidential candidate has campaigned there. The average household income is $50,000, and few families range much higher or lower. And while only one-fifth of the adults have graduated from college, the township's schools regularly win praise -- Governor Whitman singled them out last year as a statewide model of efficiency -- and the dropout rate is minuscule.
On weekends, after work, residents give time to the town. "People in Union for some reason get caught up in the tradition of volunteerism," said Mayor Greg Muller. "It's a phenomenon. Even one-parent families contribute."
The satisfaction of the PTA is in arousing oneself and one's neighbors to fix what's broken and enhance the rest. It is, when the occasion arises, figuring out a way to persuade the school board to come up with a few hundred thousand dollars to replace miserable, ornery windows.
For years Mr. Jeranek, the principal, and a succession of business managers had tried -- calling and writing the manufacturer, who made promises and sent a worker to spray lubrication. In 1988, after five years of this, the school sued the manufacturer, who subsequently went bankrupt.
Children complained to parents, who complained to teachers, who complained to the principal. The principal wrote memos and talked to the school board president, who would talk to the Washington School business manager, who would plead that the matter was in litigation.
Finally, two years ago, Mrs. Pastore, the new PTA president, took it on. Mothers stamped and addressed blank postcards to each board member, handing them out in bundles to parents, teachers and staff, urging everybody to write about the windows. "I take this seriously, like a business," said Mrs. Pastore.
Over the two years, they did this four times. Each time more than 1,000 cards were sent to board members.
"Those postcards were lethal," said Mr. Jeranek. "They slaughtered with those cards. It was not just a few people. It was the entire population of the school."
Last spring the board agreed to allocate money to replace the windows. But the replacement of a deteriorating 100-year-old elementary school pushed it aside.
Again the postcards went out. The board agreed to tack on $250,000 to the elementary school bond issue, which the voters approved. This fall the windows were measured. They'll be installed in spring.
THE volunteers of the Washington PTA, whose children are in preschool to fourth grade, used well-worn political strategies: uniting splinter groups, getting people to prod those in power, being relentless. But from the first, PTA's have been about politics.
The need for a strong voice to support children's issues was evident in 1897, when 2,000 people came to the first PTA meeting in the dead of winter. Even after the crowd was moved from the Arlington Hotel banquet hall in Washington to the nearby First Baptist Church, many had to stand outside on the steps. Among the early concerns of the National Congress of Mothers, as it was called, were child labor laws, sex education, Federal aid to public schools, the institution of a national public health bureau and of kindergartens and hot lunches in public schools. In the mid-1920's, the National Congress of Colored Parents and Teachers was formed to lobby in segregated states for schoolbooks and adequate sewers and drinking water. It merged with the National PTA in 1970.
"All we care about is children," said Nancy Paley, the departing president of the New Jersey State PTA. "Homelessness, hunger, teen-age pregnancy, abused children, children smoking. Anything that affects children."
Local PTA's raise money for books, take children to museums, arrange for theater groups to put on plays, hold drug and alcohol prevention programs, tutor students in reading, math, computer skills. The idea is simple: parents should know what's going on in their children's schools and should lend a hand.
Years ago, when Mrs. Paley was the Washington PTA's safety chairman, children were supposed to leave the building by the outdoor stairs rather than the parking lot. When it snowed, custodians cleared the lot but left the stairs covered with snow and ice. So Mrs. Paley, worried that children would fall down the icy stairs, countermanded the policy, halted cars and directed children through the plowed parking lot.
"When parents get involved, things get accomplished," she said.
She might have added that when parents get involved, children become accomplished. A growing body of research indicates that the more parents take part in schools, the higher their children's grades and the better they fare. This holds true at all economic levels, among native-born and immigrant families, in suburbs, the country, the inner city. In one study -- of a New York State program for preschoolers from poor families -- the more time parents spent in school activities, the higher their children's cognitive development.
An unsurprising corollary is that if parents are encouraged to participate in school affairs, they will -- especially if they are asked to do more than bake cookies or sell raffle tickets. No school administrator would discourage parents from helping out. But some administrators make a point of pulling in parents and even local businesses, providing projects, space and equipment and soliciting advice.
The results can be dramatic. In Los Angeles, researchers followed 500 low-income black and Hispanic sixth-graders for four years. They found that schools with the most vigorous, substantive support from parents had students with the highest reading scores and greatest improvement in reading.
"Parents hold the key to schools," said Kenneth Shore, a psychologist with the Hamilton school district in Mercer County. "Parents fight more vigorously for their kids. They push schools to do things they might not otherwise do."
Not all educators want parental attention. "Some schools place obstacles in the way or steer parents towards fund-raising," Dr. Shore said. "Some parents are intimidated -- they feel they don't have the skill or knowledge, that teaching kids is the schools' job." But he added, "Nationwide, there's a trend to enlist parents' support."
Parents first contribute to schools for the good of their own children, of course. But they wind up doing good for their children's schoolmates. Given a chance, these attitudes and these efforts could extend indefinitely, with people seeking to help children they'll never meet -- children in neighboring and distant schools, neighboring and distant counties, state, countries.
"Some people think their school is the only one that's important," said Mrs. Paley. "Washington School is not afraid to become involved with any other school. The parents are not petty. I have five kids, but I still have to care about your child, about children throughout the town and state."
WELL and good. But who has time? The trick, say PTA officials, is to limit one's participation, to volunteer without becoming overwhelmed. The National PTA even has a list entitled "How to Say No and Not Feel Guilty."
Mrs. Pastore says she tries to get parents to do what they want when they want to. One new mother knitted tree ornaments for this month's holiday boutique, where children bought inexpensive gifts for their families. A pharmacist went to the boutique to wrap presents on Friday, her day off, while other working mothers made calls and lists in the evenings.
"I don't ever put people on the spot," Mrs. Pastore said. "I let them think about it for a few days."
To make a PTA run takes a little time from most people and a lot from a handful. For Mrs. Pastore and the committee chairpeople, it's like a career.
At the year's start, they send letters asking parents what they'd like to do. Everyone who wants can join the executive board, which currently has 60 members and meets monthly.
Many, including retired people, tutor students. Sometimes there are too many tutors for the classroom to hold.
"You see parents sitting in the hall with a group of children with flash cards, teaching letters," said Ms. Signorelli. "Anytime you need help, you let them know. You say, 'This is what we're doing; this is what we need.' And they say, 'How many people do you need?' "
There are 23 annual Washington PTA events. In October, there's the book fair and Halloween party; in November, science night, where parents and teachers demonstrate flashy experiments. Family roller-skating night is in February, and in May, a fair where students in school T-shirts ride ponies. There's a track meet and an arts festival showing work by adults and children. Once a year, PTA members give teachers little gifts, apples and a catered lunch that last year consisted of lemon chicken, punch and homemade desserts.
Each event requires dozens of workers to schedule, staff, teach, buy, sell, collect money, clean up. And there are PTA lobbying efforts, and committees to achieve certain educational goals -- goals set by the state, the Federal Government, the National PTA -- by the year 2000.
Parents have run thousands of feet of cable wire -- donated by a parent -- to fit all classrooms with computers. Dozens of Union parents coach sports teams.
Washington's PTA parents tend not to meet formally. They meet on ballfields or the playground or the school parking lot while waiting to pick up a child. There, the word is spread: Can you make calls to raise money for a family in trouble? Can you talk to fourth graders about engineering on Career Night? Will you come to the board meeting to talk about the bond referendum?
"We've been allowed to establish a community in the school," said Mrs. Pastore.
Before she had children, Mrs. Pastore ran a gift shop in Montclair. She and her husband, Tony, a salesman who works out of his home, decided to forgo some income and move from a seven-bedroom, five-fireplace house into something more modest. They'd had money. Now, with two boys, they wanted time.
"I wouldn't give up time with my kids, and neither would my husband," she said. "A lot of mothers get jobs that don't interfere with their schedule with the kids. And lots of mothers in Union stay home."
Washington School is more than a place where children learn to read, write, multiply, think logically. With the efforts of the administration, teachers and parents, it has become a place for Union residents to meet one another, to contribute their knowledge, skills and good will, to feel and become a part of the town they've chosen to live in.

HEADLINE: REPUBLICAN SOCIALISM

 BODY:
I take strong issue with Lewis on two specific points. He writes: "Most Americans do not enjoy taxable capital gains." In fact, many Americans do own common stock, via mutual or retirement funds or both. In addition, almost all Americans who have jobs in the private sector are affected, directly or indirectly, by the level of available venture capital in the economy. Many older Americans are now locked into stocks they bought years ago because of the tax they would have to pay on illusory gains that exist solely because of inflation. 
 Lewis says, "The Templeton Growth Fund . . . makes risky plays mainly in foreign countries." John Templeton, who founded the fund that bears his name, is widely known to be a firm believer in buying shares in undervalued companies and holding them for a long time. After Templeton's retirement, this investment philosophy remains in place. There are speculators, but Templeton isn't one of them.

DONALD E. SCOTT
Sunderland, Mass.

HEADLINE: NEWS AND TOPICS: GOVERNMENT;
Is Simpler Better? State Readies New Rules for Building

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
New Jersey is about to undergo a subtle but important change in the way houses, and neighborhoods, are built.
Until now, every city and town has had its own standards governing development sites: how wide each street should be, what the sewer pipes should be made of, whether sidewalks are required and so on. But under regulations that are to take effect next summer, all residential developments would be subject to the same guidelines. 
 State officials say the new standards represent a vast simplification that will end up saving money -- as much as $2,000 for every new house, some of which will be passed on to buyers -- and will set a nationwide precedent.
"I don't know of any other state that has a statewide set of site standards, so this is very important," said David Listokin, professor of urban planning at Rutgers University's Center for Urban Policy Research, whose research formed the basis of the standards.
But some local officials, particularly those who have long been involved in planning and zoning, call the new guidelines an inadequate one-size-fits-all approach that strips power from the municipalities.
"This is a direct assault on home rule from A to Z. This is obnoxious," said Mayor William J. Pascrell Jr. of Paterson. "At least $15 million worth of development in our city would have been curtailed by these standards. We don't have the space to put in all the parking they say should go in; we're not a suburban community."
The standards cover a host of seemingly technical items, from storm-water management to the width of new streets. But their overall purpose is far from technical: to establish a flexible range of building requirements applicable to all communities. The rules are intended to complement the state's Uniform Construction Code, which in 1975 standardized regulations for building houses.
"As people realized savings with the construction codes of the mid-1970's, they realized the same type of thing could be applied for streets and sewer pipes," said Joanne Harkins, director of land use and planning for the New Jersey Builders Association, a trade group. "The amount of money spent running here and there to get approvals is just incredible."
In 1993, Gov. Jim Florio signed a law authorizing uniform site standards and establishing an independent advisory panel, composed of planners, builders, local officials, and others, to hammer out the details. The final report is not expected until next month; public hearings are to follow.
"I think you add professionalism, predictability and consistency," said Charles A. Richman, assistant commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs, which will adopt and administer the standards. "It's all the more important because housing starts are dropping and the inventory of readily available, zoned and approved site plans is dropping."
Beyond the criticism from local officials, the new rules have come under attack from transportation advocates and environmentalists, who say more attention needs to be paid to pedestrians' and bicyclists' concerns. These advocates have made some headway, pressing for more sidewalks, bikeways, and "traffic calming" measures like improved signs, speed barriers and raised crosswalks, depending on housing density and other factors.
"The original draft was definitely put together by engineers whose mind-set is from the post-World War II period of urban sprawl," said Mary D'Arcy, transportation advocate for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group Law and Policy Center, in Trenton. "The draft now before the board is better, but we still have work to do."
The loudest objections have come from the New Jersey State League of Municipalities and the group New Jersey Planning Officials, which represents municipal planning and zoning boards. They say the standards, while technically acceptable, create an unnecessary state bureaucracy that limits the power and options of municipalities. If used at all, they argue, the standards should be used as a guide, not a mandate.
"The majority of builders work in one or two municipalities, and these builders know those municipalities very well; they know the rules, the procedures, the time the office is open," said Gregory C. Fehrenbach, municipal manager of Lakewood Township. "The new standards are a matter of concern to builders, planners, engineers and landscape architects who want to be able to have statewide business and the same cookbook rules for all towns, not taking into account special circumstances."
The future doesn't look any brighter, Mr. Fehrenbach said. There is now talk of site standards for commercial and industrial areas, and talk of legislation to overhaul municipal land-use laws. But panel members said the residential site standards were necessary and fair.
"I'm convinced that what we've come up with is best for the municipalities," said Harvey S. Moskowitz, president of Mosko witz, Heyer & Gruel, the state's largest planning consulting firm, based in Florham Park. "I think the standards are flexibile enough. It's an attempt to bring up the standards where they've been deficient, and it cuts back where they've been excessive."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New statewide standards will change the way developments like this one, in Hopewell, are built. Commissioner Harriet Derman and her aide Charles A. Richman of the Department of Community Affairs, which will administer the rules, visited the site. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The 2 Mrs. Whitmans, As Viewed by the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is December in Washington, and there are Christmas parties for every lawyer and lobbyist in the city. These events are not for fun, not for the hosts at least, who hope to gain a little attention for their many causes. The Republican National Committee offered up some mini-pizza and chicken-with-peanut kebab in a somber room over Union Station, and Haley Barbour, the chairman, left no doubt about his purpose when he broke away from a clutch of people and set out to perform the duties of host by apologizing, " 'Scuse me while I go do some work."
That was on Monday, the day Governor Whitman met Senator Bob Dole in Edison to endorse him for President. There was not a lot of surprise in her choice, because there was not a lot of choice left for her in the Republican field, now that Gov. Pete Wilson of California and Gen. Colin L. Powell of everyone's dreams have taken themselves out of the race. 
 Mr. Barbour said he was enthusiastic about Mrs. Whitman's decision to endorse Mr. Dole, but not for the reasons many other Republicans are. Republican moderates might expect someone to note that Mr. Dole has burned a lot of his centrist bridges in pursuit of a nomination controlled by the Republican right, and that he will need all of the carpentry skills of people like Mrs. Whitman to rebuild them once -- that is, if -- he becomes the nominee.
Others might expect some mention of the gender gap, which is the evidence that the Republicans have a problem with female voters, since men far more men than women seem willing to support the G.O.P. It is a gap that can only widen with the anti-abortion language of the Republican campaign so far, and because Mrs. Whitman is the country's only female governor, and very possibly the country's most prominent Republican feminist, some might expect the party chairman to embrace a public figure who enlarges the leading contender's appeal.
But no. The party chairman's spin on Christie Whitman is to focus on the fairly narrow issues that got her elected, which is lower taxes and a government-is-the-problem message that just happens to be what most of the G.O.P. Presidential field is saying, not to mention the Republican leadership in Congress. It is an approach that may be hard to sustain if the Governor's luck runs out next year.
"What Governor Whitman brings to this race is that she is a very popular and well-known Governor who ran for office and won on the Republican agenda -- lower taxes and economic growth," Mr. Barbour said. "That's why I chose her to give the response to the President's State of the Union. I mean, I'm not as dumb as I look."
To be fair to Mr. Barbour -- it was his Christmas party, after all -- the Presidential race is still a long way off, the Republican convention is not until June, he cannot appear to endorse one contender over another, and why should he admit to any problems in his party anyway?
Here's why. Next year is going to be a very tough one for Governor Whitman's fiscal ideals, and it may become very hard for her to campaign next summer as the Governor who brought lower taxes and economic growth to New Jersey. Robert Littell, the State Senate Budget Committee chairman, believes that spending will have to rise $1 billion to $1.3 billion in the next budget. It is only a coincidence that $1.3 billion is the amount of taxes the Governor is saving New Jersey voters with her 30 percent income-tax cut, and so will not be available to the state next year.
In the coming budget, Mr. Littell pointed out, the state must complete the takeover of the county court system. State interest payments will grow, and the Governor must provide the State Supreme Court a plan, by next September, to show how the state will meet the court's order to bring spending in poor school districts up to the level of rich ones.
Revenues, meanwhile, are borderline at best, running about 1 percent below the level forecast by the Treasurer last spring. And the unemployment rate ticked up last month, to 6.1 percent from 5.7 percent, and now stands, once again, above the national average.
Mrs. Whitman's anti-tax message began to fray, meanwhile, with the introduction of a bill last week to raise cigarette taxes by 60 percent, to pay for hospital charity care and extend health benefits for poor children. The Governor supports such a tax increase.
These are serious portents, and not to be celebrated, as some must secretly be doing. No one should wish to see the Governor fail, but it is hardly perverse to wonder how she will be able to campaign for Mr. Dole next year as a tax cutting economy-booster if the news columns are filled with articles about how she had to raise taxes and her economy is flagging.
In that situation, maybe Mr. Barbour and Mr. Dole would wish to look around for some other other way to compliment the Governor. Something about the old-fashioned way she has tried to bridge the differences between the Republican right and left, and has tried to enlarge her party's appeal instead of confining it to a movement that thinks taxes are un-American and that government is author of all our problems.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Tax Incentives Make a Buyer's Heart Grow Fonder

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
A BUSINESS that owns its premises is more likely to be rooted to its community than one that merely leases. When it expands, it is more likely to try to do so in place.
"It doesn't have to face a decision every five or 10 years about whether to leave or stay," said George G. Sirras, president of Major Development Company, a commercial brokerage in Flushing, Queens. "And the banks are more willing to provide the financing they need." 
 These verities are currently finding expression in the industrial real-estate market in Queens among manufacturing companies that are both buying and selling properties. The sellers typically have had stability of place for decades, while the buyers are looking for that stability.
A leading example on the buying side is the American Umbrella Company. It is a 50-year-old family-owned business that for 16 years has rented a floor in the Cooper-Siegel Building, at 18th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, where it operates with 75 employees and 130 sewing machines. With Tishman Speyer Properties, the owner, bringing in major retailers and seeking office users upstairs, the space has become too expensive for a manufacturer.
Facing a lease expiration, American Umbrella was "within five days of signing a rental deal in New Jersey," said Richard Ziskin, 41, president of the company. But then Henry Auffrath, Chemical Bank's vice president for business development in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, with offices in Rego Park, Queens, got wind of his intentions.
THE banker sold the company on the advantages of buying, said Mr. Ziskin, and will soon move into the former Lyon Leather Company building at 1831 Starr Street, in Ridgewood, Queens.
Apart from getting a more efficient loading and unloading operation in the 50,000-square-foot building, the appeal of buying rested largely on an expanded tax-incentive program introduced by the Giuliani administration two months ago. Industrial properties are now eligible for an exemption for 16 years of 100 percent of the taxes that result from the rise in assessment caused by the work that is done to improve the building for reoccupancy. The exemption then declines by 10 percent a year for 9 years.
To get that 25-year benefit, the improvement has to add at least 10 percent to current assessed value. But if the work adds 25 percent or more to assessed value, the building is also eligible for 12 years of abatement of existing taxes, based on 50 percent of the current assessment for four years, and after that declining by 10 percent every other year for the remaining 8 years. The benefits apply to new construction or renovation.
The effect of all this, brokers say, is to allow industrial companies to own real estate for about what it would cost to rent space.
ACCORDING to Mr. Sirras, for example, a user-buyer of the former Robbins Men's & Boys' Wear building in Sunnyside -- 108,000 square feet of ground-floor space plus a parking area at 39-34 43d Street -- would be able to cut property taxes by about $120,000 a year under the program, or more than $1 a square foot.
There is also the prospect of an electric rate from Con Ed as much as 25 percent below the normal rate, available as an economic development incentive. Together, the two incentives would cut effective occupancy costs for ownership to about the same cost as renting, Mr. Sirras said, or about $6 a square foot a year, including mortgage debt.
"Until this program was improved, a lot of my customers found that it was clearly more advantageous financially to move to New Jersey," said Mr. Auffrath, the Chemical banker, who conducts seminars for manufacturers on financing issues. "Now it's a level playing field." Under a state program, he said, banks are also able to offer companies 90 percent financing for acquisition and improvement loans, enabling user-buyers to make purchases with only a 10 percent down payment.
But more often than not the purchaser is not a user but a developer-contractor who divides and rebuilds the space to rent out to several tenants. There is greater demand for small space than large space.
"The deals we make are mostly for under 50,000 square feet, and mainly for under 30,000 square feet," said Michael Fierman, a senior broker at Greiner-Maltz Company, based in Long Island City. When companies need 100,000 square feet or more, he said, they have trouble finding it in Queens.
The improved incentive program may lead to more purchases by users, however. According to the latest Greiner-Maltz survey, there are now 18 one- or two-story factory or warehouse buildings of 100,000 to 150,000 square feet on the sales market in Queens.
One of these properties is the 12-acre Edo Corporation compound on Flushing Bay in College Point. Edo is a public company that makes aircraft landing gear, among other aircraft-related products, with $90 million in sales last year.
Edo was founded in College Point in 1925 by Earl Dodge Osborne, first as a manufacturer of small seaplanes and later as a maker of the floats or pontoons that allow planes to land on water. It has branched out to many other aircraft devices, including many for the military, to which sales have declined. Edo has operations across the country, but its headquarters are in College Point.
"We used to have as many as 700 or 800 people working at College Point," said Marvin Genzer, the general counsel. Now there are 150.
Last year Edo put its three College Point buildings on the market -- one of 148,600 square feet, another of 76,100 square feet and a third of 20,800 square fee. Mr. Genzer was unwilling to discuss negotiations going on with potential buyers, but they are said to include developers who might redevelop part of the space for other tenants, enabling Edo to consolidate in a portion of it.
Another long-term Queens company that has been affected by military cutbacks is Ozone Industries, a supplier of hydraulic components and landing gear to the aircraft industry and the military. For nearly 50 years it has operated on 101st Street in Ozone Park, where it was founded.
IN 1980 the company was sold to Joy Manufacturing, and seven years later Joy sold it to BBA Group, a British conglomerate. Last winter Ozone bought a 65,000-square-foot building out of foreclosure in East Lyme, Conn., and has been steadily shifting operations there since May.
"We looked all over the Northeast, with economic development agencies helping us," said Robert P. Terenzi, Ozone's president. "We ended up in Connecticut because of the bankruptcy of the company that owned the building. We got a very attractive price."
Now Ozone is trying to sell the three buildings with 200,000 square feet of disjointed space that it collected over 50 years. Military cutbacks had left the company with more space than it needed, Mr. Terenzi said, and it was inefficient space at that. "We needed one building under one roof for production efficiency," he said.
In Connecticut, Ozone has about 100 employees, said Alan Macht, the firm's chief financial officer. As recently as 1992 it had 250 employees. About a quarter of the employees from Queens have relocated to Connecticut.
One contractor who has purchased and redeveloped industrial property for smaller users in Queens recently is Joseph LoStrito. He acquired the 127,500-square-foot three-story building at 114-02 15th Avenue in College Point a year ago. Ten smaller tenants have taken space at rents of $5 to $6 a square foot, brokers said.
That, too, was a situation that began with the departure of a long-term owner-user. Traulsen Refrigeration Company, a privately held manufacturer of stainless steel refrigeration equipment, had been in the building for more than 40 years. The company moved its factory to a 320,000-square-foot building in Fort Worth, Tex.
