LENGTH: 1579 words

HEADLINE: Wanted: Jolly Fellows, Beards a Plus

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
FINDING a Santa Claus who looks like the real thing is not easy. No one knows this better than Leslie Catlin of Berlin, who is in the business of supplying Santas to malls, shopping centers and private parties.
So Ms. Catlin is forever on the lookout for Santa look-alikes or at least reasonable facsimiles. And for a long time one of her best prospects was Bill Welch, a Scout master to one of her sons. 
 "Bill had this wonderful white beard and I was after him for years to be a Santa," Ms. Catlin said in an interview. "But he always said, 'When I retire.' Well, he finally retired and now he's one of our best Santas at the Westfarms Mall." Mr. Welch is one of about 40 Santas, along with about 60 Santa's helpers, that Ms. Catlin has provided this Christmas season for two shopping centers in Connecticut. With fewer spots open for Santas these days, there is no shortage of applicants, but ones who come close to naturally look the part, like Mr. Welch, are rare.
Why the decline in the number of Santas? Mainly, it's because in years gone by Santas could be found in almost every town's department stores. But nowadays it's the mall, and only one to a mall no matter how many stores are involved.
"It's all changed, and economics are primarily responsible," said Lud Baldwin, a drama teacher at the Kingswood-Oxford School in West Hartford, who has been portraying Santa and training others to do so for 17 years. "The stores pool their resources and you wind up with only one Santa, which is much less costly than having a Santa in individual stores. Unfortunately it can mean long lines and less time for children to spend with Santa."
Nowadays the best place to find Santa is in the center of a shopping mall. He is likely to be surrounded by Santa's helpers who pass out free candy to children and take their pictures sitting on Ol' Kris's lap -- for a fee. Considering that this very seasonal job pays between $8 and $12 an hour (longer service and a natural beard usually means more pay) and requires, among other things, a jovial disposition and intense concentration, it is surprising that so many Santas return year after year to ask tots, and some grown-ups, whether they've been naughty or nice and, regardless of the answer, what they want for Christmas.
"It's pretty demanding work and there's quite a lot of pressure," said Mr. Welch, a retired tool maker and model maker who has been at Westfarms Mall for three years. The mall, which straddles the border between West Hartford and Farmington, has six Santas and 130 stores. "But I love it and I think I have more fun than the people in line," Mr. Welch said. "And the kids are wonderful. To see the smiles on their faces makes it all worthwhile."
To Jim Weed of West Hartford, playing Santa is so special that he takes vacation from his job at a preschool center each December so that he can do it full-time. "At the risk of sounding corny, being Santa is a privilege," said Mr. Weed. "There's a very special connection between children and Santa Claus and words can't describe the magic in the children's eyes when they talk with Santa. At times you look out and see the line around the corner and wonder if you'll have enough energy to handle it. But of course you do."
Mr. Weed was a Santa at the G. Fox & Company store in Hartford for 15 years, until the store closed in 1992. For the last two years, he has been one of 16 Santas in the "Winter Wonderland" that takes up six floors of the former G. Fox store in downtown Hartford.
Mr. Baldwin, who was head Santa at G. Fox for 13 years, said "On Saturdays and Sundays there can be as many as 13 Santas at work in different rooms at Winter Wonderland." But can't so many Santas prove confusing to young children? "Not really," he replied. "After all, Santa is magical and he can be in as many places as he wants to be. Look at him on Christmas Eve and Christmas morning."
The Santas at Winter Wonderland not only come in different shapes; they also come in different colors, and some of them speak two languages. "We have a few African-American Santa Clauses and several who are Spanish-speaking," said Mr. Baldwin. "And we have a Santa who is able to communicate in sign language."
But you won't find a woman Santa at Winter Wonderland. Or, so far as is known, anywhere else in Connecticut. "We tried female Santas about 20 years ago and the kids were furious," said Ms. Catlin, the owner of Leslie Photo Promotions in Berlin. "They know that Santa is a man. We tried females again once or twice but realized that it doesn't work because the kids get upset."
Mr. Baldwin said G. Fox, too, had tried using women as Santas. "But it didn't work out because it was impossible for them to disguise their voices," he said. "The store got some complaints and stopped using them."
That is not to say that women are not a part of the Christmas scene. "I remember how I was going into a shopping center a few years ago when I saw a man with a great white beard who I knew would make a great Santa," said Ms. Catlin. "I told him so and then I said to his wife, 'You'd make a great Mrs. Claus.' And they both agreed to do it." This year, the couple, Eugene and Trudy Pike, are Mr. and Mrs. Santa Claus at a shopping mall in Natick, Mass., which is one of Ms. Catlin's clients.
What qualifies a person to be Santa, or Mrs. Claus? "No. 1, you have to like children and obviously you have to be very outgoing," said Ms. Catlin. Then there's the physical appearance, and, Ms. Catlin said, "We make very thorough security and criminal checks on people we're considering. We have to be very careful as to who our Santas are."
Santas come from many walks of life. "We have teachers, actors, students, retirees and even a few postal workers," Ms. Catlin said.
Postal workers? During the busiest time of the year for the Postal Service? "Yes," Ms. Catlin said, "and they work as Santa while they're working for the Post Office."
Most Santas require some training. "You just don't put on a red suit and start saying 'Ho, ho, ho,' " said Mr. Baldwin. "Even after a day or two of training, our Santas get coached on the side their first day or two on the job. One of the most important things we tell them is that Santa Claus doesn't make any promises. It's best to say, 'I'll see what I can do.'
"And it's important that they read the situation between the children and their parents. I practice what I preach, and even after all these years of being a Santa, it's very satisfying when, after you've been talking with a child, a parent says, 'That was wonderful.' "
While Barbie dolls and Barbie accessories -- she's making a big comeback -- and action figures like Power Rangers the most requested items for boys and girls this year some requests made to Santa are particularly touching.
"One child about 5 years old told me that she didn't need anything and that what she wanted most was peace on earth," said Bill Grace, a retired I.B.M. manager and one of the Santas at Winter Wonderland who donates his salary to Habitat for Humanity, an organization that builds and repairs houses for people in need.
Bill Welch, a Santa at the Westfarms Mall, recalled a girl, also about 5, who said, "I just would like to be able to help feed the homeless and make them happy."
Some requests are difficult to handle. "I had one little girl who told me that her one wish for Christmas was to get her mother out of jail," Mr. Grace said.
And John Torunski of East Lyme, a long-time Santa at the New London Mall, said more and more children were asking him to please bring their parents back together. "It's very touching," said Mr. Torunski.
Perhaps the hardest-working Santa in the state is Logan Jackson, who has held court as the lone Santa in the Center Court of the Stamford Town Center for the last three years. "Logan is absolutely wonderful with kids and, with his white beard, he is Santa," said Al Messer, the general manager of the 130-store mall.
"Logan comes up from Tennessee and works seven days a week from 10 in the morning until 10 at night, and he loves it. We couldn't have a better Santa." With 6 children and 23 grandchildren, Mr. Jackson, a retired house painter, knows something about the younger set.
"He has an amazing patience," Mr. Messer said. Not to mention tremendous energy and endurance.
How does Mr. Jackson do it?
"If I get tired, I just look into the eyes of the little kids coming up to me, take a deep breath and say to myself, 'You can do it'," said Mr. Jackson, who estimates he sees between 500 and 600 children a day, along with more than a few teen-agers and even grownups, particularly in the evening.
If the demand for Santas has waned since the demise of the old-fashioned department store, some of the slack is being picked up elsewhere.
"In recent years we've been getting more calls for Santas to show up at corporate parties," Ms. Catlin said. "And there've been a lot of requests for Santas at house parties and on Christmas Eve. People will hide presents outside and tell Santa in advance where they are. Then when he arrives, he brings in the presents and passes them out to members of the family."
Lud Baldwin, who also supplies Santas, said that he, too, gets such requests.
"Some of the Santas we send out on Christmas Eve follow a route, from house to house, distributing gifts," he said.
Just like the Jolly Old Elf himself, but without the reindeer.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
For Duracell, a $70 Million, Self-Sufficient Hq

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THE opening late last month of Duracell International's new 310,000-square-foot, $70 million world headquarters in Bethel could ignite renewed interest in the once-popular corporate campus headquarters so self-sufficient that employees never left the premises from morning to night.
It is the only single-occupancy commercial building of its size to have been built in Connecticut in more than a decade. 
 There are similarities between the Duracell headquarters and such icons of corporate campus life in the 70's as American Can in Greenwich, Union Carbide in Danbury and Stauffer Chemical in Westport.
Like them, Duracell is in a fairly remote location, making on-site amenities necessary. It has its own cafeteria, sundries shop and two and half miles of outdoor jogging trails, and it looks out on a pristine country landscape. Conveniences of the 90's include automatic teller machines, a media center that telecasts local and CNN news and produces teleconferences within the building or internationally, and a fitness center with 27 stair-climbing machines, treadmills and rowing machines.
When the recession struck, none of the earlier single-occupancy buildings survived the shift in corporate fashion from sprawling campuses to tighter quarters in downtown business districts. Within a decade of opening, they and other buildings like them were sold and broken up into smaller rental components. In the case of Union Carbide, the building was sold and the company took a lease on 658,000 of the 1.2 million square feet for its own use.
Duracell believes it has been more circumspect. "We didn't suddenly expand, collecting hundreds of people from distant locations," said Gregg A. Dwyer, senior vice president, general counsel and secretary. Duracell's employees, formerly scattered through eight rented buildings in the Berkshire Office Park, were consolidated at the new headquarters on 48 acres of the same park.
By comparison, American Can's 625,000-square-foot headquarters was built on more than 300 acres, almost as large as as the whole 325-acre Berkshire park property. Its employees, uprooted from other areas, were devastated by the cost of housing along Connecticut's Gold Coast. The current average cost of a three-bedroom house in the northern Fairfield towns of Bethel, Danbury and Brookfield, near the new Duracell headquarters, is $150,000 to $200,000. Southern Fairfield prices begin at $250,000.
Mr. Dwyer touched on other differences. "Our business is notoriously noncyclical," he said. "We are not as vulnerable to economic events. I don't want to sound arrogant about how wonderful the battery business is, but we didn't even notice the recession and we did not downsize."
Company revenues from manufacturing in the United States, Britain, Belgium, Canada and Brazil exceeded $2 billion this year. Duracell distributes its batteries to 85 countries.
THE company has been in Bethel since 1974, when it employed 100 people. It now has 650 employees and town approval to build an addition of 150,000 square feet, hire up to 775 employees and enlarge its 750-car parking structure by 100 spaces.
Land costs and construction were financed by a consortium of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Bank Brussels Lambert, the First Fidelity Bank, the First Chicago Bank and the Bank of Boston, Duracell's landlords under a five-year lease.. Mr. Dwyer said the lease included an option to buy the property, but he declined to discuss its financial terms.
"From the start," said Herbert S. Newman, architect for the project, "Duracell told us that they wanted a building that could be rented if they ever moved out." The design lends itself to that purpose -- carried out in four so-called precincts dedicated to specific corporate divisions and linked by a broad, skylighted spine called Main Street, whose walls display a revolving collection of contemporary art from Galleri Seven in Danbury.
Built into the side of a hill, the long, angled building reveals itself gradually as it is approached along a winding drive. The exterior and some interior walls were built of 460,000 dark red bricks made with manganese that is a byproduct of Duracell's battery production. Half of the building materials contain recycled or reclaimed ingredients, including the landfill of rock excavated during site preparation and pulverized.
"We were impressed with Duracell's interest in an ecologically sensitive building," said Mr. Newman, who has won more than 50 awards for design excellence in 30 years. He heads the New Haven architectural firm of Herbert S. Newman and Partners and teaches at the Yale School of Architecture. "We used energy-efficient lighting and relied heavily on natural light from skylights and large windows," he said. "Nobody is far from a window, and the work stations along Main Street keep co-workers in sight and in touch, much like a sidewalk cafe."
Leda M. Pierce, senior designer at the Manhattan firm of Haines Lundberg Waehler, was responsible for the interior. "The challenge was meeting Duracell's requirement for using only nontoxic and recycled materials," she said. The results include ceramic tile in the cafeteria made of recycled glass, nontoxic carpeting and upholstery, as well as furniture made of woods that are not from endangered species.
A COMPANY policy of inclusiveness permeates every aspect of the building's design. There is no executive dining room, parking area or entrance. The cafeteria seats 250 people and its attractive decor rivals that of many fine restaurants.
During the planning period, 160 employees weighed ideas for the new headquarters. Individuality is evident in the casual attire of Duracell's employees; anyone in a suit, male or female, is likely to be a visitor.
As for the almost 200,000 square feet of space that Duracell left behind, it is available at $8 to $12 a foot, excluding real estate taxes, common charges and utilities. In addition to Duracell, the Berkshire Office Park is occupied by seven high-technology companies and a day-care center operated by Bright Horizons, a national chain. That leaves 125 acres available, priced from $75,000 to $200,000 an acre depending on location, topography and the amount of infrastructure provided by the park's owners, Richard, Greg and Roy Steiner, a father, son and nephew, respectively.
"We will build to suit," said George Walker, vice president of marketing and development for the park, "anything from 15,000 square feet to as large as Duracell."
Bethel, a typical small town with a population of 17,541 in 17 square miles, has a moderate property-tax rate of $18.56 per $1,000 of assessment at 70 percent of market value. This year, Duracell paid $180,008 in taxes on the steel framework erected a year ago.
While Bethel's assessor, Christina Maddocks, declined to speculate on the taxes that the company would pay now that the property was fully developed, she said that "they will absolutely be our biggest taxpayer, and there is no question that they will affect the mill rate downward."

HEADLINE: Why Not a Detroit 'Acropolis'?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Tribute to Ruin Irks Detroit" (news article, Dec. 10): 
 The good burghers of Detroit may indeed be irked by Camilo Jose Vergara's suggestion that the pre-Depression-era skyscrapers of downtown can be turned into an American Acropolis, but there is nothing unusual about decay producing the ruins and monuments of tomorrow.
With its relatively short history of building edifices, the United States has lacked the sort of imposing, time-worn monument found in other cultures. The controversy over the fate of downtown Detroit raises the question whether relics from the immediate industrial past such as abandoned and derelict factories, warehouses, office buildings, railway stations and the like can become authentic rivals to the royal tombs, medieval castles and Gothic cathedrals of other civilizations.
All too often the response is demolition, rendering the city a patchwork of weed-filled lots.
But the process of finding new meanings and values for old structures so objected to in Detroit is under way elsewhere. The conversion of old industrial sites into landscapes of consumption is apparent at Lowell National Historical Park in Massachusetts, Baltimore's Inner Harbor, New York's South Street Seaport and Penn's Landing in Philadelphia.
The Andy Warhol Museum is happily ensconced in an old mattress factory in Pittsburgh. Important recycled industrial-era sites soon coming on line include the Roebling wire rope factory complex in Trenton and the derelict Eastern State Penitentiary in Philadelphia.
In Philadelphia, where the scale of industrial dereliction is hard to grasp (65 percent of land zoned for industrial use lies abandoned), it is difficult to see how conversion of old industrial sites into condominiums, arts centers and sports bars make up for the lost industrial economy.
But it is also hard to see how official redevelopment plans based on tax-abatement enterprise zones and the like produce much more than the occasional lumberyard, foam rubber warehouse or sawdust-bagging plant to interrupt vistas of industrial decline.
Subsequent generations may well plan holidays around an educational trek through the North Philadelphia National Park of Deindustrialization or a visit to a Disney EntropicWorld in Detroit.
 
JAMES DICKINSON
Assoc. Prof. of Sociology
Rider College
Lawrenceville, N.J., Dec. 13, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2024 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Cyberstocks: Did You Miss Out?

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
THE little guy has missed out again, right?
Now that Internet stocks like Netscape have taken off into the cybersphere, it might seem that the big shots who got in early have made the instant fortunes, leaving everyone else in the dust. 
 History suggests, though, that nothing is further from the truth. Odds are, it is not too late to invest in the Internet, and it might even be far too early. If you jump in now, you could get soaked.
Look at it this way: when the auto business was born a century ago, investors faced hundreds of choices, including Ford, General Motors and Chrysler. If you had, by good fortune, bought stock in one of those three, you would be riding high now.
But as David L. Lewis, a professor of business history at the University of Michigan, points out, for every auto company that became a giant, "there were a couple of hundred that did not make it, and people lost a substantial amount of money." While you might have bought stock in General Motors, you could have just as easily picked, say, the U.S. Motor Corporation, which failed in 1911.
Now, too, with the Internet in its infancy, you would have to be clairvoyant to hitch on to the right Internet star.
Many are tempted to try, though. The world is abuzz over the Internet, the rapidly growing network that links personal computers all over the world. Bill Gates makes speeches about it, Business Week writes splashy cover stories about it and investors fall all over themselves to participate in what they view as technology's Second Coming.
Just ask Suzanne Bell, a small investor in Houston who bought stock in one start-up and uses the Internet to discuss her picks with others.
"Use your imagination," she admonishes the skeptics. "This stuff is big. The implications are phenomenal."
Phenomenal is certainly the word for stocks like Netscape Communications. "I wish I could have gotten Netscape when it was lower," sighed Ms. Bell, who, like most people, could not get the shares at their initial price of $28 in August. Leery of buying them at two or three times that price in the next few days, she passed up the stock only to watch it rise to $130.50 recently. That is down from its high of $174 -- many Internet stocks tumbled late last week -- but it's still hot.
Forrester Research estimates that the overall Internet market will explode from about $300 million today to $10 billion by 2000. While investors can no longer benefit from the gravity-defying run-ups of the first crop of new Internet issues, there will be plenty of chances.
"The central fear people have is they've missed out," said Roger B. McNamee of Integral Capital Partners, a venture capital firm in Palo Alto, Calif. Mr. McNamee dismisses such anxiety as foolish.
As the Internet develops, investors will be in a much better position to choose the investments that have the highest odds of paying off. As with any burgeoning industry, whether cars or biotechnology, the enthusiasm, and hype, are highest at the start. Investors might want to ignore the current mania and wait for the almost inevitable shakeout.
They will most likely get another chance to buy many of today's hot stocks at far lower prices, and they will also have plenty of opportunities later to buy equally attractive start-ups and established companies. Options for some of these stocks, like Netscape, do not even exist yet, making concentrated bets difficult. "It's just coming off the runway here," said Byron R. Wien, an investment strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company
Of course, it is hard not to envy all the people, usually company insiders and venture capitalists, who have already made enormous sums on offerings like Netscape, Uunet Technologies and Spyglass. But the scarcity of Internet stocks has led to the out-of-sight price rises typically seen in everything from tulips to biotech.
Take Netscape, which develops software that helps people use personal computers and modems to make their way around the Internet. Although Netscape is considered a fine little company, it isn't making any money yet on its products. But frenzied investors have already awarded the company a market value of $5 billion, about 120 times its sales over the last four quarters.
It is not alone. Netcom On-Line Communications, which helps people get onto the Internet, has a market value 38 times its sales. Spyglass Inc., which also develops software for navigating the Internet, goes for 136 times its tiny revenues. By contrast, Microsoft, which really does dominate its industry, has a market value of less than 8 times its $7 billion in revenue.
"The equity market has failed to differentiate between the extremely large overall market opportunity and the various business opportunities available to individual companies," warned Jonathan H. Cohen, an analyst with Smith Barney who recently started following some Internet stocks and recommends that investors steer clear.
At some point, the market will likely take a less rosy view of today's hot companies, probably when one of them stumbles or if profits take much longer to materialize than Wall Street expected. Investors would then be able to snatch up shares of a Netscape or a Spyglass at much lower prices.
That is what happened in biotechnology in the mid-80's -- and again in the early 90's. Investors realized that the spate of promising young companies would not be coming up with an instant cure for cancer or the common cold, and even those that eventually proved to be success stories were available a bargain-basement prices. Amgen, for one, lost roughly three quarters of its value by late 1984, the year after it went public. "If you had bought at the offering, you'd have a great investment," said Jim McCamant, editor of the Medical Technology Stock Letter in Berkeley, Calif. "But if you waited a year or so, you'd have a better investment."
And Wall Street has not forgotten the bruising it took on biotech. Even now that many companies have started earning more money, the stocks have been slow to recover. The American Stock Exchange biotechnology index, for example, which began in October 1991, still has not matched its earlier highs.
IF you think Internet stocks are overpriced, it may be tempting to bet on a price drop by selling them short -- selling borrowed shares in the hope of replacing them later with shares bought for less. But in addition to the practical difficulties of finding stock to borrow, investors could lose vast sums if the stocks continue to defy gravity.
"You can get nailed," warned Michael Murphy, who writes the Overpriced Stock Service, a newsletter in Half Moon Bay, Calif., though he still recommends that sophisticated investors sell Internet stocks short. But because so many portfolio managers will keep buying simply because a stock is rising, he said, "you cannot afford to stay short."
The smartest strategy is probably to sit out the current buying frenzy. No matter how big a market the Internet may become, it is not going to develop fully overnight. In fact, Bob Metcalfe, who invented the Ethernet, one of the first "local area networks" for office computers, said the Internet faced some serious obstacles.
For one thing, it is difficult to measure how many people actually use the network and to protect companies' private computer networks from outsiders. Also, no one can predict how well the network, and the telephone lines, can handle the growing volume of users, or when a safe way will be found to sell things on the Internet and make it a commercial success. While companies that solve these problems may eventually make good investments, overall progress could be slow.
Also, as in any field, investors may discover that the businesses that seem the most promising at first lack long-term potential because competition drives away potential profits. Many new companies, for example, simply help people connect to the Internet. But as giants like AT&T, MCI and I.B.M. muscle their way into that business, start-ups like Netcom, Uunet Technologies and Psinet could get shoved out of the way unless they are nimble.
If investors have their heart set on buying new issues, there will be plenty to choose from in coming years. Venture capitalists are "going to plant Internet companies like Johnny Appleseed," predicted Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a Boston technology research firm.
Promising possibilities include Raptor Systems in Waltham, Mass., and Checkpoint Software Technologies Ltd. in Israel, which focus on keeping interlopers out of corporate networks. Other candidates include RSA Data Security Inc. in Redwood City, Calif., which scrambles data so prowlers cannot decipher it, and companies involved in new electronic Internet-friendly forms of money, like First Virtual Holdings in San Diego or Cybercash in Reston, Va.
But only a few will make it. "The shakeout is coming," warned Mr. Anderson, who said the industry would begin a painful consolidation as soon as next year. It's a stage every new industry, no matter how revolutionary, goes through.
The auto industry was just one example. Investors learned the same lesson when the personal-computer industry got off the ground in the early 1980's. While investing early in Compaq Computer would have made someone a fortune, there were plenty of disappointments: Vector Graphics, for example, or Eagle Computer, both of which went bankrupt within a few years. "In the early stages, you have to avoid kidding yourself and thinking you know how it's going to turn out," said Mr. Murphy, the newsletter writer.
In fact, among the biggest mistakes investors can make is thinking they can spot the right company. "My ability to name a winner is zilch," said Eric T. Miller, chief investment strategist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "For the average person to try to pick individual stocks, good luck."
Buying several stocks may be the only way to get better odds. Robert Natale, director of equity research at Standard & Poor's, notes that the odds of hitting oil are much greater if you drill 10 wells instead of 3. "What you're counting on is the one or two gushers to counter the risk and make up for all the losers," he said. He says that if investors are unwilling to pick at least 10 stocks, and bet that one of them will rise far more than tenfold, they would be better off choosing a diversified technology mutual fund.
THE safest way to play the Internet could be to bet on companies that have established themselves in other areas of technology. They have already demonstrated an ability to understand technology markets and, more important, make a profit from them. Many are already setting their sights on the Internet. "Your success ratio, in our opinion, will be much higher," said John Force, the manager of the PBHG Technology and Communications Fund.
Like Mr. Force, Ronald E. Elijah, manager of the Robertson Stephens Value and Growth Fund, is staying away from pure Internet stocks to search for companies that provide the nuts and bolts and related software for the development of the network. He likens the Internet to the gold rush, when it wasn't most miners who made money, but the people selling to the miners.
Among the hardware and software companies trying to profit from the Internet are Cisco Systems, Ascend Communications, Sun Microsystems, Bay Networks, U.S. Robotics, Intuit, Adobe Systems and, yes, Microsoft. Some, like Sun, have already seen their stocks soar, but others have yet to take off. While investors would be wrong to consider buying the stocks of these companies only in terms of their potential to capitalize on the Internet, many will benefit as much from the new technology as any start-up, and possibly even more. What's more, if the Internet explosion does not pan out as expected, these companies still have their other business to fall back on.
The best advice may be to relax and resist giving into the panic that you're missing out on it all. "Those people who want instant gratification are going to get clobbered," said Mr. Anderson of the Yankee Group.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Clinton's Tax Crackdown Would Hit Investors, Too

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
WHEN the Treasury Department proposed strict new tax rules on Dec. 7 -- Pearl Harbor Day -- big companies and Wall Street firms quickly cried sneak attack. But while the Administration's move is aimed mostly at those groups, someone else who will be caught up in the combat made nary a peep: individual investors.
Many of the proposals center on that puzzling investment known as preferred stock. These securities give investors first dibs on dividends, ahead of holders of common stock. If a company gets into trouble, preferreds give investors a claim on assets that also outranks that of common shareholders, although not that of bond owners. And because preferreds do not return any principal, they generally yield higher dividends than do bonds. 
 This year, roughly $15 billion of these part-stock, part-bond investments have been issued, making for $80 billion that is now outstanding. That makes the market about equal to the gross domestic product of the Czech Republic, and Wall Streeters say it is a legitimate as well as big source of capital.
This market reacted swiftly to the tax proposals, which the White House says will raise $4 billion by 2005. J. P. Morgan, Monsanto and Pacific Telesis withdrew sales totaling $700 million in issues whose tax advantages were suddenly in doubt. These include some of the popular new preferreds, ones carrying exotic names like TOPrS (pronounced "toppers").
And preferred stocks that are already out there have fallen since the announcement. On Nov. 30, Chemical Bank's 8 3/8 percent preferred, which is callable in June 1997, traded at 26 1/4. At Friday's close, it was trading at 25 1/2. Issues callable in a decade or more are bearing even more damage. Florida Power and Light's 6.98 percent preferred sold for 1082/10 on Nov. 30, for instance. On Friday, after thin but volatile trading, it closed at 104 5/8.
In fact, the preferred-stock market is as frozen as a Midwestern winter or the current state of the Washington budget talks. "It's been very slow," said Jeanne L. Mockard, a manager of two mutual funds at Putnam Investments that specialize in preferred stock. "Nobody wants to sell at the new depressed prices for preferred, and nobody wants to buy because the tax advantages may now be diminished."
The Treasury's plan is a two-front offensive. It attacks companies' tax benefits both as investors and as issuers of investments.
Companies can now deduct from taxable income 70 percent of the dividends they receive on the stocks they own in another company, as long as they don't own more than 20 percent of it. Because the investor-company will be taxed on the dividends it pays its own shareholders, who will in turn pay taxes on those distributions, the rule prevents punitively high taxation of corporate investments, its proponents say.
But the Treasury, saying this deal is too generous, wants to cut the dividend deduction to 50 percent. That will make these investments less alluring to companies.
What about individual investors? Unlike companies, they pay full taxes on preferred dividends -- that is why companies are by far the biggest investors in the plain-vanilla preferreds that make up most of the market. But some individuals do buy them, and they may see their choices shrink if the proposals take root. Wall Streeterssay that companies will simply issue less preferred stock if their biggest customers get a smaller tax break.
The second part of the Treasury proposal starts with the fact that Wall Street has always regarded stocks and bonds as just two different ways of raising money. But dividends paid out on stocks -- common and preferred -- are not tax-deductible for the issuing corporation, while payments made to bondholders are.
The mad scientists of Wall Street finance, however, have managed to come up with a new instrument -- a special kind of preferred stock -- that gives the issuer a big tax deduction as does a bond and pays investors high yields.
IN these exotic flavors, like Merrill Lynch's TOPrS (trust-originated preferred securities), and Goldman Sachs's MIPS (monthly income preferred securities), companies create a trust or other structure. This intermediary issues the preferred stock called TOPrS, say, and then lends the proceeds to the company. The company makes interest payments to the intermediary for the loan, and the intermediary uses that cash to pay the dividends on the TOPrS. Because the company enjoys a tax break, it can afford to be more generous in the payout.
But the Clinton Treasury contends that these exotic instruments are tax loopholes -- ownership interests disguised as debt. To close them, the Administration proposes banning tax benefits for instruments that do not mature within 40 years. TOPrS and MIPS run afoul of this "Methuselah" rule. The bond-like portion of TOPrS, for instance, matures in 49 years.
As with the plan to trim the dividend deduction, this tighter tax rule will mean that fewer companies will issue these arcane securities. But for individuals, the proposal's impact will be far greater.
The reason is that, with dividends as much as 1 percentage point higher than a company's bonds, MIPS and TOPrS have become best sellers among investors, especially older people. For example, although Pacific Telesis's canceled sale of $500 million in TOPrS never reached the pricing stage, the securities would have likely carried an interest rate of 7.75 percent, the company says, instead of the 6.9 percent for Pacific Telesis bonds.
That's a big difference. At 7.75 percent, money is doubled in a bit more than nine years, instead of 10.5 years, as with 6.9 percent.
Also popular with individuals is the price tag. Even though the average purchase is $15,000, the investments are often priced low, like $25 a share, rather than at the somewhat forbidding $1,000 and up denominations of bonds.
Are the Treasury proposals here to stay? Republican leaders strongly oppose the measure, although everything in Washington is on the table for the budget negotiations. But Robert Flaherty, president of Flaherty & Crumrine, a fund manager in Pasadena, Calif., that specializes in preferred stock, says that even if the tax rules are changed, investors and companies will change their behavior and the $4 billion in anticipated tax revenue will never appear.
"Somebody over there in Washington has a bee in his bonnet," Mr. Flaherty said. "There will be a lot of fuss and they'll wind up not collecting a nickel in new taxes."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
State Pulls Plug On Trade Center

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
To hear the state tell it, Harlem had ample opportunity to make a go of its proposed international trade center. After seven years of false starts, the state says, Gov. George E. Pataki had no choice but to pull the plug.
But according to those leading the project, the trade center was well under way; Governor Pataki simply took the $64 million in Regional Bank funds back for his budget. "He's got a budget to close," said Representative Charles B. Rangel. "If this was happening in some other community that was strongly Republican, this would not be happening." 
 The center, which was to occupy state-owned land on 125th Street at Lenox Avenue, was initially proposed in 1978 as an office, hotel and convention center and a centerpiece of Harlem's economic renewal. But the state says there was a lack of private interest in the project.
"After seven years, five extensions and $48 million that has been sitting there, they have not demonstrated that this is a viable project," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "We have decided that the money can be better spent right now."
He said the money would finance economic development projects in the metropolitan area, including a Metropolitan Economic Revitalization Fund that will try to leverage $250 million for distressed communities.
But Percy Sutton, chairman of the trade center's corporation, says he had commitments for more than 70,000 square feet of space at the center -- from Motown Records, Equitable Insurance and Essence Magazine, among others -- that would have paid for the remaining $18 million needed to get the complex constructed. He says the project was held up by factors outside its control, such as a troubled real estate market, a falling out with the center's original developer and the state's failure to transfer the land to the center.
The state's decision was announced three days before a racially motivated arson attack on 125th Street killed eight people, heightening tensions over economic issues in Harlem. It also comes at a time when local Democrats have been exploring nonpartisan avenues to economic development.
Mr. Gargano insists that the Governor's decision to take the money out of the trade center is no reflection of his larger commitment to economic development in Harlem. He pointed out that the state has committed $100 million to the Federal Empowerment Zone over the next 10 years. But Mr. Rangel is quick to point out that the Governor has yet to actually sign such a commitment.
As for the future of the trade center site, Mr. Gargano says the state hopes to develop it as retail space. But Mr. Sutton says he is not yet willing to concede defeat. "This is economic racism," he said. "Whether under this Governor or another Governor, we're going to build this trade center."
 ROBIN POGREBIN
 
TIMELINE
A Trade Center, From Start to Finish
 
Gov. George E. Pataki recently decided to cancel $64 million pledged to develop the Harlem International Trade Center. This is a brief history of the failed project:
 
1978 Center is first proposed.
 
1988 Port Authority allocates $50 million for project. Harlem International Trade Center Corporation, a subsidiary of Harlem Urban Development Corporation, is formed.
 
Jan. 1990 Saady/Milstein/Harlem Partners is named as developer.
 
Dec. 1990 $35 million in tax-exempt bonds sold to help finance center.
 
1991-1992 Federal Government declines to rent space in center.
 
1993 Developer is dismissed. City declines to rent space in center.
 
1994 Project scaled back to $80 million from $135 million.
 
Dec. 1995 Governor Pataki withdraws financing.
 
Source: Empire State Development Corporation

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
How Do You Solve a Problem Like Cityspire?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Cityspire, at 150 West 56th Street, is the skyscraper that whistled in the wind -- until some decorative slats were removed from its cooling tower. But the building's other problems have proved harder to solve.
When Cityspire's tower topped out 11 feet over its permitted height in 1987, city officials penalized the developer, Ian Bruce Eichner, by ordering three floors of studios for dance companies added atop what was supposed to have been a covered pedestrian arcade midblock between 55th and 56th Streets. 
 Today, the glass and granite Cityspire is still 11 feet too tall and is occupied by luxury offices and condominiums with stellar views. But the arcade remains unfinished -- and the studios were never started. Both languished when the recession forced the project into bankruptcy.
The building's current owners and the foundation that runs the adjacent City Center are now proposing a new solution. They would complete the arcade but, instead of adding studios over it, would renovate outmoded studios in the center. If the Planning Commission approved, both could be done next year.
When Cityspire was planned a decade ago, critics warned that the 73-floor behemoth would dwarf two neighboring cultural landmarks, Carnegie Hall and City Center. The critics were not mollified by the city's requirement for the arcade; they were outraged anew over the tower's height violation and then turned apoplectic over the city's solution.
"It's bizarre, to say the least, that the remedy for a case of overbuilding would be a proposal for additional building," said Joseph Rose, then chairman of Community Board 5. He also said the space was ill-suited for studios.
Today, Mr. Rose is in a better position to do something about Cityspire. He is chairman of the Planning Commission and is awaiting a formal application detailing the new plan. "The old deal made no sense," Mr. Rose said recently. "Now the obvious is being acknowledged at last."
Supporters of the new plan include the city's Cultural Affairs Department, which oversees the studio project because City Center is city-owned. Cityspire originally acquired the center's air rights in exchange for $6 million given to opera and ballet institutions, an addition of 10,000 square feet to the center and a promise to make $6 million in renovations, though not all the work was done.
Howard Goldman, Cityspire's lawyer, said the new plan would create 12,160 square feet of "far superior rehearsal space," nearly double the old plan, with better layouts, much higher ceilings, dressing rooms and a new City Center entrance on the arcade.
The unfinished arcade is a blot on 55th Street, next to the center's Moorish facade and opposite a canopied entrance to the Rihga Royal Hotel. Piles of pigeon droppings and trash lie inside the chain-link fence with its locked gate, barbed razor wire and plywood panels. About the only thing missing is a snarling junkyard dog. "It's been a long struggle," said Lois Framheim, director of the City Center 55th Street Foundation. "We have been living with a real eyesore." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Five Candidates Scramble for Millard's City Council Seat

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
On paper, the City Council's Fifth District is heavily Democratic, but Charles Millard, a Republican, snatched the seat in 1991. He quit this month when Mayor Giuliani named him president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
Now there is a scramble to fill the vacancy. 
 Last week, five candidates filed nominating petitions in an effort to qualify for the ballot in the special election on Jan. 16. Two of them failed to file the required number of signatures but are challenging the requirement in court.
The law bars traditional party names on the ballot, so candidates make up their own designations. But both the Republican and Democratic parties are very much involved.
The Republicans, with only 6 other seats in the 51-member Council, are eager to keep this toehold. They have teamed up with the Liberal Party to support Judith G. Marcus, a top aide to Mr. Millard and his Democratic predecessor, Robert Dryfoos. She is counting on the contacts she has built over 14 years as a problem-solver on the Upper East Side, working on everything from closing brothels to adding bus service.
She is the only Republican, and the only woman, in the race in a district where female voters outnumber men 3 to 2.
Democratic leaders back A. Gifford Miller, a top aide to United States Representative Carolyn B. Maloney. Mr. Miller is asking voters to send a message against the conservative Republican policies of Speaker Newt Gingrich and Gov. George E. Pataki, which he says hurt the city.
A dark horse is Andrew N. Schiff, a primary care doctor at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, who is concerned about health care issues. Two other candidates, George N. Spitz and Samuel D. Morell, have often run for local office but never won. Neither filed the 2,356 signatures required, but they have filed a joint lawsuit in Federal court opposing the requirement.
All five seek public financing. Ms. Marcus and Mr. Miller say they expect to reach the maximum of $124,000 in private and public funds.
The Upper East Side's many wealthy residents have earned it the nickname the Silk Stocking District, but people in the eastern portion are often of more modest means. Politicians call it the Nylon Stocking District.
Although Democrats account for 56 percent of the district's 77,000 voters, it has produced a string of liberal Republican winners. Independent voters account for 23 percent and Republicans 20 percent.
With no other contests, a low turnout is expected. "The victor," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Democrat, "will be the candidate with the best organizing skills."
For years, the Manhattan Republican organization has been led by Roy M. Goodman, and for years Mr. Goodman has been re-elected to the State Senate. The organization has also helped elect John A. Ravitz to the Assembly and Mr. Millard and Andrew Eristoff to the Council.
Whatever the outcome, more battles over the Council seat are scheduled in the next 22 months. The victor on Jan. 16 will serve until the general election next November; the e winner of that election will serve the rest of the term but will come up for re-election in November 1997. Both November races may have primaries. BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;
2 Officials Suspended, Accused of Using Jobs for Personal Gain

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The state has suspended two top officials of the agency that runs Roosevelt Island, pending an investigation of complaints by present and former workers that the officials had used their positions for personal gain. Both officials denied doing anything improper.
Several leaders on the island, including an agency board member and a tenant representative, have defended the officials and have attributed the charges to workers disgruntled over labor and contract issues. 
 The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal suspended Barry Chafetz as vice president for operations of the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation and Tom Sloan as director of facilities on Dec. 4. The suspensions are with pay. A spokesman for the state, Harry Ryttenberg, said he expected an inspector general to complete an inquiry "in a week or so."
Workers employed by the corporation have accused Mr. Chafetz of using other employees to work on his home in Queens. They accused Mr. Sloan of taking agency equipment and supplies in his private car.
Last week, Mr. Chafetz said that he had hired agency workers to repair and renovate his home but that they worked on weekends and he has check stubs to prove he paid them. "I welcome this investigation," he said. "I hope the investigation moves quickly so that my name can be cleared as soon as possible."
Mr. Sloan, whose telephone is unlisted, could not be reached for comment. But associates said he has denied taking anything and one said Mr. Sloan used his own car to deliver goods to work sites because no agency truck was available.
"I can't in my wildest dreams imagine Barry Chafetz stealing," said Ronald Vass, a member of the corporation's board. "He's too fine a person, totally competent and totally devoted. The loss of that man to the island would be devastating. It's got to be part of a revenge thing." Tim Johns, a leader in the Westview/ Island House Task Force, a tenants group, called the accusations against Mr. Chafetz "all horsefeathers."
"He may be brusque, but he's a straight arrow," Mr. Vass said. "He's been set up. I think the union's behind it." Local 32B-32J of the Building Service Employees Union, which represents workers on the island, did not respond to calls seeking comment.
Mr. Chafetz, who has been with the corporation for a decade, handles contract negotiations, which have been difficult lately because of reductions in state aid. Mr. Sloan, a relative newcomer to the corporation, and a former military man, has criticized workers for excessive slack time and has pushed for more productivity. BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Visions From the Great Bureaucracy

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
ABOUT 6:30 A.M. every working day, a van arrives at a Sanitation Department garage to test 15 workers for drug use, fulfilling a controversial Federal law. Joseph Miller, the program's supervisor, is generally surprised by the reaction. "Many sanitation workers like the random drug testing," he says. "Think about it: they work in pairs, on a truck. How would you like to have a partner who's drunk or high on something? We get comments like, 'It's about time; it's a wonderful program.' "
Those on the front lines of the city's bureaucracy bear witness that municipal work has its quirks and insights. Last week, seven city workers were lifted, however briefly, from rounds of responsibility to tell a few of their stories -- and to receive $7,500 Sloan Public Service Awards from the Fund for the City of New York. 
 JoAnn Jacobs, a fire marshal, is part of a new unit that counsels young arsonists. She has plenty of stories about the career difficulties she has faced on the way -- some more surprising than others. In 1982, after a legal fight and a special test, she became the first black woman to be hired as a New York City firefighter. "At my retirement," she says, with a gentle, almost fond, rancor, "I'm sure some guy's going to raise his glass and say, 'You still didn't pass the test.'
"And I," she says with a laugh, "will have to punch him out."
But she didn't anticipate the amicable rivalries between truck companies, which break down the doors and pull out the people, and engine companies, which "merely" man the hoses.
And she didn't know, when she moved up to fire marshal and had to give up her uniform, that she would miss it so much. "The firefighter has always been perceived positively. They run into poor people's burning buildings as quickly as rich people's burning buildings. By taking off the uniform, I lost that." But she never lost her humor. "I really loved wearing the uniform," she continues, "but not on the train: they think you're a conductor. And for heaven's sake, don't go to the Brooklyn Museum in it: you look like a security guard."
And for Frank Vardy, a demographer for the City Planning Department, work is collecting the facts and figures that turn the metropolis into a series of small towns, and history into stories -- a talent that started early. His father was born in Ireland in 1896 and came to New York. He drove a truck for the American Can Company. And he played semipro baseball.
"He'd been all over the city in the course of playing baseball, mostly in places that have been built on now," says Mr. Vardy, who remembers tootling around in his dad's '36 Packard, listening to accounts of Lindbergh's great ticker tape parade, and Buffalo Bill Cody riding through town on his white horse.
But Mr. Vardy's vision of the past doesn't eclipse his delight in the present. "Sure, I can reminisce about other eras," he says. "But the current era is as good as any. This town was made by people, by immigrants, and it's great to watch these new immigrants change them, and be changed by the city. They become New Yorkers!"
 
MARILYN RICHTER, 46
TITLE: Deputy Chief of General Litigation for the Law Department
SALARY: about $80,000
RESPONSIBILITIES: Defends city policy and city managers in court.
HOW SHE SEES IT: "City officials work under extremely difficult circumstances. You're helping them exercise the discretaion they need to do their jobs. Litigation is often not the best way to resolve disputes; it often exacerbates some of the underlying emotional issues. You see this in employment discrimination cases; there's a lot of emotional anger. Litigation doesn't seem to heal that,it seems to make that worse. I think we've become too litigious a society. I think some of the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms that people have been experimenting with are a good idea."
 
JOANN JACOBS, 44
TITLE: Fire Marshal
SALARY: about $54,000
RESPONSIBILITIES: As part of Junior Firesetters Program, counsels child arsonists. Was first black woman to be hired as New York City firefighter.
HOW SHE SEES IT: "You go to a party, say, and people say, 'What do you do?' And you either get skepticism or the guys want to arm-wrestle you. I learned to just say I work for the city. They say that with these firesetters, there's no economic pinpoint. It happens across all classes - but a lot of the families we see are black or Hispanic. I get a real kick out of being in this unit; I can establish a rapport with the mothers. And I think it helps, having someone that looks like them ringing the doorbell."

It's not even a question of money; it's a social thing. When you provide all these things, you're motivating homeless people to think of themselves differently, to change their own lives. You're socializing them into the life of the city. New York is very progressive. We want to do right. We do have this vision of a city for everybody. And when it doesn't happen, there's a controversy."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Haiti Takes the Next Big Step

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
HE is not the man whom officials in Washington had hoped to see succeed Jean-Bertrand Aristide. But everything seems to indicate Haitians will elect Rene Preval as their new President in voting today -- which automatically means the United States now has a considerable investment in his future success.
 
The Honeymoon's Over
 The balloting comes after two months of friction in relations between the Clinton Administration and Mr. Aristide. After the year-long honeymoon that followed Mr. Aristide's restoration to power in October 1994, the two countries have recently had very public disagreements about issues like privatizing state companies and returning more than 160,000 pages of documents seized by American troops from the headquarters of the military and paramilitary groups here. 
 A calm and fair election with a respectable turnout would help arrest that decline. The primary goal of American policy here has always been to carry out a peaceful transfer of power from Mr. Aristide to a democratically elected successor in the presidency -- something that would be new in Haiti's turbulent 190-year history. A credible vote today is obviously essential to that process.
Mr. Preval's ascension comes as little surprise to Haitians: He has been Mr. Aristide's Prime Minister and is popularly regarded as the President's alter ego. Washington's favorite Haitian politician, Evans Paul, the former mayor of Port-au-Prince, was eliminated from the succession picture in the chaotic and widely-criticized parliamentary elections held here in June.
But neither Mr. Preval nor American policy makers will have long to savor his expected triumph.
Even before Mr. Aristide departs office on Feb. 7, the new President will have to begin negotiations with Haiti's foreign creditors and allies about economic reforms and perhaps also an extension, at a much reduced level and for a brief period, of the United Nations military presence here.
"This remains a very poor and troubled country with an extremely weak government structure," said one diplomat here. "The new President is going to have to confront all of the same problems that faced Aristide, but without the very important advantage of being Aristide and having the authority and prestige he enjoys."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why Beijing Is So Afraid Of Mr. Wei

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
ASK average Chinese to name their most important goal and the answer will be: a good job; wealth; a visa to America or Europe; more wealth, or a good education.
Way down the list, perhaps just below dental work, would be: a democracy movement to change China. 
 In a nation that has put virtually all thoughts of politics aside, why then is the Communist leadership so afraid of Wei Jingsheng?
The pro-democracy campaigner, who got a 14-year prison sentence last week at a trial in which the verdict was decided not by a judge but by the Communist Party leadership, has never organized a march, never declared an opposition party and does not believe, as Mao did, that power comes out of the barrel of a gun.
 
Takes One to Know One
 But the crux of Mr. Wei's threat may be deceptively simple: it takes a group of aging revolutionaries to spot another one.
Sixty-five years ago, after hundreds of Communists had been rounded up and shot in Shanghai and Mao Zedong's tiny band of guerrillas was an encampment of gloom deep in the hills of southern China, Mao sent round a letter exhorting his commanders to action. He looked out across the wreckage of the Communist movement and saw a vision of victory:
"All China is littered with dry faggots which will soon be aflame," he wrote, "The saying, 'A single spark can start a prairie fire,' is an apt description of how the current situation will develop.
"We need only look at the strikes of workers, the uprisings by the peasants, the mutinies of soldiers and the strikes of students which are developing in many places to see that it cannot be long before a 'spark' kindles 'a prairie fire.' "
Today China may be another tinderbox and Wei Jingsheng the dreaded spark of a new political revolution.
A wrenching and chaotic transition has already begun here. Though parts of China's economy are booming, a huge mass of state industries with 110 million workers is stagnating or collapsing. Each month reports of strikes, labor actions and peasant unrest drift into Beijing from the provinces. Drug trafficking and lawlessness reign in broad sections of the country.
Party leaders this fall announced that they would rescue only 1,000 of the most important state industries, like aviation, petrochemicals and steel, and let the others -- there are 14,000 large and medium-sized state enterprises -- die, merge or "go to the sea," the new Chinese euphemism for privatization.
 
The Anger Out There
 The new year may bring a high tide of bankruptcies in the public sector and a flood of newly unemployed Chinese, resentful that their cradle-to-grave rice bowl is crumbling even as Communist Party cadres -- identifiable by their wealth -- skim state bank accounts to subsidize a privileged life style.
China's leaders, because they have access to the truth, know that millions of workers are now idle; millions more have been laid off. Hidden unemployment, Nanjing University recently estimated, could be as high as 14 percent among the urban workers and number of jobless rural laborers is approaching 150 million.
An international bank official, who has been traveling to China for more than a decade, returned from the countryside recently, telling a reporter "how much anger is out there."
Today's Communist Party chiefs are students of the Communist disintegration around the world. They have witnessed how one man, Lech Walesa, unhinged the Polish Communists when the shipyard workers of Gdansk rallied behind him. They saw how Russia's miners destabilized Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his final days.
The hard-line leaders here, who dispatched tanks and machine gunners to snuff out China's democracy uprising in 1989, are also watching as the rulers of South Africa and South Korea support criminal prosecutions against former rulers, especially those who have blood on their hands.
 
Message and Messenger
 Wei Jingsheng's message that the Chinese have an inalienable right to democracy may not seem profound or revolutionary to a Western ear. But in the Chinese context, Mr. Wei, 45, projects a charismatic fearlessness and speaks a compelling evangelism of freedom from corruption and repression. The Politburo is loath to expose 1.2 billion Chinese to such a message.
Many Chinese last week said they believe it is unlikely that Mr. Wei will serve out his full sentence, coming as it does at the end of the era of Deng Xiaoping, China's 91-year-old paramount leader. It was Mr. Deng who first recognized the dangerous nature of Mr. Wei and developed a personal animus toward him. From 1978 to 1979, Mr. Wei took advantage of a period of public debate about democracy to attack Mao, the Communist Party and the whole Leninist system, something that remains dear to Mr. Deng's heart.
For his sins, Mr. Wei has already spent 15 years in jail.
The future of China after Mr. Deng remains nebulous, but many Chinese believe that a new debate will then begin. Mr. Wei may finally get his chance to speak to an audience larger than his jailers.

HEADLINE: YANKEE COME BACK;
American Money Makes the Whole World Sing

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
ONCE again, American guns, carried by American soldiers, are heading into a distant fray, their reception in Bosnia at best uncertain. Memories of Somalia and, still, Vietnam, haunt every military venture overseas.
American butter, spread by American corporations investing abroad at a record pace, has meanwhile never been so widely welcomed. Although United States battleships and B-52's have in many places overstayed their welcome, Boeings filled with business executives and Commerce Department aides can land almost anywhere, even at Noi Bai Airport in Hanoi. 
 The new spirit has spread so thoroughly and rapidly, but with so little comment, that it's easy to forget how recently the United States was seen as an economic Godzilla. Nobody talks about Coca-Colonization anymore -- "Coke welcomes you to Hanoi," say a pair of signs in the shape of giant bottles bracketing the airport highway -- and seldom are Yankees bearing briefcases told to go home.
 
More Jobs at Home
 As most economists agree, direct foreign investment, as distinct from portfolio investment in stocks and bonds, generally raises demand for American goods and services and creates jobs and wealth back home. Although some foreign spending has shifted jobs abroad, most goes to penetrate overseas markets.
In the first nine months of this year, American direct investment abroad was running at a record $74 billion annual rate, more than double the 1992 pace. By now, the world's thirst for American investment is taken for granted, so much so that exceptions seem downright quaint.
When noisy Indian nationalists recently halted construction of a $3 billion American power plant and health inspectors shut New Delhi's first Kentucky Fried Chicken, nobody in other countries applauded. Even many Indians snickered. "The Tale of Two Flies," they called the Kentucky Fried Chicken case, noting that by local standards, a restaurant with so few deserved to be celebrated, not punished.
The rest of the world is competing for American capital, to finance factories, public works, telecommunications, technology transfers and jobs. This nation's capitalists are eager to oblige, and not just in countries recuperating from Communism or rambunctious self-reliance.
American products and culture are the rage everywhere. In Japan, consumers allied themselves with the United States Government in pressing officials to open markets. More and more Japanese are learning to eat at McDonald's, shop at Toys 'R' Us and strike sullen, slouching poses in clothing from the first two Gaps, which opened in September.
Western Europe -- which American executives, policymakers and journalists were calling Fortress Europe just a few years ago -- has absorbed by far the most American capital and the greatest absolute increases. Even the largest funeral home chains in France and England have been bought by a Houston-based company determined to sell Europeans the flashy, overengineered coffins that Americans crave. Mon Dieu!
And to think of all the trouble the world's revolutionaries and intellectuals took to paint foreign investment in general, American in particular, as colonialism in another ravenous form. Back when banana republics weren't just outfitters for expeditions to shopping mall food courts, they often handed over their natural resources on foreigners' terms. Lenin's description of foreign investment as economic imperialism captured and colored the outlooks of many emerging nations.
Europeans, guided by the likes of Charles de Gaulle, resisted American investment on cultural and political as well as economic grounds. "The Common Market has become a new Far West for American businessmen," the French journalist Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber wrote in "The American Challenge," published in 1968. "Their investments do not so much involve a transfer of capital as an actual seizure of power."
French and British universities provided a link to leaders and intellectuals in the developing world, steeping them in socialism and anti-Americanism while American universities provided technical skills.
In the 1980's, however, foreign investment was flowing so strongly into the United States that many Americans themselves went nationalist. First they feared the flood of Arab petrodollars. Then they were vexed by Japan's superyen, which bought up the Pebble Beach golf course, Hollywood studios and even Rockefeller Center. Americans demanded barriers, even though the prices were so crazed that the slogan among many deal makers became, "I have met the greater fool, and he speaks Japanese."
 
Japan's Retreat
 The Japanese are still taking their losses, the Europeans just starting to make many of their American acquisitions profitable. And the United States has supplanted a retreating Japan as the major font of foreign investment. No other country has capitalized so well on the political and philosophical turns of the late 1980's.
In China, Bill Gates can do what Warren Christopher often can't, which is to receive a warm smile and hearty clasp from President Jiang Zemin (followed by a decree making Windows the nation's software standard). In Vietnam, where the United States lifted an embargo on trade and investment last year, Coca-Cola is already opening its first bottling plant, Mobil is exploring for oil, Caterpillar is leasing equipment and Otis Elevator is busy with installations in new buildings.
But the failure of socialism and the ebbing of fears dating to the colonial era only go part way toward explaining America's new popularity. Many countries are adopting American corporations (calling them multinational has become redundant) as their industrial models. Asian executives go for business training at Stanford, Latin Americans favor the Ivy League and M.I.T., and British and French universities teach American management skills.
Norbert Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank, recently wrote in Die Welt, Germany's leading newspaper, that English should become Europe's second language. Some diplomats protested, he said, but scientists and business people have already made English their universal tongue. These include even the French, he added, "which was impossible to imagine 10 or 15 years ago." Mr. Walter is also on the board of The English Theater in Frankfurt, which recently presented the shamelessly American "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding."
Not that the surge in investment always benefits both sides of the deal. American companies sell drugs abroad that fail safety tests here, foul the environment and deal with apparel contractors who use child labor.
Among American workers, tens, probably hundreds of thousands have watched their automobile, apparel and electronics jobs moved to Latin America and Asia. Companies are even farming out software writing to India.
 
Still Targets
 Instead of raising the alarm about foreigners investing in the United States, politicians now search for scapegoats among countries where America itself is spending -- a hunt certain to gather urgency once the next recession hits.
In some places, Americans still make inviting targets. Not even the latest innovations in combining shampoo and creme rinse have shaken Muslim fundamentalists from defining the righteous state as one clean of American influence. But even Cuba's Fidel Castro, on his recent trip to New York, shucked his combat fatigues for the let's-make-a-deal look. To meet with people named Rockefeller and Tisch, he wore a business suit.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Vietnamese, among others, are happy to have former imperialists' investment, which is visible on the road to the Ho Chi Minh City airport. (Jeffrey Aaronson/Network Aspen)

LENGTH: 1012 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The G.I.'s Don't Carry a Marshall Plan

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMERICAN troops were already deploying in the winter snows of Bosnia last week when President Clinton joined the signing of the Balkan peace treaty in Paris; the mission could cost American taxpayers as much as $2 billion by the time it ends next year.
But even that falls short of the extent of American involvement, which will also include a disputed share of Bosnia's reconstruction and the repatriation of several million refugees and displaced persons. The Clinton Administration has played down this expense while it cajoles a skeptical Congress to support the sending of troops. But this week the Americans and their allies will sit down in Brussels to work out what needs to be fixed first and where the money will come from. 
 The Clinton Administration is aware of the stakes. The President himself has admitted the military mission cannot succeed unless the civilian population is helped back onto its feet. At the same time, his officials are warning Europe not to expect a cash-strapped Administration in Washington to footmuch of the bill.
This raises a persistent question: Alongside its military contribution to the NATO-led peacekeeping force, how much money should the United States kick in to undo the damage done by four years of war in Bosnia? Or is this the kind of burden that Europe should bear essentially by itself, since Bosnia is a European problem? Agreeing on the answer has already created tensions between Washington and its allies.
No one questions the need for reconstruction.
According to the World Bank, domestic food production last year met just 35 percent of Bosnia's needs, leaving 90 percent of Bosnians dependent wholly or in part on foreign food aid. Bosnia's industrial output has plummeted to 5 percent of 1990 production, with 70 percent of the electrical generating capacity damaged or out of operation. Coal production has dropped to 10 percent of its prewar level. Not surprisingly, Bosnia's gross national product has declined 80 percent since before the war, to about $500 per person this year. Neither the banks nor the sewers work.
A Bosnian Government survey in July found 18 percent of housing units destroyed and 63 percent damaged. More than half of Bosnia's schools are destroyed, damaged or occupied by soldiers and refugees. Teachers have not been paid since November 1994. At least 1,500 miles of road require urgent repairs.
And none of this covers the war's grimmest toll: 250,000 people killed, more than 200,000 wounded and 13,000 permanently disabled.
Nobody is certain of the price tag for Bosnia's recovery, only that it will be high. World Bank officials visiting in October identified $3.7 billion of urgent reconstruction needs in land controlled by the Bosnian Government and its Croatian allies. If areas under Bosnian Serb control were included, the team reported, reconstruction could cost $4 billion to $5 billion for just the next few years. And Christine Wallich, the economist heading the mission, said that only includes "what we think the priorities are."
 
Not Much for Housing
 Kemal Dervis, the World Bank's director for the lands of the former Yugoslavia, cited this example: "If one were to rebuild all the private houses destroyed, it would cost $4 billion or $5 billion." He expected planners to budget only $600 million for the entire housing sector.
A senior White House official thought the total reconstruction bill could run five times what is now being discussed, buttressing doubts about how much the United States can afford.
After all, the United States declined to pump massive financial assistance into the lands of the former Soviet Union. When the Persian Gulf war ended, it counted on Saudi Arabia and other oil-rich states to finance much of the reconstruction of Kuwait. And in Haiti and Somalia, American military intervention failed to satisfy local expectations of largess.
The question pops up again in Brussels on Wednesday, when the World Bank and European Union convene a meeting of more than 40 potential donor countries to identify Bosnia's most dire needs and find about $500 million for the first few months. With the extent of Washington's participation unresolved, European foreign ministers have postponed discussions at their level until next spring.
President Clinton asserted recently that for peace to survive, Bosnians "must have the food, the medicine, the shelter, the clothing so many have been denied for so long" and that "roads must be repaired, the schools and hospitals rebuilt, the factories and shops refurbished and reopened." Nevertheless, Secretary of State Warren Christopher told the House International Relations Committee that the United States would contribute a mere $200 million a year for three years.
 
Dueling Formulas
 By contrast, President Jacques Chirac of France has said the European Union expects the United States to assume one-third of the reconstruction costs -- 10 times what Washington offered -- and the 15-nation European Union another third, with other wealthy countries like Japan and Saudi Arabia being asked to pay the remaining third. President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, has dismissed this formula as "exorbitant for us." The Administration's preferred plan: international institutions like the World Bank finance half of the reconstruction, with the European Union and other countries paying the rest.
In some countries, American troops have improved the lives of residents by fixing their roads or bridges. Not in Bosnia, according to Secretary of Defense William Perry, who told the Senate Armed Services Committee that "these tasks of rebuilding the infrastructure, rebuilding the economy, creating elections, resettling the refugees, providing humanitarian assistance" would be done by other organizations, "most of them under the sponsorship and the direction of the European Union."
That leaves the United States and its brothers-in-arms starting out their military mission divided over how to split the tab for Bosnia's self-mutilation.
