HEADLINE: Ousted Labor Chief Has No Regrets

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Four months have passed since Lane Kirkland was chased from his position atop the nation's labor movement, but his wounds remain raw and his sentiments bitter and defiant.
Mr. Kirkland, who was president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for 16 years, does not have a kind word for John Sweeney, the man who now holds that job. And he admits that he still harbors some ill feelings toward the labor leaders who, he says, plotted behind his back and anonymously skewered him in the news media to help push him from power. 
 While almost all commentators agree that the labor movement has been hobbled and humbled, Mr. Kirkland says it is doing fine and remains the "most successful and effective democratic free trade union movement in the world." Mr. Kirkland is the only president in the American Federation of Labor's 109-year history to be forced to step down -- his opponents said he lacked the vision and energy to reverse labor's slide. But he said he could not think of one thing he would have done differently.
"I have no regrets," Mr. Kirkland said while sipping cappuccino in the opulent delegates' lounge at the United Nations. "Je ne regrette rien."
At President Clinton's invitation, Mr. Kirkland -- who was often criticized in labor circles for seeming more interested in overseas problems than domestic ones -- is spending three months as a United States delegate to the United Nations General Assembly.
After his stint at the United Nations, he plans to write a book, not of memoirs, but of reflections. "I don't believe in memoirs," he said in a low, lugubrious voice. "Memoirs are either lies or treason or both."
Asked what was his biggest mistake at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Kirkland thought for half a minute and responded, "I regard as a mistake something that I could have done and I didn't do. I have a hard time finding -- my mind doesn't fly directly to anything in that category."
The chief criticism of the labor leaders who forced Mr. Kirkland out was that this remote, often cantankerous intellectual was not a visible and vigorous spokesman for labor and did far too little to energize and organize workers.
When he took the federation's helm in 1979, 24 percent of American workers belonged to unions, but by the time he stepped down in August, that figure had dropped to 15.5 percent.
Among the pivotal events leading to Mr. Kirkland's resignation were two visits by Mr. Sweeney to suggest that he not seek a ninth two-year term as head of the house of labor. Mr. Sweeney knew that President Clinton had offered Mr. Kirkland the ambassadorship to Poland, and he hinted that Mr. Kirkland, now 73, accept that job to make way for new leadership in organized labor.
Mr. Sweeney said Mr. Kirkland responded, "I don't want to talk about it."
To many labor leaders, sending Mr. Kirkland to Warsaw would have been an ideal way to cap off his career and make way for younger blood. During the 1970's and 1980's, Mr. Kirkland fought tirelessly to help the Solidarity movement topple the Communist government, surreptitiously channeling federation money and fax machines to Lech Walesa.
Sitting at the United Nations, his chin buried in his right hand, Mr. Kirkland now said: "I had no interest in being an ambassador. I was president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. My aspirations were entirely fulfilled."
All along he was not planning to run for re-election, he insists now, an assertion that some mutineers do not believe. But he makes clear that he was not going to let Mr. Sweeney or other union leaders run him out of office.
"I did not intend to run anyway," he said. "But I did not want to be hustled into a hasty announcement. I wanted to organize a succession that preserved solidarity."
He dug in his heels for a few months, until he realized that the Sweeney forces had enough votes to oust him at the federation's October convention. The auto workers, steelworkers, mine workers, service employees and state, county and municipal employees were all lined up against him. He dug in his heels so long, however, that he gave the rump caucus enough time to rally around Mr. Sweeney, thus ruining the chances of the man he had groomed to succeed him, Thomas R. Donahue.
Mr. Kirkland bites his lip when asked about Mr. Sweeney's two-month-old stewardship of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "He's entitled to his shot," he said. "It's my watch below."
Nautical terms slip off Mr. Kirkland's tongue for a simple reason. He studied at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point before joining the Merchant Marine during World War II, along with the Masters, Mates and Pilots Union. Mr. Kirkland, moved to Washington and joined the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s staff in 1948. A talented wordsmith, he was drafted to write speeches for Adlai Stevenson's 1952 Presidential campaign.
George Meany, the federation's cigar-chomping president, adopted him as his protege, making him his executive assistant in 1960. Mr. Meany elevated him to the federation's No. 2 post in 1969, and, a decade later, Mr. Kirkland took over when his mentor retired.
Mr. Kirkland much prefers talking about the positive side of his ledger than Mr. Sweeney's. He talks of how he put the first women on the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive board and increased black and Hispanic representation. He also claims credit for setting up an institute to train union organizers, even though he was pushed hard from below to do that.
His biggest achievement, he said, was to bring the federation "to the highest level of structural solidarity in its history" by persuading the auto workers, teamsters, mine workers and a longshoremen's union to rejoin the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
He is not shy about claiming credit for these achievements, but when he was asked what caused the percentage of unionized workers to drop so precipitously, he points to everything and everyone but himself and the federation. He talks of rapid automation, of massive layoffs caused by imports and of the explosion in hard-to-unionize jobs in the service sector. He omits the charge cited by many critics: that his federation dropped the ball by doing little to organize workers.
At a time when the labor movement is embattled, when unions lost a devastating 18-month strike against Caterpillar and when wage increases are the lowest in 30 years, Mr. Kirkland says he is satisfied about the state of labor.
"My view is it's going through a period of adjustment to radical changes, not only in the domestic economy but the world economy, and it's weathering those changes in remarkably good shape considering their dimensions," he said.
For him, low-wage competition from abroad is by far labor's biggest challenge. The best way to deal with that problem, he says, is to have a world trade agreement that makes it an unfair practice for a country to prohibit unions, strikes and collective bargaining.
From his point of view, there will always be a need for a labor movement.
"The role of the trade unions is to try to keep big people from kicking around little people without a reaction," he said. "Your capacity to defend yourself is far greater if you're organized, if you do it as a union rather than as an individual."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lane Kirkland, the former A.F.L.-C.I.O. leader, is a temporary delegate to the United Nations. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Scholars of Political Speech Are Giving Gingrich Some Very Mixed Grades

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
This is how Speaker Newt Gingrich, in a recent talk to the American Medical Association, described the price to be paid if the Republicans failed to persuade President Clinton to accept their formula for achieving a balanced Federal budget in seven years:
"First, it'll be clear to this country that the best chance we've had in a generation to balance the budget will have failed -- not been postponed, failed. And second, you will see interest rates skyrocket and the stock market crash, because the fact is, they are counting on us keeping our word because they actually believe we are different." 
 Skyrocketing interest rates?
A stock market crash?
Most national leaders are careful to avoid saying anything that might rattle the markets. But not Mr. Gingrich, whose numerous vehement public remarks since he became Speaker a year ago have led many academic experts on political rhetoric to mark him as a brilliant but particularly imprecise orator whose fiery words have frequently added to polarization in American public life.
Mr. Gingrich's oratory, said David Zarefsky, dean of the School of Speech at Northwestern University, "is designed to force issues, not resolve or manage issues."
Although he reminds his audiences that he has an academic background as a history professor in Georgia, Mr. Gingrich is viewed by these experts as a speechmaker who is first and foremost a storyteller, not a scholar with a rigorous command of facts and logic.
"He has a great respect for information, but he has no love for it," said Roderick P. Hart, a professor of communication and government at the University of Texas.
Mr. Gingrich's spokesman, Tony Blankley, contends that the Speaker's oratory is in the tradition of labor leaders and leftist reformers who campaigned earlier in the century for safer factories, worker compensation and decent housing. Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Blankley said, "is a real reformer."
The Speaker's rhetoric, he said, "goes beyond style -- it goes to a reforming urge and how do you get people to do things." As a persuasive public speaker, Mr. Gingrich realizes that there is "a trade-off between absolute scientific precision" and making a point effectively.
Professor Hart described Mr. Gingrich is one part "lapsed historian," because "he has the language and some of the tissue of fact," and one part "a lapsed preacher, because he's moved out of the pulpit and into the civic square."
"The historian," the professor added, "isn't embarrassed by the preacher in him, or vice versa."
Professor Hart, who describes himself as a vigorous democrat "in the small 'd' sense of the word," believes that Mr. Gingrich is playing an important role. "He's engaged us in a debate that's long overdue," the professor said.
Twice this fall, in late September and again in late November, Mr. Gingrich attributed particularly grim instances of murder to the effects of liberalism and the welfare system.
On Sept. 22, he referred to a USA Today account in giving a synopsis of the arrest of a suspect in the murder of Stephanie Kuhen, a 3-year-old girl who was killed when her family's car strayed into gang territory in Los Angeles.
"Now," he went on to say, "we have had, since Lyndon Johnson created the Great Society, a 30-year experiment in destroying America. For 30 years, we have liberated prisoners, tolerated drug dealers, put up with violence, accepted brutality and done it all in the name of some kind of bleeding-heart liberalism which always had one more excuse, one more explanation, one more rationale."
On Nov. 21, addressing the Republican Governors Association in Nashua, N.H., he cited another newspaper account, of murders in Addison, Ill., in which a pregnant woman and two of her children were killed and a baby was removed from her womb. "Let's talk about what the welfare state has created," he said. "Let's talk about the moral decay of the world the left is defending."
Professor Zarefsky, of Northwestern University, believes that if the issue of race is excluded, Mr. Gingrich's use of images is reminiscent of the Southern-based populism once practiced by Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama. Mr. Wallace, Professor Zarefsky said, "did the same sort of thing in relation to the Great Society," linking the decay of cities to school busing.
Jeffrey Tulis, associate professor of government at the University of Texas, said that in tying gruesome crime to a social philosophy, Mr. Gingrich was making a kind of argument that, upon reflection, was bound to fall flat. How would the Speaker have explained the murders, Professor Tulis said, if they had occurred after the nation had lived for a time under the policies of the Contract With America?
Mr. Gingrich, he said, has a propensity for saying "things that are defensible in less-than-defensible ways."
In early March, Mr. Gingrich said liberal Democrats were responsible for creating public housing and public schools. Later questioned by the press, he conceded that Senator Robert Taft of Ohio, a conservative Republican half a century back, had supported the creation of public housing with the Housing Act of 1949. Indeed, Mr. Taft was one of three Senate sponsors of the legislation.
As for schools, Mr. Gingrich later said he had meant the "modern, unionized big-city school system, with work rules that make no sense, with very big bureaucracies, with a tremendous amount of money wasted and with buildings that don't function."
Some analysts believe there is a great deal more to Mr. Gingrich's missteps than fatigue from his workload or the perils of extemporaneous talk. "Facts for him are illustrations, not tests of propositions," Professor Tulis said.
Other academics see shades of Ronald Reagan as well in Mr. Gingrich. "Dramatizing anecdotes recalls Ronald Reagan, and even the use of things that are untrue -- or untrue as stated -- is also reminiscent of Ronald Reagan," said Karlyn Kohrs Campbell, chairwoman of the department of speech and communication at the University of Minnesota.
Whatever similarities there may be, though, there is also a major difference. "We forgave Reagan for his lapses of fact," said Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania. Americans, Professor Jamieson said, did not expect the onetime movie star to have a firm grasp of history and fact. Mr. Gingrich, in contrast, has positioned himself as a scholar and thinker who uses the rhetoric of fact, she said.
William Kristol, editor of the conservative Weekly Standard and a former speechwriter who was a top aide to Vice President Dan Quayle, does not see any Republican communicating the vision of the party better than Mr. Gingrich. "He's the heir to Reagan in that respect," Mr. Kristol said. "What makes him interesting is he does have a world view and a thesis, and he's not rattling off statistics in a prosaic way."
Mr. Kristol attributes Mr. Gingrich's lapses to speaking off the top of his head and doing too many jobs -- party leader, Speaker, Republican messenger -- at once. "Newt is both the guy in the kitchen doing the nasty things you do to prepare the food and the waiter delivering the lovely result," he said.
"I think he could be more disciplined and more careful," Mr. Kristol added. "At the end of the day, he is what he is. I can't imagine him reading speeches written for him by some boring 25-year-old staffer."

HEADLINE: Atrium Renewal, Adding Art, Chases Away Most of the Zen

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
Do bamboo trees look better with a Nevelson (or a Calder or a Dubuffet or an Oldenburg) in front of them? That is the question. And the answer is no.
The public atrium in the former I.B.M. Building at 590 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street, one of the most celebrated public spaces to have been built in Manhattan in the last generation, reopened last week after a discreet renovation. New management -- the I.B.M. Corporation sold the building in 1994 to the developer Edward J. Minskoff -- has added eight works of sculpture to the space, cleaned it up and rechristened it "The Sculpture Garden at 590 Madison." 
 On the surface of it, what could be better? The 10,000-square-foot glass-enclosed atrium, known for its spectacular stands of bamboo trees, had grown dingy in the last few years, its poor maintenance reflecting I.B.M.'s preoccupation with survival rather than corporate philanthropy. Adding a rotating exhibition of sculpture would seem to be just the sort of cure this sick urban space needed. It would liven things up and give New Yorkers a new enclosed place in which to see some first-class works of art.
At least that is what Mr. Minskoff and his architect, Robert A. M. Stern, and his curators, the Pace Wildenstein Gallery, argued when the plan to turn the space into a public sculpture garden came up before the City Planning Commission this year. (Since the original atrium was built under a special zoning permit, the commission had the right to review any modifications.)
After long debate, the Planning Commission said yes. It was probably the only thing the commission could have done -- no major changes were being made to the architecture or to the degree of public access, which would have been the only plausible grounds for the commission to withhold its approval. But now that the renovated atrium is complete, it is clear that this change, acceptable though it may have been under the zoning laws, is a loss, not a gain.
The atrium was better before. To understand why, it helps to know something about the scarcity of first-class public space in New York, and about the special role the I.B.M. atrium has played in the city since its completion in 1982.
Designed by Edward Larrabee Barnes, this was a space of unusual serenity in midtown Manhattan, and one of the only public places in which nature, rather than architecture or sculptural objects, provided the central theme.
Multiple stands of lilting, slender bamboo trees shot up from the gray granite floor of the space, and they provided a perfect counterpoint to the I.B.M. Building's stolid architecture. The bamboos are softly vertical in a part of the city that is harshly vertical -- they have a thinness, a precision, an architectonic quality that made them absolutely right as an element to play off against this boxy stone skyscraper.
Bamboo trees are not lush -- they are supple and lithe, with as much of a sense of precision and structure to them as I.B.M. has to its computers. Usually when plantings are placed in the lobbies or atriums of skyscrapers, they are voluptuous, lavish manicured flora intended to distract the eye from the hardness of stone and steel. Here, the relationship was much more subtle: these trees met the architecture and joined hands with it.
The word that came up continually in describing the I.B.M. atrium was serene, not a common adjective when discussing places in midtown. When the I.B.M. atrium was at its best, it provided something unique in Manhattan, a sense of quiet, rhythmic calm that managed still to be exactly in tune with a sleek skyscraper. This place was not created for total escape, not designed to make us think we were somewhere else -- it was midtown, made magically, momentarily, Zen.
That remarkable quality is now compromised, and it is no disrespect to the quality of the art that has been put inside the new sculpture garden to say that the atrium is now a lot like other places. The bamboo trees don't dominate the room as they once did; they struggle for pride of place with Roy Lichtenstein and Mark di Suvero, and more often than not, it is the sculptures that win.
This renovated atrium is a lot better than what Mr. Minskoff first proposed, by the way; when he first came to the Planning Commission, his intention was to remove half the bamboo trees and replace the atrium's movable seats with fixed benches. That would have turned the place into nothing but a glass house for sculpture. Negotiations with the Planning Commission brought the final design much closer to the original, with only minor loss of bamboos, and the retention of the movable furniture that is so essential for relaxed public space.
Yet it is still a very different kind of place from what it once was. Even though the works on view (which will change four times annually) are not for sale, the co-president of Pace Wildenstein, Marc Glimcher, all but admitted that he sees the sculpture garden as a showcase for commercial galleries when he called the new space "a great opportunity for dealers to work together" and said, "Educating the public is the very foundation of the art market."
So how, bamboos aside, does the space work for displaying art? It isn't bad, though it is rather pointless to speak of this space without speaking of the bamboo trees, since if the art sometimes gets in the way of the bamboos, the bamboos at least as often get in the way of the art. The two really cannot be seen apart. Indeed, in the initial show the only sculptures that are truly successful in this space, that look better here than they might elsewhere, are figures by Alexander Calder and Roy Lichtenstein -- the only two pieces that are vertical. They are slender and tall, their forms not fighting the bamboos but joining with them, like the trees reaching high toward the sky.
The very best relationship between art and architecture, however, is not to be found in the atrium, but around the corner, at the front entrance to the building at the corner of 57th Street and Madison Avenue. It is Calder's "Saurien," a bright orange stabile from 1975, and it is spectacularly placed underneath the cantilevered corner of the skyscraper. The open corner of this building has long been an awkward void, and this piece fills it magnificently, bringing energy to the building's architecture and life to the streetscape. Here at the front door, unlike the atrium, art and its surroundings are in perfect accord.

HEADLINE: Act II of Federal Shutdown: Some See Politics of Absurd

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Cpl. Yamashita Johnson locked the door of the National Gallery of Art at noon sharp today, leaving Karen Rose fuming on the street in esthetic deprivation, while Joan Phillips delighted inside at the windfall of being among the final gallery visitors to the Vermeer supershow.
"It's grandstanding," said Ms. Phillips, speaking of the politicians, not the paintings, as she sympathized with Ms. Rose and other citizens locked outside the museum, normally open until 5 P.M. "You can't really shut down the Government," she said as the gallery crowd thinned down to a precious few savoring the unhurried serenity of Vermeer. "These politicians are grandstanding." 
 On the street, Ms. Rose, who had timed her drive perfectly from Orlando, Fla., to Rhode Island for her afternoon tickets to the Winslow Homer show here, was furious. "It's just this great big drama the pols are trying to create," she insisted, gesturing angrily down Constitution Avenue toward the Capitol. "O.K., so I miss this show, but the real problem will be Monday when people can't talk to the Social Security Administration and other things like that."
Measuring the first hours of the renewed shutdown was almost a metaphysical task on a quiet weekend day. But the Americans inconvenienced by the Congress and White House -- even though their numbers were few -- were noteworthy for the similarity of their complaints. They said the underlying issue seemed to be a matter of politicians preferring to cry wolf, rather than uncle, in their chronic budget crises.
"It's just political theater, and I had enough of it in their first performance," said Robert Untreberger, who journeyed from Philadelphia for a weekend visit to the Washington Mall museums and found himself with enough idle time to wonder at the state of national politics.
Politics was hyperactive with blame-saying this day, as rival politicians indulged another Capitol art form and did weekend sound bites on Washington's busy ghetto of commentary news shows.
The White House, denouncing Congressional Republicans for the shutdown, lent a Dickensian tinge to the standoff, announcing that President Clinton had decided to keep the White House Christmas tree's 6,000 bulbs lit by paying out of his own pocket for the electricity. Republicans rejoined that the White House was deep into budgetary humbug.
Across the nation, vital Government services like the air traffic control system were maintained, but many national parks were closed.
"The big losers will be the concession operators," said Manny Strumpf, spokesman for the National Park Service in New York as the Statue of Liberty was shut to visitors, who normally crowd Liberty and Ellis Islands during the holiday period.
The effects of the shutdown varied widely, from causing a serious economic problem in this tourist-dependent city, to having little, if any, impact on places like Chicago, where the only local Saturday morning news broadcast failed to even mention the closing of some Federal agencies. Basic Federal operations, including postal, safety and health protection services, will continue nationwide.
This shutdown was not expected to affect city services in the District of Columbia because the Republicans have agreed to pass a spending bill for the district, and the President is expected to sign it.
The odd nature of the shutdown, in which some 260,000 Federal workers, about 15 percent of the Government workforce, are being furloughed yet ultimately not deprived of pay, made ordinary taxpayers consider the proclaimed crisis a peculiarly Washington concoction.
"In Cleveland when we have a shutdown, nobody gets paid," said Neil Ruddock, a visitor from Gates Mills, Ohio. "This thing is confusing and, as far as I'm concerned, it's not important."
On Monday, the effects will be clearer as workers deemed nonessential at the Departments of Education, Veterans Affairs, Justice and five other Cabinet agencies plus scores of other offices will gather long enough to be told to return home and await another attempt by Congress and the President to agree on a stopgap budget measure.
In the meantime, Social Security checks and Medicare payments will continue to be issued, and limited application services will be available at Social Security offices.
"What about my sister?" asked Maria Uricoechea, a visitor from Colombia whose sister, Lina, tried to join her last month on vacation but was denied a visa because of the first Government shutdown's effects on consulate services. She was planning to try again next week.
The effects of the shutdown are subtle. Ten minutes after the Mall museums' doors were locked, Nigina Ford, a 16-year-old student from Central High School in Capitol Heights, Md., showed up at the National Gallery of Art with a highlighted must-see assignment sheet in hand. "It may mean an 'E,' " she said, fearing failure in her art appreciation course.
Across the street, two homeless men stared from on top of a heat grate at the noontime consternation outside the museum.
"I panhandle my regulars right here, and when they don't come to work, I'm hurting," said Rodney Whipple, a 35-year-old who worried that the nonessential personnel being furloughed could turn out to be essential for him.
His partner, Monty Wandix, 36, was more concerned that the crisis not escalate to shutting down buildings and heating systems -- and their vents of hot air that shelter legions of the city's homeless.
"They cut this off, I'm facing pneumonia," he said as the warm air blasted and Mr. Whipple reassured him that the whole crisis was only politics.
Such analysis was small comfort to Christine Hickey, who makes her living off the Government museums and monuments as a private tour guide. "Now it's open, now it's closed," she fretted after finding the Western High School choir from Palma, Mich., turned away from a scheduled midday concert at Arlington National Cemetery. "Truckloads of wreaths are being turned back, and one of the florists was telling me their business will be clobbered through the holidays by this shutdown."
Overall, people interviewed at random understood the large stakes of the budget fight, but their sense of petty politics was also clear. "Fire those guys," Paul Yakubek of Los Gatos, Calif., said of the politicians. "Don't pay them this time. They're close together, talking about peanuts in their differences. But they just got to score points with the public, right?"
 
SORTING IT OUT: Open or Closed?
 Here is how some functions have been affected by the Government shutdown or will be affected if it continues into Monday:
 
AGRICULTURE -- The Agriculture Department's offices will not be affected.
 
LAW ENFORCEMENT -- Federal courts will be open, and prison guards will remain on duty. Law officers and border agents will stay on the job.
 
MAIL -- Mail delivery will not be disrupted.
 
THE MILITARY -- The military and its civilian employees will not be affected.
 
PARKS -- Most national parks, including the national Zoo in Washington, the Smithsonian museums in Washington and New York and the Statue of Liberty, have been closed since early yesterday. Some large parks remain accessible without visitor services, and the Grand Canyon National Park in Arizona remains open under an agreement with the Interior Department and the state government. White House tours have been canceled.
 
PASSPORTS -- Passport offices will be closed on Monday if the shutdown continues. Passports and visas will be issued only for emergencies. Foreign offices will offer only emergency aid to Americans traveling abroad.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY -- Some workers have been furloughed, but the Social Security Administration's field offices will be open on Monday to help people apply for retirement and other benefits, even if the shutdown persists. The information phone line will be staffed, and benefit checks will be mailed as usual.
 
TRANSPORTATION -- Air traffic controllers and railroad workers will remain on duty.
 
VETERANS -- The Veterans Affairs Department will keep offices staffed, but benefit checks could be delayed if the shutdown lasts late into the week.
 
WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS TREE -- Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said President Clinton would pay the electric bill for the tree's 6,000 lights out of his own pocket.

HEADLINE: Dilemma for Clinton on Nafta Truck Rule

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Facing a Monday morning deadline, Clinton Administration and Mexican officials talked intensively today about how they might back away from an important provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement that would let trucks from Mexico travel freely in American border states starting next week.
The Administration, which negotiated the agreement two years ago, is now fearful that the trucks could pose safety hazards and spur trade in illegal drugs. Meanwhile, Mexican officials are under political pressure at home to delay the implementation of the provision because of fears by the Mexican trucking industry that their business, already suffering because of Mexico's financial crisis, would be further hurt by American competition. 
 For weeks the Administration has been under pressure from unions, many Democratic leaders and officials in Texas and California to maintain existing trucking rules. Mexican and American trucks are now allowed to travel only 26 miles beyond their national borders. Under Nafta, Mexican trucks would be able to travel throughout Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California starting on Monday. American trucks would have similar rights in Mexican border states.
If the United States and Mexico agree to maintain the current limit for an as-yet-undetermined time, it would mark the first time that either side has backed away from a chief provision of Nafta.
Today, American officials were continuing discussions here among themselves and with their counterparts in Mexico City. A senior Administration official said it was "too close to tell how this will come out," but this evening it appeared that both countries were looking for a way to stall Monday's relaxation of border restrictions.
For President Clinton and his advisers, the question of whether to allow the trucks to range farther from the border has taken on larger political dimensions than the implementation of an obscure provision of the trade agreement would seem to provoke at first glance.
Officials in Texas and California -- two of the states with the largest number of electoral votes -- have warned the White House that the Mexican trucks often fail to meet safety standards and that their drivers often work far beyond the hourly limits set for American drivers. Many carry hazardous materials, including corrosive chemicals, toxic waste, jet fuels and pesticides, and experts question whether those materials are safely contained. Texas officials say their surveys show that 1 in 4 Mexican trucks in the state do not meet Federal safety standards.
Moreover, Mexico has become a growing source of illegal drug shipments, and there is concern that increased truck traffic could overwhelm the ability of customs officials to inspect the cargo.
"All we need is one big environmental disaster, or one of these trucks plowing into a school bus, and all of a sudden Nafta is going to look like a pretty disastrous idea," one of Mr. Clinton's political advisers said recently.
When it was signed in 1993, Nafta did not specify what kind of safety provisions Mexican trucks would have to meet, nor did it provide for increased inspections at the border. So United States officials believe that they have considerable latitude to work out new rules. But Mexico, unlike the United States, passed Nafta as a formal treaty, not just a trade accord. Mexican officials have said they are reluctant to bring a revised treaty to a legislative vote for fear that it would reopen other parts of the accord that have come to be unpopular among Mexicans.
While concerned about the safety issues, Mr. Clinton is hesitant to appear to be pulling back from one of the signature achievements of his Administration, the hard-fought passage of Nafta, which drastically reduced tariffs and trade regulations between the United States, Mexico and Canada. Mr. Clinton has argued that the agreement will create jobs in the United States largely because it require Mexico to reduce far more trade barriers than the other signatories to the accord.
In the two years since Nafta went into effect, however, the Administration has had a hard time proving its case. The peso crisis that began a year ago has plunged Mexico into a deep recession. The American trade surplus with Mexico has turned into a substantial deficit. And while the peso crisis and Nafta were unrelated events -- many economists argue that the crisis would have been deeper in the absence of the trade accord -- the Administration has been criticized by both the left and the right because few economic benefits have come to pass.
Mr. Clinton is also under attack from some of his core constituencies, especially labor unions. They opposed the accord and are still bitter that their position was overruled by the White House. This week, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters went to court in Washington to seek a stay of the implementation of the truck accord, although no hearing is scheduled until next week. Protests are planned this weekend in Laredo, one of the largest truck crossings in Texas. And many members of Congress, including many prominent Democrats, have joined appeals to have the trucking provision delayed.
In Texas, opposition is strong. The state attorney general, Dan Morales, has complained that the Federal Government has not done enough to insure the safety of the trucks coming into the state. "We do not want the cries and screams of disaster to be the wake-up call for the Federal Government," he told the Dallas Morning News. "These unsafe and uninsured cargo trucks are a traveling calamity waiting to happen."

HEADLINE: President-to-Be Of Haiti Faces Tough Agenda

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Even with 14 candidates on the ballot, the result is considered a foregone conclusion. It is what comes after the presidential vote on Sunday that promises to be the next big test for stability in Haiti and for the Clinton Administration's policy toward this country.
Everything the United States and the United Nations have done here since restoring President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power 14 months ago has been aimed at guaranteeing a peaceful transition to a popularly elected successor. 
 To the surprise of few here, that man has turned out to be Rene Preval, President Aristide's closest friend and the handpicked candidate of his Lavalas movement.
A poll published this morning by the newspaper Le Nouvelliste, the first to be made public since campaigning began last month, showed Mr. Preval with the support of 64 percent of the electorate here in the capital, the nation's political center of gravity. The survey was taken before Mr. Aristide delivered a speech Friday urging voters to support his longtime ally, saying, "I will cast my ballot for Rene Preval."
Mr. Preval, Haitian Government officials and foreign diplomats say, would not have been the heir apparent had the United States had its way. The clear American favorite, they contend, was Evans Paul, who was the Mayor of the capital until going down to defeat in a bid for re-election in June. American officials saw Mr. Paul as more flexible, less ideological and easier to work with than Mr. Preval.
But now, Washington must work closely with Mr. Preval to prevent one of the Clinton Administration's principal foreign policy successes from going off track.
The close relationship that prevailed after Mr. Aristide's return has eroded in the last two months. This was the result of disagreements about economic and security issues as well as American suspicions that President Aristide might try to remain in office after his term expires on Feb. 7, 1996.
Neither Mr. Preval nor the United States can afford any delay in addressing those and other problems, Haitian and foreign officials agree.
"The decisions Preval makes in the next few months will determine the course of this country for the next five years," a diplomat said.
Even before he takes office, Mr. Preval will have to begin negotiations with the United States and other aid donors about economic reforms. More than $125 million in foreign assistance is being held up as the result of a dispute over the privatization of state enterprises, and without that aid the Haitian Government is certain to run out of money and its currency is likely to collapse.
Equally pressing is the issue of security and disarmament. Haiti's newly trained National Police is still an inexperienced and somewhat amateurish force. With the United Nations scheduled to withdraw its 5,800-member military contingent by Feb. 29, Mr. Preval has no time to lose if he wants a reduced version of the international force to stay on for a few months.
How Mr. Preval plans to deal with these and other issues remains something of a mystery. During a brief, cautiously managed election campaign, he ducked all invitations to debate the other candidates, limited his contacts with reporters and, when pressed, pledged to do as Mr. Aristide would do.
"He frequently gives me advice, and I consult him often," Mr. Preval said this week of his relationship with the President. "He is a personal friend and a political friend. There have never been any clouds in our friendship."
No matter what course he takes, Mr. Preval will be governing in the long shadow cast by Mr. Aristide, something that could be another problem. The President said at a news conference on Thursday that he planned to spend his time at home, reading and writing, but many here are openly skeptical of that vow.
"The big question is whether Preval is going to have room to move, or whether Aristide will constantly be breathing down his neck," a leading Haitian business figure said. "The best thing that could happen to Preval would be for Aristide to do as Jimmy Carter has done and go off and mediate an international crisis, say like Rwanda."
Mr. Preval, 52, is an agronomist who was educated in Belgium and the United States, where he lived for several years during the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier. After returning to Haiti in the early 1980's, he opened a bakery and became active in civic and political movements, through which he met Mr. Aristide, then an obscure parish priest.
"Though he spent many years abroad, Preval is less worldly than Aristide," said one foreigner who has worked closely with both men. "He prefers to do things in a very Haitian way, which is to say indirectly."
When Mr. Aristide was elected President in 1990, he appointed Mr. Preval his Prime Minister. During his brief tenure, interrupted by the September 1991 coup that brought the military to power, Mr. Preval was praised for his personal honesty but often criticized as a mediocre administrator and negotiator.
He joined Mr. Aristide in exile after the coup and returned with him in October 1994, but largely because of lingering American distrust, Haitian officials said, was not given a Cabinet post. Instead, he became an informal adviser and was appointed director of the Foundation for Economic and Social Assistance, which finances and supervises development projects.
"In other words, he is in charge of what little patronage this Government has available to dispense," one Latin American diplomat here said. "That has allowed him to accumulate favors and build up a strong network of contacts."
But those advantages are no substitute for having the personal blessing of Mr. Aristide, who clearly remains the first choice of most voters here but cannot legally succeed himself. As Mr. Aristide himself put it in an interview with foreign reporters three weeks ago, he and Mr. Preval have a personal relationship so close that "they used to call us twins."
For better or worse, that means most of Mr. Preval's popular appeal derives not from his own personality or efforts, but from his perceived closeness to Mr. Aristide.
"There hasn't been enough time for Aristide to take advantage of his term, but as long as we know Preval is Aristide's friend, he's our candidate," said Alain Nouriska, 29, an unemployed man in the coastal town of St. Marc.
But there are important differences in style and approach between the two men. In public appearances, Mr. Preval often appears ill at ease and tends to deliver speeches that sound stiff and formal, in contrast to Mr. Aristide's effortless charisma and gift for oratory.
Mr. Preval devoted much of his five-week campaign seeking to act more like a man of the people. Advertisements, posters and banners baptized him "Ti Rene," an affectionate nickname that means "Little Rene," and at a campaign stop on Wednesday in the dusty village of Desdunes, he mounted a horse and took a bite from a stalk of sugar cane offered to him, gestures that seemed to endear him to peasant voters.
Still, there are those within the Lavalas movement who resent the rapport between the President and his designated successor and have been trying to undermine Mr. Preval, spreading rumors of a rift between the two men.
"They worry about what future they have after Feb. 7 and want to remind Preval that he cannot ignore them," said a Haitian with close ties to the Government.
At a campaign rally on Thursday in Carrefour, a suburb of the capital, leaflets accusing Mr. Preval of being a "traitor to Aristide" were distributed, and some Lavalas partisans paraded with banners calling for Mr. Aristide to stay in office for three more years. A few people even threw rocks at Mr. Preval's caravan as it departed.
"Nothing is ever easy in Haiti," one foreign official here said, "and it would be foolish for anyone to think this succession is going to be an exception. The job has been difficult enough for Aristide, much less someone trying to fill his shoes."

HEADLINE: Harlem Church Is Outpost of Empire;
House of Prayer Built Wide Holdings on Devotion to Sweet Daddy Grace

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ and BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Barnstorming the country in the 1920's and 30's, baptizing thousands at once in rivers and beneath the spray of fire hydrants, an immigrant preacher who called himself Sweet Daddy Grace promised salvation and upward mobility to America's black and poor. At revival meetings from Harlem and Washington to Charlotte, N.C., and Los Angeles, he flaunted his gold jewelry, flowing hair and five-inch fingernails while "love offerings" of cash rolled in from the faithful.
From those flamboyant beginnings, guided by that message of economic self-reliance, Daddy Grace's church, the United House of Prayer for All People, has grown into an unusually prosperous religious organization. A church that started out selling toothpaste and shoe polish now has extensive, and growing, real estate holdings in cities across the country. 
 One piece of that empire was the two-story building at 272 West 125th Street in Harlem, and as the building's owner, the church became a crucial player in a rancorous and racially charged dispute involving its tenant, a Jewish-owned clothing store, and a subtenant, a black-owned record shop. And in the days since Dec. 8, when a gunman walked into the clothing store and set it afire, killing himself and seven others, the charismatic sect has become the object of unwanted questions and attention.
An examination of court and property records shows that the House of Prayer is a major real estate power in many cities, with tens of millions of dollars worth of church buildings and residential and commercial space. It plans to spend more than $200 million on new development around the country.
It is also a church apart: Expanding its empire, wracked by internal strife, the House of Prayer has steadily turned away from the public glare, and often from the civic and political activism practiced by so many of America's black churches.
"They have been very entrepreneurial," said Robert M. Franklin, an expert on black churches at the Ford Foundation. "One has the sense of a theology of prosperity and empowerment in the here and now."
More than a week after the fire, the precise role of the House of Prayer in the dispute remains uncertain. But what is apparent is that the church was operating in its characteristically quiet and independent way, trying to stay out of the spotlight; indeed, many people in the neighborhood did not even realize that the church was the real landlord.
As the dispute was escalating in increasingly angry protests against the clothing store called Freddy's, church officials sought a settlement. They offered to subsidize a new site for the record shop, which was being forced out of its space next to Freddy's, and urged the police not to arrest demonstrators.
The church has used a similar strategy when other real estate projects have run into conflicts. Last summer, when the House of Prayer was criticized for plans to evict elderly residents in Cleveland to make way for a new church building and parking lot, officials quickly negotiated a secret settlement. And after Philadelphia residents challenged the replacement of a black contractor with a white one on a housing project, the church walked away from the $15 million deal.
Most of the church's affairs, though, have occurred behind the closed doors of its 135 congregations in 25 states. Apostle Sterling Green, an official at the church's headquarters in Washington, declined to discuss the House of Prayer's holdings or recent struggles over its leadership. He said the current leader, Bishop Samuel C. Madison, was unavailable for an interview. Apostle Green also would not speak about the size of the church's membership. In the past, the church has claimed as many as four million members, but religious experts believe that the actual figure is a small fraction of that amount.
Several religious experts concurred that the church's taciturn face could be traced directly back to the extravagance of its early days. While the people who flocked to Daddy Grace accepted his self-proclaimed divinity, many other blacks rejected his unorthodox theology and criticized him as a charlatan.
"They tend to downplay what they are doing in communities rather than opening themselves up to public scrutiny," said Dr. Wardell J. Payne, an expert on black churches at Howard University's divinity school. "And part of the reason relates to the church's particular history."
 
Makeshift Chapel, Dramatic Services
 That particular history began in 1919, when an immigrant from the Cape Verde Islands off the west coast of Africa -- a railroad cook and cranberry picker -- built the first United House of Prayer chapel from discarded rocks and wood in West Wareham, Mass. Then he was simply known as Marcelino Manoel da Graca. But as his charismatic preaching and claims of miraculous healing powers attracted a following, he formed branches in Washington and Charlotte, accorded himself godly status and adopted the name Sweet Daddy Grace.
He often told parishioners: "Salvation is by Grace only. Grace has given God a vacation, and since He is on vacation, don't worry about Him. If you sin against God, Grace can save you, but if you sin against Grace, God cannot save you."
Mr. Grace's followers showered him with riches, stuffing "love offerings" of cash into his hands as he paraded into the churches surrounded by a bevy of female attendants who waved large fans as he took his place on a red throne. In 1934, the Internal Revenue Service accused him of paying only $41 in tax on $190,000 income. The case was dismissed by a court that ruled the voluntary offerings were tax free.
Today, the church's chief source of income remains donations from its members, many of whom give 10 percent of their income. In addition, the church collects numerous special offerings -- for the pastor's anniversary, the building fund and even a legal defense fund. One North Carolina family said in a lawsuit that they donated more than $500,000 to the church over three decades.
Services are held seven days a week, often lasting all day on Sundays. At the start of services, members stand before the congregation and give testimonials, often "speaking in tongues," the unintelligible utterances that they believe signify possession by the Holy Spirit.
During a recent service in Harlem, Mammie Dorsey, a spry elderly woman, testified about how Daddy Grace healed her from an illness. "Daddy Grace prayed for me in 1935," said Mrs. Dorsey, who joined the church in 1929 in Georgia. "The doctor said there was no way for me to live back in 1935, and I'm still breathing today." She raised her hands and went back to her seat, strutting to the beat belted out by the church's full brass band.
From the start, Mr. Grace combined his Pentacostal fervor with a distinctly secular spirit. His followers sold products that included toothpaste, cold cream, coffee, soap and shoe polish. He acquired a coffee plantation in Brazil, an egg hatchery in Cuba, an 85-room mansion in Los Angeles and a 25-room mansion in Montclair, N.J. In the 1940's and '50's, he bought several high-rise apartment buildings in Manhattan that did not rent to blacks.
All of the property was in Sweet Daddy's name and when he died in 1960, he left an estate of $25 million and a major fight over succession. To become Mr. Grace's successor, a former taxi driver named Walter McCollough had to win a court fight and two elections.
Assuming the mantle and the name of Sweet Daddy, Mr. McCollough concentrated on projects that served the congregations, rather than the acquisition of trophy properties. He prided himself on paying cash, accepting neither bank loans nor Government assistance.
Within blocks of the gold-domed mother church in Washington, which is called God's White House, he built 288 units of housing for low-income and moderate-income families.
"We started the housing component so that we can maintain a community base and not become detached," said Mr. Green, the church official in Washington.
Adjoining the Washington church is an inexpensive, popular cafeteria, Saints Paradise. House of Prayer churches are known in their communities for serving low-cost meals.
 
Leadership Strife, Church Expansion
 Mr. McCollough's death in 1991 kindled another succession fight, pitting his son, Charles L. McCollough, against Samuel C. Madison, a senior pastor. Mr. McCollough argued that members should have a stronger voice. But Mr. Madison, a man in his 70's who was a direct disciple of Mr. Grace, won election by the hierarchy. The results ignited strife that spilled over into lawsuits, with members claiming the vote was rigged and some refusing to submit to Mr. Madison's authority.
But Mr. Madison remained in power, locking dissidents out of their churches and using security personnel to quell disturbances, according to court papers in Philadelphia, Washington and Charlotte.
When one small congregation outside Charlotte objected to Mr. Madison's stewardship, the bishop took several busloads of loyalists to the church to remove the pastor in April 1992. Court papers in one suit describe a brawl in the sanctuary between parishioners and guards affiliated with Mr. Madison, which was broken up by the local police.
Mr. Madison and the church have prevailed in the lawsuits, with the judges generally ruling that the courts should not get involved in church affairs.
In the meantime, Mr. Madison has embarked on a $178 million project to renovate and expand the church's holdings. Part of that agenda was the $4.5 million renovation of the building on that housed the clothing and record stores and has been the church's primary New York City home since 1936. Although the congregation numbers only 300, the plans called for a second-story sanctuary that will hold 1,200.
The church also is planning to build 150 units of low and moderate-income housing and 14,000 square feet of commercial space, with a supermarket and drug store, in Harlem. The church is providing $30 million in financing and is seeking a tract of land from the city.
"We're doing a lot of positive things in New York City," said Malcolm Barksdale, a church official and its primary real estate agent in New York. "I'm talking major economic development."
Despite its long presence in Harlem, the House of Prayer has remained outside the religious mainstream, eschewing political advocacy and membership in such organizations as the Harlem Congregations for Community Improvement.
"They have a history of running their own programs and paying for their own programs," said the Rev. Canon Frederick B. Williams, chairman of the congregations group.
 
Tense Dispute, Quiet Church
 Throughout the dispute over the record shop, the church tried to stay in the background.
Fred Harari, who leased space for Freddy's clothing store from the church, wanted to expand into the space where Sikhulu Shange had operated the Record Shack for nearly two decades. When Mr. Harari insisted that the record store had to move out when its sublease expired at the end of this year, Mr. Shange turned for help to the Rev. Al Sharpton and one of his associates, Morris Powell, head of the 125th Street Vendors Association.
In September, demonstrators began to appear outside Freddy's, demanding a boycott. As the protests escalated, so did the anger. In court filings the day before the fire, Mr. Harari and two employees said demonstrators threatened employees and warned the store would burn.
Tom Kelly, deputy police commissioner for public information, said Mr. Harari did not want the police to arrest any demonstrators. Mr. Harari told the police he was acting on the recommendation of church officials, who wanted to avoid any escalation of the dispute.
At one point, the church tried to persuade Mr. Shange to move to another site, but he rejected it as too expensive.
Amid the anger and anxiety since the fire, some people have asked if the church could have made a greater effort to defuse the tensions. The church has declined to comment, but people close to the investigation say Mr. Barksdale tried to arrange several meetings with organizers of the protests. But apparently none ever took place.

HEADLINE: Many Serbs Of Croatia Find Misery In Belgrade

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia

 BODY:
Milan Peksir is a forlorn and broken figure as he wanders the streets of Belgrade, timidly entering cheap diners to try to keep warm over a cup of coffee and buying one or two cigarettes at a time from street vendors.
The last few months have been a humbling time for Mr. Peksir, a 52-year-old laborer, and for many of the 170,000 Croatian Serbs who are now stranded in Serbia. 
 Not long ago, they reveled in the self-proclaimed Krajina Republic carved out in southern Croatia, trumpeted the glorious destiny of the Serbian people -- while Croatian neighbors were hounded from their homes -- and worshiped President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia as a savior. "We made many mistakes," Mr. Peksir said.
Now, he and the other Serbs from the Krajina are paying penance. All but a handful fled for Belgrade in August when President Franjo Tudjman sent the Croatian Army to recapture the territory. They are now shunted aside by the Serbs here and unable to reclaim their property, possessions or money.
More than a million people have been driven from their homes in the Balkan war, and while the peace accord calls for refugees to be allowed to go home, it is far from clear how many actually will.
Croatian Government offices have ignored petitions and legal proceedings brought by Serbs who want to return. Croatian officials, in a move that angered American diplomats, invalidated 4,000 applications by Croatian Serbs who wanted to go back, although they were hand-delivered to Zagreb, Croatia's capital, by the United States Ambassador to Croatia, Peter Galbraith.
[A Serbian member of the Croatian Parliament, Veselin Pejnovic, said in Zagreb: "All of the parties who signed the Dayton agreement know, quite cynically, that most of the refugees will never return to their homes. And the Serbs from the Krajina will now be the first to formally lose everything. President Tudjman has succeeded where the fascist Government in Croatia during World War II failed. He has driven nearly all of the Serbs from the Croatian state."]
In a series of bureaucratic roadblocks, the Serbs who try to return to Croatia have been handed one impossible task after another. For example, those who need new Croatian identity cards, which must be presented with any application to return, must travel to the Croatian Embassy in Budapest, something most cannot afford. But those who make it to Hungary are told they cannot pick up the cards until January, after a new law on nationality goes into effect.
Croatian officials in Belgrade, who wade through crowds of Serbs who gather each day along the iron gate, insist that most of the people outside do not want to go home.
"We have a list here of 10,000 people who say they want to go back, but we have determined that at least two-thirds of them really just want their property and do not want to return," said Davor Vidis, a Croatian official in the Government's office in Belgrade. "The Krajina Serbs, you have to understand, are not ready to accept Croatia as their state."
At the same time, soldiers in the Croatian Army have looted, gutted and burned dozens of Serbian villages and shot dead more than 100 elderly Serbs who were unable to flee last August, the United Nations says. Serbian homes in the Krajina are being handed over to Croats who fled Serbian-held parts of Bosnia.
The decision to dismiss the fate of tens of thousands of destitute people is, many warn, creating a breeding ground for the kind of terrorism and violence that beset the Middle East when the Palestinians were pushed out of Israel in 1948.
The Krajina Serbs, like the Palestinians who went to Lebanon, Egypt and Syria after the creation of the state of Israel, are refused work permits, identity cards and even refugee status by Belgrade. Young male refugees are being picked up in police sweeps off the streets of Belgrade and forced into the Bosnian Serb army. And the refugees, most of whom are poor and unemployed, are treated with the disdain usually reserved in the capital for Gypsies.
"We are consumed now by anger, blinded by it," said Miric Ninko, an official at the Helsinki Committee for Human Rights in Belgrade and a refugee. "As we feel more victimized we deny what we did to the Croats. We romanticize and glorify our own community and we demonize everyone else. Any type of revenge will be soon be justified."
But those who are older long not for revenge but for the chance to end their lives in dignity.
Adam Vasiljevic, 68, a refugee from Knin, worked for 42 years for the Croatian railroad. He has lost his pension, his home and his meager savings in his Croatian bank account. He and his wife live in an unheated room with no running water.
"Everything we had, everything we dreamed of and saved for, is gone," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Seeking Further Ways to Punish Nigeria for Executions

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
More than a month after the hanging of the Nigerian minority rights campaigner Ken Saro-Wiwa, the Clinton Administration is considering how best to strengthen its campaign to isolate Nigeria's military dictatorship in protest against the execution.
The United States has withdrawn its Ambassador, suspended Nigeria's application for financial credits, tightened the granting of visas to Nigerians with ties to the military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha and refused to sell it weapons. State Department officials will meet next week to consider what else they can do. 
 So far the Administration has shied away from using what is potentially the most effective weapon, an embargo on Nigerian oil, which generates 95 percent of the Government's foreign income. The United States buys nearly half of Nigeria's oil and its European allies buy 40 percent.
This week, an influential group of 54 black Americans wrote President Clinton urging an oil embargo against the Nigerian regime. But economists say the cutoff could also drive up gasoline prices here, which could hurt Mr. Clinton in his bid for re-election next November.
The Administration scored the first success of its campaign on Thursday at the United Nations, where the General Assembly committee on social, humanitarian and cultural issues condemned Mr. Saro-Wiwa's execution and called on Nigeria's rulers to return the country to democratic civilian rule. The resolution, whose sponsors included the United States, its European allies and South Africa, was supported by 98 countries, while 12 countries voted against it. But 42 countries abstained and 33 others stayed away, underscoring Washington's problems in trying to forge a consensus.
Having threatened to punish Nigeria, the Clinton Administration is stumped about how to proceed next, American officials said. The State Department has yet to devise a coherent new strategy that does not encompass sanctions.
"It's very difficult to unilaterally levy an oil embargo against a nation when other countries are reluctant to do so," a State Department official said.
The letter from the group of black Americans to President Clinton asked him to impose economic sanctions against Nigeria, including an oil embargo, a freeze on assets held abroad by the military rulers and a prohibition on new investment in the country. The letter was organized by Randall Robinson, president of the private institute Trans-Africa.
"The military dictatorship of Nigeria has plunged a once proud nation into a frightening state of national crisis," the letter said.
Nigeria's rulers, it said, had emptied the treasury, diverted billions of dollars in public funds to personal accounts overseas, crushed dissent and jailed or killed thousands of Nigerians, including Mr. Saro-Wiwa and eight compatriots who were hanged on Nov. 10 after being found guilty of involvement in four murders. Mr. Saro-Wiwa and his supporters maintained that he was innocent and had been framed because of his criticism of Shell Oil's operations in the country.
The signers included 26 members of the Congressional Black Caucus, the mayors of Atlanta, Denver and Seattle, civil rights leaders like Jesse Jackson, Coretta Scott King and Joseph Lowery, the writer Maya Angelou and the actors Bill Cosby, Danny Glover and Robert Guillaume.
So far, the toughest action taken against Nigeria to protest Mr. Saro-Wiwa's execution was its suspension from the British Commonwealth, a punishment pressed by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa.

HEADLINE: The Debate Over High-Speed Police Chases

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 13

 BODY:
Last year, more than 11,000 cars were stolen here, giving this city of 290,000 residents one of the highest auto theft rates in the country. This year, the police say, the number of thefts has been cut in half now that officers in patrol cars are allowed to chase the car thieves.
But in going after suspects, Tampa's police have been involved in a number of accidents, including one in which officers crashed into a utility pole and another in which they knocked a house off its foundation. And during a chase last week, a car driven by a suspect struck another car, killing two German tourists. 
 The deaths underscored an ongoing debate over the wisdom of most high-speed police pursuits. It also focused attention on Tampa, which relaxed its policy on chases at a time when many law-enforcement agencies have moved to restrict them for safety reasons or because of liability concerns.
At a news conference this week, Mayor Dick Greco of Tampa and Chief Bennie Holder of the Tampa Police stood by their policy, saying it would not change despite the first fatalities since it went into effect last May. The Mayor, who took office this year and had made the policy part of his campaign platform, said it was necessary to help stop crime, and he blamed the suspect who tried to elude police officers for the accident.
"The policy doesn't say go out and have an accident," Deputy Chief Kenneth H. Taylor said in an interview. "We didn't kill anybody. Some felons who decided to buck the law endangered everybody. I totally reject the idea that the police caused any of this."
But in trying to balance law-enforcement with public safety, many police departments nationwide have restricted chases in recent years, often excluding traffic or property offenses and only allowing officers to pursue suspects involved in violent felonies, said Geoffrey Alpert, a criminology professor at the University of South Carolina who is completing a study for the Justice Department on pursuits and the use of police force.
He said studies had shown that 35 percent to 40 percent of all chases end in accidents, about 20 percent in injury and 1 percent in death.
"What these policies are saying is that life is more important than property," Mr. Alpert said. "Are the few arrests for stolen vehicles and the potential deterrence, which we don't know exists, worth the risk?"
Liability is also a strong factor. Gerald Arenberg, the executive director of the National Association of Chiefs of Police until this year, said police chases have led to "case after case" of lawsuits against police departments, with most juries in civil trials finding against the police regardless of how careful the pursuing officers had been in avoiding injury or property damage.
In Pinellas County, adjacent to Tampa, the case of two sisters killed in a collision with a suspect whom police were chasing after he ran a red light led the State Supreme Court in 1992 to rule that police agencies can be held accountable for chases.
"Juries have come back and said you've got to have your priorities in the right place," Mr. Arenberg said.
For three years, Tampa also restricted high-speed chases to felonies involving violence or the threat of violence, such as murder, kidnapping and robbery. But as auto thefts and overall crime rose, Chief Taylor said, the city decided something needed to be done.
The department first tried an auto theft squad, which was allowed to pursue auto thieves. The program was successful in reducing thefts by 25 percent in five months but proved too expensive to support, Chief Taylor said.
Upon the recommendation of a citizens' advisory committee, he said, the department decided to expand permission for chases to all officers, allowing them to also go after suspects of burglary, any firearm offense and drunken driving "due to the danger such a driver poses to the public if allowed to continue."
But car thieves were the primary target. Chief Taylor said that about 70 percent of all violent crime in the city is committed by people who steal cars to commit the crime or to escape. He said car thieves became so brazen that some went as far as making insulting gestures to officers as they sped off. One suspect even held up a sign once reading: "This is a stolen car. I dare you to stop us."
"We don't want to cause accidents and when it's an innocent party it hurts," he said. But, he added, "car theft is considered a serious offense because it fuels so many other crimes."
The crackdown has shown results. Between June and November, police statistics show, auto thefts dropped 51 percent, to 2,788 from 5,699. Over all, crime is down 25 percent, and the police credit their policy on chases for a large part of the drop.
But since its implementation last May 28, the expanded pursuit policy increased high-speed chases through Tampa's business and residential streets to 85 between June and November, from 10 in the previous five months. And despite refresher driving courses and safety guidelines such as not letting more than two police units join a chase unless approved by a supervisor, 29 of the 85 pursuits resulted in accidents, most minor, and 11 in injury.
Files kept by the police department's internal affairs bureau show that many of the chases ended when suspects crashed into cars, trees and chain-link fences. At least one chase was abandoned after seven minutes when the suspect ran a red light at 80 miles an hour, police records show.
In one case last June, a police car vaulted off Interstate 275 shortly before midnight, went through a fence and hit a house. The tenants have had to move while the house undergoes repairs.
"All we heard was this huge thud and the hissing from a broken gas line," said John Carpenter, 34, a neighbor. "We ran outside and there was a cop car where their back porch used to be. The air bag saved them. It was very scary."
Then last Sunday, the police say, five teen-agers in a stolen Honda ran a red light and smashed into a car, killing Markus Rossknecht, 37, and Henz Bary, 40, and injuring a friend they were visiting from Germany. The suspects had been followed by both patrol units and a police helicopter. The driver of the car faces numerous charges, including two counts of manslaughter. The other teen-agers face theft charges and perhaps other charges.
The accident happened less than three weeks after two people were killed on Thanksgiving Day when a suspected car thief hit a car after being followed by Hillsborough County Sheriff's deputies through Tampa. Like other law-enforcement agencies around the country that have yet to tighten lenient chase policies, the sheriff's office also pursues car thieves.
But despite the deaths, many Tampa residents who are faced with economic loss, aggravation and higher insurance rates after cars are stolen, still support the police department. They say juvenile car thieves are a particular problem. The police agree, saying that car thefts typically jump 30 percent to 40 percent in the summer after youths are out of school. They say that this summer, thefts went down for the first time in years.
"People are kind of sick of it and ready to do just about anything," said John Grayson, producer of a popular morning talk show on WFLA-AM news radio, where he said calls had run 9-to-1 in favor of the policy.
But critics of Tampa's policy say the city is an example of the need for national legislation to restrict police chases so that such policies are not left up to individual law-enforcement agencies. A Wyoming-based group called Stopp, which represents families of people killed in police chases, advocates limiting chases to known violent felons. The group said that Federal statistics showed at least 388 deaths from police chases last year, with California, Texas, Illinois and Florida accounting for nearly half.
In Tampa, the families of some of the dead say they are aghast at the stance of both the city and the county sheriff's office. Veronica Elmore, whose 27-year-old cousin, Derek Johnson, was one of the two people killed on Thanksgiving Day, blames the sheriff's deputies for his death and said it is only a matter of time before more innocent people die.
"Anytime you contribute to something you're the cause of it," she said. "They initiated the chase."
She said her cousin, a former Army sergeant who was about to start a new job with the post office, died after hitching a ride with two friends because his car had been stolen the week before.

In one accident in June, a patrol car hit a house near Interstate 275. (Tampa Tribune)
